A brilliant satire on loneliness and disillusionment. It's about that weird moment when you first become an adult and are unsure of what to do with yourself. Throughout The Graduate, this early-life crisis morphs into a fantasy but it's a hilarious and awkward journey that's enjoyable from beginning to end. I love the style and camerawork in The Graduate, with the intimate cinematography (filled with iconic moments) and fantastic music making this a totally pleasurable experience. It's lively and skilfully made, The Graduate is one hell of a likeable film.

Terrific directing, but everything else ages like milk. The plot plays out like a straight white man's ultimate sexual fantasy and declaration of independence, and the fact that Dustin Hoffman groped Anne Bancroft on set only makes things worse. However, Mike Nichols' golden touch proves to be the saving grace.
If viewed from a completely artistic perspective, The Graduate is for sure one of the greatest feats in cinema history. The ingenious shots, frame composition and cinematography levitate an old-fashioned story to the next level. A young Hoffman's newbie charm works perfectly here against the milf energy of Bancroft, creating abundant sexual tensions that ultimately characterize The Graduate. Also, the Simon and Garfunkel soundtrack fits this whole experience in a truly odd manner. I just wish they didn't play Scarborough Fair three times in a row.

Still a 5/5, obviously. Still in my top 20 of all time.

‚ÄúBen, this whole idea sounds pretty half-baked.‚Äù ‚ÄúOh, it‚Äôs not. It‚Äôs completely baked."
Benjamin Braddock (Dustin Hoffman) is half-baked. He exists at that uneasy convergence of adulthood and adolescence, communicating inarticulately, careening between sullenness and exuberance. He is us at our most dangerously na√Øve, at that insufferable early-twenty-something phase when we believe we suffer no na√Øvet√©. Most of all, he does not want to become his parents‚Äîwho does? But in his ignorance and spitefulness, he enmeshes himself in his parents‚Äô world with Mrs. Robinson (Anne Bancroft).
Mrs. Robinson is completely baked, and then some. She is sardonic, intelligent, and world-weary. She is disappointed by the life she has made for herself, but not content to reside in her disappointment. She reaches for ephemeral distraction with Benjamin but wants more for her lovely but insipid daughter, Elaine (Katharine Ross)‚Äîcertainly more than the unmoored dope with whom she‚Äôs had a summer fling.
It is the great achievement of Mike Nichols‚Äô The Graduate that its nominal villain, Mrs. Robinson, is the only character with whom one would want to hold a conversation. The audience‚Äôs alliances are always uneasy. We root for Benjamin to break free from the shackles of his ennui and for he and Elaine to be together‚Äîbut not wholeheartedly, our enthusiasm tempered by their vacuity. We are wary of Mrs. Robinson and her latent (and then patent) anger‚Äîbut while she may have ‚Äúseduced‚Äù Benjamin, we know she didn‚Äôt take advantage of him.
Ushering in the second ‚ÄúGolden Age‚Äù of Hollywood together with Bonnie and Clyde, The Graduate was an enormous hit, speaking to a generation that saw a chasm between itself and its forebears. That it was insightful enough to recognize the real-life complexity its protagonists could not grasp maintains its relevance today.

takes the framework of an antonioni movie but makes it comedic through nichols' uncommon sensitivity and dreamy episodic cascade of stifling upper-class social mores -- old hollywood chauvinism and new hollywood neuroticism being forced to occupy the same space in time. the cerulean serenity of the braddock's pool is the emotional reservoir of post-war life -- small surface variation above a shallow depth, fenced in by concrete and only given expression in reflecting the blinding shimmer of an all-night 24/7 global solarscape economy. hoffman is central to the picture and does so well as a blank-slate hyper-sensitive creepo with nothing behind his eyes except for anxiety and anger who graduates (hah) into having a purpose and a heart, but anne bancroft achieves a genuine maturity that's so often faked in the american cinema -- her knowing eyes, the way she comfortably allows hoffman to orbit her like a planet, her resolute stillness concealing a deeply bitter misery. to a contemporary viewer, it's as easy to inhabit her perspective as it is hoffman's, and nichols utilizes long and zoom lenses to allow for multiple subjectivities, not to mention the godardian musical refrains straight out of contempt, the exhausted tones of a half-transcendent simon & garfunkel.
really glad i finally saw this, its influence is etched across so many future works like american gigolo and risky business -- you can especially understand how tom cruise gets a lot of his nervous confidence from how hoffman handles things here, especially that famous running shot. the graduate is so effortlessly able to juggle worldly cynicism and a budding youthful vitality; one of the great american pictures, and further proof that the 1960s might very well be the height of cinema as an artform.

Drifting. Sinking. Drowning. Mike Nichols builds "The Graduate" on these visual metaphors, crafting a melancholy comedy about the uncertain transition to adulthood. An observation of waning youth, an indictment of inexperience, and a dirge sung to jaded maturity, the film is spritely and solemn, hilarious and heartbreaking. A look at life, love, and their consequences, Nichols' film is rich and wonderful.
Beginning with Simon and Garfunkel's plaintive "Sounds of Silence" strumming in the background, "The Graduate" introduces us to Benjamin Braddock, fresh from college and clueless about his future. With obvious familial wealth but few prospects of his own, Braddock stumbles through an affairs, parental advice sessions, and a tangle of relationships. These stumbles and relationships inextricably tied together, Braddock is dealt lessons on love, sex, and the cyclical nature of it all.
The story is both authentic and cinematic, and it is a compelling blend of light and dark. Braddock is a memorable protagonist. As excellently portrayed by Dustin Hoffman, Braddock is gawky, unsure, and driven to let life come at him at its own pace. Anne Bancroft's performance as Mrs. Robinson is also remarkable: seasoned, knowing, and bored until her foundation is shaken by envy for what is genuine. Katharine Ross and William Daniels round out the cast with accomplished and sharp supporting roles.
Nichols' display of comic melancholy is lovely. His camera observes faces quietly but also captures the depth of landscapes. His characters are specks in the grander scheme of things, but they are deep and real in closeup. Compositions are varied, detailed, and lively; colors are sun dappled and real. Nichols employs editing that seamlessly pushes his story forward. Collapsing time and space, the editing reflects the blink-and-you-miss-it nature of endless summer.
Punctuating it all are the songs of Simon and Garfunkel. Paul Simon's words and music temper the comedy and underscore the longing of the characters. The songs reinforce tone and sell the drama. The combination of song and story is beautiful.
Narratively pleasing, aesthetically lovely, and technically rich, "The Graduate" is wholly appealing. Outstanding performances, direction that marries tone to deft cinematic storytelling, and a deep but gleeful authenticity, weave together a film with impact, grace, and spirit. Funny and meditative, confusing and promising, "The Graduate" is a lot like life.

Poor Elaine. All the discussion about this film focuses on Ben, when it's her fate that haunts me the most. She was only guilty of falling in love with an impulsive and entitled (but charming and exciting) guy. And now she's collateral damage in his manic-pixie-dream-boy quest, doomed to the same awful life her parents lived because of one snap decision.
Everything about post-college uncertainty still stings some fifty-three years later, of course, but would it be a stretch to say this (with the benefit of hindsight, of course) feels like a swan song for Baby Boomer counterculture? Because despite being made two years before the Mansons and Nixon, that final stare into an uncertain future, soundtracked by that famous Simon and Garfunkle song, stings as brutally as anything in Inherent Vice. I know Tarantino cribbed the opening for Jackie Brown, but it now feels like Once Upon a Time in Hollywood was an attempt to earnestly make the "happy ending" this film is mistakenly considered to have.

Benjamin is Charlie's (The Perks of Being a Wallflower) older and weirder version if you think about it, they are almost the same person during the first 30 minutes. He has the same obsession to have a purpose, the indefinition of what to do next, and his fixation with the women that enter his life are quite similar across these two movies. I know, I was expecting a five-star-review, too. The truth is, I don't think The Graduate is that phenomenal. I mean, on the technical side of things, it is. There are some amazing montages and shot compositions in here. The way one scene flows to the next, skipping over the money shots ala sex scenes in favor of a scene of Hoffman floating in a pool, or just a close up of a face for a whole minute - and all that to the tunes of Simon and Garfunkel ? Yes... God, yes.
I mean, heck, the very first shot in the movie, where Hoffman stands on a moving walkway in an airport, has been copied time and time again. There are so many great and quotable lines in the film, too.
Then, what's the matter? Well, the crux of this movie hangs on a relationship that I just don't think works at all. Now, the affair with Mrs. Robinson I'm actually fine with - it might be a little far fetched (like, why does she want him specifically?) but I'm not too bothered by it. It's the relationship between Hoffman and Ross I don't buy. There seems to be no reason to me that Elaine should want to be with Ben. He's a sleazebag, and she absolutely knows it - and he doesn't treat her with any respect through-out the film. Their only connection is that they're the same age and Ben's parents expects him to be with her.
Now, there is a scene where they hang out eating burgers in his car, which is supposed to spark the connection. It's a scene where the noise and music around them drown out their voices. It's really cool, stylistically, but it hardly drives their relationship home. Also, Ben just decides he's gonna marry her - for no good reason. He's also already decided she'll marry him. First I didn't mind it, I thought it was just a character flaw - but then we see Elaine actually considering it, and I'm totally taken aback.
The Graduate started out as a sweet, slightly dysfunctional coming-of-age story, about a bewildered post-graduate rich kid just wanting to break out of the system for a moment. I think the movie devolves when it suddenly revolves around stopping a marriage and I felt no sense of why.
Three stars because I did still have a very good time with it, I think it's a prime example of visionary filmmaking, but I was plenty disappointed by the story.

A May-December affair looms over Mike Nichols‚Äô iconic work, starring Dustin Hoffman and the great Anne Bancroft in The Graduate. While its story might seem to be outdated in today‚Äôs times, its release in 1967 broke new grounds, scandalous almost. Yet, it ushered a phenomenon in the American cinema that speaks and probes on the experiences of the younger generation during that time. Nichols‚Äô understood this generation‚Äôs collective angst, curiosity, desperation, and resistance to the pressures of tradition. In doing so, Nichols‚Äô elevated the thinness of the story and carved something more significant and deeper in scope.
The story relays the affair between a young college graduate and a mature woman. Dustin Hoffman who plays the graduate Benjamin Braddock, puts on a convincingly awkward performance in the first half. But Hoffman maturely calibrates Ben‚Äôs immature decisions as the film progresses. At once humorous, Ben‚Äôs life becomes more and more sad and melancholic once he dates the mature woman‚Äôs daughter. Anne Bancroft is stellar, giving depth and classiness in a role that sounds and feels predatory by nature. Katharine Ross is heartbreaking as Mrs. Robinson‚Äôs daughter as she slowly loses her innocence by falling in love with Benjamin.
I‚Äôm not sure about the repetitiveness of the Simon and Garfunkel soundtrack in the movie, but it sure was engraved on my mind while watching the film. However, there‚Äôs freshness and vitality to what Mike Nichols‚Äô is doing in The Graduate. It‚Äôs a film that represented a generation, and regardless of its said drawbacks, it definitely stood the test of time.

Really close to a 4 because so much of it is great but I had some issues that were big enough to make it not super great. I thought the cinematography was incredible and they used a lot of cool techniques I wouldn't expect to see in a 60s movie. I thought I wouldn't like it because of the plot, but the writing and the characters are well done, so it ended up not bothering me. I also thought the inclusion of Simon and Garfunkel was neat.
My problem is that I think they should've shown more scenes between Elaine and Ben because it just wasn't believable that she liked him too after he literally banged her mom. Their relationship seemed to feel more forced and I would've liked for it to be more developed considering how many scenes Ben shared with Mrs. Robinson. It's probably a large reason why the last act didn't seem as good to me as the first two. 
Overall, I did like it more than I expected and I totally get why it's a widely loved movie.

The Graduate is a movie that's had a profound effect on pop culture. The movie has been referenced, parodied, and praised in nearly every form of media you can imagine. It's for good reason too. It's a well made film with great performances, and a Simon and Garfunkel fueled soundtrack that hits just right. It definitely has some questionable morals at times. After all, this is a film about an older woman having and affair with a younger man and the repercussions of those actions. However, it never pushes the envelope too far into the realm of crassness. Which is part of why it has become such a classic over the years.
The movie also captures a very particular feeling. A precise moment in time that everyone reaches eventually. One where you're considered an adult by age, but mentally you're still stuck in the valley adolescence. Everyone always tells us when we're growing up that "you're young, you've got your whole life ahead of you". Well, this is the moment you've been waiting for. It's finally time to start your own journey into the world. The problem is that you have absolutely no fucking clue what to do with it. A scary time for us all...

Hold on while I sound pretentious for a minute.
This is the perfect example of how to present a film. Now not to throw shade at the plot, because I think it's great and the themes of the film hit way to close to home and that's part of why I love it (although I do think it loses a bit of steam in the second half). But this plot could have easily been presented in the most basic, shot reverse shot kind of way since it isn't the type of story you would expect to demand expert film making.
Instead an incredible amount of detail is put towards the shot composition, framing, lighting, camera movement, and focus. Almost every frame oozes with intrigue and meaning. There are literally shots of this film ingrained into my mind, the shot under the leg, the underwater scuba shot, the Elaine clueing in shot. I would never expect to remember so many frames from a film about a guy banging a milf.
This is just the kind of movie that makes me appreciate film as a medium. It's refreshing to see so much effort put into the visuals of a film that on the surface doesn't really need it. It's why I feel disappointed when I watch films that seem to only think of presentation as an afterthought. The graduate shows that any movie can be so much more.
The film does push it though with how many times it plays scarborough fair.

I love the stylistic choices and what this film is trying to do, specifically tackling that terrifying time after graduating. I‚Äôm not there yet but I do dread it existentially, and that unclear foggy time is perfectly encapsulated. Simon and Garfunkel also absolutely elevated this film to classic status. They are integral to the story (I‚Äôll get into that more in a second). I also thought the first half had a lot of genuinely hilarious moments, particularly surrounding Benjamin‚Äôs awkwardness (when he grabs Mrs. Robinson‚Äôs breast and then just stands there I laughed really hard), but I also just don‚Äôt quite think the movie comes together on the whole.
I think the introduction of Elaine into the love triangle really turns Ben from awkward hero to a creepy loser, which I understand is the point, but I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs quite executed effectively. Elaine May worked on the script and that much is clear, but I think her having even more creative control could have turned this into a black comedy and fantastic satire of middle class discontent and family boundaries but instead The Graduate gets stuck in a wishy washy area where it‚Äôs almost a straightforward romantic comedy and almost a satire about shitty people. It‚Äôs just awkward and frustrating and muddles the message. 
I do really like the ending. Using Sound of Silence at the beginning and the end shows that Ben really hasn‚Äôt gotten anywhere by the story‚Äôs end. He and Elaine aren‚Äôt going to last, and he‚Äôs using her as the only thing propping him up from a deep depression. He‚Äôs gone through a lot but he hasn‚Äôt learned anything from it. His face on the bus says it all: ‚ÄúWhat did we just do? Was it worth it?‚Äù I don‚Äôt think it was.

It‚Äôs a wonderful thing to watch a film for the first time and not click with it, only to be in total awe the second time you give it a chance. This film is not only the most meticulous and precise film from a technical standpoint but one of the most powerfully resonating films from a narrative standpoint. Benjamin is a young boy recently graduating college with no sense of purpose and direction. As well as family and friends who expect him to conform and follow the regulations of American society. He feels lost and empty, and so becomes entangled in a affair with his parents friend, Mrs Robinson. But the beauty of this film is how it shows that the true driving force in our lives isn‚Äôt the societal expectations put on us but love. The first time we truly see Benjamin flourish as a human is in his love for Elaine. The daughter of Mrs Robinson who he recently had an affair with. The transition from seeing this lost boy turn into a man with ambition and purpose is beautiful. And it‚Äôs all for a natural and wonderful thing. Love. Not for qualifications or becoming a cog in the American system, something that Mrs Robinson has so tragically fallen into. Which is clearly the reason she feels resentment towards Benjamin near the end. He could have something she never did. The use of Simon and Garfunkel throughout is also wonderfully placed. Not only within the film to create atmosphere but also in the lyricism of the songs and how they mirror the story.

If I were to isolate this movie, only considering its directing by Mike Nichols and its script as a work of literature, then the movie deserves the analysis and accolades it's received.
But there's more to look at, a lot more.
Has this movie seemed reasonably plausible to anyone? The character of Ben is not only unattractive but also a wimpy pathetic loser. And yet he's seduced by a lovely 40-something who gladly puts up with his incessant whining. Exactly how desperate is Mrs. Robinson when, frankly, there's a larger world of 21 year-old males out there. I must've missed her motivations for going after Ben. Is she that bored? (I shall ignore the fact that Hoffman was 30 years old at this point. He doesn't look like a college-age male --
Who identifies with Ben or feels sorry for him? He's a rich college graduate with an older woman trying to seduce him. Ben is such an idiot that he can't talk straight to a hotel clerk. He whines in bed to Mrs. Robinson, insisting on calling her that. He takes Elaine to a stripshow on their first date. What??
So what is this movie about? The malaise of college-age Boomers? Is Ben supposed to represent the uncertainties of youth culture circa
1967?
If so, these people are, or were, losers. Modern viewers aren't going to identify with Ben. Warriors, weightlifters, boxers, athletes, genuises, go-getters, entrepreneurs, inventors, or basically anybody with some talent and drive -- if you are any of these, you will probably despise the main character as much as I do.
And I don't see the point of representing this character, in this way, in a work of art. Perhaps, for future historians, "The Graduate" will end up signifying the dissipation and absurdities of the late US empire. And it's a nostalgia thing for early Boomers. That's about all it's good for, other than the clear skill shown in the directing (which I did really like a lot).
This movie lowers my testosterone by 95%, in spite of it being about a young male's affair with a very willing cougar. Ben is the loser's loser. He's the gamma's gamma. Do you really think I believe that he's a good athlete?
I need to go watch Conan the Barbarian now.

I think I underestimated the quality of The Graduate before going in. I certainly expected it to be great, but I didn‚Äôt expect a film from 1967 (for some reason) to be this relatable, honest and mature to some teenage boy in the 2020s.
Nearly every choice The Graduate makes, from the precise cinematography and transition scenes to the subtle performances, is absolutely inspiring. There‚Äôs something about the innocence of people and the responsibilities of growing up that terrifies, but fascinates me. I‚Äôm still a very young man, dreaming about a family, about a love, about being a screenwriter in the future or better a director and I‚Äôm still afraid of not reaching these goals, like Benjamin I‚Äôm worrying about the future. In some sense The Graduate is a very simplistic film, but that‚Äôs what I like about it.
The Graduate doesn‚Äôt jump much during the scenes and often just lets the camera rolling, at some point you forget it‚Äôs one shot or it doesn‚Äôt occur to you. It‚Äôs something that older films did much often than film nowadays, which doesn‚Äôt mean it does it better, but for a coming of age story it feels more human. There‚Äôs this patience in this film that pays off, the pacing of this is amazing, maybe also because the film lets the visuals speak, but when it uses dialogue it‚Äôs as strong as no other film.
The soundtrack by Simon & Garfunkel is beautiful, some songs are overused in this film, but that doesn‚Äôt change the fact that the music creates a mood of the future or maybe even the past. The music is simply fantastic and heartwarming.
A journey, a coming of age story that impressed me throughout with wonderful directing, sweet performances and a soundtrack that is simply unforgettable. An instant favorite

Post-grad is a weird time. Some people have a career plan and stick to it (for some reason I find they're usually business majors) and some decide to immediately pursue graduate school, but I think most kind of just float about with some vague idea of their goals and aspirations without the drive to fully pursue them. It's not laziness or lack of motivation, it's just that the shock of exiting the academic world and entering the "real one" is kind of traumatizing in its own way.
"There is a great future in plastics. Think about it. Will you think about it?"
Currently, from the moment you start forming cogent memories you enter the school system. You get through this and hit eighteen and now have the choice to enter college, but while that might have been a real choice a few decades ago it's now frowned upon if you don't. Media has greatly mythologized this experience, and not only is it the expected route but you'll miss out on so many things if you don't go! Besides, you tried so hard with standardized tests and extracurricular clubs and sports teams and leadership positions, so you don't want all that effort to be for nothing.
So you graduate and you hit your early twenties and now your life is about a quarter of the way over. School is all you've known your whole life ‚Äì which you've constantly been pushed and pressured to excel in ‚Äì and suddenly it's over and you're faced with the real possibility of exiting it. To some the natural extension is graduate school, and I know quite a few people who've said that one of their reasons for continuing was because they don't know how to "leave" school. I felt the same way and spent quite some time looking into PhD programs, because while I do love academia I also wanted to become a professor and never actually leave. And honestly, I still might do that.
The Graduate captures that feeling of post-grad paralysis really well, and it's kind of scary how relatable the first scene is. Benjamin Braddock aimlessly shuffles about his parent's house and all their friends shower him with praise for his accomplishments that every other college grad also has. Yeah, I got that award and won this scholarship and earned my degree, but this was all in the itinerary. And now that it's all over, I'm suddenly expected to make a real decision for my future? That sudden freedom is legitimately terrifying.
Even though it came out in 1967, the themes of early-20's aimlessness will never stop being relatable and it feels even more relevant today. Now college degrees are just the norm, career options are more limited, and wages have barely increased while the cost of living has skyrocketed. Except unlike Braddock, most people don't have the luxury of daddy's money to help cushion their ennui.

The only thing I knew about this movie was the incredibly famous line, "Mrs. Robinson, you're trying to seduce me." That was it. I thought that the line and the seduction was only a short scene in the film. I didn't know the entire film was going to revolve around that. As such, I had no idea what to expect with this movie. I didn't know whether I would think it was overrated or whether I would like it. I didn't know that this film would hook me as much as it did, I didn't know it would resonate with me as much as it did, and I didn't know that this film would be so amazing to me that it might actually make my top 10 personal favorite films of all time. This movie is beyond fantastic. Again, I really want to give this film five stars. However, there are some aspects of the plot that are incredibly dated, there are some cuts between shots that are really obvious (cuts in time are really obvious because the center of the shot moves a bit during the cut, so you can tell there was a cut), some of the music editing is repetitive, and there are continuity errors in some of the lighting in this film (admittedly, my parents noticed those, not me). There are so many minor glaring flaws like that that don't affect the story that I can't give this film five stars. However, that doesn't mean I didn't adore this film.
Just like The Master, all three of the Oscar-nominated actors for this film-- Dustin Hoffman, Anne Bancroft, and Katharine Ross-- are all phenomenal. It took me a while to appreciate Hoffman's performance, but I absolutely think his social awkwardness is completely genuine. Hell, it reminded me a lot of me in some aspects, which was really scary. We both have the same one-track mind and are bad liars, and that can get us into some tricky spots. I loved that about his character. Bancroft gives it her all in this movie and definitely pulls it off. She's not the Glenn-Close-in-Fatal-Attraction type of person, but she definitely has her moments, and she is really great here. Ross' performance is also really great and very likable. There's one scene in particular where the tension of a certain situation just gets to her more and more until she finally just screams to let it all out. That scream sent chills down my spine in the best way. She was really good in this movie.
The thing I loved the most about this movie was the direction and camerawork. Mike Nichols really directs the hell out of this film. Everything about his direction and the camerawork of this movie just feels tight and focused, and I really loved that. I knew I was in for some good, creative directing when the opening scene shows Ben at a party celebrating his achievements: when he's in the middle of the party, a shaky-cam zooms as close as possible to his face to follow him, but when he has a chance to breathe and relax from all of the noise and tight space around him, the camera zooms out and becomes more steady. That kind of attention to detail is why I am so happy Nichols won a directing Oscar for this movie. If the film was to win any Academy Awards, I'm honestly really glad it won for that aspect. I'm completely blown away that this guy directed The Birdcage. That was such a massive shift for him tonally from this film, and I really love that. The direction and camerawork in this film are truly immaculate. There are a couple of scenes where the camera is positioned on the back of a car as the main character drives through the streets. Those shots were incredible. I felt like I was actually in the car. Along with that, there's an action sequence at the end of this film that is exciting, satisfying, and fun at the same time. I just loved it.
There apparently was a musical score composed by Dave Grusin, but the music I paid more attention to was, obviously, the music by Simon and Garfunkel. This music fits so well into the film and really emphasizes the emotional moments on screen. It does slightly annoy me that some songs are used over and over again for, like, five or ten-minute sequences, but at the same time, they fit so well in those sequences that I don't really care. There's a scene where the song "Scarborough Fair / Canticle" plays over a shot where the camera zooms out to look at this bridge that Ben drives across, and I think it choked me up a little. The combination of the beautiful cinematography and the incredible music that both fits well into the movie and is also just really good music in general just really made me happy. I loved the use of music in this film, and I've heard that this film was apparently one of, if not the first film to use basically an entire score of re-used music instead of an instrumental score because films didn't do that a ton back then. That is super, super cool to me, and it still holds up really well.
I think the reason the main character is so likable is that you can see he has a solid moral code at the beginning of the film. Even though he at first rejects Mrs. Robinson and shows he has good instincts, he eventually ends up going back to her, and at that point, the audience knows enough about the character to know that this is not how he would normally act and that they should empathize with him. That's how you make a character like this likable: show that they have good morals and that they usually wouldn't do something like this, but then something comes over them and the audience doesn't want that something to come over them. Does that make sense? Regardless, it's what Nichols and the screenwriters (by the way, this is a great script, too, not in the sense that the lines stand out like in Aaron Sorkin's screenplays, just in the way that it feels natural) did here, and it works beautifully.
Guys, this movie legitimately blew me away. There are some strange editing and continuity errors that are very jarring and some very dated aspects of the way Ben goes about getting the attention of a girl and how quickly she seems to forgive him, but this movie really touched me. It's an incredibly-directed film with great performances, music, and camerawork to boot, and the story is incredibly engaging. The Graduate may just be one of my top 10 personal favorite movies of all time, which must mean I like it a whole lot.
Letter Grade: A

I can‚Äôt tell if I watched The Graduate at the best possible time in my life or the worst possible time. As someone who just graduated high school (I know it‚Äôs not the same as the movie, but still), it struck a deeply personal chord with me, but also stoked the fires of my anxiety, all revolving around the simple question facing all young adults: what now? The chains, yet also the security, of childhood has been cast aside, leaving no defined path to travel down. Is it best to look upon every possible avenue and choose the best path for yourself, or is it better to just skip that part of the process and just bury your head in the sand right after graduating? There are no true answers, and the ones offered by the adults who supposedly know better than you aren‚Äôt always the most appealing. Dustin Hoffman embodies the sort of aimless youth that we all become at a certain point, unsure of where to go, trapped in a seemingly endless string of detrimental decisions, often led astray and deluded by those who have already gone through what he is currently experiencing. Will his nihilistic viewpoint of his situation continue to drive him closer towards ruin, mirroring the adults whose fates he tried to avoid? Or will the snap, impulse decision made at the end of the film finally put him on the right path?
Most likely, no, of course not, but I guess it was worth a shot.

10/10
My fourth watch.
This is gonna be a long one and a bit personal, just so anyone who wants to steer clear of emotional shit can do so. Also, this review will seem really sad and maybe sappy or unnecessarily complainy. But I have some shit to say, so here we are. Continue at your own risk.
It's impossible to overstate this film's impact on me. There's something about it that truly resonates with me, whether it be the humor, the melancholy mood, or the brilliant editing, dialogue, acting, soundtrack, and I could go on. For me, I feel Ben's experiences every time. I'll get into this more in a minute, but I want to emphasize that I believe that this is one of the greatest pieces of art ever conceived and is a perfect film on every level. I just want to put that out there. I rewatched it today because of that.
Ever since elementary school, I've felt sort of cursed when it comes to love (already it sounds overly dramatic...we're off to a good start). I've always been a big nerd and was never very popular. I liked a few girls in elementary school, one of whom I was close friends with despite (or perhaps because of) the fact that I'd told her, but we were never more than friends. In middle school, I was rejected once again. As I entered high school, though, a friend and I began to like each other. We were together, and then apart, and then together again, and "split up" (if you can call the end of a ninth grade relationship "splitting up"). I won't get too into the specifics, but she and I really hurt each other on an emotional level and it left a huge impact on my attitude towards love and life. Not only did I feel that I was cursed to fail in terms of love, but the heartache I felt also left me extremely stunted emotionally and for a long time afterward I didn't really let out any emotions.
Throughout this all was film. I already loved film and The Graduate at this point in my life, but its themes of hopelessness and failure and isolation resonated with me more and more upon each watch. I love this movie wholeheartedly because it helped me understand my emotions and my worldview in a beautiful and powerful way.
If you've read some of my reviews recently, you may know that I've been having a rough eleventh grade year. It's been just about the worst few months of my life and I've been deeply depressed for much of it, despite that I have the best friends right now than ever before in my life. But, in the midst of that darkness, I began to feel something I hadn't been able to feel for a long time: I have begun to like a girl. This probably isn't a big deal to most people, but it's really important to me right now. It's so refreshing because for the first time in a long time, I can enjoy the feeling of some semblance of hope and love, and I know that if The Graduate had anything to do with it, I am forever indebted to this film. It truly is perfection.
EDIT (2/2/2021): Haven't thought about this review in awhile, but I don't really like parts of it. Feels too self-pitying, which is obviously part of both depression and loneliness. Or maybe it's how weird the situation with this girl got, idk. Just glad I'm past this point. Ight bye.

Benjamin Braddock isn't really the embodiment of any whole person, but I feel like the fact he's living his life an empty shell is what allows him to resonate through many viewers across all generations. He's indecisive, but it was all the result of the fact that the adults around him have basically formed him through societal pressures of what they expect their children to become upon finishing school - with a clear path set in mind.
But I think it's just the fact that The Graduate sees that life can't be decided right away by adults, through the emotionally resonant Simon & Garfunkel soundtrack, that allows it to last for so long. It's often incredibly funny, but realizing that there's no clear path even if it looks happy within the moment, is just all you need for something so devastating.

And in the naked light I saw
Ten thousand people, maybe more
People talking without speaking
People hearing without listening
People writing songs that voices never share
And no one dared
Disturb the sound of silence
Did I wake up this morning and immediately watch this again? Absolutely.
I'm just...so impressed with this movie and how it chooses to tell the story it does; it's something that, at a different time or from a different director, would have looked wildly different. Yet we are lucky enough to have this particular version. The editing style, the thoughtfulness of the framing, some really, truly inspired direction...this has been one of my favorite movies ever since I saw it a few years ago, but I've somehow underrated it.
Rewatching this somehow served as a reminder that movies are, for me, like memory - experienced, catalogued, lost, misremembered, relived - and they are often more real than my own memories. Whew.

Mrs. Robinson, you're trying to seduce me. Aren't you?
As I was watching Dustin Hoffman making an awkward ass out of himself in The Graduate, I kept wondering to myself: What is the point of all this? It wasn't as funny as I had been lead to believe, and indeed perhaps it's a more drama-focused dramedy than laugh out loud hilarious. But then, a certain scene in the middle of the film when Mrs. Robinson reveals her secrets to our protagonist (I won't spoil for those who haven't seen it yet) brought the film up to a whole different level for me. It revealed a deeper meaning to the characters and their motivations, and I was hooked from that point on.
Hoffman plays Ben Braddock, a recent college graduate who is seduced into having a steamy, though awkward, affair with the tantalizing Mrs. Robinson, the wife of one of Ben's father's business partners. Though he is completely against the relationship at first, he seems to be more and more involved as time goes on, but their relationship never really seems to go beyond the scheduled sexual encounters. Things get even more complicated for Ben when he falls in love with Mrs. Robinson's even more astounding daughter, Elaine. Now he is torn between keeping his past affair with her mother a secret, and revealing everything to her, which could obviously be devastating to their relationship.
The plot elements presented in this story are what really drew me into watching The Graduate in the first place. I couldn't help but be somewhat disappointed at the lack of a lot of comedic moments, but I soon began to realize that this film was more of a drama with some light comedic moments, rather than an even mix. Perhaps that's what lost my interest near the beginning- luckily the second act begins to swing the story into full speed, and it all finishes up in one of the best romantic endings in cinematic history.
My favorite part of the film would have to be the Simon & Garfunkel soundtrack. I'm a huge fan of 60's music, and the soundtrack provided in the film really added a nice atmosphere to each of the scenes, whether romantic or dramatic. I may go as far as saying that this is the epitome of 1960's music as a whole- it just rang of everything that music represented during that time, and really helped me connect with the story.
It may not be quite as good as Mel Brooks' The Producers, but The Graduate does have some really great, memorable moments. Young Dustin Hoffman gives an ecstatic performance as Ben Braddock, and his awkward nature is what provided most of the comedic moments throughout the film. The story itself is classic in every sense of the word, and the soundtrack is nothing short of amazing. One of the best relationship dramas ever put onto celluloid.

The Graduate must be one of a select few films ‚Äî maybe even the first, I don‚Äôt know ‚Äî to spearhead the subgenre of comedy that heavily relies upon unnerving the audience through awkward interaction upon discomforting situation. And it‚Äôs still one of the best to ever do it.
The whole film is chock-full of metaphors, some of which I understood, most of which flew over my head, but all of which are greatly entertaining nonetheless.

Unexpectedly, The Graduate on rewatch turned out to mirror my life as a cinephile; or of my life in general, even. The first time I've seen this I was 20, exactly as old as Hoffman's Benjamin is in the film. Back then, I thought it was fine, but this sure was no American Pie - this being my brain-dead criticism back in the day is probably the ultimate irony. Now, as it turns out, I am just a few years younger than Anne Bancroft at the time of the film's release. Let that sink in. Fortunately, I am now seeing the film with completely different eyes.
How the film portays Benjamin's aimlessness and anxiety is spot-on, if not exactly subtle. Especially the generational conflict with his parents struck me. These are all members of the "Greatest Generation", they won the War, mind you. None of their conceptions make any sense to Benjamin. Yet, I need to hand it to them, they are quite chill about him drifting endlessly in the pool. Mr Robinson, on the other hand, couldn't care less about what Benjamin has to say. He couldn't even pour him a Bourbon, even though he explicitly asked for one.
Mrs Robinson, though, she is on the prowl for Ben. There is just no way she mistook his room for the bathroom. I love how quickly the film cuts to the chase when it comes to her seduction. We're about 10 minutes in when tiny Ben is iconically framed under Mrs Robinson's legs. When their affair sets in motion, we get treated to a beatifully shot montage of weeks and months of them meeting in their hotel room. That one edit from the air mattress to Mrs Robinson: chef's kiss. And of course, Simon and Garfunkel's The Sound of Silence plays over it - again, not the obvious choice but it is a perfect choice.
That scene is so great that director Nichols just plays another Simon and Garfunkel song afterwards; why the hell not? I love how visually the affair comes to an end when we can see fallen leaves swimming in the pool. Something tells me that this film, for better or worse, must have inspired so many mumblecore indie dramas. As a 2000s kid, I saw a lot of the O.C. in these scenes. Anyhow, this is when Mrs Robinson's daughter, wonderfully portrayed by Katharine Ross, comes into play. At this point the film should probably have a dip in quality, but it just doesn't.
Then there comes the big reveal, and that's when I expected the film to finally take a turn for the worse. Yet again, it doesn't. Benjamin, though, he goes off the deep end. His behaviour in Berkeley is unbearable, and the movie knows it. At this point I am rooting for them to not get married, neither Ben nor Elaine know what they want from life. Also I don't want her to marry that other guy. So, with the often-spoofed finale the film is right on the money. Hoffman fending off the wedding guests with that huge cross is a riot - I was convinced this idea was from the end of the Wayne's World sequel.
Recently, I've learned that the final shots of the film on the bus were only a lucky accident. This was supposed to be a triumphant finale, but Nichols discovered the shot with the awkwardly fading smiles in his dailies and just put them in the film, again playing The Sound of Silence over that image. It is a bold choice that ultimately turns this movie into that special experience that it is. All of a sudden, it says something profound about growing up, about becoming a fully formed person. What a nasty gut-punch.

Have you ever seen those Black Friday videos of a store not open yet but people bust through the glass doors anyway and trample over everyone? That's basically what Mike Nichols did to the Hays Code. Technically the Code didn't end til 68, but it was almost completely inept and inefficient by the end, partly due to Nichols making a mockery of it.
It basically went like this...
Hays Code: Guys I think we are getting close to being over, but can you still make sure you make films that show the family and marriage structure in a positive and stable light?
Mike Nichols:
Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? -FUCK
The Graduate - YOU
Hays Code: Alright, I think we're done here.

Identifying the tipping points of culture can be tricky. This movie feels like the upward trajectory towards modern cinema. The style, colour, themes and music choices of this movie would go on to define 70‚Äôs cinema. These features also give the film a timeless feel which allows new generations of angsty young adults to discover it.

I will confess something about myself to you all: I am not given to writing reviews of this type of film because everything has already been saying about it and I think that sometimes my words may be unnecessary as well this review.
The Graduate is a film that for me is in the same league (without any problem) along with 2001: A Space Odyssey, The Goodfather or The Shining, films that are more than just cult films, which have become public domain and popular culture not only in the United States but the whole world and being so it is difficult to enjoy them personally because they are so well known by everyone that they become crowd-pleasers, but wow, I have nothing against them and they are respected.
Mike Nichols made a film so autonomous that he does whatever he wants without warning: at times it's slow, at others it's not. The script is sometimes simple, but at other times very intense and the characters are simple, but at the same time they are well constructed. A film that, like the ones I mentioned before, also has its own philosophy and I think that's why it has the title of being a great classic because it surpasses many of the typical ideas that existed in the years when it was released. What I like most about the film is its ending. It's so outrageous and improvised, one of those so bad it's so good that it's really great to watch.
The Graduate is and will be one of those films that you may never love fervently, but you will hardly hate it, and it's not that I didn't like it, but it is respected and should be given credit for having a place to be a little ahead of its time, iconic from beginning to end, not to mention that it has one of the best debuts that exists in an actor like Dustin Hoffman. A story that will remain with great value and essential over time.

When my new housemate, excitedly casting her eyes over my collection, spied The Graduate and immediately insisted we watch it, I knew this latest domestic arrangement was going to work just fine. What do I love most about this film? Is it the way it manages to be one of the funniest comedies ever filmed whilst nonetheless managing to make me so very sad? Is it the countercultural tendencies at its heart, questioning the dominant values of contemporary society? Is it the magnificence of its soundtrack, flooding the film's soundscape with melancholy? The Graduate is, to me, the great masterpiece of New Hollywood, its ability to so comprehensively and concisely summate the disillusionment of the then-maturing baby boomers nothing short of heart-wrenching. It says everything that needed to be said at the time, wrapping up one of the most relevant social commentaries ever put to film in what is essentially a raunchy sex comedy. Yet even with that specificity, that is a film no less relevant today; indeed watching it now, yet closer to being a graduate myself, it affected me a good deal more than the last time I saw it. The Graduate takes a serious, stark look at the society of the 1960s and reveals the underlying dissatisfaction of the human experience. 45 years on, it's scary to see how true it all still holds.

I think everyone knows it, it's iconic to this day. One of the first lines spoken in the film that is so true to life I think everyone can connect or relate to it on some level. "I worry about the future." Doesn't everyone though, the older you get the more you are aware of what surrounds you and not what's ahead of you. Swimming with a school of fish is easy you have everyone to guide you, it's like a team effort and no matter what they always stick together it's only when someone gets separated from them that they have to navigate the big, mysterious and ominous sea all on their own. Just like how in school you have teachers to attempt to tell you how to navigate life by sharing useless information with us we won't need in the real world, but nonetheless they can be helpful, obviously that's their job. But when you reach the point where you don't need an education anymore they send you out of those buildings that you called a hellscape for the past 20 years and into the real world where it could either be your playground or the death of you. If you couldn't tell by what I just wrote I worry about my future a lot, there are so many possibilities for what I could do and each second that goes by feels quicker than the last and I haven't even considered a collage I would care to apply to, granted I am probably too young to worry about that but seeing my classmates talk about what they would want to do with their life and where they would want to go creates an internal unease within me. One that can somewhat be explained in the character of Benjamin Braddock. When we first see him he seems disconnected with reality as if life is some convoluted illusion that throws everything at you if you aren't ready, staring at everything and looking at nothing. The adults in Ben's life aren't really a big help as well especially one I will get to in a moment. Out of the many themes this film deals with communications between different age gaps is the most noticeable. We see this at the party scene with people from Bens past, most if not all are only concerned about what he is going to do with his life. This scene in particular was uneasy to watch and not in a creepy way but the looks on Bens face say it all. Knowing you can't slack off anymore like you would do in school because everything you do has major effects on you now, but unsure what you want to do causes more tension in the mind of a naive young man. The pool scene is another perfect example of the misadventures of life. How the swimming gear represents responsibilities that weigh him down Ben frantically stands at the bottom of the pool trying not to get humiliated by everyone watching him, or he could be drifting in a raft not paddling in a certain direction just him letting it take him where fate wants to.
There is a unequivocal feel that comes with this movie like some sort of hypnotism while we see the sides of humanity that people of the time were so unaware of. You can argue and say that there was a clear hero and villain of the movie but I believe that there was neither, in reality there are people who do things for the sake of doing things, obviously i'm talking about Mrs Robbinson. A cynical alcoholic probably having a mid-life crisis so for the sake of it she tries to seduce Ben. Who knows very well that she will have full control over what he does because of his seemingly timid social awkwardness to easily take advantage of. In the most uncomfortable scene in the film with the lines uttered so brilliantly by the apprehensive and perturbed cries of Dustin Hoffman and the wickedly derisive chants said by Anne Bancroft. The whole connection between Ben and Mrs Robbinson feels really inhumane. Given the fact that Ben calls her by her last name makes the power dynamic heavily one sided, and like I said before she knew what she was getting into with Ben but even when he felt uncomfortable she reassured him that no one would find out. Those scenes of them talking in the dark symbolizes their lack of communication, when you (probably) can't see each other you have a hard time to try to figure out what the other one wants.
Maybe the relationship Ben has with Mrs Robbinson represents his desire to grow up because when he first encounters her he doesn't exactly know what to do like a naive child but soon he gives into her devious ways and seems more sure of himself but the innocent relationship between him and her daughter Elaine brings back the unaware of what's to come side of him. Most of their relationship is about "Living in the moment" and as we build up to the climax. Once Ben finds the church Elaine is getting married at they make the impulsive and childish decision to run away together kind of like how children do in those fantasy novels only this is heavily grounded in the real world once they get on the bus they second guess their decision (was it all worth it in the end) or is the world going to eat the two of them alive if they don't have a proper plan. This in my opinion is one of the best endings some may say that i NeEd MoRe ClOsUrE but life is one for curve balls and sometimes ambiguity and I think this ending stays true to what it wants to be close to life because life sometimes gives you questions you didn't even know you'd be asking.
As for the sound track it perfectly reflects what Ben is feeling in a somber yet meditative tone. The tunes that play out subtly hint at whats in store for everyone, Mrs Robbinson being the most obvious. The cinematography takes the hazy summer days and puts you in a trance. I think it's hard to talk about films like this a story that seems so simple but has layers upon layers of meaning and thoughts that bounce around your head for days, and i'm not gonna be one of those basic bitches who says this movie is sUcH a ClAsSic because everyone already knows that so no need to say that again. But the brilliant social commentary was sure as hell what made it what it is today, and if there are more movies being made like this I will no longer worry about my future.

52 Years in 52 Weeks: 20/52
Well if someone had kindly told me the soundtrack consisted almost entirely of Simon & Garfunkel, I would have made time for this long ago! Obviously I knew to expect "Mrs. Robinson," but the other inclusions also work so well.
I was transfixed by The Graduate. The camera work and editing all throughout is iconic. The claustrophobic closeups of Ben as he navigates his graduation party in a state of detachment are so effective. His movement and position in space is used time and again to convey a feeling of isolation, whether he's drifting aimlessly in an empty pool or sitting at the crowded Berkeley campus. His body language and way of speaking is awkward, even robotic. No, Ben is not a happy guy.
Though melancholy, this film is also very funny, deftly moving between the awkward moments and the outright hilarious. When he blindly goes in for that kiss while Mrs. Robinson is puffing away on her cigarette, oh that was gold.
Despite the relative simplicity of its plot, some aspects of The Graduate perplex me. There's some strange complexities to these characters, particularly in the way these women respond to Ben and their different motives in doing so. I find them all unlikable, yet sympathetic, in some way or another.
And boy, what an ending.

This is Benjamin. He‚Äôs a little worried about his future. 
The Graduate had me right from the tagline. There have been a lot of great Benjamin characters over the years, but this one might be my favorite. Full of uncertainty and weighed down by expectations. Every aspect is so relatable that it leads to a timeless film that will never feel dated. The initial seduction and following hotel scene were hilariously cringe-inducing.  Dustin Hoffman has that uncomfortable shyness down pat that just makes his character so charming. Besides the fantastic acting, the direction and editing stood out. Lots of framing that suits the melancholy and precariousness. To make everything even better we get all those amazing Simon and Garfunkel tracks...even if they play one too many times. Normally I prefer a more somber ending, I‚Äôm glad this ended on a joyful note. Wherever you are, Benjamin, I hope you‚Äôre happy.

Tom's Cinema Volume 1 - movie 2 | task 28 - a New Hollywood film | 
‚ÄúOh no Mrs. Robinson, I find you very desirable. I think you are the most desirable of all my parents' friends.‚Äù
Even though The Sound of Silence is iconic to this film, I can‚Äôt hear it without thinking of this. 
An enjoyable 1960s romantic drama with plenty of comedic edges. I do think it succeeds in the filmmaking front more than the plot. The editing and transitions are brilliant, with an amazing soundtrack that really adds to the entire feel of the film. It feels like something new and different for this era of filmmaking, trying new techniques and making them work for the film. 
The second half of the film lost its way for me a little bit, becoming a bit too predictable and slapdash compared to the first half which feels like it takes a much deeper look into the lives of its characters. The first half deals much more with Benjamin‚Äôs worries and angst about life, in a total arrested development of where his life should be leading, his chance encounter with the formidable Mrs Robinson helping to find himself. It‚Äôs the latter half with Elaine that didn‚Äôt work for me as well, it becomes more of a standard rom com trope, and the relationship never quite felt built up enough to earn the finale. 
Dustin Hoffman is great as our lead, likeable and charming, someone confused by his meaning in life and stuck at a crossroads. His interactions with Mrs Robison are all brilliant, with some excellent comedic moments but also smaller moments of reflection for both characters. Anne Bancroft as Mrs Robinson is fantastic too, she sells the older sexualised woman role so well, adding plenty of depth to her character to keep her feeling developed. The moment of her own reflection in bed is perfectly pitched and performed. 
It‚Äôs an enjoyable watch, and the first half certainly earned it iconic status for me. I just wish it had kept that momentum and drive for the entire run time.

This movie is ridiculous, and it genuinely makes me angry that people actually think it's good. I get that at the time it was subversive to show an affair between a young man and an older woman, but that doesn't excuse this monstrosity of moronic film.
First of all, no 20-year-old male is that naive. It's kind of insulting. You think a guy who graduated from an ivy league college can't figure out that a lady is throwing her bosoms in his hands? He's a little nerdy--he's not an idiot.
Secondly, how is this ending supposed to be "romantic"? Dude literally has sex with the girl's mom and then shows up at her wedding banging on the windows. Anything short of calling the police at that point would be unforgivable.
Thirdly, couldn't they have gotten anyone else besides Dustin Hoffman to play this role? We're going to make neurotic character actor a sex symbol now? What's next, Abe Vigoda as Don Juan?
In conclusion, this movie sucks. Anyone who doesn't agree isn't thinking rationally and needs to be under house arrest.

The Graduate is a brilliant tragicomedy about the eternal moral decadence of the bourgeois class, dissatisfied in its materialistic zeal, unhappy in its wealth, seeking in alcohol and sex some ephemeral satisfaction that usually leads to greater disappointments in the long run. It‚Äôs a film that is designed from the first minute to the last. Apart from being a film that can perfectly serve as an example to follow when learning to make a script, all the scenes, situations, and so on are designed in the smallest detail: nothing comes out just for the sake of it, everything has a coherent explanation and everything helps us guide us with what happens or is going to happen.
The film is an unforgettable character because it invites us to relive that time of uncertainties and doubts, in which many things are lived with the illusion of novelty, but in which feeling the pride of family and friends ends up having a weight similar to that of fame, which perfectly understands the act of rebellion, the explosion into the forbidden, the morbidity and the escape valve necessary to release the stored hormones.

One of the most masterfully edited films of all time. Nichols captures everything from pure angst to cathartic pleasure pitch perfectly. The camera work in this is one of the most inspiring things I‚Äôve witnessed.

This is one of those movies that you can go on through a lifetime listening about HOW GOOD this is while you keep delaying to watch for a long time for some inner feeling of laziness or thinking that this has to be some sort of mind-blowing cinematic achievement to do justice for those long time expectations set by every single fan that puts The Graduate on a pedestal. But after you've FINALLY watched, it might not be none of the stuff said before, in fact, something else far different and better.
At the same extent that it openly assumes itself as this straight up laugh out loud "romantic" comedy about teen's misfortunes in the blind (and lunatic) fight for love. As it is also shows to be this minimalistic with a Nouvelle Vague-ish editing, almost surreal and European-like-experimentalistic like if it was a Alan Resnais film, and shot like a Neo-Noir flick (if Mrs. Robinson it ain't a Femme Fatale type character, I don't know anything about cinema), that deeply dives into a complex analysis of the decreptling state of human's mind facing the suffocating reality that surrounds it. Provided by some phenomenal storytelling and the visual guidance from the forever snubbed Mike Nichols, that has an amazing power of using music as a emotional key ignition, I mean, using Simon & Garfunkel's The Sound Of Silence three times over the film and ALL OF THEM WORKS? Is a work of genius damm it!
Also marking this perfect tragic portrait of an era that nethless to say, still strongly reflects itself till today. Where society's constant need to build a life's system order of phases and stages of studies and works, only eyeing for creating 'image' and sucess, destroys all the real meanings of what is to feel alive and living. Love itself equally in crisis Just as all of them, treated here at first as a mining of survival while Ben escapes his prison of upper middle class life style when the affair with Mrs. Robinson starts, even though he is confusing love with lust (and neediness). But when the passion and affection for Elaine starts to blossom, the cold and controlling treatment of their parents, still bound to the ego and arrogance of their time, forces them to escape the claws of oppression and strongly hold on to the only sign of love that they have and allow them to escape from that life imprisoned by stagnation and pressure. But, as the hauntingly brilliant ending showcases, it was a human mistake to trust something so new and abruptly, that may not suffice to end the forever internal loneliness and loss of perspective that guide us in life.
That‚Äôs just might be scratching the overall impact and importance that The Graduate actually had on its time and forever in cinema, one of which includes teaching some valuable and genuine life lessons that people still seems not to fully grasp, but enough to validate Nichol's masterpiece as one required viewing once in a lifetime AT LEAST!

I heard this one was a classic but this was closer to legendary status if anything. 
Completely down-to-earth and relatable with its depiction of the post-college phase of life and the uncertainty that comes with it. But also absurd and hilarious in ways that can‚Äôt be predicted with some of the best examples of dry humor I‚Äôve seen. The satirization of rom-coms here hasn‚Äôt aged a day and the feeling of drifting off in your existential dread and fears of unfulfillment are fascinating simply because it‚Äôs something we go through at some point in our life. 
Dustin Hoffman disappears into his character and the precision in direction, editing, music choices, and use of repetition is astounding. This is the kind of film that can be enjoyed on its own merits but also begs to be analyzed by film fans for decades.
An instant addition to my list of favorite films and one of the best coming-of-age movies out there. I cannot recommend it enough.

The August Project - Yes, I Know I Should Have Seen These By Now
No I've not been to Scarborough fucking Fair, but why not ask me one more time in case I forgot.
The Graduate is one of a few films in this project that I should have watched by now but almost feel as though I don't need to. Because it's The Graduate, you know, and if you don't know what happens in it then you've done some pretty amazing spoiler guarding all these years. And avoided that song. Both versions. And the music video.
It portrays that brand of suburban boredom that the 1960s were really good at worming out. The middle / upper classes pushing their relationships around like chess pieces, except the ending is almost always a stalemate, and even on the odd occasion when you think you've won, it turns out you haven't.
Mike Nichols doesn't give us a single goddamn reason for us to feel sorry for anybody here either, just to make the thing work way better than it would have done in most other hands. Dustin Hoffman is a privileged, dithering idiot whose 'love' for Katharine Ross is nothing more than a way to create some excitement and drama amongst his family and their friends and neighbours and his own life. Ross embarks on a revenge marriage, of all the dumb ideas, and Anne Bancroft wants control of her daughter's life simply because she has no control of her own.
Nichols is making incisions from the moment we clap eyes on Hoffman's miserable face and is doing so right to that iconic final shot, which isn't so much 'What the hell have we just done?' more 'What the hell do we do now?' Just push the chess pieces around some more until you get that rare checkmate, I guess.
"You wouldn't be right for each other."

it‚Äôs crazy to think that when i first watched the film, i was maybe 17 or 18 and about to graduate high school. now i‚Äôm the same age as benjamin! watching it in high school, i didn‚Äôt really relate to ben because i knew where i was going to college and i was pretty excited. flash forward a few years later, i‚Äôm one year away from graduating and it‚Äôs already weighing heavily on me. i feel like i have an idea of what do next, but it‚Äôs so terrifying to even think about it, i decide that it‚Äôs best to get it out of my mind. and that works‚Ä¶for the most part. with ben, he constantly thinks about what the next step is and seeks a distraction in mrs. robinson. the future is a stormy cloud that follows you and it feels like at any second, it‚Äôs going to drench you. and instead of waiting for it to come to you, you do everything in your power to push it away.
what i noticed during this rewatch is how we are placed in ben‚Äôs point of view mostly around the time before the affair begins. that‚Äôs when his crisis of ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs next‚Äù looms over him the greatest and the audience are forced to feel that dread. the scene with the scuba suit was great because it felt we were all trapped and suffocating and the only way to emerge out of that is to have a set plan. we were constantly looking at the parents, hoping they would provide us with an answer, but in the end we have to escape them by jumping into the pool.

If I were kidnapped in a van, I would be dumped by the kidnappers 30 mins later on the street because I wouldn't stop talking about how Mrs Robinson is such a misunderstood character deserving of sympathy as a victim of extreme patriarchal biases towards older women. Or maybe the kidnappers would just pull duct tape all over my mouth to shut me up!
Oh don't get me wrong, Ben's anxieties are very real and relatable to people like me who just finished college yet overwhelmed with how to traverse life in a meaningful way; just a vague feeling of wanting to make a difference in an ever uncertain world. But my heart has always gone out to Mrs Robinson. She is who I wanted Lester from American Beauty to be. Ben is the perfect embodiment of overprivileged youth - not necessarily entitled but fortunate enough to not know what to make of his life yet. It's no wonder Mrs Robinson in her midlife crisis and loveless marriage chooses to metaphorically drink from that fountain of youth as an escape. The world is not that kind to older women past their supposed prime.
Here's to you, Mrs. Robinson! I'll love you more than you'll ever know!
It's a testament to the classic status of this movie that it still feels oddly relevant. The filmmaking is so next level for '60s standards. The conversation around generational gaps is just timeless. But give it a rewatch if you haven't in a while. Watch it from Mrs Robinson's perspective. No matter how much the material tries to make an Oedipal caricature of her, there's a nuance to Anne Bancroft's more quieter moments that reveal inner destitute.
In our current pandemic, we are all sitting in that bus as ‚ÄúThe Sound of Silence" plays out loud. Like Ben and Elaine, we have no idea what this future we face might hold for us moving forward.
P.S Notice how there are no young people at the wedding. The Graduate is more subtle about its generational divide than something like Rebel Without a Cause. Even the Simon and Garfunkel soundtrack is a throwback to '50s music like the Everly Brothers. The Graduate is removed from its era, is about its era, and is forward thinking beyond its era.

Mr. Braddock: Would you mind telling me then what those four years of college were for? What was the point of all that hard work?
Benjamin: You got me.
Took me long enough to see Dustin Hoffmans master work. And not once does this film come across as some sort of perverted mess, which I always thought it might (under these circumstances) . Even tho eventually Benjamin develops a little bit of a stalker-ish vibe, we‚Äôll just ignore that. But the whole idea doesn‚Äôt berate the situation or beat the dead horse. Simply Lost individuals merely searching for meaning in their ordinary lives is what Nichols captures and achieves so well. The aged 60‚Äôs cinematography is such a treat. It has a style that almost feels suave , debonair , but even precarious through its conundrums. 
I love the post college moody and apathetic  temperaments that the film addresses as well. Fits kind of well with my current life and career situation (lol) but it‚Äôs funny to see that these things never change. These topics don‚Äôt ever come out as insensitive , they‚Äôre seemingly fun and super intriguing. But it goes back and forth between the idea of being lost and confused but also searching for love? I found the composition from Simon & Garfunkel to be nice and relaxing at first , but then it got old when I started singing It the rest of the movie.  And even the mothers reaction to Ben getting ‚Äòmarried‚Äô when she screams was a bit absurd but funny as hell. Another point, the car driving scenes and shots from behind Bens head are great as he weaves in and out of traffic and flies towards his destinations. Such cool shots. 
The last 30 minutes of the film take another odd spin and honestly become an unexpected mess (not in a bad film way, just messy for Ben and the whole love triangle or whatever you want to call it). Eventually the bitter sweet ending is what makes this movie what it‚Äôs Known for. Incredible shots for such a simple category of film, witty lines, exquisite humor, and an overall fun bizarre love story. 
But hell, thank god I‚Äôll be a college graduate myself soon, so cheers everyone.

For me, The Graduate is best viewed as a generational peep show.
The scuba section, being forced to parade in front of your parents friends and pushed back down into the pool to put their desired time in. The post-grad malaise and existential dread that's compounded by parental pressure has been universal since the baby boom. The cross generational moment is echoed in the closing seconds of their post-rebellion; a destructive, freeing moment that doesn't quiet the dread of the future and what comes next, where their path is taking them.
Dustin Hoffman being 30 softens some of this for me. It does feel like cosplay. And the "plastics" line hits different decades later, however, as the generational revolution of the 60s was cosplay, too, as most youthful rebellions end up falling in line (mine, too).
Roger Ebert's journey with the film, extremely potent in his youth but then faded decades later and, for him, becoming less funny and more sad, is something we all go through in revisiting films we identify with when you're younger but no longer reflect back. Growing up increases the frequency of our nuance antenna. With distance, Ben looks less rebellious and more selfish and creepy. Generationally, the film that I have Ebert's journey with is Fight Club, which still has many filmmaking merits and even ends the same way as The Graduate except with an attempt at global rebellion instead of just against parents. (Fight Club was downgraded in importance to me pretty early on I think due to the scope of it, The Graduate still works well because it's an individual story.) Like that film, what remains decades later for me in The Graduate isn't the revolutionary spirit, it is the fantastic filmmaking; the blocking and focus pulling is astounding. The focus on the zooms, the distance between people, the use of Simon & Garfunkel. It's a well-made film that sits atop the shoulder of decades of being the voice of a generation.

It did bother me that when Ben was driving to Berkeley, he was heading westbound on the Bay Bridge towards San Francisco, but whatever, I‚Äôll let it slide.

The Graduate feels like the sort of thing I'll have nightmares about in college. Waking up at 5 AM, after a night of hard partying, hungover as hell. You have fine grades. You're taking the classes you like. You have friends, you have freedom. This is eternal. And then you suddenly have this nightmare that it isn't eternal, and that it'll end in a couple years. And then what? And then you panic.
But it's only for a second. You go back to sleep, you wake up and you forget your worries. We're human beings; we plan ahead, but we like to live in the moment. It's why younger people (myself often included) don't exactly care too much about "wearing sunscreen" or "getting x disease", not just because we're less biologically vulnerable, but because we're in the moment; and by the data, this moment isn't close to the end of our lives.
At least we'd expect that Ben won't die soon. If you think of dying in the biological sense. But we also see the effects of his "living in the moment". It's sort of the thing I'm suffering from right now. Going through each day, relaxed but more than relaxed - lethargic. Slipping in and out of the pool, in and out of bed. The time of day doesn't matter, and whenever it does it's only to signal that it's time to eat lunch or dinner. Even so, you're constantly eating out of boredom anyways. It's fun, isn't it?
I'm quite a few years away from being Ben. But as we all know, time flies. And whether you define living by "existing" or by "doing", it's probably important to make sure you're doing something with your life. Or you can get sucked into Ben's cycle of despair and disappointment.
Seriously, I did not laugh once. And I don't mean that as an insult. I can't fathom that this was ever intended as a laugh out loud comedy, yet it shows up in plenty of "comedy" lists. I get that movies can have dark comedy, but Dr. Strangelove's bizarre end-of-the-world humor is hilarious in a different way. This is just depressing. And sort of gross to watch. It's icky people doing icky things, and I sympathize with all of them to some degree, but it's also just like Alice constantly falling down the rabbit hole. And the nightmare isn't that she will hurt herself when she lands; it's that she'll never land in the first place.
And then the final, wistfully blissful scene. The Sound of Silence creeps in, and we sit there and watch as 30 seconds pass on the bus - and the characters' faces change, become frantic, and then depressed, and then confused. What will they do now? Have they thought about how they're going to live? What did Ben even do in college? How will he use it? Did he get a degree to say he got a degree, or because he's legitimately interested in a career in that field? Do many people even like their occupations in the first place? Do people work because they like their job or because they want money, and more money at that? When you die, can you say "it was worth it" if you made money to pass along to your children? Will your children use that money in a wise way? Are you giving your own children the opportunity to forge their own path, even if you in a way sacrificed your life for that?
Life is a cycle of madness. Every corner is a new beast. I'm dreading the day when the beast will be a void of nothingness. A slap to reality but a slap that'll make me lazy and bored. Each day the same, each day how you want it, but not how you want it. "Get busy living, or get busy dying" as Andy Dufrane said in The Shawshank Redemption. Some of us would love to get busy dying, but we no longer have the drive to even get out of our beds and tie a noose.
