In the annals of cinema, few films capture the existential ennui of post-collegiate life with the wit, depth, and visual flair of Mike Nichols‚Äô The Graduate. Amid the backdrop of the swinging sixties, this seminal work not only vaulted Dustin Hoffman into stardom but also firmly etched itself into the cultural zeitgeist. The film‚Äôs plot is deceptively simple: Benjamin Braddock, portrayed with a compelling mix of naivety and disillusionment by Hoffman, returns home after college, only to find himself ensnared in an affair with Mrs Robinson (Anne Bancroft), the wife of his father's business partner. The narrative, however, is anything but straightforward, weaving a complex tapestry of themes that explore sexual freedom, generational conflict and the suffocating pressure of societal expectations.
Nichols‚Äô direction is masterful, employing innovative cinematography and editing techniques that were groundbreaking at the time. The use of Simon & Garfunkel‚Äôs soundtrack underscores the film‚Äôs mood and accentuates the protagonist‚Äôs isolation and confusion. For example, the iconic shot of Benjamin framed in Mrs Robinson‚Äôs leg is emblematic of the film‚Äôs visual ingenuity and thematic depth. However, The Graduate is not without its flaws. The film‚Äôs second act suffers from pacing issues, and the character development of Elaine Robinson (Katharine Ross) feels undercooked, a product of the era‚Äôs gender norms, which the film both critiques and, paradoxically, sometimes succumbs to. Yet, these criticisms are but minor blemishes on an otherwise impeccable film. Bancroft‚Äôs portrayal of Mrs Robinson is both seductive and tragic, offering a nuanced look at the disillusionment of the older generation. Hoffman, meanwhile, delivers a career-defining performance that resonates with anyone who has ever felt adrift in the sea of adulthood. The Graduate remains a landmark film that is both a product of its time and timeless in its exploration of human desire, alienation and the search for meaning.

This has been on my watchlist forever and watching it for the first time was a magical experience. I have heard so many great things about this film and I‚Äôm glad to say that it exceeded my expectations. Dustin Hoffman is incredible as the worrisome college graduate, Anne Bancroft is the definition of evil, and Katharine Ross is so good at displaying a wide array of conflicting emotions. The direction by Mike Nichols, however, is the glue that holds everything together and when coupled with the insanely good writing, you get a fantastic film. This movie has a lot of great aspects. The visuals are amazing and some of the transitions are breathtaking. My favorite was when Ben was swimming in his pool and as he took a plunge underneath the water it transitioned to a bed with him and Mrs. Robinson on it. The music by Simon and Garfunkel was also magnificent and truly iconic. This just feels like an iconic movie, nearly every single scene feels iconic to me. Ben is worried about his future and it is obvious that he feels like he is being controlled or simply going through life without living it. I could tell that his affair with Mrs. Robinson and his subsequent disinterest in the future was a sign of his rebellion against this control and his desire to rid himself of the worries that had dragged him down. However, it was through this liberation that he began to be controlled by the very thing that he himself thought was supposed to help him feel free and that was Mrs. Robinson. The love Ben grows for Elaine is one filled with drama and watching that final scene play out was extraordinary and shocking to say the least. All in all, this is a great film that is still super duper relatable even after nearly 60 years.

My parents played Simon & Garfunkel around the apartment all the time while I was growing up because of this film, so there's something I find deeply comforting about watching it.
Strange, I know, given how disconcerting this film really is, a classic tale of post-graduation anxieties doubling as a eulogy for a certain kind of American innocence, soon to be lost in the tumultuous year of 1968. Nichols' camera often feels off balance, pushing through people and places, constantly zooming in and out of new characters entering the frame. This effect is accentuated by the film's use of montage, collapsing not only time and space but also Ben's subjective state into a pervasive, eerie hollowness. His awkwardness gradually starts to feel more sinister, especially when it gains an obsessive telos, drowning the film in such an overwhelming sense of misguided passion it teeters on the manic. The ending is so bleak to me, transcending a banal uncertainty towards something far more terrifying. Elaine is just collateral damage. There is no real alternative presented for her.

Really wanted to love this as it was one of my most anticipated movies but I hardly enjoyed it due to the film being rather strange. The opening fourty minutes or so were actually quite good in my opinion but once the daughter got involved it all went downhill from there. However, there it still had its fair share of positives which is why I'm not giving it too low of a rating. First of all the cinematography was absolutely sensational and really impressive considering it's fifty six years old. The zoom ins, long takes and overall camerawork were used to good effect throughout the entire runtime. All the acting performances were great aswell and the actors had amazing chemistry together, in particular Dustin Hoffman and Anne Bancroft. There was also some nice editing and well written sequences.
It's a shame that the film really dropped off in the latter stages because I feel like it had potential to be a new favourite of mine, but the film took a path that just wasn't for me.

Went into this expecting nothing more than an outdated and irrelevant time-capsule, only to find myself proven completely wrong from the film's very first frame (a close-up of Hoffmann set against a white background which zooms out to reveal his faceless surroundings, already hinting at the central character's total isolation from the outside world). Nichols use of the camera here is nothing short of inspiring, every zoom resonating with interior meaning, every composition utilising both space and semiotics to further the film's broad and complicated drama - a film which is expressive in its elucidation of isolation (something as simple as Hoffman floating in a pool turned into a hazy montage of cross-fades and refractions) whilst remaining keenly aware of how to use the frame to turn something as small as a glance into something powerful.
From the very beginning of the film there's a crucial disconnect established between parent and child - one generation dictating a future informed by past regrets, another generation confused about whether they find themselves on track to a life in which they truly desire. It's from this uncertainty that the affair with Mrs Robinson is born, a parent perhaps hoping to grasp something that they'd thought lost, and a man who want's to pursue something that's not informed by his own parents materialistic ideas of 'what's best for him'. It's made clear that this isn't a healthy relationship for either individual, Hoffman playing up the insecurities which drive his character to continue the affair (it's telling that he only consummates their mutual attraction when it's suggested that he may be inadequate), and Mrs Robinson painted as someone who's confident exterior seems to house years of pain and wistful regret. Robinson is constantly framed within Hoffman's point-of-view, either a looming figure who seems to follow him within the frame, or a romanticised representation of his lustful desires (see the iconic shot of him framed between her legs) - in small moments when Nichols breaks from this POV we see the complicated individual underneath, but it is continually established that what is shared by these two people is just as much projection as it is affection (this makes the scene where Hoffman attempts to truly 'connect' with Mrs Robinson all the more interesting, as we see a genuine sense of warmth shared between the two, but also begin to grasp how empty this affair is for both parties).
This is what makes Elaine the crucial point of difference for Braddock - their connection isn't one brought about by feelings of inadequacy or rebellion, but of actual understanding (however flimsy it may seem). On their first date they are framed sitting together in Hoffman's car, the outside world moving around them whilst they converse for hours upon end - there is no longer a disconnect established between Hoffman and his lover, both now sharing the frame with equal measure. And yet, even in this small, beautiful moment, there is a certain falseness, a romanticised view of love that Nichols subtly teases out as we see their relationship progress. They may be sharing a special moment of understanding, but it's an understanding once again created and informed by the very forces which they think they're fighting against. This is why the ending remains so utterly effective, Nichols fully immersing us within the youthful rush which both characters feel as they outlandishly fight against those who want to persecute them (the soundtrack combining with the frantic camera-work to make it almost farcical), yet even as the two seem to have won this romantic battle, a creeping unease begins to seep into the frame. The future is no less ambiguous, their relationship may very well come to reflect that of their parents and the connection that they share is one more fleeting than either would care to admit - one cannot fight the terror of uncertainty, no matter how hard each character in this film tries.

At over fifty years old at this point, this film hasn‚Äôt aged a single god damn day. It‚Äôs beautiful, relatable, hell even the costume design held up flawlessly. Its comedy is still golden and sharp as ever. This is as close to perfect and a masterpiece as you‚Äôll ever get.

This film is so masterful at balancing a sincere exploration of depression with gut-busting comedy, sometimes in the space of a single sequence. I love how the Scarborough Fair montage makes it abundantly clear how Benjamin is acting from a place of extreme melancholy and sadness, but that doesn't make it any less comical when Ben responds to his mother's question of if Elaine wants to marry him with "She doesn't. To be perfectly honest she doesn't like me." For all the film's great bits though, my favourite might simply be when Benjamin gets up at the hotel bar to get he and Mrs. Robinson a room and bumps into the table. For all the big, sweeping gestures and heightened conflicts, beats like this are so profoundly human and relatable. Then again, the cutting between Benjamin and the two monkeys in the cage, followed by the snap zoom to the one lonely gorilla, is also pretty good.

ive seen this movie 2 times in my life:
1) at 16, young and naive, freshly entering my first relationship, a bit anxious about the future but focused on the present filled with a happiness i had never felt before. i enjoyed this movie a lot, i thought anne bancroft was so beautiful, and the stark california whites reminded me of the california i was living in, driving down to santa barbara to see my grandparents. i didnt think much of it beyond just a prettily shot and smartly written comedy.
2) tonight at 20, young and naive but less so, that relationship lasting 4 years before vanishing, im older, sadder, more ill and detached, drifting, drifting. i still think anne bancroft is beautiful, and subtle and cunning and sad and amazing, and the stark california whites remind me of the california i used to live in, trips into berkeley and san francisco, warmth, tenderness, desperately trying to escape being lost before finally succumbing. i look in the mirror for hours and i cant recognize myself, i dont know who i am. i worry ill never be able to actualize myself, i worry that ill never have that feeling again i once had at 16 and lost, i worry love is dead and god is dead and that we are all stranded alone and i try to convince myself this isnt true but i can be hard to convince.
from a technical standpoint this film is gorgeous, so aware of color and distance and light and connection of images, and its just so visually playful, the affair montage still blows me away how simple but expressive it is
maybe at 22 or 23 or 24 or 30 or 40 or 50 ill revisit this film and it will serve as a reminder of who i was at this moment, and ill see myself in the past just as naive as i do now. thats what this film does, it makes you reflect on your failures and your anxieties, it tells you that everything will go right while trying not to get your hopes up. absolutely wonderful and soul crushing and amazing film.

guys my goal mostly everytime i write a review is to articulate what exactly struck me as profound or just flat out ingenious, and for me The Graduate with young Dustin Hoffman is honestly one of the great american films without a doubt. I mean from a technical standpoint the execution of this film is pretty much flawless in the way it uses editing, the zoom shots & sound to create a language for the experience & the music just fucking slappsss. Anne Bancroft is absolutely stunning, what can i say that hasn't already been said she's just perfect. The screenplay here is sooo good, so many moments i can specifically remember smiling or busting out laughing especially that scene at the end lollll. So well crafted, lightening in a bottle kind of film here, everything worked for the most part for me. That ending man... im speechless. Also big shoutout to Criterion Channel for allowing me to see this film in beautiful quality you can literally see every drip of water on Ben's face when he runs up to Elaine's room while Ms Robinson chased him, so great. Ok enough rambling this was so good can't wait to watch again!

What did I ever do to deserve this movie
It is not only one of the best written, directed and acted (most especially by Dustin Hoffman who gives the single most relatable performance of all time) films ever, but it is also quite possibly the best edited, paced and musicalized film ever made. The film is (and I will paraphrase Kubrick here) a progression of moods and feelings that never stops, more than a film it is a like a piece of music exploring the psyche of a character and how he confronts the world outside the bubble of studies, which keeps us all imprisoned but also protected for the first years of our lives.
The final minutes explicitly mark the beginning of a new movement which rebels against all traditions. The protagonists escape the church (representing the conservative order that had imperated since Hollywood's inception) and choose to live life outside it, lost but with a completely new horizon to explore. Cinematically speaking, Benjamin and Elaine represent all the filmmakers from the New Hollywood, and the inconclusive ending represents a new beginning for the artform in the USA.
A powerful movie in every sense of the word and one that hasn't lost a bit of relevance over time. Few are the filmd that make me feel as understood and listened as this one.

i‚Äôll start this by stating the obvious: this movie is a masterpiece and a classic for a reason! 
one of the reasons i watched this movie was because this is where the song ‚Äúmrs. robinson‚Äù came from and my mom is a big simon & garfunkel fan. the soundtrack is spectacular! one of the best i‚Äôve ever seen in a movie. specially the fact that the movie starts and ends with the same song. it shows how the main character is just as lost in the final scene than he was in the initial and still has no idea of what he wants to do in life.
the cast was perfect! dustin hoffman was the best person to play an awkward and lost adult. anne bancroft was stunning! (milf was milfing) she was able to play the powerful woman that takes control over the situation but also play the vulnerable burned out woman that have to give up her dreams to take care of a family. that‚Äôs something i loved about this movie.
there is so much to analyze in this film. all camera shots were mesmerizing. there were also so many metaphors and symbolism. his father described his future in one word ‚Äúplastics‚Äù. and this is what benjamin sees in his future, a fake and artificial life. he also denies himself in the beginning of alcohol and smoking, as a way to detach himself as an adult because he is not ready for that stage of his life yet. something i only noted after hearing the directors‚Äô notes is how mrs robinson is always wearing some kind of animal print, such as leopard or cheetah underwear to portray her as a predator. water is also present in most of the movie, in the form of aquariums and pools. that portrays benjamin‚Äôs constant feelings of drowning and his inability to tread water. he is just a fish in a vast sea. i love analyzing metaphors so i instantly loved this movie!
oh god, i have so much to say about this movie. it is way more than a weird taboo story and it has so many messages about identity, conformity and coming-of-age. it rightfully deserved the oscar for best director.

‚ÄúThe Graduate‚Äù is a highly influential dark comedy, character study, and coming of age movie that many people regard as a cult film.
The strongest aspect of the film are definitely the complex, fleshed out, and fascinating characters, first and foremost protagonist Benjamin (Dustin Hoffman), whose insecurities, fears of the future, and general lack of direction in life are relatable for several generations of university students. Anne Bancroft as Mrs. Robinson, a seductive older married woman in her midlife crisis, is the other standout of the movie, and the beautiful Katherine Ross as her daughter Elaine leaves her mark as well. All three actors deliver nuanced, believable, and truly impressive performances, especially Hoffman.
‚ÄúThe Graduate‚Äù is also brilliantly crafted and has a mesmerizing atmosphere. Cinematography and editing are innovative and outstanding, and there are several iconic shots. I especially loved the scuba scene. The wonderful soundtrack further elevates the already great movie. Simon and Garfunkel are among my favorite musicians and their songs have a contemplative, sentimental, and profound quality that perfectly fits the tone, themes, and characters of the film. The film could have featured a wider variety of their songs, though.
Still, I have some minor gripes with the film. Overall, the humor doesn¬¥t really work for me, some of the story beats seem weird (especially concerning the Elaine/Benjamin relationship), and in the second half, the movie loses some of its captivating atmosphere and drags at some parts (though the ending is great again). Nevertheless, it is an engaging and rewarding cinematic experience.
Since ‚ÄúThe Graduate‚Äù was one of the films that paved the way for the New Hollywood movement of the 1970s and was the starting point of Dustin Hoffman¬¥s career, even purely from a film historical perspective, it‚Äôs a must-see. Fortunately, thanks to its timeless look, themes, and performances, the film has aged really well and can still be enjoyed today.

This is one of those movies that I like and revile at the same time, and have watched lots of times over the course of my life.
I think the first time I saw it I was 11 or 12.
Things I like - the camerawork is really creative. The underwater stuff with him jumping in the pool is beautifully and masterfully done. All the Simon & Garfunkel songs are the perfect match.
The stuff about the dad working in plastics makes me laugh. My uncle had a friend who worked in plastics, and was always rattling factoids to me at barbecues about the plastics industry.
Things I don't like so much - the movie is kind of harsh making Mrs. Robinson into a villain. Sometimes women just wanna fuck, and these movies written and directed by dudes make that out to be the worst thing ever. I don't think I'd be happy about my daughter dating this guy. That is a genuinely difficult conversation to have and a tough situation.
The way he (Benjamin) won't take no for an answer from the daughter, and stalks her at school, not romantic to me. Life too short to get hung up on any one thing.
I do like the last scene on the bus, where you just read into the facial expressions, whether this can last or not, or they just made a mistake in the moment.
You can tell it was made in the midst of Vietnam/hippie culture/ generation gap era, when draft age young people hated anyone older on general principle.

This is another beloved classic that I failed to connect with. The story follows a young man, who is more or less reluctantly seduced into having an affair with an older married friend of his parents. It first starts getting problematic when he falls in love with her daughter.
The story obviously had some family drama, but I found it a bit slow and often a bit dull, since there were few of the real dramatic moments and we mostly just followed some not very compelling characters as they awkwardly had an affair. 
The first part of the story felt especially dragged out and like it forced comedy a little too often, which felt weird. The middle was decent enough and then the last part was a bit stalkerish.
The movie was very well directed and it looked great and made use of some nice techniques, but the story and themes didn‚Äôt catch my interest and it felt dated.
I was not a big fan of the music either, since it didn‚Äôt seem to match the tone of the movie and it got a little repetitive to listen to. 
The cast gave some good performances, but I just don‚Äôt think their characters were the best.

The Graduate is a film that has been on my radar for some time, and today I finally had the chance to see this masterpiece. This film truly is one of the best films ever made, no doubt about it. 
Ben Braddock is an insecure young man. He gets very overwhelmed when he's the center of attention and is very awkward when trying to take the initiative to do something. In a way he reminded me of myself. His life is full of uncertainty. Even though he graduated college, he still doesn't know what he wants to do. He also hesitates on going to graduate school, which his parents try to push him towards. This uncertainty factor is a major part of the character, but a minor part of the story. The main focus is Ben's affair with Mrs. Robinson,  a older women who seduces him one night. They develop a relationship, but Ben then develops feelings for Mrs. Robinson's daughter Elaine. This really is the main focus of the film, Ben finding himself torn between these two women. At its core the film is a drama, but it has some comedic elements. The ending is a bit comedic in its own right, but there's a sense of satisfaction as well. The dialogue in this film is also great, especially Ben's dialogue. Ben is an awkward character, and the dialogue reflects that. There are also so many quotable lines. I mean, who can forget "Mrs Robinson, you're trying to seduce me". Classic line right there. There are so many aspects of this film that make it a masterpiece, and the story is only one part. 
Dustin Hoffman gives his best performance in this film in my opinion. He plays Ben, an awkward young man who is torn between two women. His performance is oddly charming in some scenes, especially the scene where he tries to rent a hotel room. Anne Bancroft and Katherine Ross also give great performances as Mrs Robinson and Elaine, respectively. Bancroft gives an almost hypnotizing performance, which is a good thing. Her line delivery felt hypnotic, almost as if she was trying to entice the character of Ben. All in all, the performances in this film all around were great. 
A lot could be said about the direction of this film, but one element that really stuck out to me was the cinematography. Some of the shots in this film looked so great. One that stuck out to me was when Ben met Mrs. Robinson in the bar, and as she walked up the camera focused on a reflective table, showing her entering the frame. What I said probably makes no sense but when (or if) you've seen the film you'll know what I'm talking about. The cinematography stays consistent, with every scene looking great. 
Who can forget the amazing Simon and Garfunkel songs in this film. Everything from Sound of Silence to Scarborough Fair was a delight to hear on screen. Granted I felt like some of the songs were repeated a bit much, but the rest of the film makes up for that. 
The Graduate is a perfect film, no doubt about it. With a perfect story, characters and music that is a delight to the ears, this isn't one to miss. I'm excited to check out more of Mike Nichols's films in the future.

The first time I watched this was about a year and a half ago, watching this again a week before I turn 18 with only a few months left until I go to university is pretty surreal.
I loved it then and I love it even more now. It‚Äôs the best film that captures a feeling of aimlessness that everyone experiences at one point or another. Leaving high school soon, I‚Äôm 99.99% sure that the decisions I‚Äôve made regarding my future are the right ones. It‚Äôs the stuff I‚Äôm passionate about, it‚Äôs the stuff I‚Äôve been interested in for years, it‚Äôs the stuff I think I‚Äôm pretty good at. 
But there‚Äôs a part of me at the back of my mind thinking that it‚Äôs not right for me. That by some random chance the path I‚Äôve laid out for myself isn‚Äôt the best course of action. There‚Äôs a fear that the second I reach the ‚Äúadult world‚Äù I‚Äôll just aimlessly drift about trying to find some purpose to latch on to.
The Graduate taps into that universal dread of aimlessness perfectly. For some, it could be a horrifying piece of existential nihilism, but for others, including myself, it‚Äôs oddly comforting. It‚Äôs a reminder that everyone at one point experiences this drifting sensation. I‚Äôm reminded that I‚Äôm not the only one who has no idea what‚Äôs coming. 
Nobody has one purpose, we just latch on to brief splashes of happiness before becoming disillusioned and moving onto the next one. Yeah, maybe that‚Äôs scary, but in a sense that‚Äôs life, and The Graduate invites us to stop trying to avoid that fact and embrace it. 
It‚Äôs not really feel good, it‚Äôs not really feel bad, it‚Äôs The Graduate, a completely unique and incredible cinematic experience that nobody has dared try to replicate.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm a little worried about my future‚Äù
I‚Äôve tried writing about this movie several times in the past, and every time I was unable to muster up anything more than ‚ÄúI deeply relate to this film, and it means a lot to me‚Äù, but I think now is the perfect time for me to attempt to articulate my thoughts, despite still not being able to fully organize my them.
At the time of writing this, today is the day I graduated high school. It didn‚Äôt really dawn on me just how close I was to being done until maybe a couple of weeks ago when I started to see some of my old friends from elementary school posting pictures of their high school graduation. When I saw that it felt like I was being pushed full speed ahead into the ‚Äúadult world‚Äù, the ‚Äúreal world‚Äù. Unlike Benjamin, I do have some sort of idea of what I want to do with my life, but that doesn‚Äôt alleviate any of the pressure and anxiety I feel around the subject of the future. I think that is probably a universal experience, being afraid of all the infinite possibilities that lie ahead of you in your life. What will come? Who will you become? What kind of a life will you live? Mike Nichols‚Äô portrayal of youth does not trivialize the struggle of these questions, but he instead sympathizes with the character and completely immerses the audience into that headspace. We see Benjamin constantly being asked by the adults of the movie about what his plans are for the future, what he is going to do with himself, and why he isn‚Äôt doing anything productive. I‚Äôve seen some people assert that the adults are the ‚Äúvillains‚Äù of the movie, but I couldn‚Äôt disagree more. For starters, I think to say that The Graduate has a ‚Äúvillain‚Äù or a ‚Äúbad guy‚Äù is just an oversimplification of the film. Secondly, Buck Henry‚Äôs screenplay depicts both generations in almost the same light. The only reason that the older generation is seen as the villains is that we see everything from Ben‚Äôs perspective, the younger perspective. However, all the pieces of advice that the adults have for Ben come from a well-meaning place even if they are not received that way. A lot of the adult‚Äôs life is depicted as empty and insincere, but the advice is sincere even if they aren‚Äôt as close to Ben as they are socially obligated to pretend they are. Societal expectations are something that plays a big part in The Graduate. Things you should do just because that's what people do. ‚ÄúShould‚Äù is a word that I often associate with The Graduate because of this. You should go to graduate school, you should get married if you‚Äôre going to have a baby, you should get married for security, and you should remain married even if you hate your life. This is particularly the case with the most central marriage of the film. It is made very clear to the audience that Mr. and Mrs. Robinson have no real connection. They got married because Mrs. Robinson was pregnant, and live out their life side by side because that‚Äôs what you are supposed to do when you have a child out of wedlock. They tough it out despite no longer having any sort of sexual or romantic relationship with one another because that‚Äôs what you‚Äôre supposed to do. Mrs. Robinson‚Äôs character is equally as interesting as Ben‚Äôs in my opinion because of details about her that I overlooked in my first couple of views. Mrs. Robinson‚Äôs life was completely stopped in its tracks because of Elaine‚Äôs birth and her subsequent marriage to Mr. Robinson. Everything in her life is defined by her husband and her family, the character doesn‚Äôt even have a first name, and is only ever addressed by her married last name. By seducing Ben, she is exercising one of the few liberties that she still has in her vapid and seemingly pointless life. I‚Äôve also seen some people say that in their eyes Mrs. Robinson is the villain of the movie, but again, I couldn‚Äôt disagree more.
I am a person with a lot of anxiety about a lot of different things, but the big one for me tends to be social anxiety. Social anxiety is something that tends to be misrepresented in film. There are a lot of good representations out there, like Punch Drunk Love, Frances Ha or really any Charlie Kaufman screenplay. However, no other film seems to get social anxiety quite like The Graduate gets it. The way that Nichols and Robert Surtees use the camera to isolate Benjamin from those around him was incredible for the time and still holds up. Right from the opening shot of the film, Robert Surtees establishes the feeling that when you are a very nervous person, the things around you tend to feel like noise. The writing for Ben‚Äôs character is brought to life and elevated by the virtually unknown at the time, Dustin Hoffman. Everything about his performance makes it a favourite of mine. His movements are uncertain, almost every uncomfortable moment in the film is accompanied by a little whimper from Hoffman. They‚Äôre small but very frequent throughout the film, especially in the first half. Ben‚Äôs trajectory as a character is what makes me think that Buck Henry‚Äôs screenplay is not taking any sides when it comes to the generational divide. Benjamin might be painfully relatable at times because of his social awkwardness and naivety in certain situations, but as the film goes on Benjamin‚Äôs character flaws begin to show themselves more and more. The older generation in the film never does anything, but the younger generation is too impulsive with their decisions. Benjamin is shown to be very indecisive with his decisions for the majority of the film, however, sometime in the middle of the film Benjamin starts making lots of rash decisions that push people away from him, and isolates himself further. I think that the assertion that Henry‚Äôs screenplay is making is that both generations have their flaws, and simply can not understand one another‚Äôs life choices and perspectives, not that one generation is wrong and the other is right.
I sometimes see people complain that the film recycles the same Simon and Garfunkle tracks over and over, but I think they‚Äôre missing the entire point of Nichols‚Äô decision to repeatedly use the same songs. These songs are not just needle drops for the sake of needle drops. The Sound Of Silence is the song that is repeated the most in the film, and it is used to underscore a point every time it is played. It establishes Benjamin‚Äôs headspace, his thoughts, and his overall mood during certain scenes. The track Mrs. Robinson might be considered The Graduate‚Äôs theme song so to speak, but in reality, that title should go to The Sound Of Silence. Garfunkle said that The Sound Of Silence was about ‚Äúthe inability of people to communicate with each other, not particularly intentionally but especially emotionally, so what you see around you are people unable to love each other", which ties in very nicely to the themes and ideas presented in The Graduate, and explains a little bit more why Nichols would decide to repeatedly use it. The entire soundtrack is pretty incredible though, especially when it is used in tandem with some of the lovely editing in the film. The montage during Mrs. Robinson and Benjamin‚Äôs first affair is easily one of the best-edited scenes in any film, and the melancholic tunes of Simon and Garfunkle bring it to another level and give the edit even more life. Simon and Garfunkle were the perfect groups to do a soundtrack for this movie, sonically their music is both depressingly melancholic while maintaining a glimmer of hope, which matches the tone of the film quite perfectly.
The Graduate has one of the most iconic and memorable endings of all time. In my eyes, it is the greatest ending of all time. Mike Nichols does not shove a conclusion down the audience‚Äôs throat at the end of the film, he allows the audience to make their own meaning. For me, the ending is Benjamin and Elaine breaking away from their parents' control over their life and their decisions. This is a scary decision for the character and this choice is putting them both back into an uncertain and unknown future. A future where their relationship could easily devolve into something as emotionless and vapid as the marriage of Elaine‚Äôs parents, hence the use of The Sound Of Silence once again.
This rambling nonsense of a review is the closest I will ever come to being able to fully articulate my thoughts on this movie, and to be honest this still is just the tip of the iceberg.

[59]
About three decades ahead of schedule. What this has that many of its kitschy Nineties counterparts don‚Äôt is an awkward and bumbling protagonist that feels genuinely consumed by his own maceration of anxiety and, to some degree, guilt, and not in an exaggerated, played-for-humor kind of way. Jason Biggs was goofy and in many ways hilarious - as was his equally nerdy father (god bless Eugene Levy) - but Hoffman carries a briefcase of uncertainty with him at every juncture, to the point where his situational unawareness constantly calcifies into a social ineptness that borders on Asperger‚Äôs. (That‚Äôs a good thing, mind you, precisely because his character gives no indication otherwise of any sort of inhibitions, meaning the performance registers as legitimate and not overly theatrical like it does in, say, RAINMAN.) Nichols also tosses in an occasional artistic flourish - e.g. shooting Ben‚Äôs ‚ÄùYou‚Äôre trying to seduce me, aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù from beneath Mrs. Robinson‚Äôs bent leg, or capturing her first arrival at the hotel through the upside-down reflection of one of the lobby‚Äôs glass tables - without getting stale or lamely denotative. The humor is surprisingly humorous, too‚ÄîI‚Äôm not sure if the barometer of comedy has dwindled through the years or if people thirty years ago were inherently funnier, but I was cracking up at even the smallest throwaway jokes, like Ben‚Äôs dad twice shoving him back underwater during his cookout diving demonstration, or how Mrs. Robinson‚Äôs attempt at getting the room number - ‚ÄùIsn‚Äôt there something you want to tell me, Benjamin?‚Äù - is instead met with trifling sweet nothings and hesitation forms.
But for as much as I love this movie as a bit of lewd postulating, I despise it for the misshapen motley of rebellion, submission, and sociopathy into which it eventually mutates. The prickly dynamic between Ben and one of his classmate‚Äôs mothers is dandy‚Äîobviously taboo and obviously wrong but also obviously not unfathomable, a crossthread of morality and logic at which most of the succulence is acquired. Ben‚Äôs sudden - and suddenly relentless - obsession with Elaine is a diversion that bothered me the first time I saw this (over a decade ago) and greatly upset me this second time around. One can always posit that it‚Äôs a side-effect of Ben‚Äôs malaise and controlling, ultra-reflexive personality, but that only superficially accounts for his behavior, and gives no real indication as to why he‚Äôd be so interested in her in the first place (after previously having shown no interest at all). Tried to convince myself that it was some sort of surrogate mind trick at work‚Äîi.e., he wants Mrs. Robinson, knows he can‚Äôt realistically have her (beyond, you know, sex), and attempts to rectify that by dating her daughter‚Äîbut didn‚Äôt find that satisfying enough, nor do I think his rash and aggressive conduct reads as a mindless act of mutiny against the elder generation. It‚Äôs too farfetched to think that any boy could be simultaneously this aimless and assertive, so the only real ‚Äúexplanation‚Äù becomes a diagnosis of psychopathy, and this hasn‚Äôt quite the energy to pull off something that grim. Even if any of those half-justifications placated me regarding Ben‚Äôs trajectory, I‚Äôd still be scratching my head at Elaine‚Äôs blank-slated display of what essentially boils down to Stockholm Syndrome. Literally no woman in the world would put up with the shit she puts up with in the small time frame in which she does.
But clumsy narrative and thematic addling aside, the shitbag antics are composed as elegantly as the sublime first-half, shot with the same keenness and coordinated with what has to be one of the era‚Äôs finest and most well-integrated soundtracks. The final shot is magical, too, even if I‚Äôm bothered by nearly everything it took to get us there. Not sure how I‚Äôd rewrite this to jell, though. Part of me thinks that having Elaine actively pursuing Ben while he continues to sneak around with her mother - unbeknownst to both of them, at least for a while - and keeps prolonging the inevitable choice he must make would create something more stable and less frustratingly impulsive. Then again, I look at how iconic this move remains over fifty years later and concede that the writing is probably best left to professionals and not everything will make me happy.
The fear of not knowing what‚Äôs next, and the pain of being told you should.

Strong Performances - Anne Bancroft
Many of us find ourselves trailing along a life that is assembled for us. There is a compulsion to conform towards the idealism of those that raised us, presuming that their guidance would always be best. There is a lingering fear that cripples us in our youths to break against the mould that is shaped for us; a fear of implying disrespect against those who have sacrificed so much for us; a fear of dabbling our feet in completely daring and uncharted waters; a fear of reaching a dead end that only reminds us of our failure and cowardice.
This was the essence that is conveyed across within a matter of minutes with it‚Äôs protagonist, Benjamin Braddock, played here by Dustin Hoffman. An introduction so effective, the audience is able to immediately identify with the vulnerabilities and complication that lies within this individual and opens up the possible outcomes that may exist ahead for him, thus pinning our intrigue and keeping us thoroughly engaged.
Caught by the gaze of Mrs. Robinson (Anne Bancroft), she sees Ben as a potential prey, a source of relief from her own issues. She is a woman suffering through alcoholism, driven by her depression from the life that she has led; a woman who has endured so far in that no longer could she turn back and restart. Could it be that she sees a quality in Ben that finds his situation and empathetic and therefore would try to pin him as long as she could, stunting him from growth and happiness; or simply has she found a new form of substance, an addiction that would temporarily escape her from her swallowing sadness and insecurities. Despite the character seeming so unlikable, she is, however, a fascinating creature on screen, seeing and feeling the pain and desperation that sits beneath her sexual aggression; she is a wonderful contrast to the internal angsts that drive beneath Benjamin.
Many laughs are to be had with The Graduate. Mike Nichols succeeds in reflecting the awkwardness and desperation of Ben, a young man who finds new experiences confronting and when finally faced with something genuine, he finds himself self-destructive rather than productive in his attempt to preserve it. Elaine (Katharine Ross) is that shining beacon that enters into his seemingly bleak life, almost as if a living angel, a solace from the suffocating taunts and pressures from his current life, one that manages to show true empathy for the experiences that he currently suffers. It was in the juxtaposition that Nichols demonstrates between Ben‚Äôs experience with Elaine and her mother that succeeds in pushing effectively the thematic intentions behind the narrative.
Given the issues and angsts that Ben is battling, and the outcome of the story, The Graduate could be seen as a counter-culture film, one that rebels against the traditional conformity that has plagued prior to the 1960s. Ben feels the unhappiness from the pathway that was thrusted upon him, now faced at a crossroads where he fears in advancing forward as deep inside him, he knows that pursuing such a path would only bring him a life of regret and resentment; a life that may mirror the tragedy that has befallen Mrs. Robinson. The choice to rebel and be free from the shackles is inspired by the presence of Elaine, which I personally feel the film didn‚Äôt explore enough of, but her impact on Ben is well reflected. Despite the choices that both Ben and Elaine have chosen at the film‚Äôs end, the price of relief comes with a swirling pool of excitement, fear, anxiety, and elation, unknowing of the trials that may lie ahead, but at the very least the canvas is clear and from there they can create a life to their heart‚Äôs desire.

The Graduate is a film that was truly ahead of its time man I wasn‚Äôt expecting it to hit so close to home. Those final seconds where we see their smiles disappear as they realise they now have to face the uncertainties of life really stuck with me because I, just like many others, am also constantly worrying about my future.

Really wish this would have gone heavier on the identity crisis and the immense pressure weighing on a young man who had his whole life ahead of him in which he was unsure where to take it. Because early on, it's clear that's dragging Ben down.
One of the opening shots features him staring straight ahead, a white wall next to him as the automatic airport path carries him through. The camera stays fixed as his expressionless face is not taken out of frame once. He's set on a path not made by his own decisions. And when he conversates with others, their faces invade his. The camera work is simply tremendous, full of deeper meaning.
Instead the film chooses to be about the pitfalls of sex and love. I'm not against a good romance plot, but this wasn't that. I held off on critiquing the characters because I felt something in the middle or end would force their emotions to the surface and put us in their heads, where we understood the decisions they were making. Tragically, that never came to be.
To put things bluntly, I don't buy the romance between him and Elaine. I don't buy the physical attraction of Mrs. Robinson, although Anne Bancroft was a very gorgeous woman. The forgiveness was too easily earned in the end, and the music was starting to drive me crazy. No, I will not be going to Scarborough Fair, now quit asking.

‚ÄúMrs. Robinson, you‚Äôre trying to seduce me!‚Äù
The Good:
Mike Nicholos does an absolutely stunning job in the directors chair. I love all the odd zooms and sleek movement. He also does a great job of capturing the mood of the scene; for example he really makes you feel the claustrophobia of the party scenes and the intimidation of Mrs. Robinson. The Technicolor cinematography is absolutely breathtaking, the colors are so vibrant. 
Anne Bancroft is a complete show stopper! She is completely manipulative and devilishly sly in an intimidating mature way. Dustin Hoffman‚Äôs transformation throughout 
the duration of the film was magnificent. 
The Graduate is hilarious look at loneliness, sexual repression, and lack of direction in life after college. Thematically The Graduate is a much deeper film than I was expecting and that made it just that much better.
I loved the tone of the film overall. It‚Äôs got a very awkward sense of humor with some serious undertones, however they never clashed; it was always very intentionally separated. 
The Bad:
I just have some sound design issues that annoyed me alongside some questionable one scene performances.
Fun Fact:
None of the older characters is called by a first name in the film; only the younger characters of Benjamin, Elaine and Carl do, increasing the sense of a generation gap.
Would Recommend!
from the incredible direction, to the naturalistic performances, to the gorgeous cinematography and great soundtrack, this is a perfect movie.

The specific feelings of melancholy and romantic(ish) excitement in The Graduate are lightning in a (celluloid) bottle. It‚Äôs one of those awkward comedies, full of nervous energy, that makes me laugh / die inside in equal measure. I think some choices are distracting, like the repetitive soundtrack, but it‚Äôs otherwise indelible moviemaking (the leg shot, the running, the ending). Hoffman‚Äôs social ineptitude and Nichols/Surtees‚Äôs expressionism give perfect form to the various insecurities and anxieties here, many of which I felt deeply. It was either genius or stupid of me to watch this during college app season.

English text below
Benjamin Braddock hat den College-Abschluss mit Bravour gemeistert. Jetzt kehrt er vor√ºbergehend zu seinen Eltern zur√ºck und trifft auf Mrs. Robinson, die attraktive Ehefrau eines Gesch√§ftspartners von Benjamins Vater. Mrs. Robinson verf√ºhrt den unsicheren und orientierungslosen jungen Mann und geht mit ihm eine heimliche, rein sexuelle Beziehung ein. Doch als Benjamin die Tochter von Mrs. Robinson n√§her kennenlernt, √§ndern sich die Verh√§ltnisse.
Mit starken Darstellerinnen und Darstellern ‚Äì allen voran Dustin Hoffman als Benjamin ‚Äì hat Regisseur Mike Nichols (WHO‚ÄôS AFRAID OF VIRGINIA WOOLF?; CATCH 22; SILKWOOD) nach Charles Webbs Roman eine bissige Gesellschaftssatire inszeniert, die dezidiert filmisch √ºber vorz√ºglich komponierte Bilder erz√§hlt und deren Soundtrack (Songs von Simon & Garfunkel) das Geschehen perfekt unterstreicht. Im letzten Akt schl√§gt die Geschichte allerdings absurde Kapriolen ‚Äì und nimmt sich damit viel von ihrer Kraft. F√ºr mich pers√∂nlich bleibt ein sehenswerter Film mit deutlichen Schw√§chen im Abgang. Der allgemeinen Begeisterung kann ich mich nicht anschlie√üen.
PS: THE GRADUATE wurde vielfach zitiert, u. a. in der Er√∂ffnungssequenz von Quentin Tarantinos JACKIE BROWN.
Bitte beachten: Ich bewerte die Filme auf der 5-Sterne-Skala immer innerhalb ihres Genres, soweit sie sich einordnen lassen.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Benjamin Braddock has graduated from college with flying colors. Now he temporarily returns to his parents and meets Mrs. Robinson, the attractive wife of one of Benjamin's father‚Äôs business partners. Mrs. Robinson seduces the insecure and disoriented young man and enters into a secret, purely sexual relationship with him. But when Benjamin gets to know Mrs. Robinson‚Äôs daughter, things change.
With strong actors and actresses ‚Äì above all Dustin Hoffman as Benjamin ‚Äì director Mike Nichols (WHO‚ÄôS AFRAID OF VIRGINIA WOOLF?; CATCH 22; SILKWOOD) has staged a biting social satire based on Charles Webb‚Äôs novel, which tells a decidedly cinematic story with excellently composed images and a soundtrack (songs by Simon & Garfunkel) that perfectly underscores the action. In the final act, however, the story takes a turn for the absurd ‚Äì and thus loses much of its power. For me personally, it remains a movie worth seeing with clear weaknesses at the end. I cannot join in the general enthusiasm.
PS: THE GRADUATE has been quoted many times, including in the opening sequence of Quentin Tarantino‚Äôs JACKIE BROWN.
Please note: I always rate the films on the five-star scale within their genre, as far as they can be classified.

i'd somehow never seen this and i'm delighted to announce: it's very good. captures the way adulthood creeps upon you suddenly and all at once despite your very explicit wishes that actually, no please, not this, thank you very much. kind of [forgive me for this] the anti-licorice pizza, benjamin stuck in limbo just like alana but temptation this time in the form of this pristine, sexy, confident, messy adulthood, drawing him ultimately back to elaine instead. we all know this but the ending is fucking exceptional. good stuff!

I think in some way, regardless of age, gender, school grade, or social status, we all have a little Benjamin Braddock inside of us. Outwardly, one may appear jovial and excited to advance onto life, but there's also the inner confusion, emptiness, and fear to be found in Dustin Hoffman's eyes and body language. I'm no college graduate, I'm a high school freshman. And yet, I still feel lost. To be confused on what to do, what I'm learning, what's gonna happen next, and how hard it's gonna be for my concerning future. Sure, one may have advantages through planning beforehand, having very supportive friends and family, and the such, but not many people are lucky enough to have that privilege. If there's anything that feels like a thesis to The Graduate, it's probably the word 'Now what?', as it's shown heavily. Yet this film understands youth, in a way, earlier than any other film before it. And shockingly well.
For its time, it's one of the most visually creative films I've ever seen. Symbolism is captured so effortlessly and efficiently. Water as a way to describe where the fuck we are in the world. Benjamin is shown suffocating in that scuba suit in the early beginning, yet when the second act kicks in, he's all chill and nonchalant. In a way, we're all like that at some point. I slack off a lot, not caring about my future, much to the dissatisfaction of my parents, but I suppose it's just denial of my worry. And in a way, sometimes I just fall off that raft, my fat ugly ass. Yet when there's water, one can swim. I'm still in the water, but at least I'm not drowning. And in a lot of ways, the movie's style, alongside the film's just absolute brilliant writing and developed story, just captures Ben's mental state in so many ways. Mrs. Robinson is basically a wild animal. Her jungle-y lounge, her leopard print outfits, all animalistic, and Ben is her prey. The zoom-ins, the lighting, and that iconic leg frame showing his trapped nature, it's all really brilliant to me. Moments like that scare me, not just physically or mentally, but emotionally. Our confusion wraps us up in manipulation, like tapestries encasing a surprise gift. I feel trapped in life sometimes, and I don't want to grow up. One can have goals, and I guess to certain extents, go too far. Perhaps we indulge too deep in our fantasies but growing up is tough to a lot of folks, and much like Ben, we too feel anxious and prepared, simultaneously. A shadow on one end, gleam on the other, it's all just perfect to me. The music also beautifully fits the movie a lot. Needle drops like Mrs. Robinson and The Sounds of Silence play so naturally and perfectly capture what is going on with each character. It's a little depressing to listen to them a thousand times in context, but we all feel a little fitting in those shoes. Those times of regret and sadness come back at times whenever we feel like we matter, only for that inevitable doom and post-clarity to surround you for some reason. It just perfectly captures that sense of emptiness we have in life; hence its resonance still stays.
I tried watching this film 2 separate times. This is the 3rd time. I planned on watching this by the time I graduated. Yet I caved in and watched it. I was expecting to love it and I did. But I still have no idea what the hell I'm doing. And for a while I probably won't. I'll be there, eventually, but right now, I guess the best way I can truly cope with it is the art of cinema. The Graduate is probably the sincerest example of this, and it endears as a classic. It's perfect as a movie and as a touchstone for me. I may not enjoy it in the future, or who knows, maybe I'm seeing it too seriously right now. Really, everything is confusing to think about. It's hard to understand what I'm going through, but hey, how should I know. I'm just a freshman. I've got time, right? But when the time to start thinking again comes to a close....now what?

After discovering from this lovely list by LinusMxx that The Player, a film I planned on seeing soon enough, spoiled 1967's The Graduate, I decided to watch the latter film in order to not be spoiled and it was also a great time for it since I had Bleart and Sam hyping me up. Safe to say that this did not disappoint.
This was one of the first originators of the idea known as the "love triangle". Today, it's a trope that's overused and overly-played out yet to see it being unravelled in The Graduate was truly a sight to see. Furthermore, this film also covered the important topic of college and more so how we feel lost afterwards. I know what I want to do with the rest of my life but there are still many times where I've felt lost in this cruel world. It's just second-nature to us. And with that comes a certain relatability that the The Graduate greatly holds in the palms of its hands. Nichols and the three writers worked out an insane yet fairly believable plot and created something so incredible and emotionally resonant. I hope this doesn't come off as me bragging but I have felt the same way Hoffman feels in this film as he's constantly praised by family members and friends. It can get a little exhausting at times yet it's still something to be joyful about, and that relatability that this film clings onto is so greatly and effectively used here.
Speaking of Hoffman, damn he was amazing in this film! His performance felt so natural and similarly to the themes portrayed, his portrayal of Ben also felt relatable. With each passing film I see Hoffman in, my love for him grows further and further. Plus, the rest of the cast also did marvellous jobs at portraying their characters well.
Another thing is that I saw a handful of reviews stating the three Simon & Garfunkel songs were profusely overused and I can see that but it never got old for me. The songs were just so hard-hitting and they were used perfectly within this film. Just a small detail that I wanted to mention.
I was originally going to give The Graduate a 5/5 yet that climax kind of made things fall apart for me. I don't wish to enter spoiler-territory (I'll probably do so on a rewatch) but I'll just say that things got a little too crazy and unbelievable for me. Other than that, this is amazing!! Really need to see more from both Hoffman and Nichols.

Honestly, I expected something more....the film is certainly flawless in showing the traits of a society that now disintegrates the dreams of young people and traps them in a situation of absolute control and planning of an often unwanted way of life. Some sequences, such as the final or initial one, are emblematic, in which one can hear, even if only through glances or the magnificent and unforgettable soundtrack, moods, thoughts and the imprisonment of a society from which one would only want to get away.
Leaving that aside, it is a very smooth, well-acted and technically perfect film but it has disappointed my expectations, not reaching me as deeply as I had hoped.
In the future I will definitely have to do a rewatch, to reconfirm my ideas or re-evaluate my opinions about it.

I‚Äôve just rediscovered the first film review I ever published online and wanted to house it here for the memories ü•∞
A Cinematic Watershed
1967: arguably one of the greatest year for movie-goers across the globe enjoying classics such as Cool Hand Luke, Bonnie & Clyde and the Jungle Book. But audiences flocking to see Mike Nichol's 'The Graduate' in such huge numbers that it remains the highest grossing film of '67. But why did this modest drama starring unknown an new- comer - Dustin Hoffman - captivate society? 
The Graduate epitomises the sexual revolution in the most elegant yet audacious manner. The film oozes symbolism from the fantastic screenplay to the striking direction. Not only do all three leads - Hoffman, Bancroft and Ross - deliver tremendous performances, but they embody this new generation of post-war America: seeking sexual liberation to fill a void left by the disintegration of familial bonds in the wake of a resort to materialism.
Needless to say, this movie evokes a broad array of reactions within the viewer - only emboldened by the incredibly iconic and poignantly ambiguous finale. You'll by no doubt have heard the soundtrack, which is brilliant in it's own right whilst cementing 'The Graduate' as (in my humble opinion) a perfect film.

Perfectly acted. Perfectly shot. Perfectly edited. Perfect soundtrack.
It‚Äôs so satisfying when a classic film lives up to its lofty reputation.

R.I.P. Mike Nichols, you were a true maverick director. The Graduate is one of those seminal classics that is just a joy to revisit and always manages to rejuvenate my love for cinema. The cinematography, the music, the script, and the performances all build to the bittersweet genius of the ending. The themes presented are still as potent today. This is one near and dear to my heart. Some will say it has aged poorly. I say it's timeless. Maybe I've been seduced.

This was definitely really well made. I loved the way editing was used. It‚Äôs definitely more substantial than it might first seem, and I appreciated the ways it avoided being that. It took me a while to really be on the same page, but once I was, the more humorous moments were great. It‚Äôs pretty unfortunate that the abstractness if the subtextual elements subtracts from the autonomy of certain characters that would otherwise be a lot more important, but I understand where that‚Äôs coming from. I think this is a film where I could either see my opinion staying completely the same if I return to it or my appreciation growing a lot more because of a change in my personal perspective. It‚Äôs hard to tell which of those would happen, but I don‚Äôt consider those options bad at all.

Original Title: The Graduate
Year of Release: 1967
Genres: Dramatic Comedy
Director: Mike Nichols
Writers: Calder Willingham, Buck Henry, Charles Webb
Main Cast: Dustin Hoffman, Anne Bancroft, Katharine Ross, Murray Hamilton, William Daniels, Elizabeth Wilson
80/100 of A Decade Called 1960s: 2018-19 Edition
"Our greatest fears lie in anticipation"
- Balzac
The Graduate couldn't have arrived at a better time in my life. This year I will be graduating from university, and, like many others before me, I am starting to become more and more afraid at what the future holds. The expectations of people all around me, from friends to family, are overwhelming, and I am perfectly aware that all this will disappear once I actually start a master's degree or a job. But, until then, I am afraid, and I get lost in the anticipation.
This can be felt in many other aspects of life: asking out the girl you like, taking a vacation all on your own, going to a school where you know no one, emigrating to another country... You can easily get lost inside the fears you create in your mind, and you completely lose tracks of what makes life beautiful and worth living.
The Graduate is very much a film that encapsulates this feeling. Our main character, Ben, has no real goal in life, and the only thing that keeps him going is a purely-sexual relationship with the infamous Mrs. Robinson. But, once he meets Mrs. Robinson's daughter and sees how much they have in common, he feels like he has found a new purpose in life: to get the girl.
On a purely superficial level, this should be one of the most romantic movies ever made, where a young lad follows his heart and goes against all odds to reach the love of his life. However, this film is so much more than that. There is almost a cyclical nature to this story: we open up with Ben having graduated from college and going back home, with no real purpose in life, and The Sound of Silence playing in the background, and the film ends with Ben finally escaping with Elaine, yet having once again no goal in life (and Sound of Silence closes the film).
It's a rather dark ending to a film that is one of the best dramatic comedies of all time, with the first half especially having really clever moments in both its visuals and the dialogue. And it's said dialogue that makes this such a great film: every character is fully realized, everyone feels real and you have enough information about them without needing much exposition. For as much fun as the first half is, there is an underlying sadness in the film from beginning to end, and it can be felt in every character other than Ben.
Mrs. Robinson is a fascinating woman, one who has made mistakes in life that many others have done and (most likely) will do, and her seducing Ben feels (in a sick way) like she is trying to protect her daughter, shielding her from the same life she has led. But, as we all know, that is not the case, and the daughter falls in love with Ben. But is it really love? First she is mistreated and brought to a strip club, then she is revered and treated like a princess. She, like Ben and other characters in the film, is quite shallow, naive, and confused, more focused in the pleasures of the now rather than the careful planning of the future.
Everyone is the victim of their parents here, with Ben feeling the pressure of doing something with his life, and Elaine (probably) feeling the need to find someone to start a family with. That is not what both want, and they try everything they can to avoid the future their parents have planned for them... yet, by doing the complete opposite, they end up fulfilling a self-fulfilling prophecy, with Elaine and Ben likely becoming the new Mr. & Mrs. Robinson in another town.
Not only is this a perfect story, but the way it is presented is nothing short of wonderful. The camerawork by Surtees has some terrific shots, from POVs to wide shots that show the isolation Ben is feeling, as well as one of the best uses of shifting focus in the history of cinema (when Elaine slowly understands what has happened between Ben and her mother). The soundtrack by Simon & Garfunkel is a true beauty, each song used multiple times based on the feelings that Ben has throughout the story. The sound design especially has a lot of attention to detail, and the editing is used to great effect to keep the pacing brisk and light, but also to create one of the most unique montages I have seen in quite some time.
Overall, The Graduate truly is a perfect film. Its story has surprisingly affected me in more ways than one, and I couldn't have watched this at a better time in my life. It is a dense a rich film with a truly engaging narrative, beautiful camerawork and sound, brilliant acting, and life-like characters. I loved this film, and I can't wait to cherish it for years to come.

This thing really started at the pace of a turtle and went out with a memorable crescendo! Killer soundtrack (is this really where Mrs. Robinson song debuted?) THE breakout Dustin Hoffman performance, and a plot, that by today‚Äôs standards is common place, but was sure to carry shock value in 1969. 
This movie is so much about the unspoken, the tensions, the physical acting, the expressions, the shots, the music. I mean the shots and lighting in this movie are just fantastic and so clearly iconic. For example, the lighting and shadows in the hotel bedroom, where Mrs. Robinson and Ben have their illicit affair, are used to reflect seduction, the dark nature of their deeds and the loss of innocence. Most of the dialogue in the movie is pretty superficial, and that is intentional, everything that‚Äôs important is conveyed through other means. The build up on Eliane and Ben‚Äôs first date. Here‚Äôs the progression: wild car ride, leads to high stimulus environment, leads to emotional overload, leads to kiss, leads to more sensory overload at the fast food joint, leads to SILENCE (big theme in this film) in the car. That‚Äôs the formation of their relationship and it‚Äôs all done with little or meaningless dialogue. The more I think about this movie, the more apparent the unique style and genius. 
Ben‚Äôs life is directionless and captures the question-marks a recent graduate might have surrounding life prospects. As this self discovery progresses the movie shows how easy it would be to fall under the influence of a strong, beautiful sexual temptress. Then, the shift back to an interest in a youthful girl shows that Ben‚Äôs interest in the mother was more to satisfy physical desires, and that his heart really craves the youthful Elaine. This movie really did need this mother/daughter sex twist because some of the pacing in the beginning made for a slow start.
I am kind of just spitballing about some of the underlying motivations and themes I took away. What was concrete though was a really unique acting performance that started a legendary career. I loved the scene at the end where Ben sets out in a frantic search for Elaine. This tugged at my heartstrings when it became clear Elaine was headed to marry the wrong guy. Ben doesn‚Äôt give us a whole lot of reasons to root for him, but Eliane appears to be the mechanism needed to get his life back on track. Aside from the standout Hoffman performance, Mr. Robinson really stood out as being given some artistic license in his role as the cuckold. Everyone else just stayed within the bounds of their purposefully tailored roles. 
The last 10 minutes of this film was some GOOD movie making. I loved the Hoffman sprint toward the camera on his way to the church. I loved the escape onto the bus and the total lack of dialogue but a clearly communicated understanding of love between Elaine and Ben. The antagonist in this film is clearly Mrs. Robinson and it was fun to have her thwarted.
This movie just oozed cinematic marvels, and you can tell why it‚Äôs a bonafide classic. I‚Äôd love to get some more input on the shots and the lighting. I don‚Äôt quite have the insight necessary to understand all of that, but I loved the low angle shots, the use of shadow and light and would
appreciate learning more about the cinematic creativity and inspiration that went into The Graduate. 
Bottom line, plot gets spicy toward the end and it‚Äôs a heartwarming finish. I had no idea what this movie was about going in and I immediately felt the sexual tensions. I was hoping that wouldn‚Äôt be the direction of the film, but it developed well and concluded beautifully. I almost feel like we live in an age where the shock value needs to be even higher than the stakes outlined in this movie. I also felt that some of Eliane‚Äôs outfits felt way ahead of her time. I think of her walking around Berkeley and her outfit/hair, worn in the 70s, felt like something you‚Äôd see in 2021. Anyway, this is a great film. I am going to knock it a bit just based on personal preference.  I‚Äôd be selective who I recommend and watch this movie with because of the strong sexual themes. This movie manipulates your emotions and that‚Äôs the mark of talented actors and filmmakers. You get the sense of confusion and meaninglessness in the life of The Graduate. I would honestly be down to watch this movie again soon, solid stuff.

As a whole, while this film is not perfect in my eyes I still see it as a great romantic comedy-drama film that deserves all the praise that it gets. Well, let's get right into what we have here. The Graduate tells the story of Ben, a college graduate who's deeply worried about his future. What's more, is that he's torn between a forbidden sexual affair with a woman twice his age who happens to be the mother of the girl he likes. What could go wrong?
Everything about this film is gold. There are plenty of things to consider with who's actually the most reasonable character in the end. Still, I stand much with Ben for the reason that he's more relatable. I gotta tell you what: this isn't your ordinary tale about coming of age. Just as how crazy as the premise states, so as the ending or pretty much the whole story in general.
From a technical standpoint, this one's noticeably way ahead of its time. There's so much to adore in every aspect of this film, with the cinematography and editing being my favorite parts. In addition, it's a very funny film. It has terrific use of music, a great cast all around, and brilliant direction.
With the film's ending in mind, I'm pumped to see myself freed from being dictated of what comes next. I'm specifically aware of the future's unpredictability and the inevitability of things happening. We weren't born to be young forever. Growing up is easily the most inescapable part of the journey.
To sum it all up, The Graduate is a film that came out in the '60s that still holds up very well even up until this day. It's a relevant film and a true classic.

Benjamin Braddock was always going to tailspin. The film never explains exactly why he's so broken at the start, so full of pent-up nervous energy, and so dissociated from life, everything he says and does as anxious as it is mechanically routine; whatever the audience wants to guess is perfectly valid, and this allows for Ben to become a stand-in of sorts. Ben never attempts to improve himself as a person, and he would've imploded regardless of Mrs. Robinson's proposition, because anyone who willingly forefits their future as Ben does is incapable of getting better.
True, there is a pronounced generational divide in the film, but it would be irresponsible to blame the adults for what happens; every misguided piece of advice comes from a genuine intent to see their children succeed, even when it only ends up intensifying and enabling the self-destruction on display. The scuba scene is one of many brilliant scenes that demonstrates this point, combining witty writing with impressively technical playfulness to translate Ben's point-of-view as directly as they possibly could. With every clever edit and subtly artful shot, the film becomes Ben, showing us how he thinks so that we can pass judgement on what he does.
It would be impossible to say I didn't see myself in him, but the further detached from reality Ben got, the more self-aware I became. Ben never chose to get better, instead clinging to his infantile comforts and obsessions, as he destroyed every relationship he had left. The final shot is the killing blow to Ben, the worst case scenario of malaise that he embodies a sincere lesson to learn from. The fact that this film is so bold, nuanced, playful, and blatantly unsubtle in all the right ways is what makes it a masterpiece, but the fact that Ben's story played out as it did meant that it was always going to be worthwhile. The Graduate hasn't aged a day where it matters most, and might even be more prescient in an era where these comforts have never been so accessible as they are now.

With not a single thing in any way flawed or out of place, The Graduate is rich with pitch-perfect performances, interesting characters, meticulous direction from the late great Mike Nichols, clever cinematography and editing, wonderfully dry humor, gripping and hard-hitting drama, and subtle yet powerful social commentary and satire.

I can't stop thinking about their faces on the bus. I'm sitting here, the next day, in the office and I want to shout and cry and run madly off somewhere all at once, but I don't leave my desk and I imagine my expression looks just like theirs.

I'm at a time of my life where The Graduate is painstakingly relatable. In two years I will be done with my bachelor's degree and will eventually move onto graduate school. I didn't plan on taking gap year in between, but now I am thinking I have to due to everything that has happened this year. Dustin Hoffman as Ben captures the awkwardness of being in that transitional period so well, hitting both the comedic moments and the real ones‚Ä¶

Mostly stellar across the board. Hoffman and Bancroft are aces and Nichols does wonders with already strong material, focusing on character dynamics and creating a palpable tension in just about every scene. He sustains discomfort by constantly keeping the protagonist on his toes, and Hoffman plays Benjamin Braddock as a perfect blend of neurotic, timid, and kind of a dick. Bancroft similarly isn't painted in broad strokes; it'd be too easy to make her cruel, or concoct some half-baked justification‚Ä¶

There's a feeling of exhilaration that one gets when watching a very special film for the first time. It's a mix of high expectations being exceeded, marveling at the technical and artistic components, and being truly impacted by the human elements that gives off a feeling that is almost unexplainable. It's an instant indication that you're watching a masterpiece - or at least something very close to it.
The Graduate gave me that experience, and it's been far too long.

I don‚Äôt have the time to write a proper review and I‚Äôm already becoming behind in my film-logging, so I‚Äôll just say this:
This movie has what every other good movie has, but just does it all better than most. It‚Äôs got a meaty, juicy screenplay with a pull-you-in plot, excellent built-in pacing, and contemplative themes about understanding and finding your own purpose when every door has been opened to you, what makes love true, and the breaking-point of lust. Every stage of this film‚Äôs story was equally vacuum-like, sucking me up and shaking me around inside of Ben‚Äôs head, making me feel his jumbled thoughts which all come together by the end like if it were a puzzle that made itself. I love how, at least with my viewing, Ben wasn‚Äôt some perfect, redeemed character by the end, but still a very flawed and very confused boy that has maybe one or two new things figured out than he did at the start. On a technical level, pure brilliance radiates in each scene, from the directing (such tailor-made performances) to the editing (there were some scene transitions like I‚Äôve never seen before, and of course the first time we see Mrs. Robinson unclothed!) to the cinematography (that scuba shot, man). 
What really sells this movie? The correct answer is probably Hoffman, Bancroft, and Katherine Ross, but that‚Äôs not what I‚Äôm gonna say (I just read about all the allegations against Hoffman, what a gross human. He was beginning to become one of my favorite actors, it‚Äôs terrible so many women were treated they way they were by him. It‚Äôs simply disgusting). It‚Äôs the SIMON & GARFUNKEL SOUNDTRACK, MAN!! Obviously this isn‚Äôt some kind of profound take. But I cringed when, less than ten seconds into the movie, ‚ÄúThe Sound of Silence‚Äù started playing. I thought, ‚ÄúDamn, it‚Äôs a shame this soundtrack choice didn‚Äôt hold up.‚Äù But by the end of the movie, when ‚ÄúScarborough Fair‚Äù was playing for its third-time-in-a-row, I couldn‚Äôt believe how effective it was. Like another Hoffman movie, Midnight Cowboy, this movie knew it had something incredibly special with its Simon & Garfunkel soundtrack, and they USED it to its full extent. Hell yeah, I say!

Edit; I lied, this best part is how unexpectedly hilarious this movie is at times, did not expect to laugh as much as I did. I actually don‚Äôt think I expected to laugh at ALL!

An excellent character study, "The Graduate" sees Hoffman's Benjamin go from a shy, over-anxious, inexperienced young man to a manipulative, arrogant, and possessive person. These things he learned from Mrs. Robinson, and thus, by the film's final scene, he truly did become the graduate of her particular schooling. Hoffman and Bancroft are great together, and Ross, Daniels, and Hamilton are all great contributors as well. Nichols and Surtees together create a visual style that feels very advanced for its age, but also very of its time. The famously ambiguous ending is the best shot in a movie of great shots, and really drives home the lengths to which Benjamin will go to get what he wants.

My sixth watch.
I feel like this ended quicker than I was prepared for, I know it beat for beat by now but that last scene just happens so quickly. Not a flaw by any means, it's one of my favorite endings ever and its rapidity is part of why it works, but I feel like I didn't fully register the emotions of those final moments.
That slight complaint about this viewing aside, god, what an incredible movie. The general hilarity and melancholy makes me forget how strikingly emotional specific moments can be. The rack focus from Elaine to Mrs. Robinson standing through the doorway behind her, then back to Elaine, hits like a punch in the gut. And Mrs. Robinson telling Ben her major in college remains one of the most poignant and honest moments I've seen on film.
I feel like, when you're young, you relate to Ben and root for Ben and Elaine because they love each other. And as you get older, you relate more and more to Mrs. Robinson (the resonance with Ben remains but his flaws are clearer). Yet you still root for Ben and Elaine in hopes that they'll shake up and escape the norms they were raised into, despite knowing they definitely don't love each other. Both viewpoints make for such a rewarding experience. Maybe the saddest comedy of all time?
