Benjamin might be the realest, literally me character ever‚Äîan emblematic, unhinged, insanely awkward roller coaster ride of a movie that seemingly ends exactly where it started, just like a roller coaster. Dustin Hoffman delivers a brilliant and outstanding performance, with an atmosphere that, I dare say, could rival even that of Michael Cera (it doesn‚Äôt but it‚Äôs pretty darn close). It's a slow burn for sure, with parts that felt a little dragged, but not to the point of having a major impact on the film itself. In fact, this film makes use of every single scene, each being wonderfully shot, brilliantly performed, and insanely symbolic.
From beginning to end, the film is a poignant analysis of parental authority over young adults, dictating their lives to make them what the parents want them to be, rather than what the child themselves wishes. Adults discuss and plan someone else‚Äôs future without bothering to listen to their concerns. The film also acknowledges that young adults acting impulsively and without the guidance of someone much wiser and (potentially) much older, is a whole other problem (not to say that someone can‚Äôt be wise enough to make their own decisions, but to say that confiding in someone you know to be much wiser than yourself has always been a better option than blindly making a decision that could change the course of your life forever). It's a film filled with insecurity, uncertainty, loneliness, and fear, all of which often being the predecessors to the mistakes many young adults make at that point in their lives.
I would be remiss not to mention the final sequence of the film, one of the coolest, wildest, and most outstanding final sequences I‚Äôve ever seen in a coming-of-age film (or a film in general, for that matter). The final shot is incredibly symbolic and dynamic, bringing the film full circle. A life full of uncertainty and anxiety because of the decisions ones made. ‚ÄúWas it the right decision?‚Äù Who knows, but in the end, it was the decision you made, and you can‚Äôt change that now. So, don‚Äôt dwell on something already set in stone; instead, focus on what you can change‚Äîthe future.

captures post-graduation aimlessness most potently at the start as the camera finds the titular character among his family and social expectations like a deer in the headlights. the way mrs. robinson commands the screen and plays wi-- off a hesitant and shy ben is magnetic. sadly the charm wears off completely once it introduces elaine, as it signals the film kicking into underwritten/stereotypically misogynistic gear. her character is utilized as a prize for the taking, pursued by a suddenly changed ben, who is now a creepy, relentless stalker. it loses all suspension of disbelief in how elaine is robbed of any agency or autonomy in this constellation. made to give into his every whim and desire, despite the explictly stated dislike and distance she's built between them. the scene where she goes to his (!) apartment & tells him about that and it is checked off as if they're talking about a forgotten grocery list item is mindboggling. the wish fulfillment angle is taken to an extreme where it completely buries any semblance of sympathy, let alone aimlessness. not that there were ever signs of pressure due to material conditions. the ending does little to alleviate any aforementioned issues. at least ben got what he wanted, right?

I‚Äôm quite surprised at how weird The Graduate really is, considering how normal it looks on the surface. A coming-of-age comedy starring Dustin Hoffman sounds quite digestible, inoffensive, and straightforward. Turns out it‚Äôs a lot darker and a lot more bizarre than an awkward love triangle. The Graduate questions direction and certainty in the future, more specifically within the titular graduate, and the direction it decides to go in to execute this is chaotic, unhinged, and off-the-rails. It is absurd in a way that presents the film‚Äôs ideas in an emotionally and visually-compelling manner. For its purpose, The Graduate is surprisingly full of depth in terms of its direction, as Nichols‚Äô vision is clearly the standout here even with Hoffman‚Äôs perfectly hesitant performance leading the way. I wasn‚Äôt expecting such deliberate angles, lighting, and symbolism at all, considering that synopsis. The Graduate ends everything with even more uncertainty than ever, providing an open-ended conclusion that at the same time encapsulates everything perfectly without another second on screen needed.

I abosoutely love the fish tank motif throughout The Graduate. Ben is Initially drowning in a sea of indecision (i.e. in a fishbowl). He's finished the first part of his life and going into his next and he's unsure of what he'll become. Rather than confront his problems, he wants to be left alone to sulk. The diving scene reflects this indecision as he keeps trying to come up to breathe, but his parents smile and push him down. They don't give him time to develop, and instead just expect him to jump into the next phase of his life. They are enjoying watching their son in a fishbowl.
Meanwhile, Mrs. Robinson is a woman who is stuck in her own kind of fishbowl: she feels old and unloved. Her affair with Ben is to bring a sexual spark back and remind/make her feel young again. Her confidence is what compels Ben to her in the first place. The scene where Mrs. Robinson throws the keys into the tank disrupts the fish, just like it temporarily disrupts Ben's life.
The affair changes Ben. We see him fumble constantly in the hotel (booking a room, ordering drink, holding door) and is afraid of the light during his first sexual encounter with Mrs. Robinson (he's also on the bottom).
However, after several months (aka 2 montages later), Ben now tries to let light into the room by opening windows and turning on lamps. He is now on top of Mrs. Robinson. Mrs. Robinson then shuts off the lamps. Ben now believes he is confident and wants an actual relationship (not just drifting). Meanwhile, Mrs. Robinson wants to enjoy the moment and is fine if their relationship is still shrouded in darkness.
The period of the actual affair is interesting as the film constantly cuts from moments of Ben at home, to in the pool, to with Mrs. Robinson. This shows that the affair has just become a part of his routine and every day just blends into the next.
Going back to our protagonist, whenever Ben is feeling depressed there are typically two elements present: a fish tank and the song 'The Sound of Silence'. The third time the song is played is at the last scene of the film when Ben and Elaine run away together. For a brief moment it appears that they escaped, but then 'Silence' and indecision begins to creep in once again. There is no actual fish tank present because they are not caught up in a metaphorical one; trapped and unable to communicate with one another.

The Graduate is undoubtedly a classic. It's a gorgeous film to look at. It's avant-garde in its technical execution, as well as some of the themes it presents.
The direction and vision of Mike Nichols are absolutely extraordinary. The way this picture is shot and how it's framed is, of course, legendary. In terms of the technical aspect, it seemed rather ahead of its time. I saw so many great camera shots and angles that I've seen modern directors use and can sort of figure how this movie is influential.
The portrayals of indecisiveness, impulsiveness, obsession, entitlement, and lust also seem like something you didn't often see at the time it came out. I liked the story of the strange love triangle in which Ben (Dustin Hoffman) was caught up with between Mrs. Robinson and her daughter. I don't pretend to know how this was received in 1967, but I have a hunch that such a theme was rather unheard of (at least in American film).
Where this film sort of comes down for me is in its very lead. How can a character so easy to dislike have things go his way rather easily? Ben Braddock is dismissive, antisocial, entitled, and kind of a stalker.
Now, it's not that I don't dig unlikable characters and I don't need to root for all the leads. It's really case-by-case. In this one, I couldn't buy into the fact that Ben made terribly impulsive decisions to cover up how lost he felt about his future. And that they fell in his favor. He should be worried because he keeps shooting himself in the foot in the present. I couldn't find him easy to root for or to relate to.
Hoffman seems to get all the attention, when Anne Bancroft is the absolute life force of this film. Loved her here.
I can see why people say this is a "masterpiece" (in case you're new to my account, it's one of two buzzwords I can't loosely throw around). Its look, along with the great music of Simon & Garfunkel makes for a lovely picture. Mike Nichols did THIS. But, not a masterpiece, in my eyes.
NOTES: Katharine Ross was a dead ringer for Kate Mara. Also: Mr. Feeny is in this.

The Graduate is one of those films that you keep returning to, and every time you do, you find yourself seeing it in a whole new light. When I was sixteen and doing my virginal viewing, I wasn‚Äôt entirely sure of the emotion there, but I realized the professionalism and experimentation of the filmmaking itself. When I watched it again around the age of nineteen, I related to Benjamin Braddock‚Äôs aimlessness in a post-college ‚Äúadult‚Äù world - and empathized deeply with his very naive perception of love and completion among the American ideal. Watching it yet again, at twenty-five, the film became less about Benjamin and more about Mrs. Robinson - and then I realized there was a dual story here that I otherwise brushed over, because I didn‚Äôt quite understand it at that time. Benjamin may, one day, be his own variation of Mrs. Robinson. For all we know, getting the girl at the end means shit. Because it‚Äôs fantasy. It‚Äôs a happily-ever-after trope. And Nichols knew this. Knew to linger. Knew to let the audience know: ‚Äúlife isn‚Äôt like the movies‚Äù. Rightfully iconic as a classic in American cinema, but never really given the credit for being one of the most painful examinations of the American dream.

Strong Performances - Anne Bancroft
In our youths, we hope greatly for our future, we build upon expectations that may or may not be met, and often times we find ourselves stumbling past the point of no return, left with the pathways in front of us either blurred or uninviting, we hope for a silver lining or a revelation that would hopefully lead us to the right path. It is when we reach such a point, where we feel that dreaded angst towards our lives, we become selfish and demanding of ourselves, while simultaneously harmful and drained, many find themselves building the road blocks of a life unfulfilled.
This seems to be the outlook of the future under Ben Braddock‚Äôs eyes, played by the appropriately stoic and awkward Dustin Hoffman, inexperienced in much of life‚Äôs demands, yet positioned with a great sense of pressure of those around him, realising that he is unequipped with the tools that would pave the road ahead. Innocence lies deep within his heart, thus curiously motivated and also swiftly hesitant towards the seduction process of Mrs. Robinson (Anne Bancroft), a close friend of his parents, at least initially. It would be Mrs. Robinson‚Äôs impression left on Ben that would stimulate a slight change in his persona, panic-stricken at first, but soon finding immense comfort in her presence, providing him the experience that for so long, through the pressures of high school and college, have deprived him from.
Mrs. Robinson instils a sense of certainty and direction in his life, revolving a life on a particular schedule that brings forth happiness that was previously lacking. It is a relationship that is symbiotic, with Mrs. Robinson herself finding deep comfort in his presence, removed from the crumbling and disarming insecurities that runs through her, hiding away from the regretful decisions that shaped her present life, to once again touch upon the energy and flesh of youth, transferring back to a time where one can feel permitted to attend to such reckless adventure. A performance that is nothing short of insightful, one that is able to convey the deeper complexities of a woman, bringing forth the symbolic gesture of her presence in the story, yet given enough care to be conveyed as a flawed construction of humanity, she may reveal herself as antagonistic towards the latter course of the film, but through such, that human essence that would be found in the many that suffers from similar crutches remain intact and palpable.
Both were in a relationship that proved immoral but personally healthy, but as like any other element of life, random events and figures enter into our lives, our perspective changes, relationships that were once considered solid began to appear as rubble, new decisions and relationships are formed, thus forcing us to adapt and shift our priorities. What was once again a sense of hesitation and cruelty towards Mrs. Robinson‚Äôs daughter, Elaine (Katharine Ross), became a natural evolution of genuine affection and tenderness, slowly moulding Ben‚Äôs life, earning new pleasures from her company, and began to feel the burden in Mrs. Robinson‚Äôs persistent demands and manipulations.
Much like Ben, Elaine possesses the angst-inducing insecurities that define a sense of vulnerability that is precise of her position in life, and due to the deep focus on the film‚Äôs exploration of Ben‚Äôs experiences, it is doubtful that if it were to place its camera heavily on Elaine that the result would be any different. Elaine and Ben‚Äôs relationship grows in the third act in a recovery process, attempting to make sense of their passions, losing oneself in the heat, unable to reboot their rational functioning. It would have been much easier for Ben to reflect upon his experience and move on with his life, but much like the drive of youth, there is a compulsion to feed one‚Äôs immediate desires, perceiving them as incentives of necessity. It would all lead to the film‚Äôs famous ending, arguably ambiguous in its atmosphere as it finds its two lovers initially enduring through excitement and adrenaline, slowly calming as they begin to analyse the decisions they had made, their faces shifting from optimism to doubt, almost as if presently scaling the benefits and risks of their chosen endeavour; leading us to contemplate, much like the characters themselves, to define whether such a pathway would be a fitting or regretful one.
Of course, The Graduate‚Äôs charms would not have tested upon the challenging nature of time if not for the experimental assembly of Mike Nichols‚Äô construction, creating a film that aims to innovate the incorporated genres, while working through the confines of the Hollywood system, exploring new ways of expression, unafraid to heighten its metaphorical gestures through its mode of editing and cinematography, tightly held together by the achingly somber tunes of Simon and Garfunkel. It demonstrates a remarkable ability to reflect the internal rumblings of its characters, yet also paralleling its method of storytelling with the era of production, the countercultural era that seems to have bled onto the core of its storytelling and characters.
It could have easily conformed to the traditional methods of cinematic craftsmanship, and it could have butchered its story through oversimplification, but instead it defies all expectation, notably of those who viewed it upon theatrical release. It is one that would pave the way of what would be the standard of American cinema, yet throughout the decades, its own charm remain firmly intact, one that would prove further beneficial through subsequent viewings, surpassing beyond the definition of a comfort film, but instead an essential viewing that should be passed along the generations to come.

It's like I was playing some kind of game, but the rules don't make any sense to me. They're being made up by all the wrong people. I mean no one makes them up. They seem to make themselves up.
I think why I like this film so much more over Taxi Driver and why I get more out of it comes in the two ways the films study their characters. From the get-go Taxi Driver has buried itself in Travis‚Äôs brain and spends the remainder of the time attempting to justify and rationalize his actions, obviously sympathizing with him. However, The Graduate takes its time before deciding to sympathize with Ben. His early scenes are incredibly awkward and borderline hard to watch as he aimlessly drifts through various pointless social interactions with people he really doesn‚Äôt know. Our only relief comes with Mrs. Robinson, commanding the scene and giving us something to focus on outside of Ben's extraordinary lack of social skills. 
Once their affair starts though things actually get worse, depending on the type of person you are their first meetup in the room is either drop dead hilarious or borderline unwatchable from second-hand embarrassment (often I find the experience to differ from each viewing, this time was humor). Were still not on board with Ben but we're definitely not on Mrs. Robinson‚Äôs side, as charismatic as she is. Their affair is obviously loveless and only comes out of the mutual boredom each of them feels. Mrs. Robinson is dealing with her picturesque family which is nothing but a front for a loveless marriage. Ben, like Travis at the beginning of both films, has no purpose, though his pushback against the materialistic lifestyle of his parents and their friends is much more subtle then Travis‚Äôs disdain for humanity. 
While we‚Äôre not sure whether or not were supposed to sympathize with Ben, it‚Äôs the arrival of Elaine, much like the introduction of Iris is Taxi Driver, that sets our protagonist towards their final goal. But by this point in the film Ben has started to lose our sympathies while Travis has gained them by the same point, leading two similar characters to two very different outcomes. This isn‚Äôt a slam against Taxi Driver, lord knows I‚Äôve done enough of that, but it's interesting to see how the two films approach their characters journeys. 
So now we're at the second half, each characters goal has been established, Travis wants to really clean up the streets (which he can‚Äôt completely, but freeing Iris will do), and Ben wants to marry Elaine. Each of which finally solidify the theme of their respective film. The Graduate finally shows how hypocritical and empty the adults are while Taxi Driver shows how one man's delusions can go out of hand and there is no rock bottom for our protagonist to hit. I feel that the end of the 2nd/beginning of the 3rd acts are what make or break these respective movies. Ben willingly admits the affair to Elaine and cuts of Mrs. Robinson, choosing to instead pursue the only meaningful relationship he‚Äôs formed thus far. Travis proceeds to lose all good will he gained in the first half, planning random, unmotivated, and puzzling acts of violence and always managing to dodge the consequences. So that, by the time each of their respective climax‚Äôs role around, we genuinely hope that Elaine and Ben can be together while we are simply resigned to Travis‚Äôs murder spree. Leaving us with two very different emotions. 
Now we should talk about the codas that each film provides. Now, I know the death of the author is a pretty popular lens to examine art through but in this case I‚Äôd like to use two interpretations of the endings as provided by their makers. Paul Schrader has said that the ending of Taxi Driver is real and not in Travis‚Äôs head, this leaves us with a sour taste that his violent acts were celebrated by society. In contrast however, The Graduates final shot forces us to really consider the consequences of their actions, they now literally only have each other and no plan going forward, while we got some version of a fairy tale ending those final few seconds call everything into question, which is further exemplified by Nichols explanation as to what happened after the end of the film.
‚ÄúThey became their parents.‚Äù
Maybe you can‚Äôt break the generational cycle of becoming out of touch with those younger than you. Maybe you can‚Äôt make a difference no matter how many people you kill. But the way each of those ideas is presented are what make the Graduate one of my all time favorites and Taxi Driver on of my least.

The Graduate is a haunting movie. It‚Äôs listed as a comedy but I never laughed, but I‚Äôm happy I didn‚Äôt laugh. It‚Äôs perfect at displaying uncertainty and feeling powerless in life. The constant asking of ‚Äúwhat are you gonna do in life‚Äù reminding you more and more that you don‚Äôt know and you don‚Äôt know how to fix that. Benjamin keeps saying he‚Äôs scared about his future and nobody reassures him in any meaningful way. One scene that I never noticed the first time I watched this years ago that I noticed now was at the beginning when Ben‚Äôs mother starts listing off his achievements from college and he runs upstairs and hides in his room. Despite all his achievements and all that he‚Äôs done, it‚Äôs all meaningless. He‚Äôs constantly being approached by people at this party and being told he has his whole life ahead of him. It‚Äôs a celebration for him and yet he doesn‚Äôt want to be there, because why celebrate when nothing meaningful has been accomplished? Is it meaningful? Should he not be worried? Another scene that was great was when he is in the scuba gear and his parents are showing him off like a trophy. And then he gets in the pool, he tries to get out but his parents keep pushing back down, until he accepts it all and just stays down there in the water, they‚Äôre essentially drowning him, metaphorically speaking of course. The beginning is so good at setting up Ben as this uncertain person who just wants to feel like they have a purpose in life and for someone who understands him. Benjamin didn‚Äôt want any of this, he didn‚Äôt deserve any of this. Nobody ever truly listened to him when he was not confident. So once he got confidence, it was unfortunately on something that endangered him and others around him. I don‚Äôt even want to fully root for Benjamin to find Elaine and run away with her because it‚Äôs not a relationship built on trust, it‚Äôs built on spite. But Benjamin is confident and won‚Äôt back down no matter what and he wouldn‚Äôt be this way if someone had truly listened. How could Benjamin have screwed up his life this much when he had everything given to him on a silver platter, one might ask. He didn‚Äôt have it rough, how could someone so privileged throw their life away like that? Well, I understand why, in that, I don‚Äôt understand why. It‚Äôs not simple, sometimes it‚Äôs just a feeling. Like I said, he accomplished so much and felt so little satisfaction. Anyone can feel that way, anyone can feel scared and unsure. And while anyone can get over their fears and find their purpose in life, sometimes, anyone can also lose themselves in their fears and get consumed by them until they‚Äôve lost everything and have nothing to hold onto except whatever delusion they have and keep digging themselves even deeper. 
You know what, fuck it, 10/10 for being such a scarily relatable piece of art. I have my issues but god damn it, this one‚Äôs too special. The acting, the cinematography, the soundtrack, it‚Äôs all amazing and I can‚Äôt help but love it. I need this movie, as a reminder, things will always look uncertain, but it‚Äôs better to make the best of what you can and never let yourself become consumed by your fears.

If you analyze the plot itself, Benjamin Braddock is one of the most despicable protagonists in a movie, period. That it is Dustin Hoffman bringing the level of pathos that a Dustin Hoffman can do definitely makes for an awkward but strangely rewarding experience all the same. There is so much conflict to contend with in regards to this schlub. Does he have a single redeeming quality? I don't know if that is the point here. Hoffman and Bancroft were only six years apart in age but the character is a selfish 21-year-old and I can speak from experience that most 21-year-olds are preoccupied, self-involved jerks so the film isn't inaccurate in its portrayal. The film really rocked my world when I first saw it in early high school. Even as a film buff neophyte I was bowled over by the craft in the editing and camera framing. There's so much artistry in the flow and pacing and the awkward suspense of adultery. No doubt that Paul Simon contributed as much as anyone. The best shot is when Benjamin is about to tell Elaine about the affair and she sees her mother standing in the hallway. When she turns back to camera her face is out of focus and it slowly shifts back to reveal tears in her eyes, beautifully visualizing the revelation coming together for her. It's a powerful moment.

An unconventional love story that unfolds in the latter half of the film. I feel a bit of pressure after seeing all your reviews‚Äîmost rating it between 4.5 and 5. For me, however, it's a 3.5, and here's why‚Äî
The film kicks off with a young man, fresh out of college, overwhelmed and confused about his future. His initial desire for sex as an escape felt realistic, and I appreciated his nervousness during Mrs. Robinson's seduction, as well as his general respect for women. Up to this point, I was set to give it a 3.5, hoping for more depth as the film progressed. Then comes Elaine, the love interest, in the second half.
The narrative suggests he falls for her after just one meeting, and she reciprocates because he pursues her. I'm not questioning their feelings, but the rapid development of their relationship was a hard pill to swallow. Even if I were to overlook that, Benjamin's decision to interrupt her wedding and her acceptance of him post-marriage left me questioning‚Äîif she truly loved him, why did she marry someone else?
I would have appreciated more depth to Elaine's character and a more detailed exploration of their growing affection‚Äîperhaps shown through a progression of events rather than abrupt turns. On the other hand, the soundtracks and sound effects were impressive. And the cinematography, with it‚Äôs shallow and deep focus added a charm to this movie. The film consistently amused me, especially as Ben wrestled with his feelings about his father's partner's wife.
Despite my critiques, I enjoyed the movie. It just needed a bit more development in the romance part to fully win me over.

Living for the expectations and custom of people around you, ping-pong-ing through your whole youth waiting for a sense of reliability to magically fall to your feet, trying so hard to make something that you can truly call your own for once and distance yourself as much as you can from the hellscape that is living a life of checklisting through adulthood. This movie captures the sentiment of so desperately wanting to feel something real in a stage of your life when everything tells you to follow a pre-established path, which inevitably means making some brusque and thoughtless decisions that most certainly will take you through a whole lot harder path with even more anxieties and regrets‚Ä¶ but damn does it feel real for at least a couple of seconds.

"Mrs. Robinson, you're trying to seduce me." - Benjamin Braddock
Can't believe it's taken this long to watch it, but I finally have seen it, and yeah, iz preti gud.
An affair can be a power dynamic. One must give it up to the other because they know they're doing something wrong. It's a tug-of-war of right and wrong and what one party desires over the other. Each side pushes and pulls to get what they want. But they both have something in common: they both want to keep it a secret. They don't want anybody but them to know about it. But things can get complicated. One may want to spill the beans to keep the other trapped or the other might fall in love with somebody else. Who knows? It can only stay hidden for so long before everything goes wrong.
Man, what can I say? Really? Like what can I say that hasn't been said before? The screenplay was easily one of the best I've heard since last month (and I mean, look at what I watched last month. You'll understand why). All of the dialogue and characters felt realized and authentic and there were a number of poignant lines. Oh! And there were consequences! Like I thought this would all be in secret, but no! Actions do have consequences! Wow! It's like that should happen more often in film.
The soundtrack provided by Simon & Garfunkel worked in miraculous ways. Like it actually helped punctuate the intensity near the end when Ben's (Dustin Hoffman) looking for Elaine (Katharine Ross) and every moment the film needed. The cinematography was also astounded me. So many incredibly composed shots. If they're iconic, they more than deserve to be.
The acting was phenomenal here. The whole cast was fantastic, but it really came to Katharine Ross (Elaine Robinson), Anne Bancroft (Mrs. Robinson), and Dustin Hoffman (Benjamin Braddock) who all excelled. Again, as I mentioned previously, it felt like I was watching people interact onscreen and their conversations were so natural.
However, this film had a couple of problems with it. The film felt dated with the way it looked at romance and the stalking is another problem I had with it.
That's it, though! I thought this was really great and I'm happy I finally watched it!
4.5/5

"Goodbye Benjamin."
I was recently told that this movie was intended to be a comedy. If so, it's one of the worst built comedies I've ever seen. It plays into the dramatic so much that when the "comedy" comes, it's unintentionally hilarious.
Because of that, there were aspects of this film that are either too unbelievable or make no narrative sense. Dustin Hoffman and Anne Bancroft are fantastic here. He plays the socially awkward college graduate who comes into his own flawed manhood through an affair, and she plays the seductive older woman driven mad by jealousy.
For much of the runtime, it's a very serious drama with some high stakes and messy situations, then it shifts into a classic romantic comedy that is so far- fetched and ludicrous that you're not sure if you should laugh or be concerned.
Here, the performances sell this movie and it's unintentional comedy is truly a riot. Glad I finally got around to this one.

"THE GRADUATE" has been adapted by Mike Nichols, Buck Henry, and Calder Willingham from a novel of the same title by Charles Webb. I like the move much better than the book, but until I had read the book I had no idea how literally faithful the screenplay was to its source. Charles Webb seems to be the forgotten man in all the publicity even though 80 per cent or more of the dialogue comes right out of the book. I recently listened to some knowledgeable people parceling out writing credit to Nichols, Henry, and Willingham as if Webb had never existed, and as if the quality of a film were predetermined by the quality of its script, and as if the mystique of the director counted for nought. These knowledgeable people should read the Webb novel which reads more like a screenplay than any "novel" since John Steinbeck's "Of Mice and Men."
Webb's book is almost all dialogue with the intermittent straight prose passages functioning as visual tips for the director. That is not to say that Nichols, Henry, and Willingham are not entitled to their credits, but merely that their contributions pertain more to nuance than substance, more to the how than the what.
"The Graduate," more than "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?", is Mike Nichols's diploma as a director. Whereas Nichols merely transferred Albee, he actually transcends Webb. "The Graduate" is a director's picture not because Nichols wrote all the dialogue and acted out all the parts and sang and composed all the songs under the double pseudonym of Simon and Garfunkel and directed the cinematography under the alias of Robert Surtees, et cetera, ad infinitum, ad credit sheetum. "The Graduate" is a director's picture because even its mistakes are the proofs of a personal style.
Style is more an attitude toward things than the things themselves. It can be a raised eyebrow or a nervous smile or a pair of shrugged shoulders. It can even be an averted glance. By playing down some of the more offensive qualities of the book, Nichols expresses his own attitude toward the material. The main trouble with the book is its reduction of the world to the ridiculous scale of an overgrown and outdated Holden Caulfield. The catcher in the rye has been perverted by time and affectation into a pitcher of the wry. Charles Webb's Benjamin Braddock expresses himself with a monosyllabic smugness that becomes maddeningly self-indulgent as the book unravels into slapstick passion. Ben even goes "on the road" for a brief period to demonstrate his beatification at the expense of the beatniks. He is superior to his pathetic parents and adults generally. He is kind to the wife of his father's law partner even though she seduces him with cold-bloodedly calculating carnality. Ben then falls in love with Elaine, his mistress's daughter, and makes her marry him through the sheer persistence of his pursuit.
The screenplay has been improved by a series of little changes and omissions constituting a pattern of discretion and abstraction. The hero is made less bumptious, the predatory wife less calculating, the sensitive daughter less passive. The "on the road" passage is omitted from the movie, and the recurring parental admonitions are reduced in number and intensity. The very end of the movie is apparently the result of an anti-cliche improvisation. In the book Ben interrupts Elaine's wedding (to another) before the troths have been plighted or the plights have been trothed or what have you. In the movie the bride kisses the groom before Ben can disrupt the proceeding, but the bride runs off just the same. And this little change makes all the difference in dramatizing the triumph of people over proceedings. An entire genre of Hollywood movies had been constructed upon the suspenseful chase-to-the-altar proposition that what God hath joined together no studio script writer can put asunder. The minister could turn out to be an impostor, the bridegroom a bigamist, but once the vows were taken, that was the old ballgame. "The Graduate" not only shatters this monogamous mythology; it does so in the name of a truer love.
The emotional elevation of the film is due in no small measure to the extraordinarily engaging performances of Anne Bancroft as the wife-mother-mistress, Dustin Hoffman as the lumbering Lancelot, and Katherine Ross as his fair Elaine. Nichols is at his best in getting new reading out of old lines and thus lightening potential heavy scenes. The director is at his worst when the eclecticism of the visual style gets out of hand. The opening sequence of bobbing, tracking, lurching heads in nightmarishly mobile close-ups looks like a "hommage" to Fellini's "8 1/2." A rain-drenched Anne Bancroft splattered against a starkly white wall evokes images in "La Notte." The languorous lyricism of Ben at Berkeley seems derivative of Varda's "Le Bonheur" and even some of John Korty's landscape work in the same region. Unfortunately, the cultural climate is such that the intelligent prose cinema of Mike Nichols tries to become the intellectual-poetic cinema of Michelangelo Nichols. Still, I was with "The Graduate" all the way because I responded fully to its romantic feelings, and my afterthoughts are even kinder to a movie that, unlike "Morgan," didn't cop out in the name of "sanity." Some people have complained that the Bancroft-Hoffman relationship is more compelling than the subsequent Ross-Hoffman relationship. I don't agree. As Stravinsky once observed, it is easier to be interesting with dissonance than consonance. Similarly, it is easier to be interesting with an unconventional sexual relationship than with a conventional love pairing. "The Graduate" is moving precisely because its hero passes from premature maturity to an innocence regained, an idealism reconfirmed. That he is so much out of his time and place makes him more of an individual and less of a type. Even the overdone caricatures that surround the three principals cannot diminish the cruel beauty of this love story.

The first time I watched The Graduate I honestly found it quite boring and ultimately gave it a 6/10. That was over a year ago and this time thorough I found that I appreciated it a lot more. It's an 8/10 now, though just barely.
Dustin Hoffman rides the line between hilarious and pathetic so well that you'd think the role of Ben Braddock was written especially for him. Paired with Anne Bancroft and Katherine Ross and surrounded by the likes of Murray Hamilton and William Daniels it's a small miracle nobody won an acting award at the Oscars that year. My big takeaway was that nobody came off like they were hamming it up in any of the really awkward sexual scenes. It seems like that's something that could have easily happened and the fact that it never goes in that direction makes these already amazing performances just that much more impressive.
I guess my big problem with the film, and the reason I was so reluctant to give it such drastically higher rating this time around is the general unevenness of the film in both the writing and production. Story wise it touches on both hilarious and depressing themes (much like Hoffman's character) but it never seriously dives feet first to either side. It seems like whenever it comes close to doing so it kind of steers towards the other direction to be safe. Similarly the entire mood of the film, the atmosphere and setting, the camera work and creative shots all come off nearly perfectly but the Simon and Garfunkel score almost ruined all of that. If a particular piece of music just didn't work then that was a best-case scenario because most of the time it left me smirking and scratching my head - something I'm sure Mike Nichols wasn't intending to cause people to do.
For all it's faults though, The Graduate does do one thing perfectly. It's not a safe move, it doesn't ride the line between any two things and it certainly isn't expected. The uncertain looks that Hoffman and Ross exchange on the bus in the closing moments will forever be one of my favorite cinematic moments. Was it all worth it? What comes next? I just find that whole sequence perfectly fitting.

Just for the record, I don't want to know "what comes next" or "was it all worth it". So don't make a sequel, Hollywood.

‚ÄúAre you here for an affair, Sir?‚Äù
A safari with a cougar. Mike Nichols‚Äô most celebrated film is notorious for its resident seductress, played by Anne Bancroft, of which the renowned term ‚Äúmilf‚Äù was perhaps born. However, The Graduate also unmistakably remains a formal masterclass of cinematography, editing and film direction; managing to be both timely in relation to the new age of New Hollywood, and yet timeless in its confrontation of polarising age dynamics and youthful paranoia and unease. So enamoured am I with the aesthetic that Nichols‚Äô created, with thanks to Robert Surtees and Simon & Garfunkel of course, that the only time The Graduate fails to work for me is when such aesthetic begins to fade. The scenes in which Benjamin practically stalks Elaine in and around Berkeley aren‚Äôt exactly entertaining, but Nichols‚Äô use of montage in this regard ensures the sequence isn‚Äôt ever monotonous or dull. And that final scene, impossible to not mention; absurd in style yet exhilarating in action, and those final three shots sum up the entire movie. Melancholic hilarity, mixed with profound malaise.

as someone college-age aimlessly floating through life wanting to wring the necks of anyone who asks what i plan on doing and seeking out transient dopamine even in the most dumb and reckless of places this is The movie i needed to watch right now

That scene, where you see Benjamin underneath the crook of Mrs Robinson' knee and he delivers the classic line "Mrs Robinson, you're trying to seduce me" is justifiably famous but the yin to that scene's yang when Benjamin is finally rejected by her and the camera move separates the two of them should be just as celebrated. It is a masterclass in framing throughout the film as we follow Benjamin, clearly disconnected from his family and society in general and is reeled in by Mrs Robinson, who herself is in a loveless marriage that hangs by a thread. It's a film which rejects the notion of the family unit which was the prevailing way of life in the post-war years. And yet that act is undercut by the final scene as we see Benjamin and Elaine on a bus, seemingly finally finding love but the looks on their faces betray a profound ennui already with that. Here's to you, Mr Nichols.

Coming of Age Week: Watch at least one previously unseen Coming of Age movie that made it into one of these three lists; BFI's 50 Movies to See Before the age of 14, Adam's Top 50 Coming of Age movies, or mine Zapproved Coming of Age movies.
Hmm, ok... This was on my watchlist for a long time now, gaining anticipation by the week. Can't say that it completely met my expectations.
The first part, with the shy graduate Hoffman being seduced by the older woman, friend of his parents, was absolutely brilliant. The chemistry between the two leads was amazing. Also humour was balanced perfectly with the serious tones.
Hoffman is terrific throughout, he is the one that carries this one to the end. I just wish I'd see more of Bancroft in the second part of the film.
Where it went wrong for me is in the romance with Elaine, the daughter of the older woman in question. I didn't buy for one second that Ben fell head over heels for her overnight. And seeing that the complete second part of the story consisted of Ben trying to win back Elaine, it just didn't do anything for me.
*mild spoilers ahead*
When it all seemed to conclude in a happy ending, I actually found myself considering if I shouldn't rate this any lower. Than that last scene in the bus just slightly changed, at least the characters did. Have to say I felt a bit relieved that Nichols didn't go for a sugar coated ending.
All in all, a bit disappointing, but saved by Hoffman and Bancroft.

There‚Äôs something amazing about the 1960‚Äôs classics.  For instance, 1967 gave us both BONNIE AND CLYDE and THE GRADUATE.  The former could have been a typical gangster movie and the latter an exploitive love triangle about a young guy carrying on an affair with a married woman, then falling in love with her daughter.  But, both added multiple layers of subtext to the point that a Viewer could watch them several times and focus on different things each time.
    
THE GRADUATE is particularly fascinating for me.  I first saw it in the mid-1970‚Äôs as part of a film program at college.  People called it a comedy, but ... while I liked it ... I didn‚Äôt find it to be particularly funny.  (Okay, I did laugh at the ‚ÄúPlastics‚Äù line.)  Instead, I saw it as a biting satire, and a lot of that may have had to do with my being about to face the career decisions that so confused the title character.
   
Watching it again today, just over four decades later, I found myself chuckling frequently over the story while ‚Äúgroovin‚Äô on the nostalgia‚Äù of the Simon and Garfunkel film score.  This time, I still could associate with the title character‚Äôs dilemma, but I also honed in on the mature adults, particularly the Robinsons.  There is such bitter sweetness to looking at a young person starting out and reflecting on your own choices at that age.
   
The casting is superb.  No, Dustin Hoffman doesn‚Äôt look anything like the Benjamin Braddock in the book, but he completely nails the character.  He seems to have this surreal rhythm going on in his head that impacts everything from physically how he moves across a room to an unceasing monologue running through his head that he occasionally can no longer restrain.
    
Anne Bancroft as Mrs. Robinson was the villain of the piece when I first saw the film.  Now, it is intriguing to ponder how she has gone from a free-spirit art student to an alcoholic seducer of a young man, and who also has an uncomfortable relationship with her daughter.  There are some expressions on Anne Bancroft‚Äòs face that speak volumes with only the twitch of an eyebrow.
    
Katharine Ross as the daughter, Elaine Robinson, still impresses me as one of the most ‚Äúdrop dead gorgeous‚Äù actresses I‚Äôve ever seen.  When I first saw THE GRADUATE, I didn‚Äôt think that her character was particularly well-written because she made major life changing decisions with little thought.  Of course, now I see the brilliance of portraying the uncertainty and trying to balance logic against emotions.  She is terrific.
   
Murray Hamilton, the mayor from JAWS, plays Mr. Robinson.  Again, from my current age perspective, I can immediately pick up on the image his character wants to create, and the confused lack of understanding regarding the course his life has taken when he has ‚Äúdone everything right.‚Äù  It is a very understated and effective portrayal.
   
Although Buck Henry shares Screenwriter credit with Calder Willingham, the production team for years has said that it is Henry‚Äôs script that was used.  (A feature on the Criterion disc points out that Willingham‚Äôs version was dark and overtly sexual.)  The Director, Mike Nichols, uses it to great advantage as he infuses his Vision into the words, choosing imagery that is interesting to watch on its own.
    
Best of all, I am incredibly impressed by the ending.  Just watch the range of emotions on the faces.  It is the perfect set-up for an extensive after-showing pizza party discussion!
   
Although I have always liked THE GRADUATE, the movie has significantly grown in stature for me as I‚Äôve matured.  It is a wonderful film.

‚ÄúMrs Robinson you‚Äôre trying to seduce me...aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù
The Graduate is a timeless story that reflects the coming-of-age experience, capturing the journey, fears and rejections of inevitable adulthood.
The film centres on Benjamin Braddock, a fresh graduate who returns home into the open arms of his parents and family friends, all who await his future to be promising. For Benjamin, his future is obscured by his dwellings on adulthood and his ambitions are seemingly diminished. While his true feelings are invisible to those around him, only Mrs Robinson, his family‚Äôs neighbour and longtime friend, comforts him and seduces him. Though he rejects her ‚Äúdesirable‚Äù advances at first, Benjamin begins an intimate affair with Mrs Robinson, where his troubles disappear as he take in the new life that awaits him. Tensions begin as he is peer-pressured into taking out her daughter, Elaine, who Mrs Robinson permits Benjamin before he begins to fall for her.
The dwelling anxieties of Benjamin conflict him further as his steps into maturity lead him on a promiscuous journey to adulthood.
Benjamin‚Äôs story is one I believe we can all empathise with as a viewer, or perhaps a fly on the wall, as his destiny is decided for him by his surrounding predecessors and succumbs to this dwelling pressure and doubt.
At one point or another in our lives, I think we can all relate to Benjamin‚Äôs character, as his journey into a new, frightening chapter of his life is one that is undeniably real. We watch films for the purpose of escape; to dive deep into a heightened reality that plays with imagination. But this is a film which echoes that time that each one of us will inevitably have or will look back to experience, for the purpose of better understanding ourselves.
Mike Nichols‚Äô film is a perfect visual adaptation of the 1963 novel of the same name, capturing the uncertainties and pressures of Benjamin through its immersive cinematography and extremely visual storytelling. The film itself exists in a sea of imagery and symbolism that makes The Graduate the impressive and appealing story that has aged rather well overtime.
The motifs of water and darkness paint the alienation and pressurising positions Benjamin is forced into, and whether he rises above or is drowning under water Benjamin‚Äôs character continues to be stranded in a sea of uncertainty and depression.
Dustin Hoffman‚Äôs role as the bumbling, anxious graduate Benjamin is remarkably convincing. His portrayal adequately expresses the unfulfilling nature of the unambitious young adult, despite Hoffman being well into his 30‚Äôs and only 6 years younger than Anne Bancroft (Despite Mrs Robinson‚Äôs character is doubled Benjamin‚Äôs age). As Mrs Robinson, Bancroft brings the predatory, desirable and lost mother to life through a strong performance, effortlessly adding depth to her yearning character.
The film‚Äôs score is a fitting companion for the story, as the soothing tones of Simon and Garfunkel reflect the sorrows, brief ups and downs of the troubled Benjamin.
The moment that really jumps out from the screen for me is Benjamin‚Äôs reading of Eliane‚Äôs letter:
‚ÄúI love you but I don‚Äôt think it could ever work out‚Äù

I find this to be a pivotal point in the film, which can be interpreted as a premonition as well as foreshadowing the film‚Äôs closing moment. The clandestine nature between Benjamin and Mrs Robinson provided comfort to the two and they both needed each other as much as the other realises, as both characters found their affair as an escape from their mundane lives. But this escape leaves them just as uncertain as the lives they cannot bare to endure.
From here, the rocky relationship later steaming between Benjamin and Elaine becomes tense and unpromising. In the ending we see Benjamin blinded by his emotions, once more showing that what lies ahead of him is uncertain, as he dramatically interrupts Elaine‚Äôs wedding and ‚Äòrescues‚Äô her from a sealed fate. The elope on the bus is short lived, and makes one of the most hard-hitting, melancholic endings I‚Äôve ever seen. The image of the pair‚Äôs realisation, expressions of ecstasy turning to uncertainty, is indeed bittersweet. We don‚Äôt see what their fate is and are only left to the imagination, but I think keeping Elaine‚Äôs departing words in mind are echoed in that iconic frame.
The Graduate is gripping, charming and intimate all at once. Its relatable story of alienation and ambigous self-discovery darts from cringe-worthy moments to scenes which deeply resonate with its audience in a manner of emotions. The film itself is as much a journey as well as Benjamin‚Äôs own, exploring the trepidation of early adulthood through comedic, dramatic, gratifying and sombre moments. It has left a long-lasting impact as an adored classic that stands the test of time, and one that will forever change the way you listen to ‚ÄúMrs Robinson‚Äù forever, either for better or worse.

Mrs. Robinson, you‚Äôre trying to seduce me. Aren‚Äôt you?
Back in January, when I watched my second viewing of Rain Man, this time with my parents, my mother asked ‚Äúdo I know that guy?‚Äù. I had recognized Hoffman from Rain Man and Meyerowitz Stories, but I also remembered scrolling past a movie called ‚ÄúThe Graduate‚Äù that used to be on Netflix, with a younger Dustin Hoffman, but the frame they displayed featured a seductive leg so I figured it was more of a perverted film.
Back to my mother‚Äôs question: ‚Äúdo I know that guy?‚Äù I responded, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think you‚Äôd have seen him anywhere‚Äù. My father says, ‚Äúhe was in The Graduate‚Äù. I nod, ‚Äúoh y‚Äî‚Äú then both my father and I look at each other with a ü§® look, silently asking each other how we know of the film.
Fast forward to last month, I was finally able to buy it physically‚Äî during the Criterion Collection sale‚Äî primarily off my friend Saif‚Äôs recommendation.
I‚Äôd be lying if I said I didn‚Äôt have high expectations coming into the film (which I know is dangerous, forgive me), but it absolutely delivered. It‚Äôs performances, it‚Äôs story, it‚Äôs soundtrack, and especially it‚Äôs camerawork, it‚Äôs all so admirable. It wasn‚Äôt what I expected it to be, and I‚Äôm glad.
Benjamin Braddock and his moments of weakness, his mental descent, his inconsistent and contradictory feelings, half of me says ‚Äúit may not be that realistic of a story‚Äù and then the other half of me says ‚Äúif Mrs. Kojo was next to me right now... man... oh man...‚Äù, so yeah, it‚Äôs beautifully told and displays emotions I don‚Äôt feel are captured often.
There‚Äôre specific scenes that have stayed in my mind since the film has ended, but it‚Äôd be criminal of me to give anything away, more than I already have.
After all, the final frame of the film had already been shared quite a lot (like, what‚Äôs your gain out of sharing final frames of movies? I‚Äôm 53 years late... ok? That gives you the right to share any single scene and frame? OK), but I tried my best‚Äî my very best‚Äî to not let it take away from the experience.
I graduated high school in June, a day after my 17th birthday. The feeling of being lost, unsure of what the next step is, doubting I‚Äôll ever build the courage to take a ‚Äúnext step‚Äù, it‚Äôd be shameful of me to say I understand anything I don‚Äôt, but I think I do understand this level of unsureness.
Whatever may happen, I don‚Äôt think Mrs. Kojo‚Äôs coming back into my life since my 5th grade culmination anyways.

This was far harder to interpret than I thought it'd be. Looked like a pretty innocent classic rom com or something, but it tosses some serious ideas around amidst an ahead of its time (only sporadically dated) sense of humor.
It's easy to just go with the flow and be all "oh the bad boy main character gets the girl how sweet". The first quarter of the movie was a little slow, but then it started to pick up and I really started to like it. I identified with the aimlessness of Ben, and his fear of the future. By the end, when he's running all over trying to get himself out of this mess, I was there with him. I empathized with his melancholy (portrayed mostly through silent sequences with only Simon and Garfunkel music playing) and his search for somebody. At the same time, I also didn't really see the build up in his relationship with Elaine. It was there a little, but I couldn't tell if it was intentionally missing something or not.
It was.
He gets to the Church, beats her father, and runs with her off onto a bus. The iconic second to last shot plays out, and I was expecting it to be overwhelming with emotion... and it kind of was, but questionable sadness rather than joy. They barely know each other. But it's all they both have. The ending could wrap up the entire theme of not knowing what your future is going to be like. Perhaps that's why their relationship lacked development, it thematically relied on them taking a chance, and whether it pans out or not is for them to find out, not us. I actually really liked how this turned out.
Some technical issues, mainly the editing was inconsistent, and the audio editing flat out sucked.
But overall I really liked The Graduate.

It‚Äôs clever that as much as this is about Benjamin, it‚Äôs about Mrs. Robinson too, the two are basically living separate versions of the same life at different points. 60s college aged kids loved the film since they considered it a satire of everything their parents had stood for and there was finally a film from their point of view about breaking free of the shackles, arriving in cinemas right at the same time the public opinion on the vietnam war was changing. Yet for all the anti-establishment themes the film ostensibly hangs its hat on in the second half, the film is almost seen through Mrs. Robinson‚Äôs eyes, watching as Benjamin and Elaine head down a similar path that led her to becoming the dissatisfied, broken woman that Benjamin only truly gets a glimpse of during that prolonged scene in bed where he insists on having a conversation before sex. Yet despite getting Mrs. Robinson to open up and expose her wounds, he gets offended when she says she doesn‚Äôt want him dating her daughter. He misses the meat of the story, only reacting to what he sees as another oppressive adult. Mrs. Robinson laments the mistakes of the past, resents marrying her husband because he got her pregnant, and doesn‚Äôt want Elaine to make the same mistakes. Yet Benjamin becomes infatuated by the same idealist version of romance his parents fawned over, hence the endless repeating of Scarborough Fair; the same tune playing over and over, the mistakes of the past destined to be made again and again. Mrs. Robinson is the embodiment of what happens after the cut to black at the happy ending of most films, the apex of the final moment of this film when Ben and Elaine‚Äôs fervour dwindles and they have to actually live out the rest of their lives. As Mike Nichols told the kids back in the 60s who asked what happened to Ben and Elaine after the credits rolled: ‚Äúthey become their parents."

Benjam√≠n termina la universidad y vuelve a casa de sus padres durante las vacaciones. All√≠ no puede evitar sentirse atra√≠do por la Sra. Robinson, una bella mujer de mediana edad, amiga de sus padres.
Wow, realmente pens√© que me iba a decepcionar esta pel√≠cula, pero me equivoque. Esto es una joya del cine americano que amerita muchas referencias a la cultura popular, desde los simpsons hasta Friends entre otros casos. Dustin Hoffman y Katharine Ross saltaron a la fama gracias a esta pel√≠cula y debo decir que merec√≠an el Oscar.

Benjamin finishes college and returns to his parents' house during the holidays. There he can't help but be attracted to Mrs. Robinson, a beautiful middle-aged woman, a friend of his parents.
Wow, I really thought I was going to be disappointed by this movie, but I was wrong. This is a jewel of American cinema that deserves many references to popular culture, from the simpsons to Friends among other cases. Its direction, production or even the Script is impeccable and it is not surprising since it was thanks to the incredible talent of Mike Nichols, Joseph E. Levin & Charles Webb.
Dustin Hoffman and Katharine Ross rose to fame thanks to this film and I must say they deserved the Oscar.
Especially that ending gave me so much laughter that the only thing I could think of was the mythical episode of the Simpsons where Abe ends up madly in love with Marge's mother, a great classic of the 60s that aged like a wine aged with bull's blood.
I definitely recommend it, it is a classic of American cinema and world cinema, sooner or later you should see it, it is fabulous in the Anglo-Saxon sense of the word.

Hollywood has recreated the same love triangle movie over and over again. The Graduate though, is the best one. It tackles subjects that are always left out and not a single filmmaker today would ever take an angle like the one in here. It's silly, emotional but most of all, real.

Technically, this film is amazing! It has such a distinct visual style that had me completely floored. I expected this film to be quite traditional, despite the 'weird' plot, however I was so wrong!  
It's very funny in places, yet quite depressing and extremely awkward in others. But anchored by great performances from Hoffman, Bancroft and Ross alike, it certainly is deserving of the well established place that it has cemented for itself in cinema today.

"Mrs Robinson, you're trying to seduce me."
Wow, I can't believe I hadn't seen The Graduate until now.
What a brilliant film, with one of the best soundtracks I've heard (gotta love Simon and Garfunkel) and excellent editing (those cuts with the pool and hotel room scenes were phenomenal). Hoffman is absolutely wonderful as Benjamin Braddock, perfectly portraying the nervousness and anxiety his character feels. Benjamin is a character I hugely related to, I definitely felt for him in those scenes where he's feeling apprehensive about his future, it's a feeling I get everyday to be honest and Hoffman conveyed in such a sincere manner. I have to see more of his films! The great cinematography also really took me by surprise, but the thing I was definitely most pleased with was the amazing social commentary and how its perfectly intertwined into the film. There were also some terrific comedic moments here and there that work really well and make us sympathise even more with Benjamin.
The Graduate has aged beautifully in my opinion and is a timeless coming-of-age story.

Although The Graduate was nominated for multiple Academy Awards, and resulted in a best director win for Mike Nichols I wasn't very excited to see it. I've put it off for years, and I really only watched it now because I'm trying to get caught up on some of the classics I haven't seen. I've just always felt it wouldn't be my type of thing. Now that I've seen it I kinda still feel that way, but that doesn't mean it's not a solid coming of age comedy. I went in thinking it would be one of those "classics" I wouldn't like, but I ended up enjoying it quite a bit.
After recently graduating college Benjamin Braddock (Dustin Hoffman) finds himself at a party in his honor. Everyone is excited for him and his future, but the problem is he's really concerned about it. He just doesn't know what he wants to do. At this same party is Mrs. Robinson (Anne Bancroft). The wife of his father's business partner. Mrs. Robinson finds Benjamin in a room by himself trying to avoid the party guests and asks him for a ride home. After taking her home and reluctantly being invited inside, it becomes obvious Mrs. Robinson is trying to seduce him. Benjamin initially resists, but eventually ends up having an affair with her. It's their secret, but when Benjamin goes on a date with Mrs. Robinson's daughter at the insistence of his parents and Mr. Robinson, Benjamin falls for her and things get really complicated.
The Graduate is a funny, enjoyable film with quite the reputation. Multiple Oscar nominations and a win for best director. This is where I run into a bit of an issue. It's a good film, but one I don't think is as good as it's reputation suggests. Maybe in the year it was released it was one of the best films I don't know, but I don't think it would get nominated at all in a lot of years. I gotta consider the time it was released I know that, but it's simply a case where I felt sure it's good but not that good. I enjoyed Hoffman's performance, it was funny as advertised, and the story is pretty good. I actually really liked it, but best picture nominee, best actor nominee, best actress nominee? I don't know about all of that. I guess I'd have to see the competition. To me it felt like one of those feel good movies that gets a nomination for best comedy or musical at the Golden Globes (which it won). That makes sense to me.
It's strange, because while I take issue with the awards it was nominated for I didn't dislike it in anyway...well maybe in one way more on that in a bit. Maybe it's because while it was silly and fun I didn't take it seriously enough to think of it as an "Oscar" film. I saw it as just a good movie. One I probably won't re-watch anytime soon, but one that is well worth seeing.
The only thing I really disliked was the score. It's comprised of songs written by Paul Simon and performed by Simon and Garfunkel. I don't have anything against them, (not my type of music) but it was basically the same song over and over again which got old in my opinion. It didn't help that the main song has been used in what seems like a million films. It wasn't a big deal and it didn't ruin the film or anything, I just didn't personally care for it.
Overall The Graduate is a really good film. Had it not been nominated for all the awards I'd probably appreciate it a little more. Sometimes knowing a film is held in such high regard especially an older film can both help and hurt it. Here it hurt it just a little in my opinion. Factoring that in with the fact it's not necessarily my type of thing, I found it satisfying but a little underwhelming. However I would recommend it to just about everyone.

a most excellent metaphor for the aimlessness and futile absurdity of existence is the image of a sad young man, fully dressed in scuba gear, slouching despondently at the bottom of a suburban swimming pool during a party he never wanted to attend --- Lord Slaw, an observation while viewing The Graduate (1967)
Benjamin is unsure about his future.
Benjamin, as portrayed by Dustin Hoffman, is a complex character, an aggravating and frustrating character, an enraging character. Hoffman's performance is the biggest reason I'm giving The Graduate (this was my second-ever watch of the iconic film) a full five-star rating. To portray someone so relentlessly irritating, yet have them be compellingly, engagingly watchable, that's a remarkable feat.
Benjamin is a recent college graduate. Coming back home for a graduation party, he is beset by the advice and relentless questioning of his parents and their circle of friends. This scene is filmed in closeup, everybody close to the screen, close to Benjamin, which provides a great sense of unease and discomfort. This early scene is one of the only times I sympathized and empathized with Hoffman's character. Too many people, too close, for too long can be a bit much.
Aimless about his future, Benjamin has an affair with Mrs. Robinson, who is coolly, commandingly, enticingly portrayed by Anne Bancroft. The scenes between her and Hoffman are fantastic: she worldly and in control, he twitchy, sweaty, ill at ease. And I also really enjoyed the scenes between Hoffman and Murray Hamilton, who played Mr. Robinson. Those scenes, both pre- and post-affair discovery, were deeply uncomfortable, Mr. Robinson being a casually domineering presence.
The characters in The Graduate are complex, well-acted, engaging personalities. Their motivations are not necessarily overt, but can be teased out, supposed, from between the lines (or between the sheets). For example, Mrs. Robinson's motivations for initiating the affair, for continuing it after Benjamin calls her "disgusting," and for forbidding him from ever dating her daughter, are not expounded in a thesis statement, but one gets the sense that they may be related to her feeling a sense of entrapment, of loss of relevance. I'm sure multiple other readings are equally valid.
The one character who's motivations I can't quite tease out is Elaine, the Robinson's daughter portrayed by Katharine Ross. Her performance is excellent (all of the performances in The Graduate are excellent). But why Elaine makes the decisions she does, I don't know. I think it's because, like Benjamin she feels pressured and put-upon to make up her mind and decide upon, at a too-young age, her future. On that final-shot bus ride, Elaine and Benjamin's faces are happy. But the shot lingers and the smiles fade a bit. They've escaped, but it looks like they've started thinking about what they're escaping into.
Also loved co-writer Buck Henry as a hotel clerk, and Norman Fell as a landlord who isn't putting up with any weirdos in his boarding house. Marion Lorne and Alice Ghostley, both of whom had recurring roles on TV's Bewitched, have small roles as well.
The Graduate most assuredly deserves its iconic status in film history and lore. It's rich and deep and as rewarding as a good novel.

Encore Screening:  if it‚Äôs true that high tide raises all the boats, then Director Mike Nichols 1967 film ‚ÄúThe Graduate‚Äù is cinematic proof.
     The film, despite being a difficult project to get to the marketplace, still found a benevolent financier and the resulting effort saw it become the highest grossing film for that year with seven Oscar nominations to its credit.
     Not only did the movie going public benefit with a film that took our minds off the ongoing war in Vietnam, theaters lucky or willing to book it saw their fortunes increase with sold out showings, long lines snaking around blocks of viewers waiting to buy tickets and a film that single handedly saved Embassy Pictures from going under.
     Every studio passing on the project thereby road blocking funding until Joseph E. Levine stepped in to green light it.  Director Nichols the only choice Levine would accept to helm the project.  Nichols casting unknown Dustin Hoffman in the lead actor role working with legendary Oscar winner Anne Bancroft and actress Katherine Ross entering the stratosphere of screen recognition.
     The soundtrack turned down by rising folk artist Janis Ian then developed in a backwards way by plugging in some of the catalogue from folk team Simon And Garfunkel.  Simon encouraged to write new songs for it but too busy touring to do so.  Guess what?  Their music fit the story like a glove and gave their recordings an entirely new level of appreciation.
     Appealing to both the college bound audience as well as the country club set. ‚ÄúThe Graduate‚Äù crossed over and cut through a number of audience demographics.
     The story co-written by Buck Henry, would see him work further with Mike Nichols and Nichols himself would gain respect and notoriety in certain circles with his future films with Avco Embassy.  The company having been purchased by Avco Corp. would see it become a mini major.
     Like the story of ‚ÄúThe Graduate‚Äù or not, you really had to be there when it happened.  The film was nearly a movement.  A crusade for young people not wanting to follow in their parents footsteps and an eye opener for the martini set.
     Hoffman, so perfectly and expressively honest.  Bancroft in stark contrast to her Annie Sullivan role in ‚ÄúThe Miracle Worker‚Äù and Katherine Ross radiantly beautiful as Elaine would go on to steal the hearts of every young man who had dreams of finding the perfect girl.  
     I loved seeing ‚ÄúThe Graduate‚Äù repeatedly at the 1500 seat Colony Theater in Toledo, Ohio with sold out audiences.  I lost count as to how many times I was in attendance.  Later seeing Simon And Garfunkel in concert and hearing them perform the music from the film.  
     The future, though scary at that time, seemed possible for once.
