Works as a really good companion piece to High School Musical 3, as both explore transitory periods between youth and adulthood manifesting in confusion and angst due to a lack of preparedness for "the next step". There are obviously quite a few points of divergence, notably the overall tone -- this opts for a darkly comedic, and almost constantly awkward tone, while High School Musical 3 leans into an overwhelmingly optimistic exuberance, while still integrating the angst of indeterminacy throughout. That is my main problem with this film -- it goes so heavy on the awkwardness in some scenes that it loses its sincerity(primarily the first hotel scene and the club scene), but this is still very successful overall. Hoffman puts in great work here, and fully sells himself as someone entirely confused and unsure of where he's going, despite his obvious intelligence. He's able to sell some scenes that wouldn't work otherwise(though some are just Too Much, like the ones I previously mentioned), and tie together the emotionality of the film. Probably my favorite component of this film are the accents that are so often employed; it always adds color to each scene that elaborates on Ben's circumstances and emotions -- the Scotch motif particularly strikes me as furthering the idea that all the adults in Ben's life see him as an object rather than a human, and never actually pay attention to his thoughts and feelings. The overall feelings of angst and confusion are all sold very well, and the ridiculous optimism makes it a lovely film as a whole(I suppose this is another point of divergence from the initial comparison as this opts for an absolutely absurd ending, where High School Musical 3 sticks to a more realistic(albeit heightened) ending). All I'm trying to say is that the hype is justified, and I really liked this film.

A rather accurate representation of what being in your 20's is like. Chasing things that are really nothings in order to feel something, that's all there is to it. Having passed my last exam just the other day, everyone's been asking me what are my plans for the future. I don't know. Same as Ben.
Despite that little personal anecdote, I watched this mainly because I've been listening to quite a lot of Simon And Garfunkel lately, even put their CD on during lunch and thought to myself how this film has them on the soundtrack and now I'm here.
It's interesting, I was familiar with the premise, but never knew how it resolves itself. I can say that I'm rather happy that I finally watched it and that I rather enjoyed myself.

Today was my first time watching The Graduate - ridiculous, I know. I watched it at the cinema after a lecture on New Hollywood. My professor couldn't believe I hadn't seen it before. After watching it though, I'm glad I hadn't seen it before today. Not because it was bad, not at all, I absolutely adored it. But because I feel that this film couldn't have come to me at a better time.
As I mentioned, The Graduate was part of a lecture. My first lecture of second year, in fact. The first lecture since returning to university after a summer of pondering whether university was right for me. After tears and panic attacks over moving away from home again. After months of questioning what I was doing, what I was going to do in the future, why I was bothering with anything. After a few weeks of refusing to pack my things and move into the new flat. I watched The Graduate just a few hours after I had snoozed my 7am alarm, cried on the phone to my mum, yelled that I didn't want to be at uni, trudged to the cinema in the rain, and sat alone in the low light making notes about the emergence of New Hollywood and wondering if it was all worth it.
Ben Braddock is drifting. He's confused, hopeless, detached from reality, and finds himself worrying - all the damn time. He's graduated after a series of impeccable achievements at college and now has no real idea what he wants. Post-graduate school? A job? A family? An affair? A pool float and a beer? In an almost constant state of existential crisis, Ben seeks comfort in the arms of other emotionally vulnerable, lonely people. The Graduate is a heartbreaking romantic comedy and a disturbingly relatable commentary on the inner turmoil of disconnected youth. Dustin Hoffman executes a near perfect performance of a young man longing to achieve stability, lose his innocence, seek excitement, and find answers to all his existential questions which play on his mind day after day. The music, of course, is phenomenal and accompanies scenes in this film which are so unique and so perfect it's almost unbelievable. What a privilege it was to be able to watch this film on the big screen.
I'm sitting in my flat now, with my laptop, reflecting on The Graduate. All my flatmates are out at lectures and the melancholy that comes with this film has really set in. Forgive me for being self-indulgent but The Graduate has made me feel some type of way which I haven't allowed myself to feel for some time now.

I rarely rewatch films I don't care for, largely because I rarely rewatch films in general. A movie has to be special or captivating to reel me in for multiple viewings. I usually have the mindset that there are so many films I want to see, I have to constantly tread new ground in order to hopefully see them all. On occasion, however, especially if a film is well-loved, I'll give it another try and attempt to see anything I may have missed. Seldom have I been as rewarded by such a rewatch as I was with Mike Nichols 1967 film, The Graduate. Following the point in time in a young man's life that if often aimless, that time immediately following college graduation, Nichols does an exceptional job at conveying the listlessness of spirit once ones expected education level is completed. Caught between deciding between marriage and graduate school while his parent's expectations pressure him, Benjamin finds avoiding the decision as long as possible to be the option he is most content with. Starring Dustin Hoffman, in a breakout role, and the incomparable Anne Bancroft, The Graduate is a thoughtful look at the expectations of others and the soul-searching one has to contend with throughout their lives.
Just home from college after his recent graduation, Benjamin Braddock (Dustin Hoffman) is ready to relax after finishing his studies and fill his days by his parent's pool. With no romantic interests or jobs waiting for him, his father pushes him to go to graduate school, and his mother encourages him to go on more dates. Benjamin comes from an upscale neighborhood, and the parents of his friends, all of whom expect him to further his education, wait to hear of a graduate school announcement, all of them except Mrs. Robinson. A friend of his parents, Mrs. Robinson is a beautiful and lonely woman who has a daughter near Benjamin's age. That doesn't stop her from propositioning him and prompting him to "sow one's wild oats" while he still has the chance. Surprised and startled by her suggestion, the inexperienced Benjamin attempts to avoid the Robinson's all together before eventually giving in to carrying on a tryst with the family's matriarch. Despite the situation remaining strenuous for Benjamin, as he feels bad for keeping something of this magnitude from his parents, the two carry on both seeming to be fulfilled in some way by the other. As time wears on, and Benjamin seems to be no closer to starting graduate school or getting married, his parents set him up with none other than the Robinson's daughter. This clearly throws a wrench into the lives of both Benjamin and Mrs. Robinson, leaving the former no other choice but to begin making some decisions about his life.
Perhaps, part of the reason that I didn't initially like The Graduate when I first watched it, is because I don't care for Dustin Hoffman. I can almost never get beyond him to enjoy the characters he creates. Interestingly, Hoffman was initially going to pass on an audition for the film because he was already committed to playing Leo Bloom in the Mel Brooks production, The Producers. So certain that he wouldn't be selected in the role as the suitor of his wife, Anne Bancroft, Mel Brooks released Dustin Hoffman to audition for The Graduate. As much as I may have enjoyed this more the first time with someone besides Hoffman in the lead role, I'm of course thrilled that this paved the way for Gene Wilder's first strong screen role in THe Producers. I appreciated Hoffman's performance much more this time around, as he seemed to embody the character of someone uncomfortably trying to make their way through life, seemingly unsure of anything.
The Graduate begins where Say Anything...ends. Cameron Crowe's excellent directorial debut features a high school senior unsure of what direction to take his life after graduation. The Graduate begins with a long take on a young man with no direction who has just finished college, as he took the route that was expected of him. In my mind, a cinematic universe exists where Lloyd Dobler and Benjamin Braddock are the same person, endlessly wandering through life aimlessly. I anxiously anticipate a post-marriage sequel, perhaps dealing with the pitfalls of a dead-end job or unfulfilling career, I'm flexible. The soundtrack of Graduate is sensational, made up of Simon & Garfunkel songs, perfectly accompanying the mood of Benjamin Braddock. The film was also shot in a powerful way, with Benjamin's face, and the faces of those he communicates with, often obstructed excellently symbolizing the many things that hinder his life and complicate his decision-making.
The character introduction of Mrs. Robinson is beautifully communicated thanks to Anne Bancroft. Embodying the perfect balance of unattainable eminence and fragile regret, Bancroft perfectly exposes both aspects of her character. Making herself at home in Benjamin's room where he retreated to for a moment of quiet introspection, Mrs. Robinson shows her strength and control over the situation. It is instantly clear to see that she knows exactly how her relationship with Benjamin is going to play out. She seems to feed off of his discomfort, never being setback by his initial refusal of her advances. Mrs. Robinson's character is fully fleshed out. She is disappointed in herself for giving up everything she wanted in exchange for the chains of matrimony and motherhood. Benjamin isn't the only one searching for something in life. Mrs. Robionson, who finds her motherly duties nearly complete as her daughter prepares to attend college, and her duties as a wife often ignored by her husband who seems to always be inexplicably absent from their residence. Her character, in conjunction with Benjamin's, goes to show that, as human beings, we are always searching for something just beyond our grasp, and no amount of seeming contentment ever really puts an end to that search.

It‚Äôs probably not a stretch to suggest that most people feel a bit disoriented and aimless after college. Sure, some folks have their whole lives mapped out from graduation to retirement, if not their funeral already. But leaving behind the campus of your university, a quasi-Utopia disconnected from the real world that allows you to figure out who you are in a microcosm behind closed doors, is intimidating. Up to that point, Benjamin Braddock, withdrawn, sullen and clueless, is a relatable protagonist. As we see in the opening, he is nothing but a pedestrian on the slowly moving walkway of life. He has no idea where he is headed and certainly isn‚Äôt eager to pick a direction himself. Covering the film‚Äôs gorgeous symbolism could fill an entire academic paper, but this sequence, accompanied by Simon & Garfunkel‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Sound of Silence‚Äù stuck with me as a beautifully poetic encapsulation of what ‚ÄúThe Graduate‚Äù is all about. 
It‚Äôs probably also not a stretch to suggest that very few recent college graduates find a release for their bottled up frustration by starting an affair with the middle-aged wife of their father‚Äôs business partner. Benjamin‚Äôs panicky accusation: ‚ÄúMrs. Robinson, you‚Äôre trying to seduce me‚Äù, complemented by a perfect camera shot through said lady‚Äôs alluringly positioned legs has become shorthand for the absurdity of this premise, and even though this is one of the most universally agreed upon American classics of the late 60s, I was skeptical it would translate well into 2019. It doesn‚Äôt. But damn is it still hilarious! There is so much wrong with everything that transpires here that you can‚Äôt help but laugh at it. Mike Nichols, who won a well-deserved Oscar for his directing here, makes choices in every scene that overdramatize the situations and dial up the awkwardness and second embarrassment even further than what is already achieved by his actors. 
Anne Bancroft, only seven years Hoffman‚Äôs senior, but carrying herself with the weariness of a markedly more mature woman, marvelously finds the balance between poised seductress and excruciatingly bored wife who is thrilled that some fresh meat walked into her den. But Hoffman, who at times seems just as tongue-tied and socially inept here as his future career-defining role Raymond Babbitt, lays the groundwork for why he is generally deemed one of the greatest leading men of his generation. That includes a particularly hysterical scene of him repeatedly banging his head against the wall that was improvised on the spot. He is pitiable and pathetic, but also comfortable being a total weirdo in the second half and the drastic change in behavior is both jarring and admirable to see pulled off so effortlessly by a young master of his craft. 
When Mrs. Robinson‚Äôs daughter Elaine returns home from Berkeley for the summer, Ben starts to take an interest in her, even though her mother made it abundantly clear to him that such a relationship was never to happen. His parents force the issue and send him on a date with Elaine, during which he behaves like a total jackass and erases practically any of the goodwill he might still have left. It‚Äôs a humiliating scene that exposes him as a selfish jerk, whose perpetual moping covers up his elitist upbringing that has taught him that he is better than everyone else and that he can get away with anything. Even if he makes it a point to distance himself from his parents, he is still very much his father‚Äôs son in that regard. The 1960s were an era of free-spirited souls seizing the day and gleefully giving the previous generation the middle finger. I‚Äôm struggling to think of a climax in any film of the era that finds a more fitting metaphor for this battle than ‚ÄúThe Graduate‚Äù.

The most interesting thing to me about this is its place as a coming of age film. It‚Äôs kind of way before that was even a recognisable sub genre, and even then it‚Äôd be recognised as one of the most subversive if it came out today. It kind of starts off as this quirky, relatable thing but literally only like a third of the way in it becomes the craziest, wackiest shit ever and it‚Äôs honestly so jarring but in the best kind of way. The Graduate is one of the finest character studies ever created. Benjamin Braddock is an insanely relatable character for myself (and I imagine most young males) with his cynicism, resentment for people who act as if they're doing something nice when really they're being more selfish than you can imagine, awkward demeanor and most of all his complete lack of any kind of future goals or dreams. The film starts off by introducing him as a great, layered character with an uncertain future and takes him full circle throughout the course of the remarkable story. At first it seems like a top notch version of the typical story of a man not knowing what he wants to do with his life and then finding love and doing whatever he can to achieve it. Which is all well and good and still incredibly made, but pretty typical.
It seems like it's going to end on a high note of bliss, with Braddock and his love literally fighting their way out of her wedding to another man (re: a tool) and running away together, happy in love. Then in the last second it slips back into that state of despair with a blank, hopeless look from the master of acting that is Dustin Hoffman and the return of the film's recurring use of the heartbreaking Simon & Garfunkel song "The Sound of Silence". Braddock fought for his love and attained what he thought was going to make his life worth living but once he finally gets it he realizes that his life is still empty and he's gained nothing from this whole whirlwind of a journey. Groundbreaking cinema. They really just don't make them like this anymore.

The 60s had The Graduate. The 80s had Risky Business. Such a shame they haven‚Äôt made any coming-of-age movies about the ennui of young adulthood and the paralysis of the future with surprising depth, great cinematography, and killer soundtracks since.

I showed this to my girlfriend (her first time seeing it), and I was so happy that she seemed to love it as much as I do. She even noticed several gags and jokes I had never caught on to in 10+ viewings! It's so easy to be cynical about films that define a generation, especially when that generation is the boomers. When that generation has been grist for the pop cultural mill for decades (shout out to casey on that point). Hoffman: the "face of a generation" Hmmm, yes: "If that generation had a face like a slapped arse!" I hear you retort, and fair enough. But who is Ben Braddock if not his generation's Donnie Darko? His generation's, oh - I dunno, Ol' Man River in My Own Private Idaho perhaps? Sad boys are sexy I guess. I mean, I certainly pinned my hopes on that assumption throughout my late teens and early 20s, though come to think, it never really worked out for me so mayb-no, no, nevermind - Hollywood definitely wants us to know that sad boys are sexy.
There's also something fundamentally boomer about claiming the cultural space - about succeeding and seceding from the previous generation by literally fucking them, not really enjoying it and then running off with their daughter and not knowing whether that was the right decision either. Just keep on taking until you can figure out what to do with all the stuff you've amassed. Every outgoing generation likes to think of their kids as entitled brats anyway, but I keep coming back to Donnie (OK, not My Own Private River - he was sad but not middle class enough), or heck - even Timothe√© Chalamet's Paul in Dune: Little Lord Emoroys who'll no doubt grow up to become masters of the universe. It's cyclical - it will keep happening until it's 10,191 on the planet Caladan.
Funny then that Nichols and May made almost the same film in this and The Heartbreak Kid, or at least films with the same selfish arsehole at their centre who doesn't know what he wants but gets it anyway. Because of course the generational meta-narrative needs to be about getting what you want even though you're not totally sure you want it. Because it's better to have it and not want it than to be a sucker with nothing, right? Right!?
*sigh*
Take a deep breath. It's not their fault their parents were emotionally distant veterans and alcoholics. It's not their fault they came of age in the greatest period of sustained economic prosperity and cultural progress in the twentieth century. Every generation has its crosses to bear and every generation thinks that sad boys are sexy. At least Mike Nichols was in on the joke even if generation after generation falls for it.

This has always been a favorite of mine, but like few other films, I feel it more and more profoundly with each watch.
Simon and Garfunkel are one of my favorite artists. Since this movie relies heavily on their music, it would be hard for me not to love it. Yes, it repeats the same songs a lot, but I find that it actually works to great effect.
Besides the stellar soundtrack, The Graduate is one of the most iconic and culturally important films of its time. Its huge status and the countless references to it might diminish its perception, but it actually lives up to all of the talk; even surpassing expectations. It's surprisingly timeless and endlessly funny.
Dustin Hoffman is perfect in this film. I love Ben Braddock a lot more than I probably should. His awkward politeness, aloof and anxious attitude, and spontaneity are perfectly written and superbly acted. He can seem somewhat exaggerated but it just feels so right.
I could go on, but what I feel so strongly about with this film is its timeless portrayal of a young man with no direction, and with little help from the adults in his life. Do I savor my youth or plan for the future?
"It's like I was playing some kind of game, but the rules don't make any sense to me. They're being made up by all the wrong people. I mean no one makes them up. They seem to make themselves up."

The Criterion Challenge 2021
Progress: 25/52
14. 1960s
We could talk about so much in this film. We could talk about the dulcet tones of Simon and Garfunkel, and how their crooning melodies lend a nostalgic romanticism to the vagaries of young adulthood. We could talk about the purposeful cinematography - how each obfuscated view, each calculated visual sweep - compounds on the nerves, the indecision, the manipulative edge in the narrative.
We could talk about the stellar performances, how you could see Robinson hold back tears on her first date, how Bancroft coyly slithers her way around her prey, how Hoffman basically sleepwalks through the first two acts of the film only to have each weak impulse reveal itself in his confidence. And that's just what I could think of off the top of my head. There's just such a strong, clear voice to this entire thing that makes for captivating cinema. But that's not what kept my attention for so long.
When I realised that Bancroft was trying to do, my eyes were immediately glued to the screen. I was hyper-aware that Hoffman - young, inexperienced, and rudderless - is about to have his entire life changed. He's about to find purpose, the first domino in his life about to tumble over into the mother of all metaphorical Rube Goldberg machines. And it's almost like he knows it. He becomes more brash, careless, self-absorbed as his life goes from strength to strength.
I want that life for myself. I don't want to do any internal work. I don't want the burden of having to commit to something sensible, strategic or safe. I want my life to be a whirlwind of decisions where I follow my whims without any consequences, where everything works out for me, where I get to prove that I could pave my own way and I didn't have to follow whatever rules anyone else thought I should follow. But then, as I listen to the same four Simon and Garfunkel songs play on a loop, I realise that this whole thing is solipsistic and delusional, and even though this is a nice fantasy, it's not a sentiment I would be proud to build a life on.

Ahhh Mike Nichols The Graduate was so much more than I expected.
From the beginning we are introduced to a somewhat confusing young man named Ben played by a very entertaining Dustin Hoffman. Uncertain about his future after graduating school has Ben nervous, and not being able to quite focus on anything even if it's spelled out for him.
When Ben (Hoffman) is lured by Mrs. Robinson(Anne Bancroft) for a ride home after a party the intensions, and mood of the film shift to utter seduction from the much older family friend Mrs. Robinson as she wants to have her way with the young Ben.
The Graduate at times touching, at times funny was a splendid film in showcasing the extreme talents of a young Dustin Hoffman, and that of the director Mike Nichols.
A film I won't soon forget, and wished I would have seen much sooner.

One of the most brilliant coming-of-age stories ever told. A film that genuinely understands how to use dry humor efficiently, whilst also delivering a plethora of extremely important themes such as loneliness, anxiety, and making your own decisions despite being against your own will.
Dustin Hoffman could not have been a more perfect casting for the character of Benjamin, a very introverted and secluded human being that represents what the film is trying to convey to the audience. While being as funny as he is awkward, his line delivery and mannerisms could not have been more appropriate for every scene where he is present. As for the supporting cast, everyone on display does more than enough to satisfy.
The soundtrack has immediately become one of my favorites in all of film, every song that is played does its job by setting the tone for each scene, and oh man, the cinematography, truly remarkable. During every frame that was shown right in front of me, I was marveling over how well-shot it was. 
If you couldn‚Äôt tell already, I loved this film, I will continue to love it for as long as I can forsee, and I can already sense an endless amount of rewatches down the line. Incredible.

I first watched The Graduate back in 2017, and I thought it was pretty good. Now, in 2020, with a much more developed and keen eye for film, as well as being the same age as the protagonist and only being a year away from graduation, I have definitely fallen for the film a lot harder, as its brilliant film-making and now-resonant themes really stuck out on this watch. The editing is very inventive, impressively and smoothly-executed, purposeful and fun, and the cinematography is fantastic, with lots of impressively well directed long takes, good framing, blocking, lighting etc. throughout. The soundtrack by Simon and Garfunkel captures the emotional flavour of the film's content very effectively and beautifully. The script and performances do a great job of being very comedic and fun while staying grounded in the melancholic emotional core of the film, which reflects the confusion, sadness, desperation and existential crises of this age incredibly well.
Its a great picture!

The most pleasant thing is walking into your class expecting a lecture and instead watching The Graduate. Heard someone after the movie saying they "hated" this movie because Mrs. Robinson was a bad person. Ugh- guys the people I do to film school with are so dense. I can't freaking stand it. Like please watch a movie and realize not all the characters need to be heroes and there doesn't need to be car crashes and explosions to keep you engaged. You are in film school for petes sake time to broaden your horizons and realize movies just about people and their messy relationships are just as (actually usually more) compelling than your blockbusters.
Sorry had to get that off my chest I just really dislike most of my classmates.
This is a movie about a bunch of lost souls. Mrs. Robinson is a despicable character, but growing up you realize Ben is maybe even worse then she is. His naive worldview gets the best of him. His feeling of desperation and isolation leads him into a world of sin and lust. This is what several of us have to struggle with when we feel like we genuinely have nothing to do left or anything to feel.
After graduating High School, I felt the same pains Ben did. I felt like I was being pushed towards a future that maybe at the time I didn't really want. I didn't want to enter the work force or join the rat race. I wanted to continue to see my friends everyday and run around and have fun. Yet, life there are changes and to The Smashing Pumpkins, "The more you change the less you feel."
We try to keep ourselves interested and excited, just for a moment to feel something new. This movie is a cautionary tale about the breaking point of that idea, to morally bankrupt yourself for the moment of exhilaration you desire. Gosh, it's such a funny movie. A really uncomfortable one and the way Mike Nichols frames all his shots and gets every single line of dialogue perfectly timed is just ingenious. Despite the questionable decisions every character makes here- they are just all so fascinating and the movie is just so entertaining you want to see what happens next.
The way the ending of this movie is framed is brilliant. Spoilers if you haven't seen the ending of The Graduate. Okay- look I know I could mark this review for spoilers but who doesn't know the ending of The Graduate?
The ending of The Graduate is not a happy one. A lot of people (including Roger Ebert) find the ending of this movie questionable because Ben gets what he wants with no true consequence. I think that final moment gives us all we need to know though. Ben and his decisions will haunt him forever, and his nihilistic view of the world will always get in the way of him and his relationship. Him and Elaine are two broken people who will never be whole. Will they be as happy as they can be? Who knows. However- the course of this film shows that they will never truly be happy, which is what makes The Graduate a cautionary tale overall.
Anyways, this is an incredible movie. If you love movies and have never seen The Graduate, please just go on Netflix and watch it right now.

Man merkt einfach wie der Film die Generationen dieser Zeit beeinflusst hat. Nur bei Ferris mach Blau und Zur√ºck in die Zukunft hatte ich ein √§hnliches Gef√ºhl.
Mein Dad ist das perfekte Beispiel daf√ºr ist mir im Laufe des Films aufgefallen. Eines seiner Lieblingsauto ist der gezeigte Alfa Spider und noch Heute h√∂rt er fast Jeden Tag den genialen Simon & Garfunkel Soundtrack und zitiert ab und an Dustin Hoffmans Figur.
Filme die den Zeitgeist auf solche Weise beeinflussen haben bei mir einen besonderen Stellenwert. Auch die Handlung war f√ºr das Jahr 1967 ziemlich revolution√§r. Ein Mann der eine Beziehung mit einer √§lteren verheirateten Frau eingeht war zu dieser Zeit nicht allt√§gige Filmkost.
Zudem hat mir gefallen wie unsperrig der Film trotz seines Alters wirkte. Die lustige Szenen haben im Laufe der Zeit nicht ihren Witz verloren und die Handlungen der Charaktere sind immer noch genauso nachvollziehbar.
Zudem hat der Film eben auch wie Ferris macht blau eine gewisse Leichtigkeit, welche den aktuellen Coming of Age Filmen (in diese Kategorie w√ºrde ich den Film noch am ehesten einordnen) leider oft fehlt.
Visuell ist the graduate oder auf deutsch die Reifepr√ºfung einfach nur Genial. Einer der sch√∂nsten und handwerklich besten die ich je gesehen habe. Es werden Winkel und Zoomeinstellungen perfekt genutzt um Gef√ºhle und Emotionen zu transportieren und die Einstellungen (besonders bei seinen Fahrten zur Berkeley Uni) sind unglaublich sch√∂n. Untermalt mit dem Soundtrack von Simon & Garfunkel wirklich perfekt.
Hatte extrem viel Spa√ü mit dem Film. Was ich eigentlich nicht unbedingt erwartet habe. 9,5/10

Movie #1 of Extra Credit Film Club FALL 2018
‚ÄúMy whole life is just a waste... it‚Äôs just nothing.‚Äù
I am already in my junior year of college and I honestly feel just as lost and nervous as the main character is after graduating from college. It is scary to know that in just a few years, I will be in the same position as Ben is here. To relieve of the stress, I always turn to film and try enjoy the most out of it, whether it is good or bad. I am very happy and grateful that my history teacher has given us extra credit assignments where we can watch these films and write reflections on them and how the reflected the time period. The Graduate, staring a very young Dustin Hoffman, is the first of these films that we are watching... and frankly it is one of the most entertaining and interesting films I have seen in years.
First of all, it is gutbustingly funny and it used very subtle humor to get the message across. It didn‚Äôt need to be loud and obnoxious, but clever and sarcastic. Beyond that, it has terrific performances, fantastic characters, a vastly engaging story for a rom-com, powerful messages about adolescence and finding your own identity, perfect chemistry between the main characters, and THE greatest soundtrack to a film I have ever heard. I still cannot get these songs out of my head. Also, there is this one amazing scuba diving scene that I believe represents this film pretty well. It pretty much symbolizes what happens to Ben in the film. The last thing I want to mention is that I love the way this film was shot. There are many dramatic angles that show the purpose of the scenes within this film. There is not a single dull shot in this movie. I never thought a film like this would make me think about my future as much as it does. Although I am pretty sure that I will not get into an affair with my childhood friends, wife that is a good 8 years older than me.
The Graduate is an amazing film with thought provoking themes, hilarious comedy, and beautiful cinematography. It is crazy that this was made over fifty years ago. It gives me a feel for how the sixties were like. Not the entire picture, but a good taste of their culture and politics. This is how you make a good film. This is how you send a message across with your story. This is art!

"The Graduate" (Deutsch: "Die Reifepr√ºfung") ist einer der ikonischsten Dramedys √ºberhaupt. Dieser Film hat bei mir schon seit einer ganzen Weile das Interesse geweckt und da ich generell offen f√ºr Filme mit Dustin Hoffman, war dieses Ding hier ganz oben auf meiner Liste.
Regie f√ºhrte Mike Nichols und dieser Mann d√ºrfte manchen Leuten bekannt sein, die Filme wie "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" oder "Working Girl" kennen. Tats√§chlich handelt es sich hier um sein insgesamt zweites Werk nach seinem Oscar-Elefanten "WIAOVW".
Es ist kaum zu glauben, was f√ºr einen unglaublichen Start er hingelegt hat und dennoch namentlich so gut wie keinen Nachhall erschuf. Naja, wenn man so sich ansieht, was er in den sp√§teren Jahren inszeniert hat, dann wundert es einen eher weniger, aber konzentrieren wir uns auf seine fr√ºhe, goldene Phase.
Die Hauptrolle namens Benjamin Braddock wird von Dustin Hoffman √ºbernommen, der mit einer fantastischen Leistung den gesamten Film tr√§gt, wobei er selbst den Film eher weniger tr√§gt, er wird getragen. Sonst w√ºrde seine Figur √ºber diesen Zeitraum einen Leerlauf durchgehen.
In den Nebenrollen brillieren ebenso die verf√ºhrerische Anne Bancroft als Mrs. Robinson, die mit einer ungreifbaren Aura den noch heranwachsenden Benjamin in einer Aff√§re lockt, weil es mit dem Mann nicht funktioniert und die Scheidung schon vor der T√ºr steht. Ach so, Mr. Robinson wird von Murray Hamilton verk√∂rpert, den die meisten wohl als B√ºrgermeister Vaughan aus "Jaws" kennen d√ºrften. Die Tochter der Mrs. Robinson wird von Katharine Ross gespielt, auch eine Frau, die an der Seite von vielen Legenden spielen durfte.
Benjamin verliebt sich begrenzt in Mrs. Robinson, aber dann macht er Bekannschaft mit ihrer Tochter, die er niemals heiraten darf, aus welchen Gr√ºnden auch immer. Aber das spielt keine Rolle, weil der Film, seine Kamerafahrten, sein Soundtrack und die Schauspieler brillieren auf vielen Ebenen. Wer Tarantino's "Jackie Brown" kennt und die Opening Credits genauso abfeiert wie ich, dann hat man hier den Ursprung des Ganzen. Perfekt kopiert, w√ºrde ich sagen.
Es ist kein Zufall, dass die Figur von Anne Bancroft Mrs. Robinson hei√üt. Sp√§testens diejenigen, die 2019 "Once Upon a Time in Hollywood" gesehen haben, d√ºrften den musikalisch und stimmlich himmlischen Song "Mrs. Robinson" von Simon & Garfunkel kennen. Daraus entstand dieser sehr oft zitierte Song. Auch das Volkslied "Scarborough Fair" wurde f√ºr den Film von den Duo gecovert. Und nat√ºrlich darf nicht "The Sound of Silence" fehlen, der den Anfang, das Ende und eine in die Geschichte eingegangene Einstellung im Pool markiert. Diese drei Szenen haben einen k√ºnstlerischen Hintergrund, noch mehr als alles andere an diesem Film. Die inszenatorisch besten Aspekte werden eben von diesen drei Szenen dargestellt. Ansonsten wirkt der ganze Film sehr hochwertig produziert und sorgt f√ºr viele komische und bittere Momente, die zum einen Probleme der Heranwachsenden thematisieren, zum anderen aber auch die Mutterrolle auf den Kopf stellen. Gedreht wurde der Film auf Panavision, sozusagen der Nachfolger f√ºr den damals ausgelutschten Cinemascope, der trotzdem noch heute genial ist.
Es gibt auch eine Szene bzw. eine kleine, aber feine √úberblende, die ist mir echt positiv aufgefallen. Und zwar, wenn Dustin Hoffman an einem Brunnen wartet und er ganz alleine da sitzt und die √úberblende einen gef√ºllten Platz aus der Ferne zeigt. Eine tolle Entscheidung, die Benjamins unaussch√∂pfliche Sehnsucht abbildet. Wenn es um kreatives Dialogschreiben geht, dann gibt es auch diese, wenn Benjamin mit seinen eigenen Eltern √ºber das Thema "Heirat" spricht.
Dennoch ist die Message trotz der teilweise genialen Symbolik etwas blass geraten und der Film vermittelt eher mehr die Unterhaltung dieser Dramedy. Aber die Unterhaltung ist selbstverst√§ndlich nicht kritiserbar.
"The Graduate" ist ein ausgesprochen toller Beginn f√ºr diese unvergessliche Zeit im US-amerikanischen Kino.
Eine Empfehlung an Dramedy-Fans, Dustin Hoffman-Lover und Fans von Simon & Garfunkel, denn ihre Musik passt hier mit am besten.

Hmmm... Mon sujet de doc devrait √™tre: comment Dustin Hoffman a embourgeois√©, d√©radicalis√© le Method Acting pour tuer la star et ins√©rer le vide dans le cin√©ma contemporain. C'est assez √©vident ici, o√π l'incapacit√© de Dustin √† communiquer, ses balbutiements et ses h√©sitations, sont plus importants que ce qu'il aurait √† communiquer s'il parvenait √† le faire. Parce qu'en r√©alit√©, son personnage est absolument vide, et il n'aurait rien √† dire m√™me s'il pouvait parler, contrairement √† Dean ou Brando o√π les m√™me mani√©rismes servaient √† exprimer une singularit√©, une diff√©rence, qui faisait √©clater les normes. L√†, Dustin est incompris, mais c'est juste parce que les adultes sont des caricatures d'idiots ; lui-m√™me n'a aucune conviction, aucune volont√©, aucune forme d'int√©riorit√©, outre celle de vouloir du sexe de temps en temps. Rien √† d√©fendre, et quand il n'appara√Æt pas idiot, il est juste un vrai trou d'cul (il n'y a vraiment aucune raison pour se sauver avec lui √† la fin). En ce sens, Rain Man est le r√¥le d'une vie, son r√¥le le plus honn√™te: pas (ou peu) d'int√©riorit√©, juste des mani√©rismes qui valent en eux-m√™mes. M√™me dans All the President's Men, √† y repenser, les personnages n'ont aucune vie personnelle, que du travail, toujours le travail, comme Dustin n'est rien d'autre qu'un acteur que l'on voit travailler pour nous convaincre.
Ann Bancroft, Mrs Robinson, est le seul vrai personnage du film, dont l'assurance, la grandeur, l'honn√™tet√© envers soi-m√™me en fait une star dans le sens le plus noble du terme, condamn√©e √† la d√©ch√©ance dans ce monde de merde que Dustin embrasse alors m√™me qu'on essaie de nous faire croire qu'il se sent √† part. Dans Marathon Man, c'est encore une star, Laurence Olivier, que Dustin devra vaincre pour s'assurer un avenir et r√©tablir le statu quo (dans les deux cas la notion d'avenir est utilis√©e de fa√ßon assez ironique d'ailleurs). C'est une dr√¥le de chose, que ton personnage-type soit un coll√©gien/universitaire impuissant, qui doit conqu√©rir sa masculinit√© parce qu'on s'entend les gars de lettres c'est pas tr√®s tr√®s masculin, c'est g√™n√© pis toutte (il est assez puant id√©ologiquement Dustin, je redoute de revoir Straw Dogs, et j'imagine que Kramer vs Kramer sera assez terrible).
Bref, ce serait un beau prequel au m√©moire sur Tom Cruise, puisque Risky Business s'inspire largement de The Graduate, jusqu'√† reprendre l'image de Dustin avec ses lunettes fum√©es et sa clope. Mais l'ami Tom, √©videmment, n'est pas une coquille vide, et il faudrait relire tout Rain Man, o√π Dustin est la figure paternelle, comme une tentative de ramener la star √† Hollywood et r√©v√©ler comment la M√©thode peut devenir une M√©thode qui n'exprime rien d'autre qu'elle-m√™me (comme quand on mange du foie cru ou qu'on gagne et perd du poids parce qu'on veut des prix, esti que c'est con pareil). Et cette th√®se s‚Äôappelerait : Dear boy, have you try acting?, en l‚Äôhonneur d‚ÄôOlivier, et je me trouverais bien dr√¥le.
Faque le film est correct pendant une heure, mais √ßa devient platte en maudit quand Ann Bancroft dispara√Æt, et je suis pas s√ªr de comprendre pourquoi c'est si r√©put√©, √† part que c'est bien film√©. Et encore l√†, la mise en sc√®ne de Nichols est √† la Nouvelle Vague ce qu'Hoffman est √† Brando ou Dean, faque c'est assez puant aussi comme film. Ou juste cynique, mais √ßa me fait chier le cynisme faque √ßa revient au m√™me. Je vais me garder une p'tit g√™ne pour la note et pas √™tre trop b√™te, parce que c'est assez dr√¥le par moments, mais c'est certainement pas g√©nial.

WOW.
Despite this being silly, stupid, egregious, make-believe, wish-fulfillment, juvenile, I found it very lively and funny and interesting and truthful.
Like a Wes Anderson movie that's all the good things about a Wes Anderson movie and none of the bad. It takes all the immature frustrations and yearnings of youth, sexual and existential, and stays true to them, which explains giving us a narrative that's slightly more wish-fulfillment than it really is (the guy Anne Bancroft would sleep with is a jock or a wealthy businessman, not Dustin Hoffman, let's be real), but still hits us with the ramifications of the pursuit of hedonistic instincts and ego-nourishments that baby boomers substituted for real purpose enough that the film is neither over-indulgent nor is reduced to didacticism and moralism.
I don't know. This was really fucking awesome. Top to bottom. Extremely hilarious. Never boring. Although there's too many Simon and Garfunkel needle drops for my taste (one is too many for me). But I found this just so captivating. I thought a film with the title "The Graduate" would reduce itself to empty symbolisms, but this doesn't. All the characters are fucking real and interesting and confused and alienated just the same, and they're all caught up in a web of mistakes and consequences. Even the daughter in the end makes her first and only mistake, but the last shot of the film where they both stop smiling is really directorially intelligent and awesome and made me appreciate the entire movie even more.
No wonder this is considered an American masterpiece... it really is.

The Criterion Challenge 2023: Watch a film with a spine #800-950: #800
Criterion Spine #800
Viewing two. I've seen enough now to be convinced that The Graduate is a bona fide classic. The opening says it all. That brilliant shot of Braddock's head in the porcelain background. Zooming out we see he is on an airplane. That scene is referenced in different acts. It is such a cool narrative lynchpin. But how about that clown art in the Braddock home?
"I'm a little upset about my future."
The first time Braddock enters the Robinson home, he talks to Mr. Robinson in the bar. The men are backlit. Mrs. Robinson is visible in the background as she descends the stairs. Braddock drinks scotch after requesting brandy, served from a colonial Egyptian coffin flask. This scene convinced me that the lighting of the The Graduate would be no joke. 50 Shades, take notes.
"Are you here for an affair, sir?"
Mrs. Robinson enters the Taft Hotel and we see her upside down reflection in the emerald cocktail table. This woman is reverting Braddock's world, and distorting it too‚Äî which is so tastefully shown when Braddock looks up at the Robinsons from the family pool as drops of water and sun obscure his vision. Mrs. Robinson unbuttoning Braddock like a child. The sleek white of the hotel room referencing the white of the opening shot. That moment when Braddock is shaving and it is not clear to the viewer where he is. His Mom comes in asking where he goes from midnight to noon every day, and she looks like Mrs. Robinson. Uncanny.
"Wood or wire?"
Nichols and Surtees so brilliantly calculated every precise moment of this film. It has to be one the best shot films I have ever seen, if not the best. The phallic candle's reflection in the Taft Hotel room, present on the film's poster. Another shot referencing the opening when the jig is up. We see Mrs. Robinson wearing an emerald nightgown, and then the camera pans out to the white background of the family home. Just like the beginning.
Moe's Books. How the camera tracks Braddock as he stalks Elaine to UC Berkeley. Intimate and in his face, then a wide angle shot of the whole campus, Braddock only a speck of its magnitude. Braddock's behavior is cancel worthy in today's times, but the film isn't. Yes, he is a creep, but Nichols is not condoning his actions. If I have any critique of The Graduate it is that Elaine acquiescing to Braddock's advances feels very "woman written by man," but the ending is so brilliant that I left the film more in awe than anything else. In fact, I had a tear in my eye.
The Graduate is resonating with me more right now as I am a recent grad school graduate finding my place in the world, but as much as I love the story, the craft is my favorite thing about the film. Well, the screenplay, acting, editing, and directing are pretty damn special too. A new favorite movie of mine? It is up there.

Clearly I‚Äôm in the mood to watch classic and older movies recently as this is yet another pre-2000s watch! This evening was The Graduate, Mike Nichols‚Äô Best Director-winning romance drama, starring a young Dustin Hoffman, and among the candidates for several of the other leading nominations in 1968. 
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî
Benjamin Braddock (Dustin Hoffman) has just graduated from college, but now he doesn't seem to know what to do with his life. His parents are not of much help, being more interested in climbing the social ladder and having him help them along as the perfect, dutiful son. Enter Mrs. Robinson (Anne Bancroft), an old family friend, with whom Ben begins an affair to relieve some of his inner anxiety; as well Mrs. Robinson's daughter, Elaine (Katharine Ross) who he also starts a relationship with. 
The Graduate could be seen as a romantic comedy. The plot itself, if a bit heavy, especially for its time, is lighthearted enough and the character archetypes on display are such that the jokes practically write themselves. Yet a dark undercurrent floats just beneath the surface, transforming the whole thing into a scathing satire. The song The Sound of Silence, by Simon & Garfunkel, is often played over central scenes, almost functioning as the theme for the whole film. And anyone who has ever heard the song knows that it's rather dark in its message, despite the light melody. "Hello darkness, my old friend" indeed.
What this film is trying to talk about is being trapped in a circle from which you cannot escape. Ben's character gets progressively worse as the movie goes on, but you cannot really blame him, not entirely. You can see from his parents and from Mrs. Robinson and her husband that he's merely imitating the sins of the last generation. It's easy to see that he and Elaine could very easily end up just as shallow and empty as their parents. It wouldn't take much. And that's the horror behind the usual rom-com antics.
A peculiar film. It requires you to look underneath the surface, to question the events that are taking place. And for that it needs to be praised. I‚Äôm now discovering this was Dustin Hoffman‚Äôs breakthrough role, and a commendable one I will admit.

It‚Äôs hard to put into words how much this film means to me.
This is the best directing ever put it film. It‚Äôs so rich of symbolism and clever camera techniques that make the story so much more engrossing and beautiful. For example the camera frames Benjamin as either too close and claustrophobic or too far and spaced out. It really helps to reel in this feeling of loneliness and confusion that he is feeling throughout the film.
If you haven‚Äôt seen it even if you think you might not like it, please consider giving this a try. I think everyone that is even remotely into film should see it immediately.

THE SOUND OF SILENCE
Mike Nichols shows a subject as complex as a university student's sexual awakening for what it is: decision and security, the illusion of choosing a better future. However, it's important to understand that this isn't a typical romantic comedy or tearjerker drama (in fact, it stays halfway somewhere between both extremes), rather it's the conversion of all marital unions (real or fictitious) that, due to the clash between rebelliousness and strictness, leads to chaos, robbery, repentance and an atypical (and certainly bizarre) test of love. The arised apathy from shame and defeat in several inappropriate and erotic decisions, reaffirms the dubious future over the adventure.
Although Dustin Hoffman manages to maintain interest as Benjamin Braddock, the truth is that Anne Bancroft is the real star as the quintessential original sexy bad mother, it's thanks to Mrs. Robinson that the story lives on, due to how scandalous her presence turns out to be for family values. Combined with the music by Simon & Garfunkel and a level of intensity and suspense that keeps the story tense and uncomfortable, it's the perfect portrait of uncertainty as part of life, exemplified in a beautifully illustrated ending that shapes the course of the leading couple in the back of a truck. Ahead of its time.

‚ÄúBen, what are you doing?
Well, I would say that I'm just drifting‚Ä¶ Here in the pool.‚Äù
It‚Äôs hard to put into words exactly what I think about this film.
The Graduate is a film I relate to deeply. I think it‚Äôs a film many people my age relate to. 
The future is a scary thing. For my entire senior year, the future has loomed over me, and it still does. Much like Benjamin, everywhere I go, people ask me questions about the future. It seems that‚Äôs all the adults in my life want to talk about. They ask ‚Äúwhere are you going to college?‚Äù or ‚Äúwhat do you want to do in the future?‚Äù and I‚Äôve never truly had a good answer. And much like Benjamin, I don‚Äôt know why I don‚Äôt have a good answer.
Life is confusing. I don‚Äôt know where I‚Äôm going to end up, or the kind of life I will lead. I don‚Äôt even know what the next 6 months might hold, much less the next 60 years. 
And that‚Äôs what The Graduate is all about.
The uncertainty of youth. The pressure of being on the brink of adulthood, as the adults around you push you into the future. Benjamin is a well-off and intelligent man. His possibilities are so incredibly broad if he just puts in the effort. But there‚Äôs something blissful about youth. You lack the responsibilities of adulthood, and accepting those responsibilities as you grow older can be intimidating. 
The themes of uncertainty and stress for the future are only possible due to the fantastic screenplay and direction. Mike Nichols‚Äô charming direction perfectly encapsulates Benjamin‚Äôs feelings of depression and anxiety. The cinematography is beautiful as well. The lighting and framing is excellent. The dialogue is oddly syncopated, giving the film it‚Äôs awkward, naive feeling. The acting from every member of the cast is great but Dustin Hoffman was obviously the standout. Through the first act he doesn‚Äôt talk much, but expresses a lot simply through his body language and expressions. 
In conclusion, The Graduate might be the realest film of all time. Benjamin is one of the most relatable characters in film, in my opinion. This film found me at a very weird and melancholic time in my life, and I think it found me at the perfect time.

Dustin Hoffman brilliert in seiner ersten gro√üen Rolle und Anne Bancroft und Katharine Ross verdrehen ihm hier erfolgreich den Kopf. There's a corrupting force that moves throughout The Graduate, rooting itself in whatever existential boredom it can find. At the beginning of the movie, Benjamin is bumbling and nebbish and polite and sweet. By the end, he's a pretty unsavory character. Mrs. Robinson taught him that being unsavory is a possible mode of being. She is aggressively pushy towards him, and her seduction technique is to ignore his protests. But we can empathize with her rationale: she feels purposeless and powerless in life, and Benjamin is one of the few people she has power over, so she takes what she wants from him. Is she respectful of Benjamin's agency? It's hard to say. You can cast her actions as selfish, where she is taking what she wants from a world that doesn't let her take very much; or you can cast them as teaching moments, showing Benjamin how to break out of his shell. Either way, Benjamin is also rudderless and full of existential angst, and susceptible to Mrs. Robinson's lessons... she shows him how to be pushy in love. But he's rich, young, white, and male, so his subsequent rejection of conventional social norms is much scarier. When he becomes a predator, he can bend the world to his whims.
Elaine's decision at the end is so interesting. One would expect Benjamin to have fully repulsed her. Why doesn't it? (Is this a story about a stalker breaking down his victim? That's a take I've seen.) She's less developed than the other two characters, but I think intentionally so: we're meant to extrapolate from the other two characters to learn her situation. She too feels purposeless and living in bad faith. So, Benjamin's attitude toward life overtakes her just as Mrs. Robinson's overtook Benjamin. Everyone gets corrupted! Any moralizing about whether this is a negative corrupting force or a positive self-actualizing force is left unstated.
The Graduate is one of those rare movies that is breezy and hilarious while also deep and psychologically rich. It's a treatise on the contagion of existentialist thought.
I love the existential romcom. Say Anything falls in this space for me, as does The Heartbreak Kid, which was directed by Elaine May, Mike Nichols's onetime comedy partner. Nichols and May were clearly attracted to the same sort of material. (I still haven't heard any of the comedy they did together. I should fix that.) Nichols includes more assertive visual jokes in the cinematography than May‚ÄîBenjamin jumping on the pool mat cutting to jumping on Mrs. Robinson, the well-timed toast pop-up, the focus onto the gorilla, the long run down the sidewalk, the classic shot of Benjamin framed inside Mrs. Robinson's bent legs‚Äîbut Nichols and May are very similar in directorial style. Both movies have a nearly identical shot where the camera looks up from the protagonist's point of view at their love interest silhouetted and haloed by the summer sun.
Benjamin has an awful lot of the behavioral markers for autism. I wonder if this performance is what led to Dustin Hoffman's casting in Rain Man? This feels like a stronger portrayal of autism. Less heightened.

It's a little bit difficult to me to talk about "The Graduate". I mean... This is simply the best movie I have ever seen. I totally get into this movie everytime I see it, I feel Benjamin's drama in my skin.
I have to confess that the first time I heard someone talking about this movie, i really didn't give a damn about it, because of its title here, in Brazil ("A primeira noite de um homem", that means something like "The first night of a man"). I was thinking that this movie was just one more movie about young people trying to get laid. A terrible mistake. Someday, I decided to watch this movie. At the first day, I watched it at least three times, in sequence. Then I bought a copy for my small movies collection. In the same week I bought it, I watched it everyday.
Everything in this movie is perfect to me. The first thing I paid attention was the soundtrack. I'm a big fan of Simon and Garfunkel's work, and i found simply amazing that they had all the soundtrack of the movie.
I think this movies really shows something very simple: You'll never know what you will want tomorrow, and what will happen in your life. I mean, isn't life ironic? Benjamin never expected to fall in love with Mrs Robinson's daughter. If he had listened to Mrs Robinson and never went out with Elaine, would he just stand with that "empty" feeling for all of his life? He just wouldn't know.

This was a mythical viewing experience for me. At moments, I really understood why it's a cultural cornerstone of the 60's, but at other times, the movie didn't work for me. Frankly, I think along with Cabaret, it's one of those that is held in high esteem for being a great film in its time, but simply hasn't been able to transcend time periods.

This movie seems to wane in popularity and reverence as time goes on, and as much as that‚Äôs a shame it also makes perfect sense.
The Graduate is not an openly emotional or clean film. It‚Äôs curt and absurd, taking big themes and examining them in a method that‚Äôs anything but concrete. Characters are three-dimensional but also ridiculous, they interact in ways that are both natural and comedically uncanny. 
It creates an experience that could be alienating to many, like a snobby version of a Coen brothers film, but damn if I don‚Äôt fuck with it so hard. Nothing else has been so distant yet so innately honest. It‚Äôs so bizarre it that in turn becomes universal. Feelings of alienation, disillusionment, and confusion have never been better communicated. The effectiveness of these themes come across as complete in their distant and muddled execution.
Every single line of dialogue, shot, soundtrack choice (Simon and Garfunkel my beloved), and every other minute detail distinctly belongs to The Graduate. It exists as a microcosm of the late 60s but is still poignant so many years later. It‚Äôs quietly one of the most unique movies ever made and should be considered one of the best ever.

There's an odd sense of comfort amongst the awkwardness of The Graduate.
Setting the standard for the coming of age genre, what really surprised me about this was how timeless it feels - with the latest remaster and the confident direction it could have come out last year, let alone 1967.
Mike Nichols creates a film that feels so vibrant and established with technically impressive shots that must've inspired so many 50 years ago. I did initially feel frustrated that I had waited this long to watch this but on reflection, it feels like it came around at the perfect time. I am a similar age as Hoffman's character and saw a lot of myself in his fear of the future. The tension of undesirable social situations and the conflict of deciding the next chapter were both encouraging and daunting to see reflected on the screen, especially given the age of the film.
Set to the soothing tones of Simon & Garfunkel, it's no wonder that The Graduate stands as an iconic pillar of cinema, and I'm already worried about the amount of repeat viewing this will get over the coming years.

Truly fantastic filmmaking.
    A nearly perfect film. Hoffman is excellent. Aside from maybe a few problems with the story and some character choices. I think this film was absolutely amazing. I was never bored. The music in this film by Simon and Garfunkel is beautiful. Even though songs are repeated 2-3 times throughout the film, each time those song are played they just hit different and invoke a different feeling or emotion out of the viewer every time. Each time a song is played or repeated it feels like it was a specific reason or to invoke a certain feeling. 
    The cinematography, camera movements, and camera angles are all masterfully done. The cinematography is used brilliantly in order to tell the story. The POV shots where Ben is watching Elaine tell us everything we need to know with just our eyes. There are a multitude of shots throughout the film in which the shots are composed in a specific way in order evoke Ben‚Äôs feelings. It‚Äôs among some of the best composed shots I have ever seen. There are endlesss shots that are just breathtaking, for such a simple story too. 
    Overall, The Graduate is honestly an amazing film. I‚Äôm so glad I watched it. It‚Äôs a great story with amazing acting, a beautiful score and some of the most well composed shots I‚Äôve ever seen. It‚Äôs hard to tell a story and evoke emotions just by the way you place the camera, and this film does it perfectly. Nearly a masterpiece honestly. Ben is also a super relatable character. I recommend checking it out if you haven‚Äôt already, it‚Äôs free on Amazon Prime. It‚Äôs definitely worth your time. This film is also one of the films that had the biggest influence on Hollywood during its time, actually being one of the first films to start the New Hollywood movement, along with Bonnie and Clyde.

Time shines paradoxically on The Graduate. Much of the punchlines in the first act encourage the viewer to laugh at an anxious and awkward virgin being manipulated and pressured into having sex with an older woman. The first act is frankly rapey. Not wanting sex but being pushed to carry on is a major part of the film. It's somewhat uncomfortable, especially taking into account the allegations toward Hoffman. Yet at the same time, as the film carries on, a careful viewer will pick up on the fact that the film doesn't seem to really endorse the actions of any character, though it does sympathize with them. By the end, Ben and Elaine get their happy ending, but there's a subtle suggestion in their facial expressions that says "now what?" The characters are superficial. The affair was toxic. The final romance was a farce. The film may even be an anti-comedy, upon dissection. I'm not entirely sure we are supposed to laugh with it, but at it. Such is life. This superficial chaotic mess.

The Graduate is a bit of an oddity to me. I have watched it a number of times over the years. And I love it. It makes me laugh. It has fun and inventive camera-work. It feels both of its time - a wonderful capsule of the 60's, but with themes that are of relevance to modern sensibilities. You could make the case that the lack of understanding between generations (certainly as depicted in the media) is wider than it was at the start of the baby boom. So it has a point of view to express. And it has the most wonderful acerbic ending. But despite all this I don't really think it is a great movie.
The thing is it is just so damn funny. There is so much wonderful dialogue. The script is peppered with fantastic comic lines. It is simply impossible not to crack up when you hear the word "Plastics". It is uttered with such sincerity and yet depicts the divide between the parents and the kids so effortlessly and succinctly. Mrs. Robinson's (the perfect Anne Bancroft) seduction of Ben Braddock (Dustin Hoffman) is delicious - filled with desperation, excitement and ennui. The scenes in the hotel lobby - Ben trying to be an adult and in control - when he is anything but. And the splendid, over the top scenes at the strip-club and later at the church. All is wonderful. Truly excellent.
But I'm not sure what it all adds up to. I really struggle with how the main characters get themselves into such a position. Mrs. Robinson makes the most sense. But I really have to look the other way when trying to understand Ben. Is all there is to him out-of-control male hormones and a desire to escape middle class boredom? But the character of Elaine (Katharine Ross) makes the least sense. There does not really seem to be much behind the eyes. The final act is deeply problematic given what she believes happened between Ben and her mother. She would need to be pretty vacant or troubled to look the other way and act as she did.
And yet I wouldn't really want it any other way. I've never bought into the motives and plot contrivances that get Ben and Elaine to the church and on that bus. But 60's cinema would be less rich if these classic moments fell victim to plausibility. So I try not to think about its flaws too deeply - and instead just enjoy the delicious words and the blossoming embarrassment of youthful rebelliousness.

A boy trying to become a man.
The feelings of self-doubt, alienation, disenchantment, unwanted pressures and expectations for a twenty-something just out of college are explored in the Nichols' brilliant direction using water and the swimming pool as a metaphorical representation of Ben Braddock's entrapment. "Plastics!" takes on greater meaning as a symbol of falsity in the adult world, the same symbol of escape from upper middle class "plastic" society in a public transportation, the bus is filled with ‚Äúreal‚Äù people. A kick against the smug, xenophobic, materialistic, spoiled and sanctimonious middle classes. Mrs. Robinson is a epitome of the devil-may-care LA bourgeoisie who represents the darker side of America's American Dream, sedated by pills, desensitized by liquor and mind dulled by television.
Timeless masterpiece.

A handful of American films appeared in the late 60s which changed the face of Hollywood. While Bonnie and Clyde pushed the envelope in terms of cinematic violence and In the Heat of the Night dared to tackle race relations, The Graduate was busy breaking sexual taboos.
But just to focus on the way it changed everything (and it still looks extraordinarily ahead of its time) would be to diminish just how stunning a film it is. Dustin Hoffman gives what could well be his best screen performance (and I, as a sufferer of chronic shyness, know just how it feels to want to escape from social situations, which is why the party scene is so effective). Anne Bancroft is perfect as Mrs Robinson, one of the great screen villainesses, and Katharine Ross is suitably na√Øve as Elaine.
This is also the creative zenith of director Mike Nichols, who was rightly awarded that year's Oscar. He works with photographer Robert Surtees to heighten Benjamin's feeling of alienation and disenfranchisement, as well as to increase the impact of some elaborate and borderline-surreal visual jokes. Credit has to go to editor Sam O'Steen for that dazzling sequence (set to Simon & Garfunkel's "The Sound of Silence") depicting the effects of Benjamin's first encounter with Mrs Robinson.
The Graduate is by no means an ordinary sex comedy, with much focus being placed on Nichols' flashy and off-kilter style, as well as an encroaching sense of melancholy typified by the penultimate shot of Elaine and Benjamin on the bus, reviewing their decision. Better on a second watch, I'd say.

Here's the thing with The Graduate, celebrating it's fiftieth anniversary you'd think there'd be some aspect of it that doesn't hold up. Some of the writing or dialogue would seem dated by now. You'd think that, or at least I did. I hadn't seen Mike Nichols masterpiece for quite some time. When I first experienced The Graduate, I might've been a bit too young to fully appreciate it. I must've only been about ten years old, or round about that age. At that age the film struck me as different. The normal things that everyone talks about, the infamous opening and closing shots, the surprisingly serious plot points that seem more fitting for a deadly serious drama instead of a comedy and of course Simon and Garfunkel's iconic soundtrack, it just wasn't what I was expecting. I enjoyed it back then, but obviously I needed to reevaluate it.
This was long overdue another watch and when it was set for a short theatrical release to acknowledge its milestone birthday, I couldn't say no. Well, it came, and went. A week of bad show times that I just couldn't make. I then went on holiday, and missed it again in a different cinema. Once I came back after a two week break, I was pleasantly surprised that I had one last chance. Not only that, but it was the best possible experience out of all three. A cheap ticket, the largest screen in the cinema and to top it all off, a new 4K restoration. The Graduate has gotten nothing but critical acclaim since its release back in 1967. The writing, direction by Nichols and acting from the entire cast has been applauded and awarded. And rightfully so. As The Graduate is not only a hilarious coming-of-age tale with unexpected outcomes, but also an excellent window into what life was like at that moment and time. And more than anything else, it holds up, a lot.
Benjamin has just graduated from college and he's returned to his home. Where all that's waiting for him is loneliness and the incredibly strong sense that he doesn't know what he wants to do with his future. He's lost and doesn't know where to go in his life. Then, Mrs. Robinson walks in and offers him something new, something rebellious.
The character of Benjamin not only set off the career of the very talented Dustin Hoffman, but also provided him with one of his greatest performances. One that is very hard to top. Here, Hoffman is phenomenal. Beginning with his motionless stance on a moving walkway to his final, terrified stare into the unknown. He perfectly encapsulates the fear and sadness that is felt when the future isn't clear, when there's nothing to look forward to or fall back on. In moments where he longingly gazes into his fish tank, or sinks to the bottom of his swimming pool. Moments of utter silence, where all he does is look and think. He gives Benjamin so much depth and personality. He's not just the lead character in a romantic comedy. He's conflicted, a character that wants to be, as he puts it, different. Thanks to this, when Benjamin finally has something meaningful in his life, something to look forward to in the form of Mrs. Robinson, Hoffman's excitement and hesitation mix together perfectly. He delivers the comedy instantly and, it looks like, without even trying. He portrays the shy and quiet aspect brilliantly. He's scared and inexperienced which leads to hilarity. But once these meetings become frequent, he falls back into the meaningless of it all. Hoffman portrays a character that shouldn't always be likeable, as likeable. The events that he partakes in, the consequences from his actions, and he doesn't care. He's only worried about himself, and what he can do to find meaning. But I really like him. He's funny, charming and the character you want to see succeed the most. Especially with the age that I am now, I can relate to Benjamin more than ever. Hoffman's been undeniably incredible in many things, but this performance is the one I'll instantly think of when his name pops up.
Anne Bancroft also delivers an iconic performance. Not only does she define the term "cougar" better than anyone else, she also perfectly portrays a person that's living a life that she doesn't want. Up until a certain conversation, Bancroft teases and seduces in a masterful way and that's all she does, but when we finally learn about her, when Ben realises who she is as a person, it's quite sad. She's just as lost in this world as Benjamin, but instead of having a future in which anything could happen, she's stuck firmly where she is. Bancroft and Hoffman together perfect the art of awkward conversations and comedy. Katharine Ross portrays Mrs. Robinson's daughter and her character's the one deserving of the most sympathy. Honestly, Ross gives the character of Elaine such an upbeat, kind and likeable quality. She's introduced with a beautiful smile and in a polite manner. And all she gets is mistreated, lied to and forced into who she can and cannot see. In the moments where she's having fun with Hoffman the film can be classed as a romantic comedy, but those scenes are far apart. She too does a fantastic job in the final moments of the film.
When I first heard about The Graduate, I was lead to believe that it was a romantic comedy. That's what I went in looking for the first time I saw it, and even though it does have romantic plot points, and it most certainly is funny, I wouldn't say that's the best way to describe the story. The focus here isn't so much on Ben and Mrs. Robinson's relationship, nor Ben and Elaine's relationship. It's a coming-of-age drama. One that's not necessarily happy and light. Ben's just out of college and has no idea what he wants to do. Thinking about a future in which there's nothing for you isn't that much of a happy thought. He's expected to do amazing things by his family. When Mrs. Robinson comes into the picture, Ben's not thinking about anyone else. He doesn't see the implications that could happen even if they get caught. He sees something different, which is exactly what he wants. When the fairytale aspect comes into play, the film doesn't forget this. As the closing of the movie drags Ben back down to reality, back to thinking about his future which may not be as open as it once was. The Graduate is a comedy though. It's hilarious and I was smiling throughout most of the film. It's really entertaining.
Mike Nichols won the Best Director award at the Oscars for this film, and it's understandable why. It's really well paced and the subject matter never gets diluted by the tone. Serious matters are tackled seriously instead of just being thrown around. Also the transitions are incredible. There's a montage in the middle of the film that shows the passing of time in which the affair is happening, and it's flawless. The cinematography is also superb. Shots are impeccably framed, creating a very stylish and iconic looking movie. I've no doubt that the '60s were cool, but this makes the '60s look cool. The soundtrack by Simon and Garfunkel works with the film. Instead of just being a soundtrack full of amazing songs, they actually add weight to the film and certain scenes. The opening and closing in which The Sound of Silence is played over, or the excellent use of Mrs. Robinson as Ben drives like a maniac to reach Elaine in time. The Graduate can be viewed as a romantic comedy. I enjoyed it like that a few years ago when I first saw it. It's hilarious and extremely entertaining due to the incredible cast. But, when you actually sit down and watch it, when you really invest your time in the film, you'll see that it's much more. Benjamin becomes scarily familiar, and with his story of loneliness and being lost in this world, the overall impact of the film is stronger. It still feels relevant fifty years later. It's perfect.

There was absolutely no reason I can think of that Elaine actually wanted to be with Ben, which was going to be my main criticism for the movie, but that final sequence in the church made the whole thing worthwhile and I no longer care about how unrealistic it all was.
One of the strangest ‚Äòromance‚Äô movies I‚Äôve ever seen, with a soundtrack of amazing songs that they for some reason chose to play on repeat over and over which kind of removed some of the enjoyment from them, but my main takeaway from this, which I cannot understate enough, is that Dustin Hoffman puts in one of the most absolutely insane, unhinged, socially awkward, unintentionally funny performances I‚Äôve ever seen. I had no idea how this movie would end once I saw there was 5 minutes left, but watching him fend people off with a crucifix and was better than anything I could‚Äôve come up with.

One of those classics that for whatever reason I have failed to see. I have seen it on stage at the Dundee Rep, Irene McDougall was the brave actress revealing all that night, receiving all the gasps from the audience.
I find it difficult to like this version of Ben, that wasn't the case on the stage production so I see the issue being Hoffman. I have never been a fan of Hoffman, yeah I like Marathon Man, Tootsie and the President's Men but he remains a big stumbling block for me, especially in things like Midnight Cowboy and Papillion. I didn't engage with Ben here and really didn't want him to succeed, God forbid you should end up married to that little middle class prick for the rest of time.
It's saved for me by a great, very sexy performance by Bancroft. In two contrasting scenes she is both hilarious and then later tragic. The first is where Ben awkwardly moves in for a kiss before she is able to exhale smoke from her cigarette, just done beautifully. Then later when she and Ben are wet from the rain, Ben goes to confess to Elaine about his relationships with her mother, the camera is on Bancroft, panning out to reveal her in the corner of this stark room, seemingly broken by the revelation. Just brilliant.
The music is of course outstanding.

I've been wanting to watch this for a very long time. My mother brings it up a lot and she's always been a big fan of Dustin Hoffman. I liked The Graduate and I'm rating it a 4/5, but I feel slightly disappointed. I'll get into the negatives later.
The performances are really great. I can't say I've ever had the love for Dustin Hoffman that my mother has, but I thought he was good in this. The cinematography was a surprising standout. There are some seriously gorgeous frames here that I didn't expect at all. Often in films like this the cinematography is an afterthought, but it was towards the top of their priorities for sure. The editing, which is not something ai usually pay attention to, was some of the best I've seen in a while. During the iconic time lapse scene of Benjamin's meets with Mrs. Robinson there are some very impressive cuts and transitions that made that scene so much more interesting.
All that being said, I still expected more. Or rather something a bit different. Based on opinions from others I figured it would be much funnier film. I found it more frustrating than funny. This leads me to my primary issue, the writing. I know it's sort of the point, but Hoffman's character is such a loser. He starts out on one end of loser spectrum and the other side by the end of the film. He never does anything that makes me want to root for him. Even by the end of the film when we're meant to cheer him on for trying to get his act together I honestly wanted him to fail.

Minor Spoilers:
My least favorite part is that I can't possibly understand why Elaine would want to even look at Benjamin after learning the truth. He slept with your mom basically every day for a month and you still "love him"? Not buying it.

I really did enjoy my time with The Graduate, but for such a highly regarded film I thought I was in for an easy 5/5.

The first watch is for relating to Benjamin Braddock: baby boom detritus haplessly thrown from conveyer belt to hotel room to chapel. But the second watch is for relating to Mrs. Robinson, a woman further down the line on the conveyer belt whose loveless marriage has repressed her passion. What makes the imagery here as iconic as it is really is the fact that it's a brilliant bait-and-switch, emphasizing and eroticizing the age gap between Ben and Mrs. Robinson (notably both adults); their affair is by far the most socially constructive relationship depicted in the film, wherein he learns about the rules and regulations of dating. By the film's end, he's tried as hard as he can to approximate the cowardliness-masked-as-pragmatism that the world was built for, and lands in a situation where absolutely no one is happy. Play stupid games, etc.
