What a journey. The movie presents itself as a shallow, fun and exotic comedy but in reality hides deep in itself so many hints for an existential introspection all for the viewer to explore. The structure, the editing, the cinematography was solo ahead of its time.. The characters are just so deeply studied and brilliantly performed: for more than half of it I thought that Mrs. Robinson was actually one of the good guys and that she had something to her that made her really complex and fascinating to read and I wish I'd seen her more; one of the best villains of all time. Even though we are left with some questions to be answered (like what was the dynamic between the families? Was it something that happened in the past that led the Robinson's to act like that toward Benjamin?) the finale makes us forget everything, answering the question that matters the most. As a big fanatic of music in movies I have to say that I don't mind Simon&Garfunkel being played over and over and actually it worked better than some other movies (it was one of the first movies to have not composed music in a film).

What can I say about a movie that has been talked about to hell and back since its release? It‚Äôs undeniably iconic, and now that I‚Äôve seen it for the first time I can finally join the consensus. The Graduate is very good!
I finally took the plunge and watched this because in the book I‚Äôm reading, ‚ÄòGlorious Birds: A Celebratory Homage to Harold and Maude‚Äô, the author Heidi Greco draws parallels between the two films and talks about how much The Graduate must have inspired screenwriter Colin Higgins. I can definitely see the similarities. Besides the ‚Äòyoung man has an affair with older woman‚Äô plot, the loneliness, awkwardness, and overall dissatisfaction with life on display from Benjamin‚Äôs character is definitely comparable to Bud Cort‚Äôs Harold. However, The Graduate ditches some of the darkness present in Harold and Maude and replaces it with a more conventional sense of humour and a more conventional love story, too.
Being 21 myself, it‚Äôs easy to relate to Ben‚Ä¶ well, besides the affair with a MILF and running away with someone else‚Äôs bride at their wedding. But really, I don‚Äôt think the essence of Dustin Hoffman‚Äôs character has dated at all. Young people are always going to be lost when entering the world of adulthood, and I think that‚Äôs a big reason why The Graduate has remained so popular and relevant.
The camerawork is gorgeous, the repetitive use of Simon & Garfunkel songs to score the movie works brilliantly, and the story is just so exciting to watch. (Oh, and I have to mention that as a vintage Barbie doll collector, spotting the 1960s Barbie wearing the Enchanted Evening dress in Elaine‚Äôs room was pretty cool!)

A fantastic film and a true classic. The cinematography and editing are clever and creative, the direction is superb, the acting from Hoffman and Bancroft are outstanding, and the soundtrack is one of the best and most iconic in cinema. This is a more complex film than I anticipated, and can be interpreted in many different ways. You can view it as a showcase of the fear and uncertainty young people face going into adulthood. You can view it as a study of creepy obsession. You can also even view it as a satire of youth culture.
I‚Äôm not sure why it took me until age 24 to view this film. But I‚Äôm glad I finally got around to it, even if it was years too late.

Not for me. 
An absolute masterwork. One of the greatest, the most essential American films. I feel so alive after watching this again. It‚Äôs such a dense, wonderful tapestry of characters and dialogue and details that Nichols puts there for us. Dustin Hoffman is astonishing, yes, and Anne Bancroft is simply superb - but dammit, this is Nichols‚Äô film. 
It‚Äôs a phase that we all go through, that aimlessness that comes about between the end of our youth and the beginning of our adulthood. Benjamin Braddock‚Äòs just done four years of college, he‚Äôs absolutely aced his work, his parents bought him a car - but for what? *Naturally* a beautiful older woman seduces him and he subsequently falls in love with her daughter. What a fantastical, dreamlike story - I think that‚Äôs why it works so well. So many of the details and shots and supporting characters turn this into an surrealist dark comedy. This movie works in so many ways, it‚Äôs perfect for so many moods, it just *works*. 
It‚Äôs sad, it‚Äôs happy, it‚Äôs funny, it‚Äôs scary, it‚Äôs unpredictable, it‚Äôs completely wild. The fact that it came out over fifty years ago is just insane so me. It‚Äôs truly timeless, the kind of thing the human race should want to be remembered for. Some of the best filmmaking of all time is present in this thing, and we should never take it for granted. The Graduate is a fucking mammoth.

After making his directorial debut (some consider it a surprise) with the excellent Who‚Äôs Afraid of Virginia Woolf?, Mike Nichols‚Äô next film would be this classic comedy drama, an adaptation of the novel of the same name by Charles Webb, which was published four years earlier, in which a young graduate who falls in love with an older married woman but then finds himself falling in love with her daughter.
Benjamin Braddock (Dustin Hoffman) has just ended college and, back at his parents' house, he's trying to escape the one question everyone keeps asking him: What does he want to do with his life?
An unanticipated change pops up when he is seduced by Mrs. Robinson (Anne Bancroft), a fed up housewife and friend of his parents. But what begins as an enjoyable encounter turns difficult when Benjamin falls in love with the one woman Mrs. Robinson wanted him to keep absent from - her daughter, Elaine (Katharine Ross)
Dustin Hoffman gives one of the most memorable performances in his role as Benjamin, ‚ÄòThe Graduate‚Äô (hence the title) student who is torn between the two loves and he has to make a really difficult decision about who he loves the most. He also acts like he is determined to dodge the question that really keeps bothering him.
Hoffman suits his role really well and this is his breakthrough role. This performance definitely made him an actor to look out for at the time of this release and without any doubt makes the most of the time he has on the screen. He certainly could not have played the part of Benjamin any better.
Anne Bancroft gives one of her best performances in her role as Mrs Robinson, the woman who acts like she makes it very clear to Benjamin that he stays away from her daughter. There is one particular scene involving the two leads which had one of the all-time classic quotes ‚Äì ‚ÄúMrs Robinson, are you trying to seduce me?!‚Äù
This is perhaps Anne Bancroft‚Äôs most memorable role of her career and she suits the part really well and definitely makes the most of the time she has on the screen.
Elsewhere, Katharine Ross is superb in her supporting role as Elaine, Bancroft‚Äôs daughter who Benjamin begins to date, despite what Mrs Robinson said to him.
The direction from Mike Nichols is excellent because he allows the facial expressions to be seen to a strong effect throughout, while the script is written to a very decent standard by Calder Willingham and Buck Henry as they make the movie really easy to follow.
The technical aspects that stand out best are the camera and editing, because the camera makes very good use of the locations and also captures the tense moments well, which deservedly get the edge-of-the-seat status, while the movie is edited to an excellent standard.
The Simon and Garfunkel soundtrack is awesome to listen to.
The movie saw Mike Nichols win the Academy Award for Best Director and because of this, it means that The Graduate was the first and will probably be the last film to win Best Director and nothing else.
But the Academy also deservedly nominated for: Best Picture, Best Actor (Dustin Hoffman), Best Actress (Anne Bancroft), Best Supporting Actress (Katharine Ross), Best Adapted Screenplay (Calder Willingham and Buck Henry) and Best Cinematography (Robert Surtees).
At the British Academy Film Awards, the movie won the awards for Best Film, Best Director (Mike Nichols), Best Screenplay (Calder Willingham and Buck Henry), Best Film Editing (Sam O‚ÄôSteen) and Most Promising Newcomer to Leading Film Roles (Dustin Hoffman).
The British Academy also deservedly nominated for: Best Actress (Anne Bancroft) and Most Promising Newcomer to Leading Film Roles (Katharine Ross). Ross was unlucky to have been nominated with Hoffman in this category. If I had it my way, this category would have been a two-way tie.
At the Golden Globes, the movie won the award for: Best Motion Picture ‚Äì Comedy or Musical ‚Äì but this a disagree with, because I don‚Äôt consider this to be the funniest film to have been released in this year.
On the other hand, the Hollywood Foreign Press Association also deservedly awarded the film Best Director (Mike Nichols), Best Actress ‚Äì Comedy or Musical (Anne Bancroft), Most Promising Male Newcomer (Dustin Hoffman) and Most Promising Female Newcomer (Katharine Ross). It also deservedly got nominations for: Best Actor ‚Äì Comedy or Musical (Dustin Hoffman) and Best Screenplay (Calder Willingham and Buck Henry).
I am thrilled Dustin Hoffman, Anne Bancroft and Katharine Ross all won something for their fantastic parts in this film rather than nothing, because they would have been very unlucky to have walked away empty-handed.
Overall, The Graduate is a comedy-drama that absolutely deserves to have its classic status. It works so well due to the excellent performances from Dustin Hoffman, Anne Bancroft and Katharine Ross, along with Mike Nichols‚Äô brilliant direction and the well written script.

The Graduate gets better every time I see it. It has taken me quite a long time to recognise its brilliance. I have seen it every few years since I was fifteen, and now in my early thirties I fully acknowledge its masterpiece status. I think most people come to this conclusion fairly quickly and early with The Graduate. The Graduate is an easy film to like, it is remarkably and consistently funny throughout its 100 minutes, it has two superb performances from Anne Bancroft and Dustin Hoffman and an incredibly likeable one from Katherine Ross; it is directed with a wild invention and has one of the great song-track soundtracks. The refrain of "Hello, darkness my old friend" becomes more and more resonant every time it is used. A wonderful melding of sound and picture.
The aspect of the film that most stood out to me on this viewing was Mike Nichols ability with the camera and his direction to tell jokes, highlights lines and underline comprehension. There is a lovely moment where the three main characters are in the same space and it dawns on Elaine (Katherine Ross) what has been happening, Nichols draws from out of focus to into focus, Ross has a slight look on her face and all of the audience understands that she understands without the need for any dialogue. It is a small moment, but Nichols is fully in control of the film.
The Graduate is uproariously funny, glib and witty; it treats existential ennui with a perpendicular irreverance. Nichols has a wonderful command of the material, the first half hour is particularly amusing, the initial seduction scene remains one of the great sequences in all film. Anne Bancroft steals the whole film for me. Her character, I think now, is the most sympathetic, there is genuine pain to her performance and the character evokes great empathy, even when she is lashing out. It is a remarkably atuned piece of work. Though, I will say Anne Bancroft is clearly not old enough to play Katherine Ross mother and Dustin Hoffman's older woman, she is easily still in her thirties and, frankly, looks amazing.
Dustin Hoffman's stammering Ben is really fun to watch, I love the transformation that goes through him during the film, particularly towards the end. His passive existential distress giving away to a frenetic desire, willingness to throw everything away for essentially not much. All underlined by Nichols in one of cinema's best, and most ambiguous endings. An ending that gets sadder and sadder every time I see it.
Wes Anderson owes a heavy debt to this film, he has been lifting its style and themes for twenty years, but I am not sure he has ever made a film quite as good. Quite as affecting or effective. You'll laugh through your tears and sing lines from Simon and Garfunkel the rest of the day.

Can't do it justice in a full review after just one watch but wow this really captured me. Was meaning to watch this for ages and was spurred on after starting Geoff King's "New Hollywood Cinema: An Introduction" for class and finding mentioned often as one of the key founding texts for the movement. And I can see why: here Benjamin is like American cinema in the 60s, alienated by the older, richer generation and only able to spring into life when youthful passion finally enters his world. I loved the scenes early on, at his parents' party and the diving suit sequence, his impotent desire to be treated like a grown man at odds with his lack of drive to do something with his life. And it's not Mrs Robinson or Elaine who gives him agency but himself, realising the world is moving on beneath him and it won't wait for him to find his feet. Loved loved loved it.

The initial helter skelter emotional outpouring from Ben seems a bit heavy handed but it‚Äôs so assured in itself and quickly becomes finely tuned as the film progresses. An enigmatic experience that recants any fling, crush, love you may have had. The pool scene fade to phone booth was such a brilliant invasion of headspace I almost found myself letting out an audible gasp.

Benjamin's shakiness and agitation, his DIY haircut, his clammy face, his wide-open glazed eyes, his bizarre timidity, his feeble whimpers, and his general atmosphere are all extremely unnerving. Actually, he's unbearable. I've had anxiety before; this is a fucking creepy weirdo. Hoffman's‚Äîdare I say it‚Äîshoddy acting (especially his strange intonations) unintentionally heightens this further.
Even the scene with the scuba equipment follows the same tone, as the camera slowly zooms out as Benjamin sinisterly lies motionless at the very bottom of the pool, the cloudy water slowly obscuring his figure. It was at this moment that Benjamin decided to murder his entire family with a corkscrew. That doesn't happen, but after the first 25 minutes that seems more likely than the real plot.

Re-watching The Graduate is something I've been wanting to do for a while now. The first time I reviewed this, I gave this film a 9/10. I severely regret this now. 
They just don't make movies like this anymore. 
This film drives by so quickly. It sucks you in right from the beginning. Benjamin is one of the most interesting characters ever developed. His sexual struggles and desires, his often awkwardness, and his worriness about the future is so believable. Hoffman turns into the character itself with so much ease and transformation. 
Do you honestly get better than the ending as well? It's triumphant and insane. 
The soundtrack, especially the songs by Simon and Garfunkel are timeless and so catchy to this day. 
This is the classic that will stand the test of time forever. It's so relatable and iconic. And, I don't mean it's relatable in that you're sleeping with your parent's friend. I'm talking about the struggles of becoming an adult. I'm 15, and I'm worried about my future. What kind of job will I get? Will I succeed? Will I get to marry someone? The people around us expect certain things from us. Benjamin is constantly surrounded by people telling him the path to life. That's why this is so damn relatable. The future is scary to be completely honest. You hope for happiness, but many things can happen. It's just how we make our lives. One last thing, the editing in this movie is flawless. I really don't understand why this didn't win the Best Editing Oscar.
I swear though, if Hollywood remakes this, I'm starting a damn petition.

As every generation comes of age, they think they are the first to rebel against convention and expectation ‚Äì that they are the first to see the world for what it is. No matter how specific the injustices that youth rails against, this energy to rebel always manifests in some form. One view would be that this is a product of the naivety of the youth; the other is that it is the consequence of the ability of previous generations to reconcile an unfair world.
It is in the universality of this generational urge to rebel that The Graduate gains its lasting power. From its iconic opening scene, we see that Benjamin Braddock feels isolated from the strange world that he has arrived into. He is static and expressionless, fixed to the same spot. But the technological winds of change motion him onwards regardless, in the form of the airport travelator. This sense of someone withdrawing and letting the world wash over him is seen again and again upon his return home, surrounded by the mediocrity and conformity of middle-aged suburbia. Day after day of aimless pool drinking and sordid homewrecking compound, blurring into one another.
Benjamin only comes to life when his path crosses with the only other person his age in this middle-class purgatory. Here, our would-be rebel discovers his cause. In Elaine Robinson, he sees an escape from his stifling surroundings. But the film more broadly suggests a sense of social rebellion writ large, highlighting student movements and agitators as the film moves from suffocating suburbia to the restless energy of the Berkley campus. Although Benjamin himself seems ignorant of anything beyond his own desires, his own small rebellion can thus be seen to relate to a broader sense of discontented youth.
Key to communicating this sense of withdrawal giving way to rebellion is the visual language of The Graduate. Images are beautifully composed and lit, particularly in the way that heavy shadows obscure faces and occasionally whole personages ‚Äì the shadowy vices hidden underneath idyllic suburbia. The camera largely moves with the same laconic energy as Benjamin, with zooms at key moments conveying isolation. But are so many flourishes of momentary genius that inject life into this, including something as basic as the slow refocusing of the camera on Elaine‚Äôs face as the truth about her mother and Benjamin dawns.
More important still is the editing, which evocatively captures how Benjamin‚Äôs withdrawal translates into empty summer days that blend into one another. Fades and one iconic match cut reflect the hazy passage of time. But as the film arrives in its final third, the purpose that Benjamin now feels reflects in a more energetic sense of pacing and narrative progression scene-to-scene. We can feel the newfound sense of purpose, as time seems to speed up rather than blur.
Of course, the emotional ambivalence of the ending hangs a question mark over this newfound purpose. Finally, Benjamin and Elaine triumph over the demands and restrictions imposed by the previous generation. As they make their escape from a lifetime of conformity and repression, their exuberance seems to be exploding out of them. But as the adrenaline and novelty of freedom wears off, their expressions become pensive. They‚Äôve won the freedom to truly forge their own lives, but what does that freedom actually mean? Sat in a bus that could be heading anywhere, neither Elaine nor Benjamin can answer that question.

The Graduate perfectly depicts what it's like to be lost and scared about growing up for good. Everyone in The Graduate is unraveling, some more quickly than others, and there's no right way to have an existential crisis. It's a brilliant choice to have every character based in an uncertainty or discontent that is never quite defined--just generally felt and understood.
Dustin Hoffman and Anne Bancroft are both fantastic, the Simon and Garfunkel soundtrack is lightly somber, slightly cryptic, and very fitting, and even the scene transitions in this film are more artistic than they have any‚Ä¶

As I was looking through my movie collection, searching for a feel-good film to watch tonight to remedy the bad evening I was having, I came across my Criterion Collection edition of The Graduate that I bought on my 19th birthday a little over a month ago. The craving for a stereotypical "feel-good" movie went out the window instantly. I hadn't seen the Criterion edition yet and immediately knew this was going to be the right choice for tonight.
First, the transfer. The beautiful 4K restoration. Jesus. Everything looks so vibrant. Everyone looks so beautiful.
Second, I've seen it about once a year since I first watched it as a thirteen year old and it's so interesting to see it now as a college student. This is also my first time watching since graduating from high school. You pick up on the themes a lot better the older you get, I think. You understand Benjamin more the older you get. Actually, this summer I was Benjamin.
Third, "I've had this feeling ever since I graduated. This kind of compulsion that I have to be rude all the time. It's like I was playing some kind of game, but the rules don't make any sense to me. They're being made up by all the wrong people. I mean no one makes them up. They seem to make themselves up." Dead on.

It's been a bit since I last watched The Graduate. And even the last time I watched it I feel like I wasn't giving it my 100% attention. The movie has a well known reputation for being a comedy film, but this time around I found it tone closer to the drama side of things, edging on pure dark comedy.
In some sense I think I'm beginning to subscribe a bit to the thinking of the great Roger Ebert, who came to see a swap in roles between Bancroft and Hoffman. In the beginning it's painstakingly obvious that Mrs. Robinson is in the cougar role. She is looking for an outlet. We don't really find out why until later, but for the first section the film she is 100% in control.
Then, after the two finally do the big deed, I noticed a massive shift in dynamic through two scenes. The first is the losing of Ben's virginity, with a dreamy sequence of Ben finally floating on the water (as opposed to being under it as we've seen up to this point) and shifting between his life at home and his life in the hotel room now with Mrs Robinson. The whole sequence is punctuated by an outstanding use of Simon and Garfunkel's April Come She Will. We get the passage of time as well as the literal shift in persona on Hoffman's face.
The second scene that truly shifts the dynamic is, I believe, the final time the two meet in the hotel room. This is where Bancroft truly gets the moment to shine and steals the scene totally from Hoffman. She conveys so much through such simple, painful, sadness in her eyes. The conversation concerning where the two are at, how they feel about this morally, and the prospect of Mrs. Robinson's returning daughter Elaine.
Now normally, this first half of the movie or so is where I consider things to be at a perfect pacing. Moving into the second half is where I usually start to take some minor issues with the films somewhat outdated techniques and mindsets. Even some of the plot points I began to question as usual. The idea of wanting to get married after a single date seems antiquated on the surface, even if it ties in with Ben's act first think second mindset. Perhaps my largest issue with this part is Ben essentially stalking Elaine and this being perceived as "healthy" or "loving". Perhaps thats just a ploy to lure us into thinking these two might have a chance after all. Maybe Ben really can stop the wedding and get the girl of his dreams! Fortunately the film doesn't take the easy way out, and while I never found Ben sympathetic to begin with, this time I found him downright unlikable.
You see after the dynamic shifts I don't believe that Ben is still the dewey eyed moon cow that he is in the beginning. He gets cocky, he gets arrogant and reckless. While some people see this movie in a negative light because of the way it portrays Mrs Robinson as a predator, i'm beginning to realize thats a false analysis. Mrs Robinson, is a depressed, alcoholic and lonely woman who puts on the facade of being the strong, controlling type, but as the film wears on and the mask breaks down we see just how damaged she is. Ben was so clearly taking advantage of her by the end I'm surprised I never read it this way before.
It's all completely punctuated by that final shot. The happy couple on the bus, finally beat the mean, cliche adults who wanted to tell them what to do, only to sit for a moment and realize just how naive and downright stupid their thinking is. As Elaine looks over to Ben with hope in her eyes and Ben looks straight ahead, never looking at her, we see all the pain he's caused to others rush into his headspace. He fucked up. He know's it, and he's not likely to admit it at this point. Yet the two go on towards an uncertain future, and one I picture is just the beginning of his own misery.
This review may contain spoilers.

A delicately directed swirl of indirect sympathy and a almost disconnection from reality in a silly fantasy that is never complete, perpetually going. With at the center, Dustin Hoffman‚Äôs character being quite literally successful, at something he doesn‚Äôt know if he wants to. He‚Äôs any graduate, clumsily running around in a funny, bleak fashion cause only now, he takes his steps on his own.
He makes big gestures, and is easily taken back and forth, seeing new things left and right ‚Äî doing all the above.
But he looks away right after.
Remaining in bed with Mrs. Robinson, somehow living in complete darkness as they make love, routinely staring off.
Nothing moves forward, Mrs. Robinson, Elaine, and Benjamin are all just sort of forced to or go for it, there is no reasoning. It‚Äôs the most saddest love triangle ever, and one that is meant to be funny. It is quite funny, but then..
 The sounds of silence, creeping in their brains.
 It somehow remains even in the most happy of places.
And so does the legacy of this film, somehow. And at this point you probably even know certain scenes even without watching it. 
It‚Äôs almost ironic that it has become as iconic as it is. As if it should be shimmered in iconography and happy ol‚Äô references.
Trolls uses it as a joke, but it‚Äôs empty reverence for imagery.
The classic interruption, runaway wedding ending that has endlessly lived in hopeful or ironic laughter, is just a road to the same bus stop. Elaine and Benjamin have learned only to scream each others names, not to understand ‚Äî they have learned nothing. And somehow people forget that, a trick of the memory.
For a film about a loss of innocence, and trying to find direction without any teacher, people hold this movie in such happiness.
When it never was, and maybe, we were just trying to ignore the silence.

Hello, darkness my old friend.
A movie scientifically designed in a lab to cause an existential crisis in every young person regardless of the generation. A movie that uses humor as a razor-sharp tool to carve open the facade of false promises fed to fresh graduates in general and fresh male graduates in particular. A movie that is supremely erotic and sexually liberating without being exploitative or gratuitous.
The Graduate is a one-hour forty-five-minute long film school disguised as a motion picture. From the opening shot to the very last frame, every choice made by the filmmakers is a reminder of the kind of genius required to create true art. Nothing is ordinary. Nothing is safe. The rules of cinema are taken apart and put back together to create a unique grammar that has been endlessly referenced since 1967. Each scene is a complete story in itself, taking you on an emotional journey through the use of sweeping cinematography, dynamic staging, kinetic editing, and captivating performances.
Performances that are simultaneously incredibly natural and just heightened enough to be both relatable and entertaining. Anne Bancroft is devilishly gorgeous as the seductive Mrs. Robinson. She is heartbreakingly lonely. Just watching her face during each scene is an absolute treat. She paints a picture of a woman who had to make hard choices in her youth and is looking to rekindle the flame that once burned brightly. Dustin Hoffman, on the other hand, is wonderful as the dazed young boy trying to fit into a grown-up world. His back and forth (back and forth huh! get it? Nothing? okay) with Anne Bancroft is hilariously awkward and oddly romantic.
And obviously, the Simon and Garfunkel soundtrack is mesmerizing, melancholic, joyful, immersive, and frankly way better than what we deserve as a species.

Opening half is far stronger than the second, which uses Scarbourguh Fair about four times more than is absolutely necessary - but the surprisingly complex and layered script about disconnection and identity and drifting, landing on some powerful, thoughtful musings. The mighty fine performances from the cast elevate it further: I think this is easily my favourite Dustin Hoffman performance.

One of my favorite things in the whole world. This jumped to my second favorite movie and wouldn't be surprised if it became my favorite at some point. I've been dealing a lot lately with people trying to tell me what to do or what I can and cannot do (specifically my parents), not really knowing who I want to be, and the fact that I graduate college next summer with a degree in media theory. I related to Ben so much this time that I feel like I am him, but I'd be suspicious of anyone my age who didn't relate to him.
There's a melancholic feeling throughout but it's also hilarious. It's the kind of humor I love and wish I could write. To me the sadness washes over you as soon as it's over. Even without Simon and Garfunkel's wonderful music this would be a masterpiece, but with it it's one of the greatest movies ever made. This is my 5th time watching it and it does not show one sign of wearing on me.
I know the ending is supposed to be dark, how they got away but they still probably won't make it together much like Mr. and Mrs. Robinson, but I also think it's optimistic. If you're going to fail you should fail on your own accord. For once, Ben and Elaine made their own decision to do something rather than listening to what other people told them. Maybe we're all bound to fail and we should fail our way and not someone else's.

‚ÄúSimpsons did it!‚Äù
Gugh! Throughout the entire church scene that line kept going through my head! At one point I just hoped Dustin Hoffman would fall through the window Abe Simpson style. Guess that's what comes with it being an American classic I suppose.
I've mentioned this in my first Force Awakens review, but like Mrs Robinson, classic films can sometimes rub me the wrong way. Sometimes it feels like I'm watching this faded relic made for another audience. Clunkiness sometimes can be more noticeable, the messages can grow irrelevant the more time has passed, and the praise can set it on a pedestal so high a new viewer could possibly never reach it. The Graduate thankfully doesn't fall into (most of) those traps, still holding up as the delightfully cynical tale that inspired so many films today.
The film follows Benjamin Braddock (Dustin Hoffman) an introvert graduate student that has no clue where he's heading. What course did he study? Who knows. What did he do during his four years there? Beats me. What career does he want to purs- ‚Äúyou know what, stop asking me that‚Äù is what he'll say, since he sure doesn't have the answer himself. From the minute Braddock walks aimlessly into frame, as we hear Simon & Garfunkel‚Äôs "The Sound of Silence‚Äù in the iconic airport opening shot, you understand just how isolated and unguided he really is. Benjamin in a way is like myself, and many other students transitioning from youth to maturity: Existing, without any clue where life will take us. Right off the bat, that's scary shit, man. Really. And it should have freaked the fuck out of its 1967 audience, because even today, god damn.
Once he returns home, he reluctantly finds himself in the arms of Mrs Robinson (Anne Bancroft) who wants nothing more than to make it rain, man (10 points if you get that). Her character could have been quite one dimensional, playing the sexual diva role up for pure comedic effect, but the film does make an effort to flesh her out. Yes, in a sense she does just want to jump on Dustin Hoffman‚Äôs tootsie roll (try go for 20 points), but we see she too is lost. Once having ambitions of her own in school, which were blocked by her own aimless actions and inactions that lead her here. Left with a marriage she doesn't care for, having an affair with a twenty-something year old introvert, and raising her daughter Elaine (Katharine Ross) who Ben of course grows an undying, ungrounded infatuation for.
The way Mike Nichols handles this relationship was quite interesting, particularly because of how annoyed it got me. We see that Elaine is quite similar to Ben, as the two seem to be searching desperately for the privilege they feel due, both of which wanting this through a romanticised, fake version of love and false attraction to one another. While the development of this wasn't as pitch perfect as I wanted it to be, the ending immediately leaves you cold as the characters themselves begin to realise the unfulfilled hole left in their hearts, unsure how long this relationship will last, with their desires still yet to be filled. All told through three shots, facial expression and one simple song. It's brilliant storytelling.
In regards to negatives, I did have a few things I couldn't really get behind. A minor aspect was some of the dialogue and performances feeling a bit "showy" and artificial, particularly the parents and relatives, that never really sucked me out of the movie, but it did distract. The part I did find troubling was the execution of Elaine and Ben. I totally understand the relationship is meant to develope quickly. That's what makes the final shot brilliant. One issue I had was it felt almost *too* instantaneous. As though the film took place over the span of two weeks, at least six of those days the two knowing each other and by end she has already considered marrying two guys. One of which she's actually going through with. A rewatch may help, but that transition of time in this viewing just wasn't as clear as I wanted it to be. In addition to that, Ben had this looming predatory vibe over Elaine towards the third act, which didn't reinforce the ending, but instead made me question how they both mutually got to that point. After his affair is revealed to her, Ben constantly tries to win her back, and we see this with him following her to the library, pursuing her on the bus, pursuing her to the Zoo (where she's meeting a guy) pressuring her for details about this guy, and by the end she goes along with the false romanticized idea. The ending still works, but before then it just made me a bit ill and left me wondering how A lead to C. Might need to think that over too.
The Graduate, despite all that, is pretty damn solid, people. And you are going to watch it‚Ä¶‚Äùaren't you‚Äù?

Why does everyone like this so much? How is this a "classic"? I don't get it.
For starters, don't cast a 30 year old to play a 20-21 year old. It looks absurd. Sometimes older actors can be passed off as younger characters and it works but there was no way a 30 year old Dustin Hoffman passed as a recent college grad. As such, any time that his father or family friend would ask him about schooling or any other young adult thing it would look ridiculous because Hoffman couldn't pull it off.
I'm almost certain my main qualm with this film, aside from the fact that it's boring, can be attributed to a generational difference. Maybe in 1967 it was normal for people to go on one date, fall in love, and discuss getting married. Nowadays that is very outlandish. Thus, when Ben and Elaine go on one date after not having seen each other for 4-5 years and claim to be in love and discuss marriage it comes off as farfetched and unrealistic. Maybe in 1967 this wouldn't have bothered me, but now, in 2014, it does. Unfortunately these era specific differences are usually what have caused me to not like the majority of old(er) films.
Had I watched this right after graduating college I don't know if it would've "spoken to me". That is what I kept hearing the past--that recent college grads should watch this as it deals with issues that those people will be dealing with. I am not so sure. Not much here seems relatable. Yes, Ben displays feelings of hopelessness and uncertainty regarding his post-college future, like most new graduates, but those sentiments are put on the back-burner and the film moves in a different, unrelated direction.
I am not at all surprised that I didn't like this too much.

Everybody's a little worried about their future, right? I know I sure am! And this classic captures that feeling so unbelievably well. Three performances and characters. Katherine Ross as Elaine, the future, the goals of a prosperous life. Anne Bancroft as Mrs. Robinson, the present, the desire to live now and only now. And Dustin Hoffman as the lost soul who gets torn between the two. Not only is the acting by all three spectacular, but the writing here is really something to behold. The whole movie, dialogue, cinematography, camera movement, zoom ins, zoom outs, soundtrack; it's all got such an infectious fun energy to it, while still maintaining the bubbling melancholy under the surface. 100 minutes feel like 40 with how feverishly this thing moves. The timelessness, the relatability, the humor, the music; it all had me entranced from moment one to that oh so beautiful ending, one that I'll probably be thinking about for a while. I loved this! I loved this a whole lot! But as I watched it, I couldn't help but realize how much I'll likely LOVE this someday. It's just that kind of movie. One that'll live forever.

This isn‚Äôt just a ridiculously fun and engaging film but it‚Äôs also expertly crafted. There are these masterful parallels between the camera movements/ shot selection and the dialogue to perfectly invoke feelings of anxiety and unnerves. Close and constant movement in the hallway full of people, but still and medium close ups when alone or with Mrs Robinson and then later removing this and replacing it with Elaine‚Äôs presence.
Most notable is that under the leg shot. It‚Äôs just breathtakingly good.
Dustin Hoffmans acting is so ranged as welll- he masters comedy, fear, and excitement, which brings another element to the well-crafted film that truly elevates it to one of the greatest of all time.
It feels as if everything is intentional with the camera but there‚Äôs an experimental side as well, which makes it feel fresh but impressive. 
It‚Äôs just an incredible film that‚Äôs a must-see.

"The Graduate" stirs up comedy and drama in its premise and it certainly does blend well together. The soundtrack and the cinematography are what make it iconic though. Throw in some amusing but well thought-out characters and we get a good story out of their dilemmas.
It may not be as grounded in reality as some might like it to be but I think that's part of the charm. It is a 'chasing dreams' sort of fantasy that only happens in our own heads and not in reality. This is probably what makes the Mrs. Robinson character sort of tragic but also devious in nature. While her daughter represents the 'eternal good & innocence' that Dustin Hoffman's character so desperately desires. The fact that they hit it off right away is what makes that desire feel so much more urgent and important than anything else.
By the end though we can see how rash decisions can stir up complicated and ambiguous moments that make the dream seem impossible, even when it is in the palm of our hands. Thus, we are left with the burning question; does everything turn out alright in the end? For me personally, I am left to believe that we are right back where we started when the ending credits roll. It is a great coming-of-age tale that recalls back to the similar works in literature that came before it. The whole 'life after college' bit is the main thing that will hook young adults too most likely. Not knowing what to do with one's future is probably something most of us have experienced before or eventually will. And that's when the rash decisions start coming into play.
Overall it is a fun ride. Dustin Hoffman plays the naive and gullible character very well but also supplies an emotional edge to him as well as the story progresses. His actions are not necessarily heroic but I did find myself rooting for him by the end. We get a good observer's view of all the events that unfold that keeps us entertained. The fact that the viewers get to draw their own conclusions by the end is what makes "The Graduate" memorable. The mixed feelings serve as a good statement on what life is like in general. Did Benjamin (Dustin Hoffman's character) make the right choice? To society's standards the answer would most likely be no. And so this film has a hidden cyclical nature to its premise and outcome. This is especially prevalent in the grey and morally ambiguous areas of the film. And since we see mostly what Benjamin sees and perceives, it is especially hard to discern what is going on in the minds of the others.
By the end the characters accomplish relatively little but it is the colorful journey that leads them to where they are at now that makes it all the worthwhile. Uncertain futures make for some great storytelling. It's probably more of a black comedy than anything else really and the 'humor' will most likely go over most peoples' heads. The showdown at the church is pretty hysterical though. Most people will probably really enjoy that one part of the film if not anything else. It's a personal favorite of mine and it is definitely worth a watch for those looking for a great onscreen affair.

The movie still works like gangbusters BUT I've always had a very big problem with Mrs. Robinson's complexities disappearing in the third act as she becomes just a one-dimensional villain. It really does her character a disservice as she's so strongly written in the rest of the movie!

Wow. 
I really don't know what to say.
This movie is just absolutely perfect in nearly every way imaginable. 
Dustin Hoffman gets so much emotion out of his performance as the desperate and neurotic Benjamin Braddock that by the third act you are just begging for him to come out okay.
Mrs. Robinson is one of the most memorable antagonists ever to be put to screen. She is so despicable and discomforting with her schemes against Ben, yet Anne Bancroft gives somewhat of an emotional center, showing a dissatisfied housewife just begging for something different in her life.
I shouldn't forget to mention Simon and Garfunkel's ominous and soothing soundtrack, creating some of the greatest songs of the century ("Hello darkness, my old friend...").
I found that the biggest reason for why The Graduate is such an essential film to be studied in classes is not the performances, but the tone set by the unnerving cinematography  and effective drama, mixed with a surprising amount of light-hearted comedy.
This will be a movie that I will think about for years to come, as a staple of my history of film-watching and as one of the greatest movies ever made.
(P.S. Thanks for letting me borrow the DVD, Truman.)

Love it when a movie is designed for two parallel viewing experiences: the standard romantic drama sexual awakening movie for most people, and a relentlessly anxious bad vibes watch for anyone with difficult family relationships and a history of being yelled at and manipulated by sexual partners. Fortunately (?), I got to have both viewing experiences, the former as an undergrad when I was assigned this movie for a class, the latter this afternoon.
It's so difficult to watch Ben, a terminally square figure destined for a standard, "safe" cishetero marriage by tragic circumstance suffer so much at the hands of the Robinsons in an uncommon inversion of the standard "outsider ruins family" plot. His desire for Elaine, seemingly motivated purely by it being in line with what his parents would expect of him, keeps him alive through some nasty body blows and truly psychotic behavior by her parents. But it is genuinely thrilling to see him transform from the anxious, autistic sheltered kid at the beginning into a fearless tiger by the end, and this energy sustained me through the totally incongruent happy ending.
The only reprieve from the tension is the road movie in the second half, which is regularly interrupted by the plot. I don't know if you know this, but the Simon and Garfunkel soundtrack in this movie is excellent. The way that "Mrs. Robinson" plays as Ben drives to the church, has its instrumental parts extended on his pit stops, and then slows and sputters out and ends with a loud chord when his car breaks down and he has to run the rest of the way is one of the best uses of music in one of the best bits of cinema of all time.

The first half to two-thirds of this movie were quickly and easily in my favorite movies of all time, because wow, what an incredible set up 
This is a fantastic example of a strong and simple premise executed perfectly, and the viewer is thrust into the film just as Benjamin is thrust into the real world
A million questions about the future, no answers in sight, and unable to enjoy the present. Until Mrs. Robinson. Yet as living in the present goes, eventually you have to move forward or look back, and this film does an incredible job at working through all three realms of time in a way that feels so organic and natural
Reminiscing on a life that is long gone, clinging to what you can. Trying to set up a future that brings you back to a time that is long gone. Doing whatever, or whoever, you want in the hopes of hanging on a bit longer. When the future is uncertain, we look to the last until we can‚Äôt anymore. Hopefully, by the time we look to the future again, there are still options available
Although this film goes off the rails a bit in the final third, that ending is so perfect and eases my qualms about how it gets there
Dustin Hoffman is a gem, and I can‚Äôt believe this is a debut because it feels as if they plucked an actual graduate out of class and into the film
He‚Äôs quirky, he‚Äôs clearly in so deeply over his head, and he‚Äôs just a charm to watch in the early half
Mrs. Robinson is such a fantastically layered character, and she really is the thematic crux of the whole film
I wish Elaine had more, because it would strengthen the ending and final third more in my opinion
There‚Äôs also so many nuances in this that are mind bogglingly great, such as the slow focus change when Elaine has her revelation or the deep zooms in and out with Ben and Mrs. Robinson
Plus, Simon and Garfunkel, I mean come on!

"Hello darkness my old friend..."
+Dustin Hoffman is excellent playing an awkward 21 year old- Ben Braddock. His facial expressions and mannerisms are spot on. Anne Bancroft is also great as Mrs Robinson.
+The film is shot really well, I loved the smooth scene transitions and cinematography. I can see why it was technically ground breaking for the time.
+The plot is enjoyable from start to finish.
+I really enjoyed the dark comedy, especially between Ben and Mrs Robinson.
+The Simon and Garfunkel soundtrack fit the tone of the film perfectly. In fact it's like one big Simon and Garfunkel music video.
+The final shot is iconic, I love the fact that the mood changes so quickly from excitement to what happens now?
-In the opening act there is a strange edit where Ben looks down at Mrs Robinson's body, and we see what he sees for literally 1 frame at a time. I get this is the effect that they were trying to achieve, but the edit looked choppy to me.
9/10
Overall- The Graduate is a timeless classic.

DID YOU KNOW- During rehearsals of Dustin Hoffman's and Anne Bancroft's first encounter in the hotel room, Bancroft did not know that Hoffman was going to grab her breast. Hoffman decided to do it because it reminded him of schoolboys trying to nonchalantly grab girls' breasts in the hall by pretending to put their jackets on. When Hoffman did it, Director Mike Nichols began laughing loudly. Hoffman began to laugh as well, so rather than stop the scene, he turned away and walked to the wall. Hoffman banged his head on the wall, trying to stop laughing, and Nichols thought it was so funny, it stayed in the finished film.

Ever since 'The Graduate' was referenced in the opening monologue of Marc Webb's '(500) Days of Summer' I had wanted to sit down and check it out.
This film packs an almighty punch. From the melancholy opening credits with Dustin Hoffman's Benjamin arriving home from college, to the movie's soul crushing final moments. This is not a feature for the faint of heart.
Mike Nichols produces a reflection of society that is still relevant today.
If it wasn't, would I really be this taken away by it? 
Described as a "comedy/drama," 'The Graduate' has more in common with an ancient tragedy than a modern comedic adventure. Hoffman's Ben falls for Mrs. Robinson, an alcoholic mother, and wife of his father's friend. Hoffman's neurotic and anxious acting has transcended into so many films these days. A truely remarkable performance.
Now, I finished high school (about) a month ago. And I find myself in a similar scenario to Ben. I'm not having an affair with my dad's friend's wife, don't worry. But I am struggling to work out where I am going to go next. Part of me wants to write, part of me wants to act. Then a whole other part of me feels one of these jobs may be too "dreamy" for an Adelaide boy. 
In some bizarre way, 'The Graduate' helped a lot. To see where you go, and what you do when you are not ready. In telling the tragedy of Ben and the Robinsons, Nichols has given this young author a boost in storytelling capacity.

Mike Nichols‚Äô 1967 comedy/drama ‚Äì newly restored and special edition-ed by the Criterion Collection ‚Äì was one of the key instigators of the New Hollywood movement, and as such, it‚Äôs hard to work up much of anything new to say about it. But a fresh viewing reveals that much of what‚Äôs stuck in the popular memory is all but confined to the first 30 minutes and the last ten, though the innovative use of pop music and inventive cutting reverberate throughout. Yet what‚Äôs strongest is the overall sense of displacement, the way Nichols uses off-angles, flash cutting, discombobulated sound, and general unsteadiness to create both empathy and detachment, and then ferociously tears those devices down with the rawness of Elaine‚Äôs discovery scene and their subsequent fight in his room in Berkeley. And even the iconic moments maintain their impact; you can watch this movie a dozen times and keep making discoveries in Ben and Elaine‚Äôs expressions in that famous penultimate image.

When one thinks of The Graduate, one has a multitude of feelings about it. The feelings range from the addictive Simon and Garfunkel soundtrack to the ridiculous the story itself. Mike Nichols in his sophomore film, created a classic piece of work that will continue to stand the test of time. It has such a ridiculous premise (and scandalous when it came out) but maintains a high level of realism in the process. Every character was portrayed with utmost passion,‚Ä¶
Not only does this film have a fantastic soundtrack, it has one of the best endings I have ever seen in a film.

The Graduate from my overall viewing experience is a good film that's worth a watch. While I personally don't see it as one of my all time favorites, it's visual style, soundtrack, acting and storytelling help to make it a captivating film.

Just brilliant from start to finish. It perfectly captures that depressive mood of having absolutely no ambition about your future.
Hoffman gives one of my favourite performances of all time. It's so dry and sad that you can't help but laugh. The scene where he's waiting behind the doors on his 21st birthday is honestly one of the funniest things ever to me - simply because of how perfectly and monatonously Hoffman delivers those lines.
As a viewer we know his decisions are completely eratic and probably terrible ideas - for instance, moving town to convince a woman who hates you to marry you. But we get so swept up in his spontaneouity that we can't help but root for him. It's so exciting watching him finally take control of his own life, regardless of our nagging doubts over how it will actually end up for him.
Ultimately this leads into that ending where he rushes to stop the wedding like a complete fucking lunatic. Despite being too late he just goes for it and is able to run off with Elaine in the end. And then we get that iconic final shot: one of the best movie endings of all time. The dust settles, the excitement wears off and Ben and Elaine are left with doubt and regret. But at least they finally took charge of their lives, and won't always wonder what could have been.

They agree to a second date, yet before they are on it, HE TELLS ELAINE IT IS HER FREAKING MOTHER HE HAS BEEN HAVING SEX WITH. She's understandably pissed and wants nothing to do with this douche. Then she leaves for Berkeley, and he straight follows her and precedes to actually STALK her. Chases her down and interrupts her date. At this point, the audience has no clue what she knows about the affair other than what he told her and any unknown conversation with the mother. Then the conversation dynamic flips, and she is kind and asking questions about what's next, and he's a big douche canoe again with his standoff attitude, believing she has the audacity to ask any questions to mister high and mighty. I‚Äôm about to graduate high school in the coming weeks, and I‚Äôve never had a more bittersweet feeling about anything in my life.

It's very rare that I watch a movie that leaves me speechless, especially as a reviewer. The Graduate is a pretty special film, and one that I am completely in awe of - I adored it. The only words I can find to say are that this was perfectly acted, gorgeously shot, expertly paced and the Simon and Garfunkel soundtrack brought everything together tidily. This is easily Dustin Hoffman's best performance, yet I absolutely fell in love with both Katharine Ross and Anne Bancroft. I was having a wonderful time from the minute I hit play, but that ending swept me entirely off my feet despite already being familiar with the final shot. This was one of the most well shot movies I have seen for a while, from the first frame to the last. I already can't wait to revisit this gem, I can see it becoming a firm favourite.
side note: Scarborough Fair is a beautiful track, but including it three times in the space of 5-10 minutes was definitely... a choice.

The Graduate: Having just finished college and concerned about his future, Ben becomes romantically involved with a friend of his parents‚Äô, the intoxicating Mrs. Robinson, soon after having his attention drawn to her daughter. Dustin Hoffman as Ben embodies the angst and confusion of adulthood, having been on the straight and narrow all his life without much deviation. Anne Bancroft is alluring yet domineering as Mrs. Robinson, dissatisfied with where she‚Äôs at in life, trying to recapture her youth. Through their encounters, Ben awakens a side of himself he didn‚Äôt know was in him, taking more risks and putting everything on the line for love. Mike Nichols‚Äôs direction is visually playful and full of energy, conveying a sense of isolation and emptiness felt by the characters. Shots of Ben being carried on a conveyor belt at the airport or walking down a long dark hallway in a hotel emphasizes these moods. The scene where Mrs. Robinson attempts to seduce Ben is a great example of camera work and visual storytelling. Simon & Garfunkel‚Äôs music adds a layer of melancholy and quirkiness to the events, emphasizing the uncertainty of what lies ahead for their futures. Overall, a classic coming-of-age tale with sharp writing and timeless appeal.

I watched this around 25 years ago when I was a teenager. I found it unremarkable but ticked it off my list of classic movies that I was supposed to watch as part of my film education.
This time round, to my own surprise, I was captivated from beginning to end. It is interesting how much the a person can change over the passage of time to see something in one moment as average to then become a revelation.
The Graduate is a film more about existential crisis than it is a "coming of age story". It is significantly elevated by Hofmann's quick, its post modernist sentiment, Nichols striking symbolism and the ethereal qualities of Simon and Garfunkel's music.
What interests me the most isn't the morality of the film because there isn't any. In fact Benjamin & Elaine probably won't stay together in the future in most part due to his erratic and odd nature. The point is that love shouldn't be governed by pragmatism, its should be free and selfish. It should be determined by individual and not the world around it.
Two of my favourite scenes involve movement and the concept of moving forward. The first is the moving airport walkway in the opening credits that a dejected and pensive Benjamin is pulled along by and taken into the future by the expectation of the world around him. The next, near the end, is after a moment of intuitive agency after an epiphany to stop the wedding. In his red car he hurtles past neon streetlights at breakneck speed as they reflect the electrifying colours of his emotional state. It is in making choices that fulfil our instincts that, for better or worse, we are truly alive.
The Graduate isn't about the outcomes or moral certainties in life. Its about living in a world of sensibility and the animal within us yearning against it.

Although I can‚Äôt say for certain that I feel assured by watching it, I can‚Äôt deny that it‚Äôs a solid classic that‚Äôs both entertaining and tense.
Three strong, charismatic performances from Hoffman, Bancroft, and Ross make for a terrific cast, alongside everyone else involved in-front of the camera. It‚Äôs got wonderfully varied cinematography, with clean lighting and quality production design. I was blown away at the sleek editing on display throughout, with flawless transitions at key moments that I could not believe were from a film dating back to 1967. I greatly enjoyed the script, as well as the directing from Mike Nichols. The Simon and Garfunkel soundtrack, while a tad bit repetitive, provided a nice, fairly calming mood to fill the scene. Like the kind of music one would listen to while going for a long drive on a beautiful summers day. I also picked up some neat symbolism here-and-there. 
This is more-or-less a brief summary of what I think of the film, since it‚Äôs such a well-known feature after all these years, and I‚Äôve got a lot of worrying consuming my mind. Regardless, I had a great time finally watching The Graduate.

Even knowing it was coming, the ending hits like a ton of bricks. All that has happened between the first scene and there and still the sense of isolation, alienation and soul-deep depression. Hoffman and Bancroft are perfection, but every character and actor has a moment where we peek beneath their facade, revealing their poignant humanity.
The scene where we realise all the pain just beneath Mrs Robinson's perfectly groomed appearance is heartbreaking, and so much sadder than any of the angst Ben is dealing with. He can still make a new future while her life feels already written.
Artful cinematography, editing and soundtrack. Instantly one of the best films I've seen. That New Hollywood alienation is just impeccable.

A Mike Nichols triumph. The shotmaking is innovative, especially in the scuba diver scene. The dialogue is spotless and quirky ("Alvin Romeo," "plastics"). The story pushed the boundaries of its time and was influential for decades. The acting, helmed by Dustin Hoffman, is nuanced and pitch perfect. And the Simon & Garfunkel is a beautiful touch that anchors much of the film.
By keeping you with Benjamin the whole movie, you empathize with him. As the movie rolls along, you start to know how he's feeling before he even voices it. You can feel how adrift he is, how in love he is, how devastated he is.
It's funny and tragic and ironic and, most of all, human.

22. The Graduate - watch a film with a Older Woman Younger Man Relationship
This is the second time I've watched this 1967 pioneering youth film, the first ever to include contemporary pop music as part of its mood-setting soundtrack (as opposed to being there to specifically showcase the performance, as with '50s Elvis films for example); but the last time I watched it was over 30 years ago, in a "Film Studies 101" class at my university popular among freshmen for being known as an "easy A" (spoiler alert: it was), so perhaps we shouldn't actually count that. More importantly, earlier this year I read the astounding nonfiction book Pictures at a Revolution, which examines the five 1967 films nominated for that year's Best Picture Oscar (including this one), as a way of painting a portrait of the growing countercultural of those years and the way it snuck up on the mainstream with almost no one prepared for it.
Famously the second film directed by Mike Nichols, at the time a cynical stage comedian who was unexpectedly hailed as the "next Orson Welles" for his film directorial debut the year before, the indelible Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?, the movie improbably made a sex symbol out of the nebbishly Jewish Dustin Hoffman, in the same years that his contemporary Philip Roth was doing so in the literary world with Portnoy's Complaint; and unbeknownst to nearly everyone involved, ended up tapping into the twentysomething zeitgeist in a far more profound way than even the filmmakers meant, a slacker-like tale of a recent college graduate who doesn't want to join the square world of his plastics-manufacturing parents' generation, but can't exactly picture anything else that he does want to do instead, drifting by default into a hate-filled dysfunctional affair with his father's business partner's bored middle-aged wife (Anne Bancroft, a justly celebrated high point of her career), until meeting the woman's college-aged daughter months later and unexpectedly hitting it off with her in a legitimately sincere way.
Yeah, I know, it sounds like a real bummer; but in the deft hands of writer Buck Henry, a veteran of sharp Mid-Century Modernist comedy (he was the co-creator with Mel Brooks of Get Smart!, and later in life was one of the founding writers of Saturday Night Live), the meandering source novel by Charles Webb is turned into a sharp diamond of black humor, a preternaturally world-weary tale that makes you laugh in all the places you shouldn't in polite company, a logical extension of the work Nichols was doing in the '50s with his writing partner Elaine May that just happened to catch fire with college students nationwide, not the least of which was because of being filmed in the messy handheld style of the then-cutting-edge French New Wave movement.
A must-watch for anyone who considers themselves a serious film fan, it's especially recommended to read Pictures at a Revolution right before it, one of the most entertaining and thought-provoking books about film history that I've ever picked up. Rightly revered as both one of the best film comedies of all time and one of the most principal examples of the so-called "New Hollywood" of these years, you should rush out right this second and see it if you never have...and it wouldn't hurt to watch it again even if you have before.

The entire first half of this film is a mastery in subjectivity. The way the camera moves and the scenes are blocked reflect Benjamin's state of mind so clearly and heighten the empathy one feels for him. As the film transitions into the second half, Benjamin transitions into essentially the villain. Yes, he is finally acting for himself, yet he is not really thinking for himself, just moving off impulse and gut feeling. He becomes extremely destructive in everyone else's lives, ruining multiple (albeit unhappy or dull) marriages and basically stalking Elaine repeatedly. There's a whole lot of generational shit in this movie that is very muddled to me. I think one's understanding of that stuff changes significantly with age and time period, so I bet it's just that. Overall, I know this is a great film, but I don't feel really any connection to it all, except for all of the parents being annoying.

The opening shot mirroring the closing shot.
The opening credits with Benjamin moving to the left while everything else is moving to the right, expressing he is not getting forward.
The anxiety-inducing scene with his parents' friends.
The first encounter with Mrs. Robinson wearing a leopard cloak, a predator announcing the hunt.
The hilarious and uncomfortable back-and-forth between the two, leading up to the legendary leg shot.
The hilarious and uncomfortable scene, containing of a continuous shot where Mr. Robinson unintentionally encourages Ben to engage in an affair with his wife.
The wet-suit scene, showing the disconnect between Ben and his parents while they try being modern.
The hotel part. So funny you almost can't breathe, so embarrassing you almost can't look. The build up to Ben shutting the door, and that brief shot of Mrs. Robinson's grin, knowing that she got him.
The sex montage, closing with the single greatest match cut I have seen in my life.
The incredible "We're going to have a conversation" scene, starting off with the two characters laying in bed next to each other, and finishing with the two separated on screen, looking in different directions.
The almost unwatchable strip club scene.
The rest of the date. Relief through pure chemistry.
The rainy build up to Ben confessing to Elaine by pure "show don't tell".
The driving to Berkeley, the bus encounter, the zoo. The hilarious encounter with a suspicious landlord.
The nerve-wrecking, nail-biting drive to the wedding.
The wedding scene that came before every wedding scene there is, before it was a cliche.
The going on the bus and the slow, slow, slow realization what they did.
The closing shot mirroring the opening shot.

And, guys: I haven't even mentioned the music...

The Graduate contains two distinct parts that coherently play off each other, tell different messages, but also arrive at the same conclusion. 
We have the first half that starts with Ben looking in the fish tank at the diver (who is undoubtedly himself, as we see later) and Ms. Robinson fades into focus in the background, like the manifestation of what is to come. 
This first half ends with Mrs. Robinson saying "goodbye Benjamin" in all black and wet against an all-white wall. As it fades to black the Sound of Silence plays again. With this song we get a series of shots that not only act as exposition for the second part, but also reflect Ben's emotions. 
The second half begins completely opposite the first half. The first half began with Ben having no sense of purpose or direction; the rolling sidewalk was his parents, his parents' friends and society pushing him to go places he ought to go (go to graduate school, don't date my daughter). However, this second part is Ben absolutely set on getting Elaine, something that no one wants him to do except himself.
The dichotomy of these two parts makes the ending shot so much more palpable. Ben does achieve his goal, a goal that he intensely desired (just watch him run!). But just like when he graduated he is still faced without a direction or a purpose. The perpetual lack of purpose is shown here by the song, Sound of Silence, which plays once again. Additionally, Ben is on a vehicle that is taking him somewhere unknown, much like the walking sidewalk that was taking Ben somewhere unknown [we are unable to see what's ahead of him (literally) in both situations].

There's not much I can say that I haven't said before. It's great, but you probably already knew that.
Edgar Wright totally picked up the quick-changing location shots for Scott Pilgrim from Mike Nichols.

Really really excellent cinematography. Cool transitions toward the middle, and I especially liked the sort of simulation of being overwhelmed by the guests in the opening scene -- the camera wasn't just there to record the plot; it was actually utilized to enhance the storytelling process.
Though I'll admit I'm not sure I'd be up for eloping with a guy who slept with my mom -- even if he loves me and my mom's a manipulative bitch -- I was satisfied with Benjamin's character arc, as well as his happy ending. And yes, I say happy because those placid faces on the bus at the end do not equal regret; this core theme of this movie is the concept of the lost young soul, constantly trying to figure out what to do next. It's not that Ben and Elaine don't love each other, they're just not sure what to do next. And given that I feel like that about 3x a day and I'm still breathing, I'm willing to bet they turn out okay.

After re-watching this I appreciated and enjoyed it more. I also realised how funny it is while also being one of the most important films in the wave of new Hollywood movies. This is a classic because it still speaks to people today. At the time, it spoke to the generation of teenagers and young people who felt the generation gap, which can best be explained as a result of Post-War, and the change in America.
The plot simply focuses on the young Ben, who has turned 21 and returned from his studying- now a graduate. It isn't long before one of the family friends Mrs Robinson begins seducing him, meanwhile he struggles with his life decisions.
Dustin Hoffman's character is so brilliantly played, and is the reason this film resonates. There are plenty of people in this generation just the same, unable to decide what direction to take, and what lies ahead for them. You may not realise it, but the past 15 years has been a significant change on society globally, with the rise of social media, Internet and technology. But, not to get off track, the film doesn't directly show us the societal and political changes, but you can feel them in the background.
The direction from Mike Nichols (who recently died), cinematography and editing style is also unconventional and noticeable. There are shots zooming out from Ben, showing his isolation, and zoom-ins showing the characters in deep thought, making full use of the camera. The film also has its fair share of laughs with well-timed hilarity, and awkward situations. While it is lighy by today's standards, its head-on look at sex (especially in such a way) was considered very scandalous at the time, and I still think it surprises you today. The Graduate is an important, entertaining and timeless film.

"Ben, this whole idea sounds pretty half-baked."
#1 on Berken's Favorite Movies Of All Time
There are quite a few things that make The Graduate a masterpiece (starting with possibly the most effective and enjoyable movie soundtrack ever), but above all it comes down to this - there could be no more even-handed (yet hilariously exaggerated to satiric effect) portrait of the relationship between financially well-off youths and their parents than what's on display here, somehow so timeless in its portrayal that even nearly half a century later not a single scene rings false. Unlike nearly every other entry in the "parents just don't understand!" genre, everyone in this movie is fundamentally broken and misguided in their own way and the filmmakers let no one off the hook, despite clearly feeling for the plight of all involved. A shallow viewing of the movie might imply that the titular graduate is in the right and that his actions get him to a better place; yet both the song lyrics and the facial expressions of the final scene combined with a dollop of common sense imply otherwise, to the likely future chagrin of our callow young hero.
That's not to excuse the older generation, however, who here have either A) become so disenchanted with life that they've checked out morally and become something of an unfeeling monster or B) reduced life into a checklist of practical and appropriate actions - graduate, indulge in the pleasures of youth for a sensible period of time, get married, and find a good job (in plastics, perhaps) - which they then pressure upon their children in the form of self-satisfied doses of wisdom. The effect is almost cult-like; in the graduation party scene as the attendees crowd around a miserable Ben to bestow congratulations upon him for behaving as society's definition of a successful youth, it's all too easy to imagine them breaking into chant: "One of us! One of us!"
On the other hand, while the young characters are clearly dissatisfied with having their whole life already paved out ahead of them, they never come upon a satisfying response to their dilemma. Instead, they drift along in an aimless haze, until something comes along that inspires them to feel feelings in a way that doesn't seem pre-ordained by society, then impulsively latch on to the source of that tide of emotions with a desperation bordering on lunacy. I've been there, Ben. I think we all have.
The movie leaves Ben in the wake of his decisions, while the aforementioned music, facial expressions, and common sense cast doubt on his direction. Yet I don't want to be too cynical - just because a decision was born out of youthful desperation and hormones doesn't mean it won't work out. Sometimes there are worse things than making a bold move that there's a good chance you'll come to regret once emotional sobriety sets in - like, for instance, not making any bold moves. (Living in China, where the rebellious counter-culture presence embedded so thoroughly in American music and movies and so definitive of the American high school and university experience is somehow completely absent, I've met quite a few twenty-somethings that could stand to benefit from a bit of Ben's foolish impetuosity and individualism.)
One last personal digression, I promise - when I was in high school and college my favorite movie was Fight Club because of its obvious iconoclastic appeal to a young person that felt his life was on rails, ever chugging forward without any consideration of the appropriateness of that direction. Since then Fight Club's hyper-masculine, emotionally charged, and combative rejection of society's mores has slowly lost its sway with me, much in the way I expect Ben will feel differently about his actions as time passes. (Though to be fair to Fight Club, it does reject Durden's philosophy in the end, even if that's not saying much when the philosophy in question involves blowing up half a city.) With The Graduate I think I may have finally found a movie worthy of filling the void of "movie that defines my perspective on the world" left when Fight Club vacated the spot years ago, one that takes a no less cynical and piercing, yet more measured, truthful, and compassionate approach to skewering both the conformists and their rebellious offspring. It's probably too soon after first viewing to call it my favorite movie, but, hey, it's not like an impulsive decision made under a rush of emotion and an intense desire to define oneself ever ended up looking silly in retrospect, right?

The Graduate. For a while I was somewhat disappointed (Hoffman‚Äôs sometimes effortful performance didn't always appeal to me) despite strong points (Bancroft is flawless, Ross very effective). But soon I developed a strong emotion for the film that overrode my reservations. The story suggests a parable in how little it needs to tell us (the omnipresent Simon & Garfunkel soundtrack becomes an abstracting element as well) - in this regard Ross‚Äôs simplicity of effect is perhaps more important to the film than is Bancroft‚Äôs command of the screen. Finally the inevitability of the love story and its happy outcome is what organizes the narrative - right up to the perplexing final scene, the main function of which is to restore the film‚Äôs modernist credentials. It‚Äôs hard to leave the film behind when it's over: it feels almost like a musical, albeit one with forbidding overtones. (21 Sep 2023)

What a delightfully sadistic film The Graduate is. Dustin Hoffman is as charming as he is vile, the perfect anchor point for this tale of depravity. In many ways this is almost a fairytale, filled with disgusting people and so many morals to be mined from the experience. Festering with outrageously dry humor that will be with you long after the film ends. Deftly balanced with an original soundtrack by Simon & Garfunkel that has become ever so timeless. All while encompassing the landscape of poor choices and the ramifications that reciprocate those decisions. It‚Äôs a never ending lesson on how not to behave. You can take pleasure in the idiocy of others as they attempt to navigate their own hubris. It leaves a mark on you, for as hilarious as the escape from the church is, the final scene on the bus is chilling as you can see into the future that the struggles are far from over. Nothing awaits these selfish individuals but misery and heartache.
