On the surface, ‚ÄúThe Graduate‚Äù is a romantic comedy about a young man (literally and metaphorically) drowning because of the pressure and expectations put on him by his parents and other grown-ups in his life. He‚Äôs an object to them, something they can be proud of. They love him, sure, but they suffocate him. Benjamin is living the life they picked for him, which is reflected on his loneliness and his lack of relationships, as well as all his academic achievements. He focuses on school not because he cares, but because they do. So when the opportunity comes to take some risk and start living his life (as advised by Mr. Robinson himself) in the form of Mrs. Robinson, he takes it and starts an affair, which he soon realizes is not a real relationship, but one purely based around sex. Ben cares about Mrs. Robinson, but not in the way he wants to. That‚Äôs when her daughter, Elaine, comes into the picture. They get along, she‚Äôs young, she feels the same way he does. Ben thinks he‚Äôs fallen in love and so he does everything in his power to stay with Elaine. When her parents push her into marrying a man she doesn‚Äôt truly love, it is Ben who rescues her and they drive off into the sunset, unsure about their future.
Now, some problems come with looking at the film this way. The big one is Benjamin, who‚Äôs not really a hero in the story. At first he looks like a guy who gets taken advantage of by an older woman and eventually fights back in an attempt to save the woman he loves. But he‚Äôs not exactly that. He‚Äôs a creep and a fucking stalker. There might be some good in Ben‚Äôs rebellious spirit, but he himself is not a very nice guy. Mrs. Robinson is also not just a villain. She‚Äôs a bit more complex than that. She‚Äôs a lonely woman trapped in a loveless marriage looking for a young man to be with her. That‚Äôs where the real power of the story lies.
‚ÄúThe Graduate‚Äù is a story about loneliness. Ben lives to live up to his parents‚Äô expectations. He doesn‚Äôt seem to have many friends or any previous relationships. The opening shot of the film frames him by himself as he sits on an airplane and ‚ÄúThe Sound of Silence‚Äù plays. The first scene at the house shows us how lonely and trapped he feels surrounded by his parents‚Äô friends, until he comes across Mrs. Robinson. She‚Äôs been married for over 20 years with a man she never loved because of a careless night in a car. She was young and made a mistake, she married him and is still paying for it. Her daughter‚Äôs away in college, so she‚Äôs all by herself at home. She doesn‚Äôt even sleep with her husband. She desires human contact and so she looks for it in Ben, an attractive young man. But he has morals, he won‚Äôt sleep with her. However, after once again being paraded around by his parents, Ben realizes some human interaction (not contact) is all he needs. He wants to truly connect with someone. Now that he‚Äôs an adult, he wants something good in his life. He tries to find it in Mrs. Robinson by talking to her, but all she wants is sex. To Ben, that‚Äôs enough, it‚Äôs more than what he‚Äôs had for most of his life. He changes, he becomes a free soul, just hanging around his house, enjoying life, he finally has something of value in his life. Or so it seems. ‚ÄúThe Sound of Silence‚Äù can be heard for the second time in the film during the second act‚Äôs iconic montage. Ben is still as alone as he was in the beginning. He just doesn‚Äôt know it.
When Elaine gets brought up by Mrs. Robinson one night, she warns Ben not to take her out, ever. He assumes Mrs. Robinson thinks her daughter is too good for him. They fight. We realize how much they both care about their encounters, it‚Äôs the one good thing they have to look forward to in their lives. Mrs. Robinson doesn‚Äôt think Elaine is too good for Ben, she just doesn‚Äôt want her to get him. She doesn‚Äôt want to lose what little she has. When they‚Äôre forced to go on a date, Ben tries to get rid of Elaine. He makes her cry, he pushes his moral compass to the limit, his loneliness allows him to do what he wouldn‚Äôt have been able to before. That‚Äôs how desperate he is to protect his affair. Of course, Ben eventually regrets what he did and kisses Elaine in an attempt to calm her down. That‚Äôs the kind of affection he knows, because that‚Äôs the only kind of affection Mrs. Robinson shows him. This is also why he has no problem entering Elaine‚Äôs room while she‚Äôs getting dressed later in the film. Ben and Elaine hit it off on their first date. They‚Äôre not necessarily soul mates, but they agree on a second date. We can assume from their conversations Elaine is just as lonely as Ben. Her parents are similar to his. Even her friends and dates are selected by her parents. She‚Äôs glad she‚Äôs finally found someone she can connect to on a more honest and personal level. Then everything goes to shit when she finds out about the affair in the most brilliant rack focus ever.
The third act sees Ben go nuts. His loneliness is too much to handle, his morals are gone, he‚Äôs insane. He lost the only people he‚Äôs ever truly cared about. He lost the woman he thinks he loves. Ben moves to marry Elaine, even though she hates him. He begins following her around until she confronts him in his apartment. If she thinks Benjamin raped her mother, why would she go to his apartment at night instead of asking for help from her parents or the authorities? It‚Äôs clear she‚Äôs trying to escape her parents‚Äô grasp. She doesn‚Äôt want to date Carl, the friend of the family. She wants to feel the same way she felt when she first dated Ben. She never really believed her mother‚Äôs rape story, which is why she instantly believes Ben when he tells her that‚Äôs not what happened. Ben thinks he loves her because their date was the realest encounter he‚Äôs ever had. Elaine feels the same way. She spends the next few days being unsure about everything. She might marry him. She might not. She‚Äôs a young woman trying to figure out what to do with her life. She‚Äôs lonely, but not as lonely as him. Not yet.
After finding out about Benjamin‚Äôs plans, Mr. and Mrs. Robinson arrange a wedding for her. The ultimate act of oppression against the young. Mrs. Robinson is dooming her daughter to live the same life she‚Äôs been trapped in for decades. Except this isn‚Äôt Elaine‚Äôs fault, but someone else‚Äôs. This is Elaine‚Äôs darkest moment, where she feels completely alone. And that‚Äôs when Benjamin arrives at the church, shouting her name. Before running towards Ben, Elaine takes a look at her parents and new husband. They‚Äôre mad, they‚Äôre furious. This pushes her into actually running away with Ben. Two lonely young people finally getting their happy ending. But then ‚ÄúThe Sound of Silence‚Äù plays one last time and the couple‚Äôs smiles disappear from their faces. It‚Äôs not a happy ending, it‚Äôs a tragic one. They didn‚Äôt think any of this through. Everything is real all of sudden, they see their actions have consequences, and their actions were all so rushed and fueled by a desire of rebellion, fueled by the desire to escape from the loneliness of their lives. But the loneliness is still there. They don‚Äôt love each other. They barely know each other. They just made their own mistake, like Mrs. Robinson did many years ago. ‚ÄúThe Graduate‚Äù is a tragedy, a cautionary tale about the dangers of loneliness. A brilliant story about love, parenthood, rebellion, youth and the future. No wonder Benjamin is a little worried about it.

There are pictures that catch you on the first frame.
There are stories so familiar to you, you have no option but to love them. You might even swear that, by some strange coincidence, the director and the screenwriter took inspiration from your life and they're now taking it to the big screen.
Me, personally, I've never felt that... I could vaguely relate with the themes and characters on screen, but not to the point where I'd think that, somewhere in the world and in a specific point in time, somebody felt the same way that I feel.
Until now, when The Graduate (1967) managed to do that for me.
For those that have yet to see it, let me tell you that this film goes beyond that famous quote: ‚ÄúMrs. Robinson, you're trying to seduce me‚Äù. The journey of Benjamin Braddock to find happiness is one most viewers can relate to. And man, when it ended, I was devastated with most of the choices he made.
The soundtrack is one of the best ones I've heard in the history of cinema. I used to find ‚ÄúThe Sound of Silence‚Äù pretty funny because of all the lol memes that are circling around, but holy shit! Hearing it in context gives you a totally different perspective and it is now a piece of music I can hear over and over and unironically. (I even have it on my favorites playlist)
Whew! What a ride. I don't think I have given that much 5 star ratings as I am doing in 2018, but I think this one is worth every single one. Definitely one of my favorite movies of all time, too.

Both Benjamin and Mrs. Robinson are creeps, I don't think that's a particularly controversial conclusion to come to, but they're both creeps who've largely been made that way by the society surrounding them. However, there's a major difference between them in terms of how they've been moulded, and it comes up during the scene where Benjamin tries to find something to talk about with Mrs. Robinson. After initially stating that she has no interest in art, Mrs. Robinson reveals that she was lying, that she was actually an art student in college, and that while studying there, she had a one-night stand with the future Mr. Robinson which resulted in the conception of their daughter Elaine, forcing her to marry him and abandon any plans she might have had otherwise so that she could become what all women would be made to strive for under the insidious guise of traditional values: a wife. She even starts quietly crying, just to hammer it all home.
And therein lies the difference between them. Benjamin is celebrated for graduating college by his rich parents and their rich friends who see much potential in him, but he feels aimless, directionless; he's a creep because he's awkward, not a kid anymore but not truly an adult yet, trying to figure out what normal human behaviour is supposed to look like. Which isn't anything to sneeze at, mind you, but Mrs. Robinson also had potential, also likely had a direction, and instead of those things being celebrated, they were stolen from her; she could almost have been a possible vision of a future for Benjamin if he was a woman, but since he isn't, the worth of his goals - whatever they may be - isn't even questioned. It's no wonder she ended up as troubled as she did; with her life taken away from her like that, why wouldn't she drown herself in drink? Why wouldn't she become a creep?
So it's disappointing, I think, that the second half goes in the weird direction it does, and that the nuanced balance between the two characters seems to end. Benjamin's shiftiness is not only exacerbated through his stalking of Elaine, but it's not even shown in a particularly negatively light; meanwhile, Mrs. Robinson turns into a straight-up villain who falsely accuses him of rape (a hilariously pointless aspect of the plot that's brought up once by Elaine and then never mentioned again). Elaine's behaviour is also really weird; I'm not sure how, when or why she goes from thinking that Benjamin raped her mother to believing that he didn't to falling in love with him (again?), but it's some really dumb writing, especially for a movie that otherwise has writing that's not particularly dumb.
And then the nuance is restored through that ending: Benjamin and Elaine, having fled from her wedding, sit next to one another on a bus, going who knows where. And they go from being happy to... puzzled, awkward, unsure about what's gonna happen now, somewhat dissatisfied. "The Sound of Silence", a song used previously to represent Benjamin's insecurities about his life, plays once again. These aren't star-crossed lovers fleeing towards happiness; this is both of them about to become very unhappy because they weren't really sure what else to do. Elaine may even end up just like her mother, and in his own way, so may Benjamin.
In short, this is a very sad film about very sad people.

There are a lot of themes within The Graduate, so I'll be picking just one to discuss. Has ther ever been a film that best represents truth and realism in regards to early twenties lifestyle? Answering the big questions of "what to do with my life," as we wonder aimlessly around looking for that answer to an unanswerable question. Ben finds solace in a woman twice his age, allowing this to suffocate and vape that fear away. Until Elaine walks in the picture and changes the game; he has found the answer. But the ending, where life finally hits back at them like a bus hitting a cross walker, suggests otherwise. Where do we go from here? What now? Where will this take us?
"Hello darkness, my old friend
I've come to talk with you again
Because a vision softly creeping
Left its seeds while I was sleeping
And the vision that was planted in my brain
Still remains
Within the sound of silence
In restless dreams I walked alone
Narrow streets of cobblestone
'Neath the halo of a street lamp
I turned my collar to the cold and damp
When my eyes were stabbed by the flash of a neon light
That split the night
And touched the sound of silence"
It almost seems like our singers seem to warn Benjamin of his looming fate; the fact that he may not have one. But the spiraling dream of love topples over and life hits back. Wake up from the dream.

A rejuvenating piece of filmmaking, one of those movies, exactly like Breathless, that gives a lot of insight to what comes after. It's like finally listening to a classic album that's been sampled by late-comers over and over again and suddenly things begin to make sense.
I thought this captured the eagerness and awkwardness of post-college immaturity and the uncertainty of how the world works. Benjamin is clumsy and stupid and makes all the wrong choices, and his desire to just drift around is endlessly relatable right now. I just want to sit here and do nothing and after three/four years I think I deserve it whether I do or don't and whether it's the best decision or not.

He‚Äôs not your man, he‚Äôs Benjamin Braddock.

I've never quite dug THE GRADUATE. It has a great cast, excellent directing by Mike Nichols, and all of this is accompanied by a lovely soundtrack of Simon & Garfunkel songs, with "The Sound of Silence" in particular being one that has resonated with generations of audiences. But the story leaves me cold.
The first two thirds or so of the movie set up a great premise. We meet Ben Braddock (Dustin Hoffman), a recent college-graduate now adrift in the world and disillusioned with life, uncomfortable with himself and unable to connect with others. Ben is constantly alienated from those around him, often framed in water as if he is suffocating. He gets roped into an affair with Mrs. Robinson (Anne Bancroft in an iconic performance), a family friend and older cougar who seduces him.
This leads to a lot of funny situations, with Ben being endearingly adorkable to his ever-increasingly uncomfortable arrangement. Many have pointed out that Ben is attracted not so much to Mrs. Robinson herself but to the idea of the affair, and how it is a way to rebel: against his parents, against their generation, against what society expects of him.
But then Mrs. Robinson's daughter, Elaine (Katharine Ross), enters the picture. Ben falls for her, but once she discovers about his affair with her mother she is distraught, and wants nothing to do with him. This is a pretty dark low-point, one that no romance would realistically ever be able to recover from.
And then...this is where the story loses me. The entire last third of the movie is Ben chasing after Elaine, borderline-stalking her at her college, pursuing her relentlessly, until the famous climax of Ben crashing her wedding. The problem is that Ben and Elaine's romance isn't particularly interesting to me. I don't feel Elaine's character has all that much to her and it's hard for me to buy that she ever would want to talk to Ben again. In the case of Ben, I can understand that he's a confused kid chasing his hopeless dream, more in love with the idea of being in love than genuinely in love with Elaine. But as for Elaine...I honestly don't know her character.
I feel the screenplay never gives us time to get to know her personality. There basically is no reason for her to fall in love with him. And he doesn't really grow as a character nor do anything to make her fall in love with him. In fact, how does Elaine feel about what happened? We never get any scene of her and her mother alone, and surely some kind of confrontation between the two must have happened at some point.
The common argument I've heard is that she's a female version of Ben; also a confused adolescent uncomfortable with the world controlled by her elders, and running out on her wedding is a way for her to rebel against her parents. Again, I would buy her running out on her wedding to escape if it was any other guy on Earth...except the guy who had an affair with her mother.
There's been a lot of discussion about whether THE GRADUATE's ending is a happy or sad one, that the entire tale is one big tragedy about how rebellious youth repeat their parents' mistakes, and that Ben and Elaine are heading to a sad future of becoming another Mrs. Robinson and her husband. And again, I would go for this interpretation...if she wasn't the daughter of the woman Ben was having an affair with. I sort of wish Elaine had been split into two characters: the daughter of Mrs. Robinson who shows up and ruins the affair, and a different (and more well-written) love interest that Ben fell for and spent the third act pursuing. But combining these two into one character creates too much baggage and doesn't give the character time to develop.
THE GRADUATE doesn't work for me because I know too little about Elaine. And I don't believe any woman on Earth would ever feel any attraction for a man she was aware had had an affair with her mother. I've heard some people defend this by stating that the film is intended as satirical, but this strikes me as a selective interpretation. "It's satire" is not a be-all end-all argument for having poor characterization.
-ADDENDUM-
Years after writing this review, I discovered THE HEARTBREAK KID (1971), directed by Elaine May, Mike Nichols's old comedy partner. It makes sense there would be a lot of overlapping themes in their work, and all I can say is not only is THE HEARTBREAK KID a masterpiece, but it's the answer to THE GRADUATE that I never knew I wanted. For all the people who told me I just didn't understand the satire in THE GRADUATE and especially its ending, all I can say is I find THE HEARTBREAK KID a superior film as well as a superior version of that same ending. Elaine May was a master.

99: Probably the most unintentionally disturbing movie about how scary the future is‚Äîor maybe it‚Äôs not so unintentional?‚Äîbut it‚Äôs also a film that, on paper, should‚Äôve lost its bravura decades ago; its implied sexual provocation, the voyeurism and experimentation of the camera, the near endless needle-drops of the same four Simon & Garfunkel songs, and Dustin Hoffman‚Äôs Ben certainly comes off as a creep in the second half of the movie, that stuff isn‚Äôt new or ‚Äúdaring‚Äù anymore. But the magic is still there, and it‚Äôs almost undeniably one of the funniest movies ever conceived‚Äîwith Hoffman nailing practically every line, facial expression, and emotional cue in the script‚Äîthough I think most of that charm comes from its technicolor cinematography. It‚Äôs just visually startling eye candy throughout, with everything so well thought out and composed, whether that‚Äôs the tight, claustrophobic framing of Ben‚Äôs graduation party or the neat, calculative zooms and match-cuts scattered in the film‚Äôs runtime. More importantly, I guess, I just find The Graduate really sad, which sounds like a blanket statement, but in comparison to something like Elaine May‚Äôs The Heartbreak Kid, which is also a good film, that second-to-last shot is fucking brutal. It just captures coming-of-age angst impeccably well, and it‚Äôs almost impossible to replicate to full effect. Even outside those final moments, however, the whole movie is filled with a subtle underbelly of melancholy, with Ben drowning in his materialistic sorrows. Emotionally taxing in the weirdest of ways.

‚ÄúIt's like I was playing some kind of game, but the rules don't make any sense to me. They're being made up by all the wrong people. I mean no one makes them up. They seem to make themselves up.‚Äù

The Graduate may be one of the most relatable films ever made. Life keeps pushing you along before you're even ready, and before you know it, you find yourself in a world where others are telling you how to live your life. And just when you think you've found where you want to be, more obstacles show up and stand in your way; but you can overcome them with all the motivation you can acquire in just a short amount of time.
We've all felt like Ben at one point or another; unsure of what our future should be; feeling like we're going nowhere. Just keep thinking; just keep going with the flow, and soon you'll realize that the future is full of unexpected twists, turns, and surprises that are sure to keep you on your toes, and get you ready for anything that comes your way.
This film really left me speechless in a way I rarely ever experience.

Appreciated way more this time. The first hour is basically perfect. Incredibly visually inventive and well directed (Nichols deserved the Oscar) but also funny and poignant. Was struck now by how complicated of a protagonist Benjamin is on a rewatch. I can sympathize with his disillusionment but some of his decisions are plainly selfish, at times showing little concern for other characters' feelings or boundaries.

*SPOILERS*

I think where the film loses me (and lost me on the previous watch) is the section where Benjamin is trying to marry Elaine. I understand that the film is saying that they are both sort of deluding themselves by thinking that getting married will fix all their problems and uncertain futures but the film only implies that things might not turn out well in the long term in literally the last two minutes of the movie. So the whole time Benjamin's basically stalking Elaine I'm thinking: "things probably won't end well for anyone" and so I've disassociated from the conflict of the film, up until the last 2 minutes where the film states what I was just thinking for the previous half hour.
Keeping in mind my criticism of the last 30 minutes, there isn't a moment in the film where the craft of the filmmakers and actors isn't incredible.
Also the music's good :).

"I'm a little worried about my future"
That quote goes so hard and is incredibly relatable. In fact The Graduate is probably the most relatable movie of all time. Benjamins character ticks all the boxes of what it truly feels like to be alone, to love someone but not be loved back and really just not have a clue as to what life really is ment to be. His lack of direction and uncertain, impending future, a desire for experience end up getting himself into a terrible situation. He becomes desperate which led him to begin an affair something he knows is wrong.
I really can see why this movie is so iconic and loved by all and it's utterly groundbreaking in its unique visual style and use of the camera and colours. It changed the face of modern film and is incredibly influential on over films and film directors.
Dustin Hoffmans performance is truly one of the best in all of cinema, the way he encapsulated the feeling of loneliness and confusion. Katharine Ross as Elaine is one of the best supporting roles of all time and one of the best female performances ever as well, same goes with Mrs. Robinson both incredibly great love interests.
The cinematography is phenomenal, shot to perfection. Seriously a great use of the camera every shot is beautiful and means something, shows a certain feeling and feels necessary to the film. The final shot is one of the best final shots ever, for once Benjamin succeeded and got what he wanted, really just shows that good things can always happen.
The score is beautiful and really made the film just that bit more special. Made an already pretty popular song one of the most well known ever, that being 'The Sound Of Silence'

Somehow I feel like The Graduate is underrated? Which is strange, because its so celebrated by the many who have seen it, but for me there was not much hype going into this. It immediately has some of the most poignant cinematography I've seen to date. The entire movie has this almost perfect camerawork for its genre and presentation. The purposeful and conspicuous zooms get us in the headspace of Benjamin's still relatable struggle. The way he reacts to the increasingly crazy events show us what he's been looking for, or rather what he's trying to avoid. As a recent Graduate myself I too feel the insane pressure to finally "get off my ass" and make something of myself. Obviously I'm not scoring any milfs, but that's not the important aspect of the plot. Its the sudden change and disappearance of rules and structure, without the use of a mandated schedule. We take for granted how organized education is, in the real world we very much have to play by ear, and what enters Benjamin's ear isn't very helpful. His parents and colleagues all seem to be giving him directions, but never explaining how to get there. Dating, marriage, and job searching is not something college teaches you, you have to figure it out for yourself. Benjamin is the result of someone who is so by-the-books that it ends up hurting him. He tries to stay in his own lane, but you can't do that for the rest of your life. In an attempt at some kind of control or just to prove to his parents and himself, he goes off and makes his own choices, whether or not they will even prove beneficial. In less than two hours The Graduate taught so much about myself that my 23 years of living never quite reached yet. I'm surprised filmbros don't raise this up with the likes of Pulp Fiction or The Wolf of Wallstreet. Then again, that would imply they might have actually learned something.

I was in the mood so I gave this one a rewatch and holy fucking shit I love this movie. Definitely a top 5 favorite for me and maybe a top 3. The direction of Mike Nichols is immaculate. So incredible how he manages to create all these scenes without a single pacing problem. This movie flows so perfectly. Also this movie is fucking hilarious like I was laughing out loud at moments. The acting is very strong as well. Hoffman, Bancroft, and Ross turn in some great performances here. The screenplay is literally perfect. The dialogue is amazing and the narrative is incredible. Cinematography and editing were also off the charts good here. The transitions especially in the first part of the movie were so incredibly good. No matter how many times you‚Äôve seen The Graduate... it always feels like the first time. It is stuffed with great character writing (Buck Henry RIP), sharply refined symbols, and the finest coming of age story of cinema. A counterculture act of generational rebellion, The Graduate is the perfectly timed ‚Äò60s movie that gets the moment and the movement right. Exceptional and well rounded. Ben is all of us.
Having seen it many times as a young adult, watching as a grown adult, with a child, I‚Äôm now on the other end of the subject and find my sympathies with the adults and increasingly adverse to my own inner rebellion now that I have done enough of it and my life is refined by many events where I‚Äôve felt like Ben and Elaine at the back of the bus. Still remain profoundly, thoroughly moved by the verisimilitude of the thing.

I'll be writing an essay about this for my last college film class, I'll post it here. It might not be as long as Chris Mell's review of My Dinner With Andre.
Quick review though: Excellent film on a generational rift. My favorite films are ones that can talk about sensitive topics not by preaching directly to camera (not that I don't love a good Spike Lee monologue), but by focusing solely on individual stories. Benjamin Braddock's isolation from society captured and represented the underpinning feelings of the growing counterculture very well and that is why this film feels as fresh now as it did in the 1960's.

Not the fun jolly romp that I'd heard it was and not in a while has my opinion been so off-kilter from the general consensus of a film. The Graduate is a classic I just never got round to watching and to be honest I didn't know much more than the Mrs Robinson plotline and seeing clips here and there.
Maybe I missed the depth of the social commentary here but the retrograde attitude of the film really put me off. The first half was really good, Hoffmans character trying to find a purpose in life after graduating, your peers asking you about your future at every opportunity. This situation can be relatable for so many people whether it just be school you have left or what. You can find yourself in an angst ridden phase in life and it really caught them emotions on screen. It shows Hoffmans progression from graduate to maturity with his affair with Mrs Robinson. This is all great stuff some of the editing is outstanding, the camera work is a film students wet dream.
However, it's the second half where I found it not just uninteresting but quite creepy. I thought the story really lost focus at this point, the camera was still a major part and it was always worth it for that alone. It contains an intense courtship of Hoffmans love interest (or stalking would be the best word), a love interest I'm not sure was meant to be taken seriously or if this was a play on the falsity of young love. I don't think it was clear though.
I feel having time to reflect on The Graduate though has only made me appreciate it more and there is probably benefits to re-watching because I'm not sure all is what meets the eye. The soundtrack is grade A classic Simon & Garfunkel though.
Tfw you saw Wayne‚Äôs World 2 before you ever saw The Graduate.

Benjamin Braddock is numb.
Numb from all his achievements and the abundance of options in front of him but mostly numb from his own personal existence in this world. He's numb and so he's drifting on water and through his life because it feels like all purpose was sucked right out of him after college graduation.
Benjamin Braddock is me.
Not all of me, but I have felt the way Benjamin feels in the film and, if I'm quite honest, there are moments when I still do. It's a world weariness that can get overwhelming at times and it's not something that's easy to shake. Perhaps a reason why I've become so obsessed with film because it's a form of escapism into different mindsets but it also is a great teacher that let's you know who you are or who you would be in any given situation that you're watching. It doesn't always reflect the real world out there but it's often a magnifying glass onto human behavior.
Benjamin Braddock rubs people the wrong way.
For all the praise he's getting for being a star track runner, Benjamin doesn't feel well in his own skin. He feels like the compliments he's getting are choking him because they come with strings attached. Everyone expects him to continue to do well because he's done well before and in a moment of nervousness and weakness he falls prey to an older woman, who seems bored and unhappy with herself and who is toying with him at all opportunities and ultimately, the most intimate act between two people becomes numbing in its endless repetition.
Benjamin Braddock shines in the thrill of the chase but not in the catch.
This is just my personal take on the film but it feels to me like Benjamin only does well when he can chase after something. He spends his life running and that also shows clearly in his chosen sport but most definitively in perhaps the most somber endings to a film ever, we see the thrill of the chase wear off in an instant. Benjamin has caught what he was chasing against all odds but both he and his prey are looking ahead at an uncertain future, suggesting one of those famous "I've made a huge mistake" moments that Arrested Development specializes in and that's one of the most haunting visualizations of what it means to grow up that I can imagine and I finally fully appreciate the film for it.
Side note: The soundtrack provided by Simon & Garfunkel really captures the zeitgeist of the 60s, the oddness and the humor. Most of all though, it captures the disillusionment right from the start, when the haunting notes of The Sound of Silence first echo across the speakers and the film couldn't be the same without the music.

I don‚Äôt have much to say about The Graduate that hasn‚Äôt already been said, but one of the few movies that have captured how it feels to be alive so accurately.

‚ÄúIt just happened. It‚Äôs just this thing that happened along with everything else. Can you understand that?‚Äù
The Graduate is a sweeping-along. Things seem to just happen to Benjamin Braddock, who is swept along in such a way as to suggest a serious falling out with autonomy. What are the operating forces, then, that cause things to just happen, as Benjamin says they do? Mrs. Robinson is a big one; Elaine is another. But there remain internal causes, like fear and lust, that contribute just as much to Benjamin‚Äôs plight. These dominate his actions for most of the film until other, less malevolent forces‚Äîthose of love and courage‚Äîbegin to swim about in his soul. 
The last quarter of the film still has Benjamin caught in a sort of current, only it becomes more or less one of his own design, like a railway that he‚Äôs laying the tracks for: there‚Äôs no stopping the train, but at least it‚Äôs his railway. This may seem too happily simple, but all he needed to be less miserable was a goal of his own making‚Äîa plan, as Elaine says late in the film. And we who have tasted the perpetual ennui of post-childhood know that Benjamin is to be envied for this sudden fit of motivation. There is not always so romantic a future to fight for.
I should note that this sweeping-along coming across in the narrative hinges quite heavily on the way the film is cut. There‚Äôs a ton of ellipsis here, and it works to effect what might be called lean filmmaking. Mike Nichols pares The Graduate down to the bare necessities, leaving exposition and other assorted fat on the cutting room floor. The effect is such that about half of protagonist Benjamin Braddock‚Äôs character development lies in the title of the film and nowhere else. What isn‚Äôt needed for the story to land simply isn‚Äôt in the movie. 
And yet for all its leanness I wouldn‚Äôt call The Graduate a minimalist work or anything close to one. Nichols‚Äô visual language is dynamic, with zooms both sluggish and wickedly fast, with lilting long takes and one-frame shock cuts and even the odd Dutch angle. The ultra hip licensed soundtrack, though trite by today‚Äôs standards, was a novel innovation in 1967 (as well as a brilliant shortcut to invoke the spirit of the times with a handful of songs). Everything about Nichols‚Äô work here screams movement. And as a product of late 60s America might rightly be, The Graduate is always in motion, drifting between necessity and excess, between pop culture frivolity and spirit of youth social malaise, between teenage perversion and high-flung romance. I couldn‚Äôt dream up a better introduction to New Hollywood.

There is this great interview where Harold Ramis talks about people who have watched his film, Groundhog Day, many times. Ramis talks about the many people who come up to him and say how each time they watch it, they feel something different. Ramis then explains that although the movie never changes, it seems to change when you're at different stages in your life. Where you are in your life determines how you view a film.
The Graduate is exactly that. It hasn't been that long since I last watched this, but I still found something different while watching. It's such an amazing thing to make a movie like this, to make a movie that changes even though every single thing stays the same.

'DvD' Challenge #22
The Graduate was a movie I had super high hopes for. And although it's not bad movie, it's not the great movie I had believed it to be. Dustin Hoffman puts on an acting clinic as the shy, nervous Ben Braddock, as you can see all the emotions clearly and consistent as the movie goes on and the dilemmas he faces and the situations he puts himself into. The story is also intriguing and kept me entertained, with the shift in the middle of the film being a strong point.
And although the music of Simon and Garfunkel is something I do enjoy, it got super repetitive and borderline annoying as the movie went along. I also felt that the relationship between Ben and Elaine was not fleshed out enough, was forced on us too quickly and ended up not believing in their chemistry.
However, those negatives aside, I did still enjoy the film. If you're looking to mark off a staple film from the classics, this is one you should watch.

I remember watching this back in 2014 and falling in love with it, but forgot it over time.

The Graduate is such an engaging and relatable film, that it's impossible to ignore it. 
Benjamin Braddock is such a relatable character, as I myself found some similarities between the two of us.

I wanted to start 2017 off right film-wise, so I decided to watch The Graduate, a film I first saw over a year and half ago. This was my fourth viewing and it continues to get better every time for me. I love the character of Benjamin Braddock (played brilliantly by Dustin Hoffman), as I find him very relatable and easy to sympathize with. The film moves at a good pace, has a great story, great characters and performances, is very well shot and edited, and has a terrific soundtrack. This time I watched it with my brother, as he'd never seen it and I'm happy to say he really enjoyed it. Simon & Garfunkel will be stuck in my head for a while now. 9/10

As I said back when I was just about to watch it: this is probably one of the biggest movies that I have had on my watchlist for ages without ever actually watching. Dustin Hoffman is an amazing actor, so that obviously had me interested enough on its own, but also the fact that I have seen so many classic scenes from the film by now I feel like I already know and love it before even watching it. And I was kind of right, because I absolutely loved this film... It is not perfect, but there is many groundbreaking things about it and it sort of holds a good balance between controlled and lively filmmaking. What I mean is, that the film hasn‚Äôt got a problem being smart and witty while also pulling of some interesting and inventive shots and frame-compositions.
I think the story it wanted to tell was extremely interesting though quite obvious at times, but overall you just have such a fun time with it that you don‚Äôt care whether or not it departures from what it set out to be ‚Äì or that it wants to have more fun than what it should be ‚Äúallowed to‚Äù. This already stands as one of my new favorite films, I think, and I can‚Äôt wait to watch it again some time.

The Graduate is a really interesting movie. There're some scenes that appear to be from a romantic comedy, a light tale about a boy dragged to an affair with an older woman and ending falling in love with her daughter, but deeply it doesn't feel like it. Just like Ben and his circle of family and his parent's friends they all seem living the life, but if you pay attention they are just hollow, sad and numb. Mrs. Robinson and Ben actually are very alike, looking for thrills to feel alive but getting back to their lifeless existence after they get what they want.
The acting and the soundtrack are amazing. They transform the movie in a melancholic journey and the editing is also very smart. I wasn't really sure what I would get out of The Graduate and it was better than I ever imagined.
One of the most gorgeously directed films of all time; excellent use of camera and blocking to create mood, character and setting. Mike Nichols will surely be missed.

Watched this again after reading Mark Harris‚Äô excellent book about the 1967‚Äôs Best Picture nominees: Pictures at a Revolution. Kind of one of those movies that‚Äôs so perfect and said perfection so covered upon ground, that it‚Äôs hard to write about. The tight screenplay, Nichols showing off his formal chops in his sophomore effort (insane that he was learning on the fly just a year earlier with Virginia Woolf), Sam O‚ÄôSteen‚Äôs editing, the gaudiness of California‚Äôs Noveau Riche, the lingering mood of generational ennui, the Simon & Garfunkel‚Äôs soundtrack, and (of course) just how much of a shockwave this type of European influenced cinema felt compared to the decade‚Äôs penchant for aesthetically conservative musicals and costume dramas‚Äî folks, it‚Äôs all here. 
This is my first time watching this since graduating from a somewhat ‚Äúprestigious‚Äù college in December. Now I‚Äôll be the first to say that it‚Äôs not a 1:1 to my experience, but it does really capture the worst feelings of feeling lost in a world that feels stupid, callous, and emptily superficial. Especially those early scenes where Benjamin has to field the questions about his future to his parents‚Äô friends. Everyone offering what to do when it all feels so plastic. As everyone had said; that final scene is the type of thing that keeps you awake at night with so many ambiguous, mixed emotions.
Tangential story: had a roommate in college who had maybe the worst taste (MCU and streaming slop kind of guy) in everything imaginable. He once told me he said this movie was overrated because ‚Äúthe ending made the parents seem right‚Äù. It seems like a straw man that I just made up to make fun of zoomer media literacy, but if Andrew is reading this review he can confirm that one for me.

I love the feeling when you go into a film expecting to love it and it still blows you away.
‚ÄúThe Graduate‚Äù is one of those films that I would have no problem with watching the whole day over and over. 
I love the atmosphere, the feeling, the mood, the tone and just everything.
The cinematography is beautiful. I love the way they position and move the camera, the framing, the lighting, the colors. The soundtrack is absolutely masterful and perfectly complements and emphasizes the mood. I absolutely love (!) the dialogues, which are not only humorous but also very witty and smart and everything is perfectly timed and the film is very funny. The writing seriously is on point and gets you very involved and engaged. And it also is very relatable in some ways and therefore really got to me. And the pacing is PERFECTION!
Dustin Hoffman again is a pleasure to watch and delivers a performance that fits his character as perfect as any performance can fit a character. And both Anne Bancroft and Katharine Ross are absolutely fantastic too. The three are all so mesmerizing and enchanting.
‚ÄúThe Graduate‚Äù is a damn masterpiece and for me a perfect example of cinematic perfection. I loved everything about it. Every second, every frame, every tone, every dialogue and every second of the performances. The film is everything I could ever ask for and so much more.

Mrs Robinson are you trying to seduce me?
Yes, as it turns out she was. The Graduate was better than I had ever hoped it would be. Truly brilliant in pretty much every way. Let's start with those performances, my golly Anne Bancroft in all her cougary glory was truly remarkable and Katherine Ross as the sweet yet strong one who gets caught in the middle. But Dustin Hoffman was just the full package, he was a little awkward but confident and headstrong and genuinely funny. His awkwardness contributed to that but ultimately he just made everything seem to have a little edge of comedy, his character was so endearing and loveable he totally carried me through the film.
The music is magical, Simon and Garfunkel are so criminally under-utilized by the film industry, they had 3 songs I think in this film and everyone one of them fitted the context perfectly, added to the melancholia or the panic and boy was there panic, towards the end I was looking at the clock thinking "no this isn't enough time" this is one of the few films that I actively wanted to be longer. The whole time I was so heavily invested in this relationship which seemed doomed from the off. But they were so sweet together and one of my only criticisms is that I wish we could have seen more of Ben and Elaine and less of Ben and Mrs Robinson. On top of that it was a really funny film, I laughed hard that I have laughed at a film in a while and this from a non-comedy. As I mentioned earlier the awkwardness was a big part but also Benjamin's whit was outstanding. Right now I'm sort of feeling like I did with nocturnal animals, absolutely loved it but for one little problem which stopped me giving it 5 but for this one I have to go with 5. It was remarkable right up to the last scene which was filled with uncertainty as to whether or not this would work out. Fabulous film.

Movies don't age but movie reviews do. Some get the two mixed up, perhaps naturally. Ebert, in his unintentionally comical 1997 re-review, said that 20 years later, The Graduate was a movie of its day and not the present; in fact, he's referring not to the movie but to how it was interpreted; many apparently read it as a piece of counter culture, which indeed was naive. But that's not the movie's fault. (I agree, incidentally, that it was revolutionary not in general but for a kind of movie and especially for a kind of moviegoer). Kael picked up on this but left it neither here nor there. She felt, as some do, that the movie starts strong only to go cheap after "turning" Mrs. Robinson "bad". I find this to be simplistic and cutting the movie short, driven by this wishful thinking that because Anne Bancroft is so sympathetic, and because Mrs. Robinson initially has some degree of psychological mystery, she must also be the underdog hero somehow.
Everyone had good amount of time to notice what the movie is truly up to, which is to tell a story about being young and unsure about the future; this is simply but distinctly contrasted with the adults, who are conscientiously stuck in the dead-ends of their lives. The first scene plants this quite obviously, with Benjamin saying he wants his future to be "different". The whole movie is about him trying to make some kind of desicion even though he's shooting in the dark; he's no hero, nor is he a bad person, but he does learn. He takes some kind of charge. This why I prefer the Swedish title over the original (which doesn't happen too often); here it was called "The Manhood Test", which admittedly doesn't sound good in English but I like how it randomly notices that, yes, Benjamin is challenged by adulthood; as a title, "The Graduate" is much more suggestive to the fact that you should read Benjamin as a symbol for some kind of general societal change (and this was likely not the intention, as it wasn't in the novel, which this apparently follows quite closley).
This is not to say that Benjamin does a very good job of growing up. In fact, his success can't even be measured as the movie ends before any kind of ramifications can be seen; in any case, his quest to retain poor Elaine is in no way an act of maturity or pure will - though again, future romcoms have distorted our view of the ending perhaps, where Benjamin simply doesn't care anymore and where Elaine is possessed by a kind of momentary lapse of judgment; I'm sure there's a psychological term for this. The ending is an act of desperation from both parts; when you don't know if you should stay or go, you can only momentarily run. It's the same thing that triggers suicides, a burst of an impulse that is purely reactive. None of them have any judgment or experience in regards to the realities of life.
All they really know is what they don't want (at least not now, and at least not like this). It is very hard to keep out the notion, and I think it's quite an optimistic one, that they'll both end up fine wherever, with whomever, and that this whole episode will just end up a big anecdote; as the 60s rolls by, an entire world of decorum is buried with it, and in the modern world, one cannot consider this story provocative. Young people are crazy. It was a bigger deal in 1967 than even in 1977.
And since Benjamin and Elaine are crazies, not rebels, the adults are not square fascists but merely normal. Mrs. Robinson, by contrast, lives in a fixed world of set values; she may cheat on her husband, cynically taking advantage of a young man too inexperienced to have a say in the matter and that is precisely why her mellow moment in the bedroom (where she admits to "sort of" having lost interest in art) is so touching; because how she allows herself, this one moment, to let her guard down. Notice the sublime ease with which Bancroft allows for Mrs. Robinson to allow the conversation to lead her to an inevitable place of pain. This is not something she talks about easily; it looks like she's flying easy on top of her own psyche, but she is actually doing some advanced manouvering to avoid real pain. (This is why I mention the Ebert review as comical; not only is he provoked as a middle-aged man by what he loved as a young man, walking right into the very same anti-authoritarian trap he set 20 years before; he desperately holds on to this weird case of stubborn projection by claiming that Mrs. Robinson seduces Benjamin "out of kindness or desperation"; this is not an opinion but a direct lie). And as we see, the moment her lifestyle is threatened she is ready to sacrifice everything to keep it up.
This doesnt make her evil, just predictable; indeed, this trap she's living in is the bad circle that generates her entire behavior to begin with; were she not protective of her destructive lifestyle, she would not mood alter with alcohol and feeble boys (again, it's astonishing to notice how effectively the character blindsided many critics, who simply saw too much of themselves in Mrs. Robinson to allow for her to be an antagonist).
Benjamin is not predictable, but that is to be expected. He may very well end up precisely as dull and gray as any of the adults. But as with many good stories about youth, The Graduate is not actually about speculations about the future but about what the present feels like. The movie, especially the ending, captures the notion of a young person aching along with the world. The same thing happens in Moodysson's Fucking √Öm√•l; both films capture that strange sensation one has but a few times in life, as a young person, when you may cast yourself to the wind and notice a kind of rip in the fabric around you; the feeling that something actually happens now and you don't know why or what it means. He takes the advice from Mr. Robinson, funnily enough, to shackle off a bit and be young. There is excitement in the air, there is somehow nothing between your mind, your body and the rest of the world; as if you're a free spirit soaring in the wind.
The final moment is classic for a reason, it resonates every time you see it. Just like in Moodysson's film, we slowly land in the real world. Everyone who's not present (in The Graduate it's the screaming parents in the church) somehow grow in our minds the further away the bus goes. And as it goes, they suddenly look like prisoners in a jail bus; the destination is the rest of their lives, of course, as we all know. And if you don't, yet, go easy dear child and I'll see you later.

After watching The Graduate over a dozen times, I am still finding new and unique ways to relate to this film. The shot of the two monkeys cuddling while laughing at a lonely Ben at the San Francisco Zoo is one of the most powerful moments in the entire film that I always overlooked until now. In a way, it's symbolic of the entire film's themes. Loneliness sucks. And when you're lonely, it feels like no one else is.
I'll always be a little worried about my future, but while watching The Graduate, I feel slightly less worried. The Graduate is a film that speaks to me more than anything else, and it's truly one of the only things that is able to remind me that I'm not actually as alone in this world as I think.

I once went out on a few dates with an experienced theatre actress and director who told me she‚Äôd never heard of Marlon Brando. I‚Äôll just let that sink in. I suddenly had a hunch any possible future between us was likely in serious jeopardy in that instant. I couldn‚Äôt get over the fact that an accomplished actress did not know who Brando was! To me its kind of the equivalent of not knowing what oxygen is. Why do I bring this up? Because, now the shoe is on the other foot. I have my own ignorance confession to make. This is the first time I‚Äôve seen The Graduate. But to my defence I have known what it is and that it exists. Up until now I‚Äôve been able to smartly dodge my ignorance by politely nodding whenever the topic arose. Thankfully, I can now proclaim my instant admiration for this brilliant film.
After watching it twice in succession along with the many supplements on the disc, thankfully now I‚Äôm fully able to be conversant on this seminal film. The commentary track containIng a conversation with director Stephen Soderberg interviewing Mike Nichols is easily the greatest thing ever recorded! The amount of innovation in this film is staggering. It just boggles the mind that risks of this magnitude in filmmaking seem so rare today. It‚Äôs odd isn‚Äôt it? With all our innovation and technology, on the surface it would seem we have so many more advantages now compared to then. Maybe it‚Äôs just that so much has been done now it‚Äôs that much harder to innovate. Whatever the reason, I‚Äôm so happy I‚Äôve found, at last, this seminal film to inspire. 
Even though it didn‚Äôt workout between the actress and me, I hope that WE can continue on post-confessional. ;) LOL. Btw, it wasn‚Äôt the Brando thing that ended us, we just turned out to be in different places. I‚Äôm mean, if you don‚Äôt know who Elvis and you call yourself a singer, that‚Äôs a pretty different place to be than most.

This film feels mostly like a '60s in-joke, but without the cultural context and angst and ennui of the age, it's just barely mediocre. Or barely bearable. Mostly because of Hoffman's character being thoroughly detestable. How are so many people empathizing with this? You are rich and bored so you fuck your father's partner's wife and then run off with her daughter? I get shit was confusing in the 60s, but goddamn is this film barebones and crude. It has a wink and a nod at the end, but way too little too late. Does not excuse for the rest of the film that made me want to call the Marx emergency hotline.

Much less horny than I once wanted to think and much more melancholy, even straight-up sad. Maybe the movie I‚Äôve most needed to see a second time, even if only to put my already-high esteem into proper perspective.

The Graduate gets better every time I see it. It has taken me quite a long time to recognise its brilliance. I have seen it every few years since I was fifteen, and now in my early thirties I fully acknowledge its masterpiece status. I think most people come to this conclusion fairly quickly and early with The Graduate. The Graduate is an easy film to like, it is remarkably and consistently funny throughout its 100 minutes, it has two superb performances from Anne Bancroft and Dustin Hoffman and an incredibly likeable one from Katherine Ross; it is directed with a wild invention and has one of the great song-track soundtracks. The refrain of "Hello, darkness my old friend" becomes more and more resonant every time it is used. A wonderful melding of sound and picture.
The aspect of the film that most stood out to me on this viewing was Mike Nichols ability with the camera and his direction to tell jokes, highlights lines and underline comprehension. There is a lovely moment where the three main characters are in the same space and it dawns on Elaine (Katherine Ross) what has been happening, Nichols draws from out of focus to into focus, Ross has a slight look on her face and all of the audience understands that she understands without the need for any dialogue. It is a small moment, but Nichols is fully in control of the film.
The Graduate is uproariously funny, glib and witty; it treats existential ennui with a perpendicular irreverance. Nichols has a wonderful command of the material, the first half hour is particularly amusing, the initial seduction scene remains one of the great sequences in all film. Anne Bancroft steals the whole film for me. Her character, I think now, is the most sympathetic, there is genuine pain to her performance and the character evokes great empathy, even when she is lashing out. It is a remarkably atuned piece of work. Though, I will say Anne Bancroft is clearly not old enough to play Katherine Ross mother and Dustin Hoffman's older woman, she is easily still in her thirties and, frankly, looks amazing.
Dustin Hoffman's stammering Ben is really fun to watch, I love the transformation that goes through him during the film, particularly towards the end. His passive existential distress giving away to a frenetic desire, willingness to throw everything away for essentially not much. All underlined by Nichols in one of cinema's best, and most ambiguous endings. An ending that gets sadder and sadder every time I see it.
Wes Anderson owes a heavy debt to this film, he has been lifting its style and themes for twenty years, but I am not sure he has ever made a film quite as good. Quite as affecting or effective. You'll laugh through your tears and sing lines from Simon and Garfunkel the rest of the day. "Hello, darkness my old friend..."

Some of my favorite things on rewatch:
- Nobody except Elaine talks TO Ben. They‚Äôre all talking at him or talking about him, nobody has a conversation with him. It‚Äôs safe to assume the same for Elaine based on the harsh decisions she makes at the end.
- The Sound of Silence is used to show the loneliness characters feel in certain scenes. It‚Äôs use in the final scene gives one of my favorite effects, making me want to cry, smile, and giving me chills all at once.
- Nobody grows to understand Ben during the movie, not even Ben himself. He starts uncertain of his professional future after college and ends uncertain of his personal future after running off.

-Extreme overuse of Scarborough Fair

The graduate is one of the few films that I consider to be perfect. Within an hour and forty-five minutes, Mike Nichols manages to package in everything I was every wanting from this movie, with a well done mix of comedy, drama and romance, that leads to a finale that while a bit over the top, yes, feels appropriate and is absolutely hilarious in execution.
When it comes to the film, there isn't really much I can pick out as my personal favorite element, cause it's all done so damn well. The Direction By Mike Nichols is fantastic, with every scene feeling extremely thought out and well done. It's so damn good, you could say it's oscar-worthy. So damn Oscar worthy it Got Mike his only oscar. The Cinematography by Cinematographer Robert Sertees is absolutely gorgeous, taking advantage heavily of the lighting of each scene to cast lots of shadows over the various characters through the film, making every shot feel unique in how it's shot and lit. Many shots have become iconic because of how great they are, and for good reason. The shots with Bejamin in the pool, the leg shot seen in the poster, and of course many more are all extremely memorable, along with the final shot of the film, representing the entire journey that they have gone through. Amazing work overall.
The productions design is of course phenomenal, and all of those types of technical aspects are great. The editing (Sam O'Steen) is perfection, with various edits helping add to the comedy especially, but also being used to tell the story in unique and interesting ways.
I know I just said that I can't pick out my favorite aspect, but what I can do is narrow it down to my three favorite parts. The performances, the script, and the music.
The performances in the film are top notch. You can tell everyone involved cared a lot about the production, and as a result every single performance feels extremely natural, and it doesn't take long for you to forget that they are actors, and start to think of them as the people they portray on screen. Anne Bancroft is Fantastic as the titularly lonely and alcoholic, Mrs Robinson. Katherine Ross is of course great as always As Elaine Robinson, bringing the right amount of confused and Steadiness to the role to bring her to life and give her a personality unlike any other. The real talent here, However, is Dustin Hoffman in the role of his career. He gives the exact amount of awkwardness his character needs, and delivers every line with perfection. Many of the most memorable Deadpan lines come from his mouth and simply wouldn't be as memorable coming from any other.
In my opinion, the graduate should have won the academy award that year for Best Screenplay the year of 1967. The script is among the best I've ever seen, with every single scene written excellently. Each character feels extremely fleshed out, and the plot at hand has the possibility of becoming unremarkable, but instead is written with the exact tone needed to make it as memorable as it is. Each line if dialogue is fantastically written, and each moment of comedy is hilarious. What's also remarkable is the pacing. It's paced so perfectly with every scene going on no longer or shorter than needed, and as a result of how entertaining it is, the experience of watching it flies by.
And then you have likely the most talked about part of the movie: the music. If you know me, you know I love the duo Simon and Garfunkel, so of course I'm going to adore a film with every track is one of there songs. Many of the usages of the Singers' Various songs have since gone on to become iconic, especially the sound of silence scene. One of the most famous scenes ever made, and it deserves it. Every usage of their tracks fits extremely well with the scene and tone, and adds a lot of emotion and value that I don't think the film could achieve with a more simple score. Definitely a major highlight of an amazing film.
Among the best of the 1960s film stands the graduate, deserving every bit of praise it gets. From the memorable characters and amazing comedy, it rises above the rest of the comedies of the era to give us a unique and expertly told story that only Mike Nichols himself could give us. Each time I rewatch, I expect this film will resonate less as I get further away from Benjamin Braddock's 21 yr old young man's angst. And yet I just keep loving it more & it keeps gets deeper & it feels much less about a specific age than just being alive.
Like most people, I prefer the pretty much unimpeachable & impeccable first hour to what follows. But the second half has grown on me more & more as a pretty unflinching look at the confusions & delusions of the American psyche.
It may be commonplace -- I dunno -- but it seems clear to me that the major theme of the film is Benjamin & Elaine's struggles to not become mere objects. To avoid the mild affluent inhumane passivity of their parents. Ben & Elaine want to be humans with passions & ideals & dreams.
The basis of their entire torrid, tumultuous ordeal is just one single night of human connection. It's not even that romantic. They just simply feel human around each other in a way that they don't around their parents or the general population.
The famous last scene, where Benjamin & Elaine's elation at escaping her wedding hits the reality on the bus: "what's next?" They don't know. Maybe it'll work out. Probably it won't. They've mistaken their escape from objectified status for the confirmation of some kind of love.
I think we're supposed to feel the irrationality & possessiveness & immaturity of Benjamin's stalker-esque pursuit of Elaine. Likewise her strange reciprocation of his obsessiveness. They are trying to flee the same condition, but confuse each other as being the antidote to it.
Within this strange melodrama of stunted individuals -- there isn't one fully self-knowing person in the film -- we get some of the most perfect filmmaking in American cinema. I've noted this before: Sam O'Steen's work here might be my favorite editing in any film.
It's no wonder at all that this was such a smash. It catches the spirit of disillusionment so well -- in Benjamin of course, but also in Mrs. Robinson, who only grows in stature & tragedy for me as I get older. As the movie unfolds, I get almost impatient anticipating each scene.
And the music is genius. There are very few stretches of pure filmmaking & editing & scoring that I love as much as the stretch summarizing more or less the entire summer fling between Benjamin & Mrs. Robinson in the form of the most soulful music video of the pre-MTV era.
Basically, this is one of a dozen or so films that I can watch & internalize endlessly. It always feels fresh & new & urgent & surprising. I can't imagine ever growing tired of it.

This diary entry was part of a 52 Weeks Challenge (Week 23: 1960s). The themes of the challenge, my more comprehensive reviews, and theme recommendations are collected in that list & also included below.
SPOILERS FOLLOW IN 'COMMENTS'
Theme: 1960s
Comments: My motivation in picking this movie was really just the way it's referenced in (500) Days of Summer, one of my favorites, so I figured I would get the context around it.
I expected this to be one of those slow-burning, awkward films considered "classics" and that I wouldn't play along, but I was genuinely surprised. The real highlight of this was the direction and shot choice. There were a lot of cool focus pulls and interesting imagery that made it a very enjoyable watch just from a technical perspective.
I was also taken aback by the subject matter and the nuance of the actual plot elements. There is so much moral ambiguity and subjectivity in this story that it almost felt like a case study of romantic relationships. The acting is terrific too, and without that, the entire premise would fall through.
My only gripes are the ones I usually have with movies pre-1985; the dialogue feels clunky and shots are often too drawn out, showing unnecessary detail, plus the speech can have weird, awkward cadences. The pacing is also a little off, with a lot happening back-t0-back and the plot advancing super quickly at times.
Theme Recommendations I've Already Seen: Dr. Strangelove, 2001: A Space Odyssey

The cinematography is incredible here man. Every shot feels deliberate. Every zoom and every pan has purpose. Negative space is brilliantly used to isolate the characters feeding into the sense of aimlessness and loneliness. The soundtrack is great as well and I‚Äôm sure my grandparents thought this movie was hilarious. I‚Äôd safely assume that the Better Call Saul team went to The Graduate school of filmmaking.

‚Äúi‚Äôm a bit worried about my future.‚Äù
benjamin braddock is waiting for something. he doesn‚Äôt quite know what that something is, and he wouldn‚Äôt know what it was if it came up to him, but he know‚Äôs he‚Äôs waiting for it.
if only it could already show up.
mike nichols‚Äô the graduate is a movie that pretty easily stands the test of time. an existential comedy that touches on the uncertainty we face in life as we grow older, relationships we get trapped into, and the expectations people have of us based on the merits and skills they believe that we have. it‚Äôs about the social situations we find ourselves in and it‚Äôs a perfect example of suburban ennui and the ways in which things that we show to the world may not necessarily be our truest selves. dustin hoffman is amazing in this as well. i love watching the transformation that he undergoes from beginning to end, starting off as shy and anxious, then slowly becoming more confident in who he is after his tryst with mrs. robinson (a seductive and narcissistic anne bancroft). the character of mrs. robinson is such a fascinating one, as she transcends the stereotype of the bored housewife and becomes something all the more sinister. there‚Äôs inklings of depth to the character at times, particularly the scene where she talks to benjamin about how she got roped into marrying mr. robinson, and i would‚Äôve loved to see more of that honestly. her argument with ben in the hotel room where ben berates her and tears her down seems so out of character for ben (at first), but upon closer inspection i think it speaks a lot to the character as a whole. ben is someone who is diligent in his thoughts, who prefers to ponder over his situations and think clearly about them. it‚Äôs what causes his immense anxiety in the beginning of the movie. but we also see that, when backed into a corner, ben is a reactive and impulsive person who throws his careful plans out the windows. he is the one who initiates the affair by calling mrs. robinson, he is the one who closes the door and starts the relationship, he is the one who pursues elaine despite warnings not to and he is the one who drops all plans for his bright future to pursue (and get) the girl. it mostly works out for him too, which says something about how impulsivity often leads him into situations that can be seen as better for him, but are also detrimental in others. another subtheme that i think is really interesting is the very quick mention of plastic at the beginning, the so-called material of the future. it‚Äôs a business which ben has easy access to and yet, compounded by his own fears of what the future may bring for him, is something he chooses to not pursue. it says a tom about the overhanging worry about the finality of choosing a future can mean for one person. the ending for this is one of my favorite endings to a movie i think i‚Äôve seen this year. the triumphant glee on elaine and ben‚Äôs face that gives way to nervousness, the picture perfect look at how even already they‚Äôre questioning the decision they made, the slow fade back in of the sound of silence. it‚Äôs masterful, as is the whole soundtrack and the way it‚Äôs used to highlight moments of change. one of the greatest american films ever made.

‚ÄúElaine, it‚Äôs too late!‚Äù

Oh my gosh, I just adored this film!!

BASIC REVIEW
A film that communicates very well everything it wants, even when we don't want to face its messages. Many people told me that the ending was sad and the last minutes of the film were an eternal agony for me for this reason, but when Ben and Elaine get on the bus and their faces are deformed in a vortex of feelings with no future I finally understand what the level of sadness Nichols' masterpiece released in theaters in the 60's. It's not a sad ending, but the ending the protagonists wanted and the ending we wanted. The consequences of this romantic impulse that approaches a truly cinematic and dreamy resolution will only appear after the adrenaline. Love, the now, the present is what is enough, or what will continue to be missing. Nichols' brilliant directing is not only enviable, but hateful; Watching "Closer (üë©üèº)" before "The Graduate" left me ending up as confused and immature as Ben and Elaine, as there isn't the same exorbitant, seductive subtlety as Nichols in the 2000s film, ending up as a merely amateurish, brainless piece of work, different how visually delicious and precise "The Graduate" looks when it wants to talk about the guilt of immediate success in a generation born on promises, to perpetuate promises from their parents (the shot of Ben's father's face taking up half the camera and completing the other half of Ben's lonely face is a genuinely complex and sad example of the heritage of our parents' mistakes). Even in the most erotic scenes Nichols avoids controversy and still manages to bring all the sensuality of the predatory desires of a funny and impulsive Hoffman devouring Anne Bancroft. Everything is very calculated, but breathes with a creative care that each symbol and dialogue understood manages to unite drama and caricature causing a strange masochistic pleasure in the spectator. Some passages even resemble a dreamlike reality caused by all this sexual rebuke in constant struggle with the norms of growing up, the social isolation within the brain itself that turns a simple welcome dinner into a horror short film, and the celebration of a dive into a possibility of mental suicide. When things try to be fixed in the end, Ben and Elaine get carried away by the choices, and their barriers come down. Like a Schr√∂dinger's cycle, we will only know who to blame for the unhappiness of the protagonists' lives until everything goes wrong and we observe, trapped, the seduction of the first experiences that led them there. Until we get back to the Robinsons, it's as much the fault of the parents in this story as it is the false graduates of the school of life.

Everyone has their first time, and this is mine. For me, the sign of a great piece of art is that it offers multiple, often contradictory interpretations, each perfectly valid on its own terms, and that is certainly true of The Graduate. Had I watched this 20 years ago, I am sure I would have had a great deal of sympathy for Benjamin and seen Mrs Robinson as a self-obsessed monster, and now I think the opposite is true.
What is left to say about The Graduate? I loved every second of it, even when I was being beaten over the head by Simon & Garfunkel.

Like the lead, we have no choice but to ride along and watch what unfolds, through fast and quippy dialogue, unraveling with speedy finesse and red-hot wit. Bogged down by delayed gratification, the immediacy of a desired choice has enticing pleasure as well an option to completely disregard immediate consequence. When the desolate future reveals itself, it‚Äôs impossible to ignore and is somehow able to create a fully-formed, existential dread appear without warning. This film encapsulates exactly that‚Ä¶ I think.

Mike Nichols
American romantic comedy-drama film based on the 1963 novel of the same name by Charles Webb, who wrote it shortly after graduating from Williams College. The film tells the story of 21-year-old Benjamin Braddock (Dustin Hoffman), a recent college graduate with no well-defined aim in life, who is seduced by an older married woman, Mrs. Robinson (Anne Bancroft), but then falls for her daughter Elaine (Katharine Ross).
Kritiker loben den Film weiterhin, wenn auch nicht immer mit der gleichen Begeisterung. F√ºr die Neuauflage des Films zum 30-j√§hrigen Jubil√§um zog Roger Ebert einige seiner fr√ºheren Lobeshymnen zur√ºck und bemerkte, dass er das Gef√ºhl habe, dass die Zeit abgelaufen sei und dass er jetzt mehr Sympathie f√ºr Mrs. Robinson habe als f√ºr Benjamin (den er als ‚Äûunertr√§glichen Wimp‚Äú ansah), wohl als eine Folge des Alterns und zunehmender Weisheit.
Zusammen mit Gene Siskel gab Ebert dem Film eine positive, wenn auch wenig begeisterte Kritik in der Fernsehsendung Siskel & Ebert. In der abflauenfen Begeisterung sind die beiden Epigonen der amerikanischen Filmkritik nicht allein: In der AFI-Liste der gr√∂√üten amerikanischen Filme fiel THE GRADUATE allein in den Jahren 1997 - 2007 von Platz sieben auf Platz siebzehn...
Ohne den brillanten 60er Jahre Soundtrack von Simon & Garfunkel w√§re der Film l√§ngst in Vergessenheit geraten. Wenn wir jetzt noch die ausgezeichnete BW-Cinematographie (Kamera Robert Surtees, Ben Hur) abziehen, dann bleibt nicht viel √ºbrig vom klischee√ºberladenen Musikfilm-Klassiker.

Maybe because I'm at a stage in my life where I'm closer in age to Mrs. Robinson than I am to Benjamin, but this is the first time watching this film that I realized it's really about two lost people, not just one. I've always watched this from Ben's shoes, but Mrs. Robinson's just as lost and adrift as he is, trying to reconnect to that lost feeling she had when young. Her story is a tragedy and what she sets into motion over the course of this film really isn't going to work for anyone involved. It's devastating.
That's why the film works so well time and time again. Ben's story of connecting with Mrs. Robinson's daughter Elaine is wonderful, but it also ends in that powerful last bus ride that says everything about their future together. Ben may have won the battle but Mrs. Robinson's essentially destroyed all three of them.
