All time favourite films

The graduate is a perfect example of what art can generate if one puts soul and wit into it. Firstly, I find human emotions and life issues depicted in a bitter-comic manner to be a charming combination. 
This film is for anyone who's ever wondered what they are going to do with their future, anyone who's been in love with someone their parents didn't approve of, or anyone who's had an affair with one of their parent's friends. Granted, not many will fall in the latter category, but it throws an interesting spin on the film. The graduate perfectly encapsulates and portrays the feelings of self-doubt, alienation, disenchantment and unwanted pressures and expectations for a twenty-something just out of college. Dustin Hoffman is the only person we can possibly imagine in the role of Benjamin as his imprint and superb acting makes this film a great one. 
Ben is supposed to represent the confused state of a college graduate stuck in between youth and adulthood. As best depicted by the scene where he holds the hotel door open for both the elderly group and the younger group, he feels alienated from both generations. He does not want to hear the loud music of the car next to him at the drive-thru, nor is he interested in `plastics' or the materialistic pleasures of his parents.
As the movie goes on a far darker film reveals  itself, one which was not about innocent young love but obsession and loneliness. Take Ben Braddock's behaviour: one can accept his gaucheness in view of his seduction by Mrs Robinson and even his tactlessness to the older woman once the affair is underway can be excused, as indeed Mrs Robinson, a woman of the world, does excuse it. But his subsequent pursuit of Elaine, a girl he barely knows, which could all to easily be mistaken for stalking, is decidedly unhealthy. This is not 'true love' needing to find its way as we once thought, it is the obsession of a young man who knows little about the world, isn't particularly aware and quite probably suffers from a bad case of extreme solipsism.
The first part of the film went extremely well but it‚Äôs the second half which is where things start to fall apart. The only problem with the film is Elaine's character. After Ben stupidly humiliates her at the burlesque club on their first date, we suddenly cut to the now happy couple chatting away at a burger joint. What happened in between? Why didn't Ben's cruel behavior end the date right there? The filmmakers don't seem to know. Elaine runs away with Ben at the end without ever mentioning that it might have hurt her when he broke up her family. It's another inexplicable, unearned forgiveness. What real woman acts like Elaine does in this movie? How could someone so flighty and spineless make the stand that Elaine does at the end of the movie?
I don't believe there can be any doubt that the first half of the movie is much sharper, funnier, more intense, and just all-around more involving than the second half. Though I do believe that by the first part being *so* strong, and involving us so well, it does tend to make the weaknesses of the second part less jarring than they should be: we already know and care about these characters ,¬ñ and we want to follow them anywhere, no matter how sketchy and unfocused their stories begin to seem. The point I want to make here is that, though The Graduate becomes a different *kind* of film in the second half (a romance, versus the sex farce/comedy of manners that was the first half), it never ceases being jaundice-eyed and satirical about its characters. I say this because it is an easy enough assumption to make that the film makers expect us to take Benjamin's love for and quest of Elaine at face value: to believe that they were `meant for' each other, and that their ultimate triumph is a resolution to be sincerely wished for. 
Nichols' brilliant direction reinforces the complex exploration of confusion and uncertainty. The flow of shots after he first sleeps with Mrs. Robinson is incredible, as is his use of the swimming pool to enforce his entrapment. He effortlessly switches in and out of focus at different depths of each shot to emphasize certain characters and dialogue. It goes without saying that the performances by Hoffman and Bancroft are first-rate. Add Paul Simon's haunting Sound of Silence, Scarborough Fair, and the instrumentals of what would become Mrs. Robinson, and you have songs and images that downright haunting. 
Ben has no idea what he wants out of life, and only thinks that marrying Elaine will be the solution to this problem. As the last shot depicts , Ben only seems to be happy for a few seconds after he and Elaine get onto the bus with no money, no prospects, and no certain future. In fact, Nichols cleverly uses Paul Simon's Sound of Silence, and drowns out much of the background sound to show that Ben's is in the same position at the end of the film as he is at the beginning. He has not found what he really wants to get out of life and is as confused as ever. This scenario is not dated nor is it only appropriate for the 60s, it can apply to anyone who is lost or has no idea what to do with his/her/their lives. 
Overall, The graduate is a timeless classic loved by many. It‚Äôs actually a very interesting character study but it‚Äôs not entirely perfect. Accompanied by an amazing soundtrack and incredible shots, this film is definitely worth the watch.

This is my 1,000th film that I have logged on Letterboxd, which makes me very happy. My relationship with this film has been interesting to say the least. I saw it towards the end of my Senior year of High School & thought that it was good. However, truth be told, I do think a lot went over my head as I wasn‚Äôt as open minded as I am now. I watched it a again about a year or so later, liked it, but didn‚Äôt love it. I then revisited it a third time in college for a Film class where I analyzed it & I liked it a bit more. However, I hadn‚Äôt revisited it since then. 4-5 years later, I took a gamble & bought it as apart of Barnes & Nobles 50% Criterion Collection Blu-ray sale last month. I am so happy that I did. There are so many details this time around that I picked up on. I never noticed before the jaw dropping editing. Especially impressive are the splicing of shots from one scene to then seamlessly transition into another scene that is somewhere else completely. Cinematography is brilliant too. Filled with many zoom in shots, close up shots & long takes; every shot works. The acting, soundtrack, directing & makeup are all top notch too. The story & character development are also very timely with being able to look at it as a representation of the counter culture of the 1960‚Äôs, as well about young people in general not knowing what they want other then to rebel. Which leads me to the ending which I absolutely love. I think it perfectly sums up the film as a whole in a nutshell, with doing something that you think you want, but that it might actually be anything‚Äôs but that. It‚Äôs the adventure of going against the norms, rebelling, but not 100% knowing what you fully want. The story & characters are all so brilliant because every character has elements of the themes & message in them that the lead character is dealing with too.  In the end, The Graduate is a very well crafted film that gets better & better with each viewing. Filmmaking & entertainment value combined make for a truly great, influential film with many positives & comes highly recommended!

The epitome of an American classic. Thanks to Hayden for mercilessly insisting for me to watch this.
Mike Nichols' The Graduate has been a staple in American pop culture ever since its release. I've heard endlessly about the film ever since my interest in the medium spiked about a couple of years ago, and it somehow delivered on already high expectations.
My personal favorite aspect of The Graduate is the layered, consistently engaging dialogue by the writing trio (Henry, Webb, Willingham), which capitalizes on deliveries by the iconic duo of Hoffman and Bancroft, who each deliver perfect performances in both separate and collective scenes.
For something regarded as such a classic, I was expecting the narrative delivery to be a lot more by-the-books, so it was a surprise to experience how much the story plays out like such a fever dream with the help of the winding chaos of the plot, the swooping, moody camera movements, and sporadic editing by O'Steen. The most particular segment that encapsulates this aura would be the final 20 minutes and the seesaw it has your heart riding.
Many people that aren't huge fans of the film critique that they feel Benjamin is a spoiled child that doesn't deserve any sympathy for his actions, and while I can understand that on a surface level, I completely disagree:
In a lesser film, the audience would naturally be expected to justify the protagonist's actions simply because he's the protagonist, but The Graduate delivers so much more to convince its audience that this isn't one of those films. Through Benjamin's actions and mannerisms throughout the film, it's hard to argue that there isn't a deep-rooted change within his character that causes him to realize the weight of what he's done.
Whether you want to deny that or not, I think it's still wholly apparent that what comes off as a spoiled upbringing is a definite commentary that these issues of sexual repression, disillusionment, and misdirection are inescapable whether you're a rich, Helpingham award-winning track star or not.
My only minor complaint would be the commitment and downright stubbornness of the emblematic reprises of a pure Simon & Garfunkel soundtrack, more specifically the track The Sound of Silence. In most scenarios, it's used well, but there are a couple instances that bugged me.
The Graduate is the perfect coming-of-age film, as it tackles essential themes with immense efficiency and style, in a way unlike anything else being released at the time. Pitch-perfect performances, fluid cinematography, and a daring sense of editing will have you constantly revisiting scenes and shots in your head long after the credits roll. Transcendent.

Hoffman is a bored, naive college graduate uncertain about the future, in the meantime he's banging his father's business partner's wife and falling in love with her daughter. The star of it all is definitely Mike Nichols. His camerawork is so creative and influential, you can practically see him inventing a new kind of cinema before our eyes. Back in 1967 the impact must've been thunderous, I can feel it 50 years after seeing it for the first time ever. Off the shame list! Finally!

Jesus, this was a scary movie to watch as a twenty-one-year-old approaching the end of his college career. I see a lot of myself in Benjamin Braddock: less so in his sexual endeavors, but absolutely in his post-college aimlessness, and increasing stress stemming from a constant barraging of questions from family and friends of family. Braddock is literally and figuratively drifting his way through life. This was a wildly unique take on coming-of-age rites of passage, inhabited by characters I found myself shifting from feeling sympathy for to questioning said sympathy on numerous occasions, in a way that really fleshed the characters out and really kept me engaged. Hoffman, Bancroft, and Ross are all fantastic, though I was truly captivated by the former two and their particularly complex relationship. And Mike Nichols offers some very creative directorial choices, such as the strong cinematography and the editing that masks passages of time under seamless cuts. Really loved this one.
And for the record, I'd 100% let Mrs. Robinson seduce me. Anne Bancroft was quite a looker <3

The Graduate has almost everything I want in a film. Sometimes you watch a film and it just connects with you, I knew I was going to love The Graduate from the first scene. We see the main character being pushed along a moving sidewalk, like he's pushed forward by adults in the first half of the film, with Simon & Garfunkel washing over us as we focus on him.
Dustin Hoffman is marvelous. He's able to play the naive, shy, and nervous college grad so well yet later on play the cocky, lovestruck guy who gets the girl in the end. The whole movie hinges on him and he elevates it to a whole other level.
Mike Nichols direction is fantastic too. You are able to see emotion so well on screen even without any character showing it clearly. I loved some of the shots in Benjamin's bedroom with his small aquarium. There were some elaborate camera movements that really helped the scene move forward and convey new information. Of course the famous through the leg shot.
There are few films that have "it" and I knew from the beginning that the Graduate had it for me. The rest of the film did not disappoint. Most films about youthful ignorance towards love I'm going to enjoy but this is one of the best.
I can‚Äôt even believe it‚Äôs possible for a movie to hold up as well as this one does after over 50 years.

I have a weird relationship with the work of Mike Nichols. Out of the three films I've seen by him, Carnal Knowledge has been the most compelling, albeit, the least enjoyable. Working Girl was the most enjoyable, but the least compelling. The Graduate seems to fall somewhere in the middle.
On a technical level this movie is pretty much pitch perfect. Camera movements are smooth and effortless, and certain technical tricks are utilized to maximum impact (the infamous rack-focus towards the back end of the movie was magical). The sound design is crisp and the dialogue is extremely audible, especially considering the clunky TV I watched it on. The soundtrack, despite being well known, still fits perfectly. And the acting is fantastic all around.
My one gripe with the film is I just...didn't feel it. On a cerebral level I did. But I don't like watching dramas where I'm simply mentally nodding my head to every beat and going "yup, I understand the pressure of getting older, I understand the sense of drowning (metaphorically and then in an infamous pool scene brought to life by a scuba diver), I understand the sense of complicated relationships, I understand loving someone you can't, I understand having someone love you that you don't want to", etc etc (arguably the emotions Nichols is trying to bring to fruition are probably more complicated than I'm making them out to be, but I digress). I understand these emotions because I've felt them deeply. I've experienced them many times since graduating high school, and since graduating college. I continue to experience them and continue to come to a better understanding of them.
I didn't feel like I gained anything or felt any emotional heft while watching The Graduate, though. Part of me feels like this is partially due to how notorious this movie is. It almost felt too relatable. That normally isn't a bad thing but every beat in this movie to me felt like "hey heres this funny moment, here's this awkward moment, here's this claustrophobic moment, here's this angry moment, here's this gratifying moment, here's this disappointing moment." Certain scenes felt momentarily subtle, but never nuanced or complex.
I can't even fault this movie for having a lack of moods, I just felt like it was so telegraphed for some reason. I assume if I had watched this when I first started really getting into film, I probably would've loved this, who knows.
However, I have to tip my hat off to the finale of the film that completely deconstructs the "lost guy gets the girl" ending every fucking mainstream movie up until that point was intrinsically tied to (out of the three films I've seen, Mike Nichols seems to be very interested in gender dynamics and the way, we, the audience, have experienced them on film). I would've loved to have been there in 1967 when this movie first played and just seen the looks on audience members faces the moment the movie takes this fantastic nosedive from upbeat and assured, back to completely confused and saddened.
Is this another movie that audiences, can go home to after, satisfied? Nah man. Life isn't satisfactory. It's not tied up in a nice bow. You might not get the girl. On the flip side, you might. But what next? What are you going to do now? I think any interesting movie should ask the question "well, what now?" and The Graduate's final note feels like the embodiment of that question in a weird way.
Even though I don't think it's a masterpiece or spectacular, I do think The Graduate is a good movie, a good movie I appreciate and respect, and slightly enjoyed. And a movie that was very much of it's time and place.
Side Note: This movie came out a mere four years after the MPAA was formed, eliminating guidelines produced and overseen by the Catholic Church. Despite this being a PG movie, I have a feeling the Church would've probably made some changes to the story, including the ending, as one of their major principles (at least according to this random Vox Youtube video I watched) stated that "good must overcome evil." Given the attitudes towards women at this time I wouldn't be surprised -- had this been made pre 1963 -- that things would end up happily ever after. Whatever that means.

Second viewing and much like I expected, The Graduate gets a boost up to a 5 Star film for me. I don't know what it was on the first watch that made me give this 4.5 Stars, but on this second viewing, I loved everything the film does. 
It's funny, it's sad, and there's so many inventive little moments. Hoffman is perfectly cast as Ben Braddock. He plays this awkward, unhappy young man so precisely and everything he does is just amazing. I know there was a lot of other actors considered for the role, but I feel confident enough to say that this film would be nowhere near as good as it is without Hoffman in that role. The same can be said for Anne Bancroft. She plays the cougar role so so well and there's so many layers to the character that her performance is able to bring out. The way she plays the scene where Benjamin wants to have a conversation for once and she asks to talk about art is fantastic and she really elevates some great writing to a higher level. Katharine Ross is also fantastic. Ben falls in love with her character straight away in the movie and it's important for that to seem understandable for the audience, and it is because of how great she is at playing that character. All three leads were absolutely vital to this film being as great as it is.
Then there's the Simon and Garfunkel score, which so perfectly suits the film it's amazing. The little rhythms and tunes that play over some crucial moments in the film are fantastic. I think there's a lot more of their music in the second half, but that's where it's necessary. So many of their songs used in this have gone on to become classics. The perfect marriage of film and pop music.
The cinematography, direction, and editing is almost flawless. The film looks amazing and everybody's skin seems to shine with an orange glow, enhancing the California setting. So many scenes are brilliantly shot and lit, especially many of the hotel room scenes. There's so many genius cuts here too. The song "April Come She Will" plays over a montage of Ben's life and the amount of clever cuts and moments is awe inspiring. Every department knocked their job right out of the park. 
Seeing movies like this and Cool Hand Luke from the late 60's really makes me mournsome. They really do not make them like this anymore.

I completely understand why everyone loves this and why this is hailed as one of the greatest films ever made. Mike Nichols is a masterful director, Anne Bancroft and Katharine Ross give great performances, the script is tight, the cinematography and editing is great, but I just can't help being bored while watching this. I don't know what it is. It just puts me to sleep. I'm sorry, I really am, but I can't enjoy a movie that I can't stay awake for.

The Graduate is a creative, fast-paced and extremely entertaining film - and was revolutionary in its day.
The story is about the model student Benjamin, who is seduced by Mrs. Robinson, a friend of his mother. The whole thing starts to get problematic when Benjamin later falls in love with the beautiful daughter of his affair, Elaine. A simple and ingenious story that never gets boring.
Dustin Hoffman plays his first big role in The Graduate and does a good job, as does Anne Bancroft and Katharine Ross. The staging is also very successful, some settings of the film have even entered the history of film, especially the iconic beginning and end scenes. One thing bothered me about the movie, but it is absolutely subjective and due to that time: Simon & Garfunkel is just not my music. But whatever.
All in all, a highly recommended film that is still worth seeing even after 50 years.

The Graduate is one of the great time capsules in the history of the movies, and captures the deep-rooted generational divide of the ‚Äò60s with a subtle bitterness that still rings true today. And yet it remains a very funny movie, filled with enough laughs to simply pass it off as a fiendishly funny entertainment to those whose its satire misses.
A woman living in blas√© disinterest is unhappy with her empty home and cardboard cutout of a husband, and decides to do something about it. She seduces another soul as disinterested as her, hoping to find excitement again. But his boredom comes not from exhaustion with life like hers. His comes from a lack of aspiration and a mindset seemingly destined for professional and personal monotony.
Together, they share escape. We want them to be happy, and so we cheer when Mrs. Robinson breaks down the walls of her awkward, bumbling lover-to-be, but we‚Äîand they‚Äîknow that what they‚Äôre doing is wrong and unethical, so we cringe at Mr. Robinson‚Äôs every entrance and Benjamin‚Äôs mother‚Äôs inquires as to where he‚Äôs been every night until noon the next day.
This frustration, this dynamic interplay of audience alliances, and this tug-of-war between ethics and sympathy lie at the heart of The Graduate. It‚Äôs a film that encapsulates the modern mindset of justifying your existence, where we count every day as precious and can‚Äôt bear the thought of wasting it on something we‚Äôve lost interest in.
When Elaine Robinson is introduced into the story, her mother‚Äôs affair with her own soon-to-be love interest is already coming to its tipping point. By that point in the film, we‚Äôve already observed how Mrs. Robinson has sidelined her husband in favor of younger excitement. Now it is Benjamin‚Äôs turn to do the same, and the cycle comes full circle. Mrs. Robinson a taste of her own medicine, and we see her both as an opportunist and a victim of that same opportunism, all in under two hours.
Benjamin, who we once sympathized with, now comes off simply as a creepy, self-obsessed stalker. And so we‚Äôre ambivalent about all three major players of this scandalous love triangle: Benjamin is truly in love, but we can‚Äôt ignore the sins of his not-so-distant past. Mrs. Robinson is now ostensibly the ‚Äúvillain‚Äù for hypocritically forbidding Ben to date her too-good-for-him daughter on account of his affair, but we understand her concern, and it‚Äôs not as though she had taken advantage of Benjamin, anyway. Elaine is the innocent collateral damage, but her inexplicable quickness and willingness to forgive makes us think she had it coming.
By the time it‚Äôs all said and done, we don‚Äôt wish a happy ending for any of these characters, but we sigh and accept it when it comes. The people who take the morally questionable path are the ones who end up riding off into the sunset, while we‚Äôre left feeling sorry for the poor saps like Mr. Robinson who are blindsided by the wrongs of the people around them. Isn‚Äôt that how it usually happens in real life?
But following every sunset is a nightfall, setting the same vicious cycle back into motion for the day to come. The film‚Äôs final shot shows the wedding-crashing Benjamin and the nearly wedded Elaine glancing at each other in nervous glee. We expect this from a couple riding off into the horizon together, but the film suggests another reason for their wordless exchange. They both wonder how long their happiness will even last.

'The Graduate' is one of the greatest films ever made. Landing with Embassy in summer 1965, 'The Graduate' was a major success, opening in 950 cinemas and grossing $35 million dollars; Nichols won an Oscar for Best Director. In a 1968 press release, producer Joseph E. Levine described the film‚Äôs success as ‚Äúlike an explosion, a dam bursting‚Äù, predicting the film would become ‚Äúthe highest-grossing film in motion-picture history‚Äù.
www.newyorker.com/magazine/1968/07/27/the-graduate
But 'The Graduate' was equally shaped by the experimentation emerging from the French New Wave, on the cusp of the emergence of New Hollywood amid transformations in technology, film schools and American counterculture. As Mark Harris explores in his 2009 book 'Scenes from a Revolution: The Birth of the New Hollywood', aging executives and the commercial failure of big budget family friendly musical spectacles like 'Doctor Dolittle' left room for new voices. But as Nicholas Godfrey writes, many of New Hollywood‚Äôs lesser-known works display ‚Äúformal and thematic adventurousness that far exceeds the ambition of the films now typically identified with the New Hollywood canon‚Äù, offering ‚Äústylistic maximalism‚Äù and ‚Äúpoliticised self-critique‚Äù; the influence of Godard is ‚Äúdifficult to perceive‚Äù, accounting to a ‚Äúgeneral loosening of intellectual shackles‚Äù.
sensesofcinema.com/2016/feature-articles/outer-limits-new-hollywood/
'The Graduate' was shaped directly by its period. Nichols had directly engaged with the Civil Rights Movement: as he tells in 'Mike Nichols: An American Master', he performed with Elaine May at Selma, recalling the 20,000 marchers and people fainting. Jacob R. Brackman describes in his illuminating 'New Yorker' piece the ‚Äúnational nervous breakdown‚Äù. In his 1987 audio commentary for the Criterion laserdisc, Howard Suber notes a scripted deleted scene with Benjamin Braddock (Dustin Hoffman) hitchhiking.
‚ÄúWhy aren‚Äôt you there?‚Äù the man would have asked, again and again, referring to, but significantly never mentioning the word ‚ÄúVietnam‚Äù.
‚ÄúBecause I‚Äôm here,‚Äù Ben would have replied.
As Frank Rich notes in his Criterion booklet essay, the characters are ‚Äúuniformly upper-middle-class (or wealthier) and white‚Äù; Benjamin never smoked pot and doesn‚Äôt fear the draft; Berkeley‚Äôs students are ‚Äúunreconstructed frat guys‚Äù from ‚Äúthe Eisenhower fifties‚Äù. Brackman offers a different picture, celebrating the film‚Äôs ‚Äúlook of today‚Äù, arguing the Berkeley students aren‚Äôt from a ‚Äúdozen years ago‚Äù. But as Harris writes, ‚ÄúEisenhower was barely out of office when Webb had first gotten the idea for his novel‚Äù (2009:122); Doris Day and Reagan were considered for the Robinsons.
Upon release, 'The Graduate' created a cultural conversation. As Harris describes, ‚Äúthe film‚Äôs release marked the first time in many years that so many American moviegoers had felt the direct sting of a generational insult‚Äù (2009:381), becoming a hit amid college students and baby boomers, no longer relying on the epics and musicals their parents chose for them (2009:382). As Suber notes, what was new was ‚Äúhow many people there were‚Äù; Braddock‚Äôs peer group had increased by 60%, the amount of college students doubling. Writing in 'Vanity Fair', Sam Kashner notes students at Columbia University in spring 1968 ‚Äútook turns sneaking out of the occupied president‚Äôs office to go see The Graduate‚Äù. But some objected to the lack of radicalism; as Brackman comments, the ‚Äúsubversive message‚Äù is that you ‚Äúcannot sustain an opposition to America‚Äù; youth must ‚Äúfind someone to submit with‚Äù.
www.vanityfair.com/news/2008/03/graduate200803
A 21 year-old graduate from Williams College, the same college author Charles Webb graduated from, Benjamin Braddock conduits the anxieties and uncertainties of drifting in an uncertain world. According to Harris, Nichols saw Braddock as ‚ÄúHolden Caulfield‚Äôs literary descendant‚Äù (2009:50), over a decade after 'The Catcher in the Rye'. As screenwriter Buck Henry tells Harris, him, producer Lawrence Turman and Nichols saw themselves as the ‚Äúprotagonist of the book‚Äù (2009:119). But Hoffman‚Äôs casting was controversial: speaking in 'American Film' in 1979, Levine thought Hoffman was a ‚Äúplumber who had come to fix the leaks‚Äù (2009:276). Hoffman returned to New York registering for unemployment (2009:311). Speaking in a 2007 commentary with director Steven Soderbergh, Nichols described Hoffman‚Äôs as ‚Äúorganic‚Äù; he never contemplated ‚Äúchanging anything‚Äù in the industry of stars.
Benjamin‚Äôs awkwardness and isolation is rarely captured on film. Hoffman ‚Äúworried about his ability to manufacture nervousness on camera‚Äù, shaking through ‚Äúthe entire movie‚Äù (2009:311). In a deleted scene from the screenplay, Benjamin is shown giving his valedictorian speech (2009:291), but Nichols introduces Benjamin as an emptier slate. In the opening, we pan out from Ben upon the airplane, as the intercom announces their descent. He stands in isolation, down the escalator against the white wall; luggage reiterates his isolation, asking if the tags match, when Ben has no match of his own. At his parent‚Äôs house in Pasadena, this isolation becomes pronounced. Family friends list off awards and accolades: a track star, the college newspaper, debating club. Mr McGuire attempts to seduce Benjamin, suggesting a career in plastics. Suber notes a deleted scene from the screenplay where a ‚Äúminiature set‚Äù depicted mute adults as ‚Äúgiants‚Äù hosting a dinner party. But his life is his own. The camera moves through upstairs, drifting through like Ben. Production designer Richard Sylbert achieves genius in Benjamin‚Äôs room: a fish tank, dartboard, model ships, sailboats and a globe, juxtaposing an outgrown childlike sense of play and yearning for escape; a framed picture of a sad clown in the corridor reflects his inner state. In reflections upon the glass aquarium, Buck Henry sought to convey ‚Äúthe disaffection of young people for an environment that they don‚Äôt seem to be in synch with‚Äù (2009:314).
But perhaps one of the most well executed elements is its use of the family pool as communal space. In his commentary with Soderbergh, Nichols recalls conflict with Turman over the scene in the wetsuit, wanting to create an image of Hoffman as a ‚Äúcreature in the corner‚Äù. Shot through an Aeroflex camera, we follow Benjamin through first person perspective, forced into the water by his parents. As Suber parallels, both 'The Graduate' and '2001: A Space Odyssey' encased its protagonists in ‚Äútechnological apparatus‚Äù, focusing on ‚Äúdeep, aspirated breathing‚Äù to reflect ‚Äúa combination of terror, isolation and imminent suffocation‚Äù. 'The Graduate' is built by images; as Harris notes in 'Scenes from a Revolution', Sylbert wanted a ‚Äúcolder, more muted palette‚Äù that ‚Äúrefract[ed] Los Angeles through a prism of East Coast amusement‚Äù, photographing ‚Äúevery ostentatious new faux-whatever mansion with a swimming pool‚Äù in Beverly Hills they could find. One deleted scene from the script panned out in a helicopter to reveal 30 identical homes and pools. Speaking in a 2007 audio commentary with Katharine Ross, Hoffman comments he ‚Äúhad been born into a generation not dissimilar to this‚Äù, his father a Depression baby embracing materialism and consumerism; Nichols and Hoffman wanted to depict drowning around the ‚Äúworship of objects‚Äù. Benjamin must negotiate his relationship with his parents: he sits by the pool sunglasses on, unable to see their faces. As he shaves by the mirror, steam engulfing the room, his mom pries into affairs; learning to shave, but still cutting his thumb. Over breakfast, his mom mixes pancake batter, acting as a clear family construct; suggesting he get with Elaine (Katharine Ross). At the suggestion of marriage, his mom lets out an excited screen; as the phone is picked up, the toast pops, right on cue.
Benjamin exists within a liminal space, without purpose: he sits in his bedroom watching TV over a beer, needing to get off his ass. Benjamin has expectations of what life has in store for him, but cannot put his finger on it; as Nichols tells Soderbergh, those ‚Äúwho expect wonderful things have serious problems‚Äù. Author Charles Webb remembers his mundane existence before the film‚Äôs release, stocking perfume in a Pasadena department store, working as a shipping clerk and in life insurance. The disillusionment of Benjamin extends beyond the generational sense of loss of 60s youth and an unclear path in life; as Harris writes, Nichols realised Benjamin was a ‚ÄúJew among the goyim‚Äù, ‚Äúa visitor in a strange land‚Äù (2009:319), mirroring his adolescence as an immigrant from a German mother and a Russian Jewish mother growing in Berlin. As Nichols recalls in 'An American Master', he attended a ‚Äúspecial Jewish school‚Äù, remembering ‚ÄúBlackshirt kids taking my bike‚Äù. As his boat from Germany departed, he stood as he listened to Hitler‚Äôs ‚Äúunintelligible‚Äù speech. Speaking in 'Vanity Fair', Nichols remembers the Bremen landing in New York, shocked by a ‚Äúdelicatessen with Hebrew letters‚Äù and ‚ÄúRice Krispies and Coca-Cola‚Äù. Hoffman experienced anti-Semitism through his childhood and casting, living in ‚Äúanti-Semitic neighborhoods‚Äù in L.A., returning to those same neighbourhoods where he felt aware ‚Äúof how different I looked from them‚Äù that he‚Äôd escaped in New York.
Pursuing a secret sexual relationship with family friend Mrs Robinson (Anne Brancoft), Benjamin adopts a pseudonym as Benjamin Gladstone. Nichols underlines neat juxtapositions through his awkward comedy: elderly couple pass at the hotel entrance, a vision of the age that will meet him one day; crossing between contexts, the clerk (screenwriter Buck Henry) asks if he‚Äôs ‚Äúhaving an affair‚Äù; the party mistakes him for a porter. Benjamin‚Äôs sexuality is covert: communicating with Mrs Robinson over the payphone asking for the room number; taxis and guests crowding around the booth. The immaturity of his rite of passage is a mess of contradictions; the act of booking a hotel room is a sign of status and adulthood, devalued by his inability to interact with hotel staff. In the Soderbergh commentary, Nichols comments the young man/older woman formula is a ‚Äúclassic situation‚Äù and how ‚Äúmost guys started their sex lives‚Äù; it ‚Äúhappens again in every generation‚Äù. Driving in his red Alfa Romeo across the sunset bridge, moving through trees, green lawns and night gives a feeling of freedom. We speed through the climax, running out of gas and running out of breath.
Both Mrs Robinson and Benjamin negotiate power dynamics. As an older woman, Mrs Robinson has power and allure. During one scene in rehearsal, Hoffman describes ‚Äúbreak[ing] the scene‚Äù as both him and Nichols cracked up; he ‚Äústood against the wall‚Äù and ‚Äústarted banging my head‚Äù. Benjamin‚Äôs relationship has foundations within immorality, but Mrs Robinson never acknowledges her own power, victim blaming and twisting Benjamin into a ‚Äúrapist‚Äù, becoming increasingly acidic. Dave Grusin‚Äôs score underlines their generational difference, utilising a jazzy music cue. But Benjamin looms over with the upper hand, decrying her to Hell as a ‚Äúbroken down alcoholic‚Äù, their relationship the ‚Äúsickest, most perverted thing that ever happened to me‚Äù. When he tells Elaine it‚Äôs all over, it ‚Äúwas just something that happened‚Äù. The stresses and anxieties of the past become just another anecdote.
Mrs Robinson‚Äôs coercion should not go unacknowledged. As Ben takes her home at night, it‚Äôs under the guise of protection, feeling safe with the light on; she offers a drink attempting to seduce him; violates his own private space; she enters the room naked, appealing to her own desires. She asks Benjamin if he would like her to ‚Äúseduce‚Äù him, throwing back Ben‚Äôs question as though appealing to his desires. Surtees and costume designer Patricia Zipprodt are immaculate in using setting and outfit to reflect character, from Mrs Robinson‚Äôs black dress to leopard skin coat; she sits on her black sofa watching TV with bourbon, greenery overgrowth behind her; Sylbert wanted to literalise the image of Robinson as a wild beast. In the commentary with Soderbergh, Nichols points to the fact he had ‚Äúmonths and months‚Äù to prepare, allowing thought to be taken into strap marks visible on Mrs Robinson. Mrs Robinson still has her story: the cigarettes she smokes, her fractured marital relationship, her tears as Nichols moves out from her crying face, her abusive scream as Ben tries to tell his own story. Her husband‚Äôs initial brief interactions with Benjamin communicates perfect dramatic irony and comic timing, giving Benjamin relationship advice on women filled with assumptions, suggesting he ‚Äúought to sow a few wild oats‚Äù and that he has to ‚Äúfight ‚Äòem off‚Äù; Benjamin responds with emotionlessness. As Mrs Robinson recalls the conception of Elaine in the back of a Ford, Benjamin must deal with the reality of Elaine‚Äôs age and the nature of their relationship. Nichols creates suspense: as he confronts Elaine about his relationship with her mother, Mrs Robinson‚Äôs head appears in the doorframe, foreshadowing Jack Torrance‚Äôs murderous rampage in 'The Shining'. In his commentary, Suber emphasises Mrs Robinson‚Äôs and Benjamin‚Äôs separate narrative arcs: Ben‚Äôs narrative is a comedy, ending in ‚Äúintegration and fulfilment‚Äù; Mrs Robinson experiences tragedy, ending in ‚Äúalienation and frustration‚Äù. Mrs Robinson is a narrative function as the active agent and aggressor; at the pivot, Benjamin ‚Äúseizes control‚Äù of ‚Äúdestiny‚Äù.
Elaine is introduced from the beginning: in Mrs Robinson‚Äôs bedroom, a picture of Elaine sits behind them, watching in in plain sight. The 60s bought its own wave of films about love, sex and relationships; 'The Graduate' is but another lens to express values about sexuality and relationship politics, positioning marriage as a rite of passage. As Hoffman notes in his commentary with Ross, Benjamin‚Äôs dates with Elaine carry a 1950s vibe, going to a drive-in burger place; as he describes, they‚Äôd be ‚ÄúRepublican kids‚Äù. Benjamin is rebellious, driving across the curb; taking her to a stripper. On the Boulevard, Nichols captures a documentary quality, moving past young teenagers through a long lens. Elaine‚Äôs presence allows for a different environment in which to view these characters: the study halls and sports halls of the University of California, shot over 1 day without permission in the Berkeley campus. But Benjamin and Elaine have little chemistry; Benjamin has few date ideas besides coffee; he stares at her across campus through a fountain. Elaine‚Äôs relationship with Carl becomes a perfect Redford stand-in: blonde, inoffensive, walking through the zoo as Benjamin stalks her. Marriage carries uncertainty: Ben‚Äôs conversation with his parents about his intention to marry is a masterpiece in comic diffusion, stressing his ‚Äúhalf baked idea‚Äù is ‚Äúcompletely baked‚Äù, before admitting ‚Äúshe doesn‚Äôt like me‚Äù. In bed, as he asks her, tired and asleep, yawning and embracing; she tells him ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know‚Äù. Their screwball comedy-esque wedding has become the centrepiece, shot with a focus on close-ups as Ben screams for Elaine. The final scene parallels Elaine‚Äôs earlier departure on the bus, Ben running runs after her. They sit in silence, uncertain of their future. As Nichols tells in the Soderbergh commentary, the ending was ‚Äúcreated by my unconscious‚Äù; rather than laughing, they look terrified and upset. As Nichols concludes, his ‚Äúdefinition of shooting a movie‚Äù is to shoot ‚Äúuntil something happens than no one could have predicted‚Äù.
Benjamin‚Äôs relationship with Mrs Robinson opens a question around what sex represents. In the age of the production code, sexuality was repressed, but as the production code tore itself apart and foreign cinema pushed boundaries, 'The Graduate' allowed shock cuts to the breasts of a stripper substituting for Bancroft. As Stanley Kauffmann wrote in a contemporary review in 'New Republic', the ‚Äúmoral stance‚Äù is ‚Äúrefreshing‚Äù, accepting ‚Äúa young man might have an affair with a woman and still marry her daughter‚Äù, though ‚Äú[m]oral attitudes‚Äù are ‚Äúgetting stricter and stricter‚Äù. As he concludes, beyond the ‚Äúmoral revolution‚Äù of ‚Äúcontemporary American fiction‚Äù from decades ago, cinema makes these statements ‚Äúintrinsically new and unique‚Äù.
newrepublic.com/article/120348/stanley-kauffmann-reviews-mike-nichols-graduate
Mrs Robinson realises it‚Äôs his ‚Äúfirst time‚Äù, stressing it‚Äôs ‚Äúnothing to be ashamed of‚Äù. Benjamin‚Äôs inexperience plays in subtle movements: unable to take hangers off the rail, touching her breasts, undoing her zip, but without devolving into lewd sexuality. In the bedroom, Surtees uses shadows; Benjamin kisses Mrs Robinson, inhaling smoke. Nichols took advantage of Hoffman‚Äôs experiences: he asked him when he first had ‚Äúany action at all‚Äù (a junior high production of 'The Jazz Singer', performed in blackface) (2009:294) and his struggles buying rubbers from a female clerk (2009:310). In the novel, Benjamin spent three weeks on the road post-graduation, admitting to his father he slept with a few prostitutes. By removing this backstory, Nichols elevates Benjamin‚Äôs awkward inexperience around sex to a place of greater universality; more people have had bad, awkward sex or should expect bad, awkward sex than have slept with prostitutes. Nichols was caught between two uneasy places: an industry of sex comedies that, as Harris writes, featured ‚Äúas little sex as possible‚Äù (2009:313), and a film under Levine that didn‚Äôt feature sex, with Levine suggesting an arthouse poster with Hoffman and Bancroft naked (2009:361). Writing in the 'Vanity Fair' piece, Turman recalls novelist Calder Willingham‚Äôs ‚Äúvulgar‚Äù draft of the screenplay, incorporating ‚Äúgratuitous homosexual and man-woman sex.‚Äù Benjamin seeks human connection within a relationship that cannot allow it: he wants to ‚Äúliven up a little conversation‚Äù, before finding there‚Äôs nothing to talk about. As Kauffmann writes, the film‚Äôs ‚Äúsexual dynamics‚Äù allow Benjamin to ‚Äúassess and locate himself in every aspect‚Äù in identity formation, beyond the ‚Äúsexual sphere‚Äù.
Perhaps one of the most important elements is the soundtrack, using a selection of songs by Simon & Garfunkel. But 'The Graduate' isn‚Äôt a Simon & Garfunkel film, without the commercial backbone of 'A Hard Day‚Äôs Night' though still promoting an artist and album in the process. Though some films play best in silence, a good soundtrack isn‚Äôt just interested in the charts, but in consistency. Simon & Garfunkel‚Äôs split might still feel tragic, but their 6 years together produced gems; my parents grew their relationship together to Simon & Garfunkel, and did the same to their kids.
The recurring theme of 'The Sound of Silence', cutting between the blackness, the pool, water and reflections, reflecting Benjamin‚Äôs ‚Äúdeep depression‚Äù of his ‚Äúemotional suicide‚Äù of ‚Äúfuck[ing] Mrs. Robinson‚Äù (2009:360), and its return in the final scene, and Scarborough Fair during the montage at the zoo, are incredible beyond words. During the final race to the church, Simon riffs along, in the zone. As Hoffman recalls in his commentary with Ross, Nichols told Hoffman the film has ‚Äúno second act‚Äù; the ‚Äúsecond act is Simon & Garfunkel‚Äù. As Nichols tells in his commentary with Soderbergh, Paul Simon ‚Äúwas so clearly Dustin‚Äôs voice‚Äù because his voice was still ‚Äúsearching‚Äù. Nichols had listened to Simon & Garfunkel as a morning ritual (2009:358), the duo receiving $25,000 and reaching the top of the billboard.
Having trained in theatre, Nichols embraces the theatricality of cinema in his attention to performance and small details, through 3 weeks of rehearsals (2009:290) and 100 days of shooting. Speaking in 'An American Master', he recalls being stunned when he first saw 'A Streetcar Named Desire' and the power of its performances. But 'The Graduate' is equally made by visuals, with freedom to move and shoot from a long distance that would continue through New Hollywood in films like 'The Panic in Needle Park'. Surtees pays close attention to the sun and rain, reflections upon the hotel table upon Benjamin‚Äôs meeting with Mrs Robinson and in the car window, and the dimmed lights as Elaine‚Äôs father confronts Benjamin. Kauffmann enthused of Nichols‚Äô formal effects: his ‚Äúexpansion and ellipsis‚Äù, ‚Äúsubjective time‚Äù in sound editing and the ‚Äúballetic‚Äù, ‚Äúquintessential rhythms‚Äù akin to Kurosawa. As Brackman enthused, Nichols was like ‚Äúa child who has been given a great many presents at once‚Äù, discovering the ‚Äúcamera will do all sorts of remarkable stunts at his bidding.‚Äù
Speaking in in the commentary with Soderbergh, Nichols cites the long takes and filled frames from 'A Place in the Sun', and Preston Sturges‚Äô endless shots where it felt ‚Äúlike something really happening‚Äù. Speaking in 'An American Master', Nichols rejects the notion of auteur theory. Nichols argues ‚ÄúFrench guys with cigarette ashes all over them‚Äù had ‚Äúmisunderstood the whole thing‚Äù, whilst ‚Äúignor[ing] our greatest directors‚Äù. As he concludes, whilst ‚Äú[o]ne man can‚Äôt make a movie‚Äù, the film itself has to ‚Äúcome from one mind‚Äù.
When I first watched the film aged fourteen, the same year I watched 'Metropolis', 'Modern Times' and 'Seven Samurai' for the first time, I was transfixed by how radical its filmmaking style felt. But I‚Äôd already been introduced much earlier: in 'The Simpsons' episode 'Lady Bouvier‚Äôs Lover', the closing scene in the church is transposed with Grampa and Jacqueline Bouvier, complete with a parody rendition of 'The Sound of Silence'. The Graduate has lived on in the popular consciousness: 'Saving Face' modelled its final act on the church in 'The Graduate', using the same tropes to explore 21st century Asian American lesbian identity and generational love. 'The Sound of Silence' has become one of the most precious memes. But 'The Graduate'‚Äôs power has never left.

A great and intense coming-of-age movie with a great soundtrack. The audio and the visuals blend perfectly together.
Dustin Hoffmann delivers a great performance as a young unexperienced boy that goes into adulthood with all the consequences that love and desire bring.
Anne Bancroft is brilliant as the cold, calculated and bored woman that seduces a young man.

"The Graduate" (1967) is a classic film directed by Mike Nichols, adapted from a novel written some years before.
The film follows Benjamin (Dustin Hoffman), a recently college graduate that returns home and fights the most frightening and confusing thing for people to think about and question: the Future. Besides that, we watch him being seduced by an older woman, Mrs. Robinson (Anne Bancroft), and entering into a love spiral.
The thing is the "relationship" isn't, at least for me, the most important thing about the character, but a way to show what's going on in his troubled mind.
In the intro scene, we watch Ben on a moving walkway, almost like being pulled back to the past (his hometown and family house). After that, the scenes like the pool one, where he's at the bottom, just felt like isolation, melancholy and confusion (the blue tones and the muffled sound). The last scene, for me is one of most simple endings, yet with alot of meaning: the close-up of the two characters shows us their expression of happiness, yet for a brief moment, until the doubts and question of life come again. Also, the soundtrack is stunning and completes all the feelings surrounding the picture, along with the great acting.
All in all, "The Graduate" is a must see classic.

The film moves at a very fast pace and the performances feel so real that you forget you are watching a movie sometimes. After Benjamin (Dustin Hoffman) graduates from college, he is trying to find himself as one of his parents friends (Mrs. Robinson) try to seduce him into having sex with her. She becomes very convincing, so they sneak around. While this goes on, his parents really want him to marry her daughter. Everything spirals out of control here and the film unfolds. I loved watching this movie, but there was a little too much "sexuality," instead of development in the story. Still, it is a great film all around with fantastic writing, great motivations, and a superb cast. "The Graduate" is worth it's hype!

An absolutely immaculate production. Wow! Dustin Hoffman instantly stamps himself into the annals of comedy history, his performance is so brilliantly awkward and questionable, his misdirection achingly relatable at times. The entire film is out and out an editing masterclass - some of the greatest montages on screen, some of the finest symbiosis between picture and sound (with a rightfully heralded score). It's easy to take for granted films that align their audiences with the protagonists so effortlessly, but The Graduate really pulls this off to a tee. That 4K restoration brings out the beauty of this film, so much so that it really doesn't look as if it's aged a day (the water hues!). Just a lovely way to spend 100 minutes.

Isn‚Äôt it kind of amazing that when we reach about 20 years-old and get to college, graduate college, or hell even graduate High School there‚Äôs this implanted expectation upon us that we‚Äôre supposed to the fit the mold of what our elders anticipated us to be? Rather we just forge our own paths of destiny to define our journey after unparalleled success? 
It‚Äôs so crazy to think about the fact that I don‚Äôt go to school anymore and all my life I‚Äôve tried to meet the expectations of so many of my family members and never once was I presented with just a simple, ‚ÄúCongratulations‚Äù, but tagged along with that was a constantly unnerving question of, ‚ÄúWhat are you planning to do?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat are your sights set on?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the next step?‚Äù But reality has never been that way. We never know what‚Äôs truly next.
We intend to make plans or abide by social norms to satisfy the needs of others but do we ever stop to wonder if this is what we really had in mind? Then when we do take that inevitable next step it‚Äôs down a path we never initially intended, and then it‚Äôs a domino effect from there on out. 
What Mike Nichols does is nothing short of a masterclass in direction. How he goes about achieving those goals and accomplishing them the way he did is the definition of ‚Äúfilm-making‚Äù. Dustin Hoffman delivers a wide-ranged performance that covers all bases and powers the film forward like an immovable force. 
The Graduate is everything I love about movies and everything I love about the experience of watching one. I feel as if I‚Äôll never see a bad movie in my life ever again after seeing this. 
BRA-VO.

The Graduate is a classic coming-of-age story with some of the best acting I've seen from Hoffman. It's a film about the mistakes we make, the loss of innocence and youth, and pursuing the ones we love most. After watching this again in a theater, my biggest issue was the shock I felt when Ben started to stalk Elaine. On the slightest whim, he transplants himself to an apartment near Berkeley, roams the campus hunting for the girl, and then follows her onto a bus. He confronts her in a manner that came off as very frightening and creepy (in fact, I even exclaimed with a whisper "that's so creepy!" only to hear the row behind me chuckle‚Ä¶

The Graduate made me realize that the only beneficial aspect of growing old is gaining a better understanding of The Graduate. The rest of aging compromises of a cycle of aimlessness and regret. No matter what, I'll always laugh at the acidic suburbanite party at the beginning and I'll always get chills down my spine when the new generation futilely rebels at the end. But while the characters and story will stay the same, my perspective on them will inevitably change. I'm worried by the thought. I'm worried about my future. I'm worried about life.

Probably the most nihilistic coming of age film in the American canon, even Godard couldn't turn his nose up at this one. Anne Bancroft's performance is stained into my soul - she effortlessly conveys Mrs Robinson's constrictive manipulation through a veneer of middle class politesse, but her longing eyes still provide that underlying sense of loveless menopausal desperation which completes her character. Equal parts terrifying and sensual, while somehow still being heartbreakingly sympathetic - she has to be one of the most truly human characters I've encountered in cinema so far.
The 35mm presentation at Bradford's Media Museum was exceptional, one of the only things keeping me alive is the promise of their widescreen festival later this year. Who knew that one of the UK's finest cinemas was situated in Yorkshire's anus?

My initial reaction to this film was confusion over finding no logic at all in the decisions made by Ben and Elaine in the second half of the film. But as I think about it a little more, I think I come closer to understand what director Mike Nichols was going for.
First of all, this was a film whose existence I've been aware since I first watched 500 days of summer back when I was 15 years old. I already knew about the iconic ending, so it was nice to watch the film and finally get some context over how things finally lead do that point.
There is a lack of direction, a feeling of confusion and uncertainty over the future that is relatable to me, certainly at this point in my life, nearing the end of my course and student life. Ben starts out as a proper young man, refusing Mrs Robinson's advances, hyper focused and stressed about his future. He is a character that is in dyer need for a purpose. There is also a heavy desire to be a contrarian and to chase the forbidden fruit, to disregard the whishes of the elders in a rather rebellious way, perhaps driven by the urgency of creating a new roadpath for himself. The ending is indeed beautiful, probably the strongest part and it captures precisely what the character is about. Youthful desperation to grasp whatever it is that we're searching for in life. Whether that may be just a burst of adrenaline or true love. From the looks of their faces in that final shot, it seems like it was the former.

This was a fantastic movie with an even better script. I love watching films that came out in ‚Äò67 and this pivotal Mike Nichols film had been on my watchlist for a while so I‚Äôm glad I finally got to check it out. It‚Äôs tough because there were things I absolutely love about this and some things I didn‚Äôt.
Love first, that Simon & Garfunkel score/soundtrack is literally amazing and used so well. I‚Äôve loved them since like junior high and when I first heard they did all the music for this I knew I wanted to watch it. And now I understand what ‚Äú Mrs Robinson‚Äù was really all about! The use of ‚ÄúScarborough Fair‚Äù was my favorite though, just so calming and introspective and to be used during that montage with the mood of the story, it‚Äôs a perfect pairing. The sputtering guitar as Ben‚Äôs car dies was so brilliant and added to the moment for sure. 
The cinematography was gorgeous for being such a simple dialogue driven picture, it goes to show how you don‚Äôt need an epic story to still have a lot of style even in a more subtle story such as this. The use of wide shots and framing and that incredibly isolating wide shot of him on campus and then the perfect zoom-in on Elaine... Really great stuff!
Now what I didn‚Äôt like, I‚Äôm sorry but Hoffman is great as the bumbling sort of schlub dorky college graduate that‚Äôs lost in life and doesn‚Äôt know where to start. But he just feels TOO old for the role. I think he was like almost 30 when they shot this and it felt off a little bit to me. The scuba sequence was‚Ä¶ interesting. I like the concept and the breathing sound, the underwater shot. It just maybe went on a tad too long. And I just think the relationships overall just feel rushed, not a whole lot of time in the film showing them develop. They just go on a date, cry then kiss, then they ‚Äúhave to be with you forever‚Äù and try to get married? These kids are 21 or something and it seemed so rushed. Anne Bancroft is beautiful and really great in the first act but then I feel the character kinda loses her steam when she starts to resort to the false rape allegations and with her whole demeanor it just didn‚Äôt feel accurate, like maybe this mother doesn‚Äôt go to such extreme lengths over some kid affair she has. But I get it for the story purposes. 
Overall it is a really special film and I understand why it‚Äôs held in such high regards. I liked quite a lot about it and it definitely deserves its spot amongst the best of classic American cinema.
That toothbrush exchange is one of the funniest scenes I‚Äôve ever seen
incredible. I wouldn‚Äôt even know what to do in that situation. Also that ending was so goofy I love it

I read the criterion essay before watching and Frank Rich, the author, points out that the reason it is such a classic is because it is a blend of old hollywood and new hollywood. There is absolutely truth to this, largely on a technical level, but I find the use of romance to be the best outcome of this mixture.
The famous 'Hello, Darkness' post-runaway scene is an explicit announcement of the theme of chasing something that will only bring harm to everyone in the end. However, I am more intrigued by how the rest of the film portrays Elaine and Ben's relationship. The cold process of courting from old hollywood remains, yet the casual attitude towards love and sex invades, highlighting the empty prospect of both. I can't decide if the film goes harder against one or the other, as the combination of the themes indicates complexity. This is a film where no option was correct because every turn was so wrong. At the end of the day, that's why people relate to it. Life is too complicated to have a triumphant ending. Even that which appears triumphant, will likely end in disappointment.

Nichols‚Äô grasp and creativity in using distinctly cinematic techniques‚Äîbe it zooms, scene transitions, and just editing in general‚Äîmakes it somewhat hard to believe that he was first and foremost a theatre director (and that this was only his second feature!). The satirical shots at ‚Äò60‚Äôs American suburbia (‚ÄúPlastics‚Äù! Loveless marriages! Those clothes!) are pretty specific to the time but the cringe comedy and exploration of post-graduation what-am-I-going-to-do-with-my-life anxiety are timeless. At the same time, the film seems to me less iconoclastic than its reputation or what one would expect for a classic American film of its era; Ben‚Äôs ‚Äúconcern about [his] future‚Äù turns into an aimlessness that, I think it‚Äôs safe to say, doesn‚Äôt lead him unto great places. Maybe adhering to the norm of going to graduate school woulda been better for him than, you know, starting an affair with his dad‚Äôs business partner‚Äôs wife. Perfect except for the fact that I can‚Äôt believe any woman in the entire world would respond to Ben‚Äôs insane ‚ÄúI love you!‚Äù antics. Dude is a total cheesebag.

This was a first-time watch for me. It is a film that is almost a time capsule of what I imagine 1967 was like as I can't picture it sitting snuggly in any other era.
The story is simple enough, recent Graduate Benjamin (Dustin Hoffman) is seduced by older woman Mrs Robinson (Anne Bancroft) after he gives her a lift home from a party thrown by his parents t celebrate his graduation. The two begin an affair that continues until Mrs Robinson's daughter Elaine (Katherine Ross) returns home and catches Benjamin's eye.
The first half of the film is light, breezy and very funny, as the chaotic, bumbling Benjamin tries to keep his affair secret from everyone, the second half turns a little sinister. The courtship of Benjamin and Elaine progresses very quickly, he practically proposes marriage after their first date. The final half-hour shows Benjamin develop rather abusive behaviour towards Elaine, including stalking and imprisonment, which results in the now-famous conclusion which is rather baffling on Elaine's part.
I'm sure at the time it was played lighter than it comes across now so I will attempt to judge the film on the time that it was set.
It is beautifully shot and carries one of the finest soundtracks probably of any film as Simon and Garfunkel's folk led sensibilities perfectly capture the feel and essence of the film. Performance-wise it is excellent, both Hoffman and Bancroft excel and there is strong support from Ross, Murray Hamilton and William Daniels.
Shot with an almost psychedelic haze by Mike Nichols, there is never any doubt that this is set in the summer of love. There are plenty of scenes set in and around a swimming pool that glistens in the summer heat throughout.
An interesting film throughout. I preferred the humourous first half to the overly chaotic second.
Honestly was way better than I thought. Very modern film for 1967.

Whenever I read about a movie being selected for preservation by the US National Film Registry, it‚Äôs characterized as being, ‚Äúculturally, historically, or aesthetically significant,‚Äù - that description, always makes me think of The Graduate. The Benjamin character (Dustin Hoffman) is actually quite unlikeable, but the general malaise surrounding that post-college time period is relatable (for many, I‚Äôm sure). Director Mike Nichols uses creative camera techniques that give an artsy feel, which seems unique for the era. The soundtrack, consisting primarily of Simon and Garfunkel songs, is iconic and a perfect fit.
There‚Äôs an absurdity to the story that really just continues to ratchet up all the way to the end, but it‚Äôs never to a point of being off putting or taking the viewer out of it. Ok, maybe the church scene feels like a bit much, but the final bus scene gets us back to a much more subtle ending that leaves you wondering. One must give credit to Benjamin‚Äôs resilience - really just a shocking amount of it.
In all seriousness, this is one of my favorite movies. It really highlights the directing ability of Mike Nichols to have a 50+ year old movie that still feels so relevant.

Another film analysis I did for my class:
As a decade filled with fear of nuclear war, paranoia of communist infiltration, and an increased prevalence of protests and movements such as civil rights and Vietnam, the sixties were a time of rising polarization and sociopolitical anxiety. The Graduate‚Äîreleased at the cusp of the decade, in December of 1967‚Äîaddressed none of these topics. As Mike Nichols, the director of the film, recounts on the Criterion edition of The Graduate, every test screening held at a college campus was met with the question: ‚Äúwhere‚Äôs Vietnam?‚Äù A question that if addressed, would likely have stripped down the film‚Äôs incredible relevance today. Instead, the movie became immortalized by having its focus on the timeless facets that everyone can relate to at some point in their life: alienation, existential worry about your future, and the dark places these things can take you.
The titular graduate, Benjamin Braddock (played by Dustin Hoffman) is fresh out of college and unsure of what he wants to do next. His life at home is meaningless and devoid of action, he is merely a spectator in the busy social life of his parents. In one of his parents‚Äô get togethers, a chain of events is set in motion which will culminate in an affair between Ben and one of his parents‚Äô friends: Mrs Robinson (Anne Bancroft). An affair which Ben initially resists, but he changes his mind after being humiliated for the amusement of his parents‚Äô guests‚Äîat his own birthday party‚Äîby being forced to model his birthday gift, a scuba suit, in their backyard pool. When Mrs Robinson‚Äôs daughter, Elaine (Katherine Ross), comes home from college, Ben instantaneously falls in love with her. This creates a big conflict with Mrs Robinson that will make her do everything in her power to separate Ben and Elaine.
At the film‚Äôs release, the critics were initially mixed about The Graduate. As Frank Rich says in his essay ‚ÄúIntimations of a Revolution‚Äù for the Criterion edition, ‚Äúsome of the most influential critics, including Pauline Kael and John Simon, dismissed it.‚Äù But there were also contemporary critics who praised the movie, like Roger Ebert, who gave it four out of four stars and called it ‚Äúthe funniest American comedy of the year.‚Äù Despite the incertitude, The Graduate turned out an enormous success, becoming the top grossing movie of 1967 and raking up seven Academy Award nominations‚Äîthough being snubbed of all but one.
Aside from it being a commercial success and one of the best comedies ever made, the filmmaking prowess displayed in all aspects of The Graduate‚Äîfrom acting to directing to cinematography and beyond‚Äîhas come to inspire and influence countless forthcoming directors; one of them being Wes Anderson. On the Criterion commentary of his movie Rushmore, as well as in some interviews, Wes mentions how influential Rosemary‚Äôs Baby and The Graduate were for the film. The most conspicuous evidence of this is Wes Anderson‚Äôs use of water as a motif. He goes as far as having a scene in which a character lingers at the bottom of the pool in one of their lowest moments, exactly like the event that pushes Benjamin to accept Mrs Robinson‚Äôs offer (Wes himself points out the direct theft of that scene).
Water is only one of the many motifs and devices used in The Graduate to portray the theme of feeling lost and alienated, and the darkness that can bring. Right from the first shot, we open with an extreme closeup of Benjamin, on the white headrest of the airplane seat, with a look of ambiguity on his face, and we hear ‚Äúladies and gentlemen, we are about to begin our descent into Los Angeles.‚Äù A descent which Mike Nichols himself says reaches its lowest point‚Äîliterally and figuratively‚Äîin the aforementioned pool scene. In the following shot, Ben steps onto the airport travelator, once again on a white background, and the Simon & Garfunkel song, ‚ÄúThe Sound of Silence‚Äù begins playing with the lyrics ‚Äúhello darkness, my old friend.‚Äù A theme that will later become apparent, Ben starts out surrounded in white‚Äîor innocence‚Äîand slowly immerses himself in darkness. But as the shot progresses and Ben slowly creeps from the right edge of the frame to the left, we can see that Benjamin‚Äôs shadow is cast on the white wall behind him, suggesting that the seed of his darkness had been already planted. This shot of Ben on the moving walkway also suggests how he is being passively dragged through life while other people‚Äîwalking in front of the camera, off the travelator‚Äîare in control of theirs.
The first scene at the hotel, on top of being one of the funniest, makes clear the symbol of Benjamin‚Äôs plunge into darkness. As he enters the hotel room, he turns on the lights, winces as if in pain, looks around the room, and turns them back off. He then turns on the bathroom light, so as to not be in full darkness while not being drowned in light, and proceeds to close the blinds. When Mrs Robinson arrives, she immediately flips on the lights, but Ben adamantly flips them back off. When Benjamin‚Äôs nerves make Mrs Robinson question his adequacy and begin to leave. Ben stops her in her tracks and‚Äîdetermined in look but hesitant in timing‚Äîcloses the door to the bathroom, making the room completely black. In the darkness, ‚ÄúThe Sound of Silence‚Äù returns, starting a montage where we see him further succumb to this darkness; closing the door to the light and to his parents‚Äîliterally and figuratively‚Äîin one shot. The montage ends with Ben drifting in the pool, once again capturing his mental state in the literal. His father interrupts him, bothered by his lack of plans for the future. In the same scene‚Äîwithout cutting, in fact‚Äîthe Robinsons arrive, and with a shadowy, disapproving look from Mrs Robinson, Mr Robinson introduces the thing that will take Benjamin out of the darkness: Elaine.
The next time we see Ben and Mrs Robinson together, in bed at the hotel, he tries to get her to actually have a conversation. She refuses at first but they end up talking, and Elaine comes up in the conversation. Ben tries to find out more about her, and when she shuts him down, he jokingly says he‚Äôll take her on a date to find out. Furious, Mrs Robinson pulls him by the hair and angrily commands him to never take Elaine out on a date. This is essentially a setup for the rest of the movie: Ben trying to get Elaine and Mrs Robinson trying to stop him. It‚Äôs worth noting that throughout the long scene, the lights are flipped on and off periodically.
Pushed by his parents, Ben does end up taking Elaine out on a date‚Äîwho unsurprisingly wears a white coat that night. Scared of Mrs Robinson however, Ben is hell bent on making Elaine dislike him. He wears sunglasses at night, drives like an asshole, takes her to a strip club, and pretends she isn‚Äôt there. Only when a stripper twirls her breasts right over Elaine‚Äôs head and she begins crying, does Ben realize how far he‚Äôs taken it. He takes off his sunglasses, and looks at her without blinders for the first time. In trying to comfort her, he reveals part of what was making him act like a monkey‚Äîsomething he will do again later among real monkeys, in the zoo‚Äîthe fact he was forced into it. They go to a drive-in restaurant to talk and get to know each other; their connection is immediate. Ben asks the car next to them if they could turn down their music, they turn it up instead. In response, Ben puts the convertible‚Äôs roof back on and they roll up the windows, blocking out the entire world outside of them; not even we get to hear what they continue to talk about.
Enraged at her lover by his newly formed relationship with her daughter, Mrs Robinson threatens to tell Elaine about their affair. In a move she wasn‚Äôt expecting, Ben rushes to tell Elaine first. Despite his honesty, Elaine doesn‚Äôt want to see Benjamin anymore, but he doesn‚Äôt lose hope. In a new montage, his face is now half covered by the fishtank, where before it was fully ‚Äúsubmerged,‚Äù and although sulking, Ben is not in darkness. With his faith unsnuffed, Ben stalks Elaine and follows her back to Berkeley, where he is successful in getting through to her and reclaiming her love. After doing so, however, Mr Robinson finds where Ben is staying, confronts him about the affair, and tells him that if he keeps seeing Elaine he will take legal action. He tries to go see Elaine anyway, but her parents have dragged her off. With an external force now between him and Elaine, Ben‚Äôs hope is grimm, and in his chase for Elaine he now drives at night‚Äîbut not in complete darkness. Once he finds out Elaine is getting married, he once again drives in sunlight as he gets closer to finding her whereabouts, though he still passes through tunnels of doubt on his way there. Of course, once there, nothing can stop them. Not even the fact that he got there as the ceremony just finished taking place. Ben and Elaine fight off the angry, disapproving crowd and get into a bus. Elaine is, of course, wearing her wedding dress‚Äîall white. Ben discovered what he wanted, and he‚Äôs got it. He‚Äôs out of the dark. Seemingly a happy ending, but as Ben and Elaine happily sit down on the bus, we don‚Äôt fade to black for the credits. Instead we linger on them for far too long, ‚ÄúThe Sound of Silence‚Äù comes back, their expressions slowly become ambiguous, just like Ben‚Äôs was in the opening shot. We cut to a shot from behind the bus and watch it drive away. When we finally fade to black, there is an awkward pause before the credits fade in. Once again, our protagonist is lost, and this time his future is as uncertain to us as it is to him.

Writing that will stay with you forever

"Well, it‚Äôs comfortable just to drift here.‚Äù
The first time I watched The Graduate, I was in tenth grade and the day after I watched it, my parents gave me an ultimatum: Either volunteer at a summer camp for three weeks or get a job. Back when my life was this simple, this was the only worry for my future that I had. As my priorities shifted in the coming years, I began to worry about my future in more substantial ways that only allowed The Graduate to impact my life in more profound and relevant ways.
After my last viewing of The Graduate, I thought that I had finally shared this film with friends who liked it, or at least appreciated it. It turns out that they all blatantly lied to my face and I‚Äôm back to square one being all by myself in my love for this film -- just like Benjamin Braddock‚Äôs cycle of loneliness at the beginning and end of The Graduate.
Every single shot and every single edit is simply and utterly perfect in The Graduate. The opening scene in particular is made up of only a handful of shots (less than ten), but it feels like a rapidly edited montage straight out of the May 11th, 1980 sequence from GoodFellas because of how dynamic the direction is. The camera is centered on Ben in a close-up, but he constantly paces back and forth as new characters surround him in claustrophobic and exhausting ways. Punch-Drunk Love also undoubtedly derived some of its style from this film.
In addition to the brilliant and innovative camerawork that permeates The Graduate, the editing is just as prevalent. Montages truly give off the feeling of time passing as well as a meandering curiosity. Specific cuts also make for some of the best use of editing in film. My favorite single cut in a film is still the match cut of Ben climbing onto the pool raft then onto Mrs. Robinson. Even the hoppy and precise editing of the nude Mrs. Robinson is simultaneously witty in its guilty and uncomfortable tone, but genius in its radical pushing of the boundaries for an American movie.
The soundtrack was revolutionary for its use of pre-released popular music in a contemporary film, but the way it uses music is just as revolutionary as the music that it uses. "The Sound of Silence" is perhaps the first use of a song as a motif in film, and it could not have been executed more thoughtfully. I can't think of any other film that cues up the exact same song not once -- not twice -- not three times -- but FOUR times in a row in the same way Mike Nichols does with Simon & Garfunkel's "Scarborough Fair" during the middle of this film. The soft, finger-picking guitar drifts in and floats away aimlessly, just as Ben does through life. The Graduate signaled the arrival of New Hollywood in more than just themes, but in style, and cinema would never be the same without the surprisingly radical style incorporated into every element of The Graduate's production.
All of the characters in The Graduate are plagued by the same problem in life -- loneliness. Some characters are aware of it, and others aren't. Every adult, with the exception of Mrs. Robinson, feels perfectly content in their "plastic," superficial, and meaningless lifestyle. It might be difficult to love any specific character in this film, but you can't blame any of them for any poor decision they make. The promise of deeper human connection can be a blinding one, and thinking you've found something meaningful in life when it's just as shallow as everything else is difficult to come to terms with.
Paying attention to the characters more, it's easier to see the tragic plight of Mrs. Robinson. Mrs. Robinson clearly doesn't love her husband. Her entire life is essentially one tragedy disguised as the 1960s ideal. She turns to Ben to escape her loneliness, and Ben comes to her out of desperation for human connection after one of the loneliest images of the entire film -- Ben in a scuba suit at the bottom of his pool as he stands helplessly in the corner of the frame. By the end of the film, both Ben and Elaine feel just as doomed to follow in the footsteps of Mrs. Robinson, ultimately leading to a loveless, lonely life, making the ending profound and meaningful in every way possible.
Watching The Graduate by myself for the first time in a long time, I found myself falling in love with it even more than I thought I was capable of. Obviously, on a purely cinematic level I was enthralled and riveted by everything in this film. The story is just as powerful, if not more powerful than it was the first time I experienced it. The Graduate is that special film for me where I see more and more of myself in it each time I revisit it. While I wouldn't say that I'm doing much with my life right now, I genuinely hope that someday I find the courage to ruin an entire wedding and elope with the bride on a bus going anywhere.
