It finally happened. It only took three years, but I've finally shown this film to friends who didn't absolutely hate it. Maybe it has to do with people being more mature in college, so they are better able to appreciate everything that this film stands for, such as the generation gap, the feeling of being lost and aimless, and the desperate search for connection in a lonely world.
Mike Nichols' direction never fails to amaze me with how intentional and coordinated every singe shot of this film is. No shot feels static. Every shot incorporates either a unique and creative camera movement, or action taking place in both the foreground and the background to make the world of the film come to life. I noticed that more than half of the shots that feature Ben have some visual device or object that is intentionally placed in front of or around him to visually convey the feeling of being trapped, restricted, and confined.
The most iconic example of this visual motif is during the film's most well-known line, "Mrs. Robinson, you're trying to seduce me," in which Ben is framed within the confines of Mrs. Robinson's leg. Glass is also the most present framing device used to separate Ben from the world as well as the audience. Behind glass, Ben is able to be viewed as normal, but he is still physically isolated from us. Even the last shot makes sure to position Ben, and Elaine for a change, behind the glass of the bus window.
The way that most of the adults in Ben's life are concealed behind shadows, or other cover-ups (with the exception of Mrs. Robinson) is effective at conveying the emotional distance Ben feels from the older generation. There are very few times in which Ben's parents or other adults are shown clearly or in full without wearing sunglasses or being hidden by harsh shadows. It's interesting how Mrs. Robinson, the only adult Ben feels like he has a connection with, is always shown clearly whenever she's in a scene. More than just being fully-visible, she dominates every frame she is in, creating a truly iconic and unforgettable character.
The use of music in The Graduate is more than simply powerful. It's revolutionary. Being the first film to incorporate a soundtrack consisting entirely of popular music, Simon and Garfunkel narrate the path of youthful aimlessness better than any instrumental score could have done. Their lyrics and harmonies are haunting and complex, sublimely conveying the exact feeling of every moment. The feeling of Ben and Elaine's temporary happiness is as weightless as Simon and Garfunkel's voices. "The Sound of Silence" becomes a motif in the film through its repetitive usage during pivotal moments in Ben's life -- moments in which he experiences the exact same feeling of uncertainty and worry about his future.
The comedy in The Graduate is brilliant. The humor is never obvious and is entirely situational. Not a single line is funny if taken out of context (maybe with the exception of, "Mrs. Robinson, I think you're the most attractive of all my parents' friends."). Every laugh arises from the combination of a visual and a line that works perfectly with the current situation to create comedy. The discomfort is so palpable in many moments because the situations are crafted so meticulously and carefully to not rely on obvious jokes for an emotional response or laugh.
When I say that The Graduate is my favorite film of all time because I find it to be the most relatable film I've seen, people who have seen this movie have trouble taking me seriously. While I have no experience in sexual relations with my parents' friends and their daughters, I have more than enough experience in feeling lost, aimless, and "a little worried about my future."

Ultimately just one of those films where I can‚Äôt quite pinpoint exactly why I loved it so much. I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs Nichols‚Äô calm, assured direction, with his use of long takes and the beautiful use of light, but it could also be Hoffman‚Äôs performance; his awkwardness and unstableness, or even how the film gradually evolves into an exploration of love and happiness, with a conclusion that made me tear up. But in reality, it‚Äôs not any one technical aspect that made me fall in with The Graduate. I guess it‚Äôs just the mood and feeling achieved. The feeling of confusion, of thoughts racing and consistently worrying about what the future holds. It‚Äôs something to which I relate, and I felt myself growing closer and closer to what took place on the screen. It left me feeling both warm and cold, feeling hopeful and afraid, but ultimately just happy.

The Graduate is a great film that I highly recommend to anyone who hasn‚Äôt seen it and wants a great comedy/coming of age story. It has a really simple story, but it is still super entertaining due to the chemistry between Dustin Hoffman, Anne Bancroft, and Katherine Ross, as well as the great humor/romance aspects. Most of the time Romance movies aren‚Äôt my thing, but this one was such a fun spin on the genre and I loved it. The first half tells the story of a woman, Mrs. Robinson, having an affair with her friend‚Äôs son, Benjamin. This gets called off about half way through the film because Ben falls for Mrs. Robinson‚Äôs daughter, Elaine. The rest of the film is about how Ben must win Elaine back after she finds out about the affair. Doesn‚Äôt sound like anything all that great on paper, but something about it was just amazing. I never got bored, and I had a smile on my face the whole time. Benjamin was a great lead character, the way Hoffman played the character was just great. Simon and Garfunkle made an amazing soundtrack that fit the movie perfectly. Also the ending was fantastic, it was the perfect way to end the film and I loved the last scene more than anything else in the movie. Overall, The Graduate is now one of my favorite films ever (in the 60s right now), and I recommend it to everyone.

Woah....don't you ever just watch something and just get amazed by it and just sit down and process your thoughts....that was me for this film. I always love films that are carefully crafted by directors who are really trying to get something special out,and my God this was something special. Oh and it's cool to also know that Anne Bancroft is a total MILF.....well to be honest she was a Milf before the term Milf even existed which is even more impressive. This film is directed by Mike Nichols and stars the wonderful cast of Dustin Hoffman,Anne Bancroft,Katharine Ross and everyone's favorite Murray Hamilton in this film that....really felt special. I'm sure we can all agree that the cinematography and pacing here is just ahead of it's time in this one and it's all just so perfect. You can tell Mike Nichols is a director who wants to make his film as perfect as possible and yeah he does certainly make a perfect film and I just.....have the biggest respect for him. Dustin Hoffman as Ben is just perfect casting and Dustin really did portray this character as I would expect and he did a phenomenal job at acting and making you really feel for the character,he really shines and makes a wonderful lead in here. Anne Bancroft easily has the best performance in here as Mrs. Robinson and she really makes her presence felt this film and makes every scene HER scene and it's just amazing to watch. Katharine Ross may have had a little less screentime then most other characters but you really get to like her and there is a good amount of development for her in her short amount of screentime. The writing/story was all just perfect and it was very interesting to watch....I will say this is one of the most interesting films I've seen by far,I just always wanted to know what was gonna happen next. Also this has quite the ending that I wasn't expecting and...um....I absolutely loved it. I'm not gonna say anymore about this film other then you're gonna love it and it's just a masterly crafted film that hasn't even aged a day...so yeah,highly recommend this MASTAHPIECE.

Mike Nichols‚Äô The Graduate is a great film. It takes an interesting premise and fuses it with strong performances, a hilarious script, and a great Simon & Garfunkel backed soundtrack. Dustin Hoffman and Anne Bancroft are particularly special in this film, delivering amazing performances. This movie does not only have effective comedic scenes, it is also successful in its dramatic moments. It is an emotionally resonant film that does a great job of capturing its time. It paves the way for countless movies of the future, and it is a pretty darn great film itself.

The Graduate is an American classic directed by Mike Nichols starring Dennis Hoffman and Anne Bancroft, and is the story of Benjamin Braddock and his maturity into life. More specifically his relations with the Robinson family. Ben is seeing Mrs. Robinson at hotels in the night, and having an affair. However once Elaine comes to town he realizes his love is not for Mrs. Robinson but for her daughter, Elaine.
The Graduate succeeds in telling two different stories, both remaining central to Ben's character. One tells the story of Ben and his first steps into the real world, and the other is the ever changing love in Ben's life. The first story is told in the first half of the movie, and the second story is told in the later half of the movie. The best part of the movie is how the two stories intertwine.
The Graduate is a really funny movie, with all the jokes being subtly hinted at. The delivery of this movie is top-notch and the talent of the actor extends the quality of the script (even though the script isn't bad at all). Also this movie is a very entertaining and captivating movie, with the story being very interesting and the runtime a very short movie.
This movie is crowded with applause and accolades, with it even landing a spot on AFI's Top 100 (I don't really remember what spot). So my opinion and rating won't convince anyone who hasn't seen the movie to watch it. However if you are hanging on to my every word, then I highly suggest this film, and if you are into classic American cinema then few films get better than this.

A movie so sublimely simple (and stylish and funny) that its easy to overlook how seminal it really was. Basically the bridge between the straightforward, played for laughs comedies of the 50s and 60s and the modern prestige dramedy (there would be no Silver Linings Playbook without this, and thats just one minor example).
I love the use of color in this movie. I love how it starts off very blue and green and then becomes brown when he heads north. I love the all time great two shot cinematography and the flawless composition and camera movement. It's also probably Buck Henry's best script, which is saying a LOT. There's sl many great zingers in the first act. I got to Buck talk at Cinefamily last year at a screening of Heaven Can Wait and he was still witty as all hell. Can't remember what he said about The Graduate though but he definitely mentioned it. He also Parke his Beemer in the car port there and asked for a large coke at the bar. Definitely a hero.

50 years! This movie came out 50 years ago, and it could have been made today. Sure, it's an average romantic comedy, but creative input and time makes this stand out from the rest. Certain scenes were shot with more depth than you think, and to understand the meaning you have to look up the making of the movie. I really like the characters because in some moments you never really know their goal or understanding. It sounds weird, but that personality trait makes the characters feel more real. Dustin Hoffman as Benjamin is the biggest praise here, I felt his struggle and understood his trouble for what he wanted to do with his future. Anne Bancroft was good as Mrs. Robinson, but sometimes I felt her character was too mean. Sometimes she would be mad at Benjamin, but I never really understood her reason why. All the actors do their jobs well. I really enjoyed the ending. It hangs on an open note, but satisfies as a closing to an enjoyable, classic comedy.

It's exceedingly ironic that the older generation in this film is epitomized by their obsession with superficiality, when the only word I can come up with to describe Benjamin Braddock's personality is "plastic." Similar to the previous decade's Rebel Without a Cause, it's a film that achieves a lot, despite having a terribly underwritten lead character (both proudly performed by two talented actors) -- characters that were written and directed by men who were only marginally in touch with the youth culture of their day. Both of these characters come from privileged backgrounds, and seem to be disillusioned by this, even though they're blatantly (blissfully?) unaware of any issues beyond their own feeble attempts at happiness. If Nichols had been able to convey a character who even remotely resembled the youth culture of the late 60s, then this film would be more than just a technical success. The saving grace in the instance of The Graduate is Nichols' still witty social satire, that gleans many laughs, even if they're partly unearned. The editing and cinematography are what really stand out -- both absolutely top notch. The music is cool, but it seems to have done more to inform Wes Anderson's aesthetic than to help the film itself. The Graduate did a lot to advance the maturity of popular films in America, but it's still a popcorn version of what the French had been doing for nearly a decade.

The characters are endearing and fun, it's funny in the most unexpected ways, and the soundtrack is a force that drives this awkward but engaging story from beginning to end, as well as really great direction. The Graduate is a terrifically acted, cleverly written, and wholly unique coming of age film!

The Graduate (unfortunately) is one of those films, that's going to go on the "I just don't get it" pile...sighhhhh. All this time I've been waiting to watch it and I finally did yesterday and I gotta say, it was nothing like I expected it to be and I feel a bit disappointed. Were nipples taboo in the 60's? I didn't think so...that moment when Mrs Robinson first undresses and the camera does several quick cuts between her nakedness and Ben's face made me burst out laughing. I guess I would have thought of it in a completely different way if I'd been watching this in 1967, but watching it today, made it seem very...aged. The thing that confused me most about this, was not long after this, Ben goes into a stripclub(?) with Elaine and you see an almost naked woman swinging tassels around on her nipples...very strange indeed.
For me, Ben Braddock was unlikable. He displayed very stalker like tendencies and he was a little but insane haha.
Mrs Robinson was a manipulative bitch (so now the Fifty Shades reference makes wayyyyyyy more sense haha).
Elaine was an absolute crazy fool.
Love does make people do strange things.
The pacing was off, the characters unlikable, but the soundtrack was AMAZE and my favourite thing about the film and the ending saved it from being a total flop, only because it was so bonkers!
Maybe I will watch it again in 10 years and try to figure it out some more.

I don't feel the need to do a full length, "critical analysis" type review for this one. There're plenty of great reviews on here already and I would be adding nothing new to what is already a very well received classic.
Sometimes, it's just easier to record what I actually thought of a particular film at a certain point in time so that when I re-watch it, or if I decide to look back on it for whatever reason, I can remember exactly what impression it left on me. What mood I was in at the time of watching. Seeing if anything changes over time.
To that end, the impression I was left with at the end of Mike Nichols' 1967 adaptation of Charles Webb's novel 'The Graduate', was a positive one. I didn't expect it to be quite as funny as it was. Ben (Dustin Hoffman,) a recent graduate terrified about the future who becomes embroiled in an affair with the mother of a girl he comes to love, is so pathetic sometimes you can't help but laugh at him. My first assumption was that he was far too naive and easily manipulated, but then that got me thinking about why he was so easy for Mrs Robinson (Anne Bancroft) to snare and control. It's because, I think, deep down he just wanted something to do, and being in a love affair gave him a purpose. He may have appeared frightened and reluctant at first, refusing Mrs Robinson's advances, yet all he was actually doing was playing a game. The very famous last scene at the end of the film as he's sat at the back of the bus as it pulls away, his face turning from one of triumph to one of .. well ... it's expressionless; that is him realising the whole "project" has completed, he's finished, it's back to "reality" and facing all the same problems he's been running away from over the past few months.
I'm sure that's not news to anybody who's seen the film, everyone eventually seems to come to the same conclusion as this, but I remember as the credits slowly faded that it was a happy ending. Gradually as I thought it over, I began to realise that it wasn't at all a happy ending for him. In fact it was probably the worst scenario for him to have ended up in. You're tricked into thinking it ends on a high just through the sheer dramatic "love conquers all" style ending, but boy, is it anything but!
Anyway... I'm not going to try and go all pseudo-intellectual and try and analyse what that all means and if/how it's a parable to the American Dream and blah blah blah. I'm sure that's there if you really look for it and far cleverer folk than I have no doubt already studied it in much more depth.
I loved the music, by the way. Can't say I've ever been a big fan of Simon & Garfunkel before now. I haven't stopped listening to them on Spotify since, however! It's a stunning sound track. The Sound of Silence is used perfectly throughout - also, I now fully understand the "I've made a huge mistake" joke in Arrested Development!
Oops. I didn't mean to go on and on and on about The Graduate. I'll wrap it up by saying that I really enjoyed it. Completely understand why so many others love it and how it came to be regarded as the classic that it so rightly deserves to be.

Awkwardness at its finest. I understand this movie so much better on a rewatch, and Mike Nichols is becoming one of my favorite directors. This film only becomes more relatable with age, as I also have no idea what I want to do after graduation. I have time, but I can‚Äôt wait to figure it out.

It‚Äôs been a while since I‚Äôve seen something this great. Often described as the quintessential coming of age film, The Graduate follows a man who just graduated from college and undergoes the typical identity crisis felt in early 20s, under the backdrop of the 60s.
It could just be because I‚Äôm in a similar point in my life, wondering what my future will be that this resonated so much with me but I feel like everyone can really empathise with Hoffman‚Äôs character, even if you disagree with some of the choices he makes later on. This has to be my favourite Dustin Hoffman performance I‚Äôve seen and can easily see how he broke out into the new Hollywood crowd - it‚Äôs true of a lot of these veterans but when it‚Äôs one of their first performances there‚Äôs a certain purity and vulnerability to their performance, and given the film‚Äôs trajectory this is a perfect place to showcase that. Further, it definitely feels intentional that the older costars are from the golden age of Hollywood, which are ultimately very different acting styles, furthering the generational gap and thus how they react to different life events. This is one of many examples of director Nichols being ahead of the times, as the perceptiveness to pick up on this shift in acting style is something I haven‚Äôt seen before.
I actually think calling this a coming of age movie is selling it short, really. In a small 106 minute runtime, themes of identity, expectation, sexuality and even depression are explored in nuanced detail and through very purposeful and often harsh cinematography, without taking a firm stance on any of these topics and leaving it to the viewer‚Äôs interpretation. This is true of the ending too, which while I don‚Äôt think is overly subtle, the small sense of ambiguity is enough to leave you pondering if the characters felt they made the right decision, which is very true of most 21 year olds.
On a side note, at the point I am in my film journey, seeing the iconography from classics like this which has been imitated so much from films after I always get so giddy to see where it actually originated from - it just feels like one of those special moments you can‚Äôt recreate again.
On that note I feel like that‚Äôs a pretty good way to sum up The Graduate, it‚Äôs simply an experience you can‚Äôt recreate. I‚Äôm so glad I watched it at this point in my life, but I look forward even more to watching it in the future as this feels like the kind of picture you‚Äôll view through a completely different lens as you get older and experience more of life, and that‚Äôs something I can say for only very few movies I‚Äôve watched.

I had a pretty unique reaction to The Graduate the first time I watched it. If I recall correctly, I initially rated it at about 1.5 stars. I really disliked it, borderline hated it. After a few days, maybe even weeks of sitting on it, it grew in my estimation. My fondness towards the ending and the wonderful Anne Bancroft performance in particular were what ultimately made me go back and change my rating to the 3.5 stars I‚Äôve had it at for the past year and a half. But today I decided to rewatch for one specific reason, I‚Äôm currently Ben Braddock.
I graduated from University back in December. I applied for numerous jobs and for the most part, had very bad luck. However, after months of waiting and doing what felt like absolutely nothing, I finally heard back from a company and got hired. These past few months, weeks and days have all been so strange. This time between finishing school and what I hope is the start of a long career has felt like an eternity with little to no positive moments. So if I can‚Äôt relate to or sympathize or root for Benjamin Braddock when I‚Äôm in the exact place in life as he is, then I never will.
So after my first viewing I walked away thinking that the acting and directing were extremely poor, despite the praise they have had garnered over the years and the successful careers of those same individuals went on to have after the release of this film. I was wrong. The directing is actually quite brilliant, and though I still wouldn‚Äôt consider myself a fan of Mike Nichols, his direction here is not the issue. It in fact is the acting, but more importantly, the script. This film is wildly inconsistent, extremely unfunny, wants you to root for a psychopath, and treats its women characters like shit.
So Mike Nichols is a comedy director and The Graduate is a comedy. But it is funny in slightest. Its attempts at comedy come from Ben‚Äôs ‚Äòquirkiness‚Äô and social awkwardness. Neither of which are charming, but rather extremely annoying. Nothing annoys me more than a ‚Äòquirky‚Äô character. Now my real issue with this film starts and ends with the character of Ben Braddock and the performance by Dustin Hoffman. Believe me, everything else I‚Äôve mentioned annoys me as well, but if I didn‚Äôt have Hoffman‚Äôs performance and Braddock‚Äôs characterization as much as I ultimately do, I wouldn‚Äôt dislike this film as much as I do. He‚Äôs insane. He‚Äôs uncharismatic. He‚Äôs smug. And with all do respect to Dustin Hoffman, and actor I greatly adore and respect, he‚Äôs just not that handsome (Robert Redford was initially up for the part of Ben Braddock, so that tells you what the filmmakers wanted this character to be). The two scenes that most annoy me are the scene that Ben and Mrs. Robinson share in the bed in which Ben gets her to tell him about how she got pregnant. And the second scene being when he forces Elaine to tell him how she got proposed to. Those scenes are clearly meant to be charming and funny but are the complete opposite.
No explanation will ever make me make sense of why both Mrs. Robinson and Elaine Robinson fall for Ben. Let me be clear, my issue isn‚Äôt why is Mrs. Robinson having an affair, it‚Äôs why is she having an affair with him specifically. Why can‚Äôt she go for someone her age, or quite literally any other human being, of Ben‚Äôs age or older. The age doesn‚Äôt matter to me, what matters to me is WHY HIM? He‚Äôs annoying, and it clearly bothers her. He also takes control of the relationship almost from the get go, often forcing her to do things she doesn‚Äôt want to do and keeps her from doing the things she does want to do. So again, she‚Äôs not with him because she can control him. Then there‚Äôs the Elaine of it all. After finding out that Ben had been sleeping with her mother, she first reacts like any person would react, by rightfully pushing him away. He then reenters her life by stalking her at school and then following her around and creating the most absurd situations. Again, why is anyone attracted to him? Why does anyone find him charming? Both the people in the film and the people who watch this film, why do people like him?
Now I mentioned that after reflecting on the film, I was won over by the famous ending and the Anne Bancroft performance. Neither worked for me this time around. I think Anne Bancroft is fine. She‚Äôs not bad and I don‚Äôt really have anything to say about her. However, I do hate the way she‚Äôs written. She exist solely to be dunked on by Ben Braddock. He ruins her marriage, he ruins her relationship with her daughter and he ruins her entire home life as well as her social life. How do you think people are going to talk about that family after the disaster of a wedding they put on, in 1969 nonetheless. As for the ending of the film, it has no substance, at least to me. Everything has gone Ben‚Äôs way during the entire film. He‚Äôs gotten everything he wanted. The final shot, while for the most part ambiguous, leans more towards the side of hinting that things will not work out between Elaine and Ben. But why is that the case? Literally everything has gone his way up to this point.
Look, to get straight to the point, my issue is this: I hate Benjamin Braddock and I don‚Äôt understand why anyone finds him to be anything other than annoying and repulsive, and all I want for him is to be unhappy for the rest of his pathetic life but that‚Äôs exactly what a piece of shit like him deserves. And while sure, the ending may be hinting that he won‚Äôt find that happiness, it‚Äôs just not enough for me. That ending does not undue all the damage that came before it.
I will never like this movie. I will never like this Dustin Hoffman‚Äôs performance (it‚Äôs easily my least favorite of his) and I will never like Mike Nichol‚Äôs as a director (I don‚Äôt like any of his films). All three of those are controversial/unpopular opinions that I‚Äôm not necessarily proud of as I don‚Äôt mean to be a contrarian, but will stand by them until the day I die.

Mike Nichol‚Äôs second feature film, The Graduate, was released in the late 1960s and shows the distinct differences between the youth and adult generations of the time. However, this film has virtually nothing to do with the late 1960s era or youth culture at all. There is no mention of hippie culture, student protests (despite featuring the most politically active student campus, UC Berkeley), or ‚Äúrebellious‚Äù rock ‚Äòn‚Äô roll that came to define this generation. Instead, The Graduate seeks to explore the connections, or lack thereof, between the people living during this turbulent era of war, protests, hate, violence, and, surprisingly, affluence.
A major theme of the film is present in the unofficial theme song by Simon and Garfunkel, The Sound of Silence. The song is heard three times throughout the film whenever Benjamin feels uncertain about his future and his current state of happiness. This song is one of many aspects of the film that made it relevant during the 1960s and keep it relevant today. The main characters in The Graduate all feel lonely many times during the film and can‚Äôt quite express their true feelings or emotions to one another. During the 1960s, this lack of communication was caused by the generational gap. Nowadays, there is a shocking lack of true emotional interaction due to the development of technology that has become the barrier between people. The film‚Äôs theme of people being unable to truly express their feelings is most clearly represented in the song by the line, ‚ÄúPeople talking without speaking. People hearing without listening.‚Äù People come in contact with each other physically, but never break through the invisible barrier to create an emotional connection with one another. When large generational gaps, technological distance, and loud, materialistic societies are present, the only thing truly heard is the sound of silence.
There is also a visual motif of glass separating characters, particularly Benjamin, from the other people around him. Ben is frequently framed behind or in front of glass, such as sliding glass doors, a phone booth, the glass window at the church, his fish tank, the goggles of his scuba diver suit, and the glass window of the bus that he rides away with Elaine on. These semi-invisible barriers serve to show the isolation and distance that Ben feels from his society and the older generation around him. He is physically present with the people around him, but never fully integrated with them emotionally. People can see through glass, but they can‚Äôt feel through it. Whenever glass or other physical barriers separate Ben, he is often very lonely and feels the least connected to others. When Ben reaches out to Mrs. Robinson early on the film, he is metaphorically trying to shatter the glass of his loneliness to forge a human connection, but this only ends in more isolation.
Similar to glass is the visual motif of water. Water, like glass, is transparent and also serves to divide Benjamin from the people around him, most often his parents. During his affair with Mrs. Robinson, shots of Benjamin floating in his pool are frequently shown. He is literally drifting through life as he questions his happiness and refuses to commit to a certain future. At his graduation party, Benjamin doesn‚Äôt want to interact with the house guests who are there to congratulate him and instead isolates himself from his parent‚Äôs generation in front of a glass fish tank filled with water and a scuba diver positioned in the bottom left-hand corner of the frame. Later on in the film, Ben‚Äôs parents‚Äô birthday gift to him is a scuba diving suit that they force him to wear for their friends. Despite feeling uncomfortable, he reluctantly tries it on and tests it out in his pool as his parents literally push him away underwater. Instead of returning to the surface where there are other people, he chooses to float in isolation at the bottom of his pool, pictured on the left-hand side of the frame, just like the scuba diver in his fish tank. He floats in isolation and loneliness as he likely reconsiders Mrs. Robinson‚Äôs offer to create an artificial emotional ‚Äúconnection.‚Äù
If there is a single word that defines The Graduate, it‚Äôs ‚Äúplastics.‚Äù During Ben‚Äôs graduation party, one of his parent‚Äôs friends gives him a word of advice: ‚ÄúPlastics.‚Äù On a literal level, this word obviously means that there is successful business to be had in the plastics industry, especially during the relatively successful consumer economy of the 1960s. On a deeper level, the word ‚Äúplastics‚Äù represents everything wrong with society to Ben. Plastic is homogeneous, false, artificial, and unnatural, just like most of the adults in The Graduate. Plastic is one of the many symbols that further divide and reinforce the generation gap of the characters in the film. Ben and Elaine seek true happiness and something much deeper than fake, artificial materialism represented by the term ‚Äúplastics.‚Äù The adults and parents in The Graduate seem perfectly content with their hollow, material lives, with the exception of Mrs. Robinson, and never try to form true emotional connections with other people. The scuba diver figurine in Ben‚Äôs fish tank is made out of plastic (probably) and Ben is later seen wearing a similar costume from his parents. This represents their attempts to project their materialistic beliefs onto Ben, but he finds no happiness or pleasure from this. Ben pursues Elaine in an attempt to marry her, even though the two of them clearly lack love for one another. The ending can be interpreted as symbolically representing Ben and Elaine‚Äôs attempt to escape the materialism of their former lives and families, but the outcome is questionable and uncertain.
The final shot (technically the second-to-last shot) is cinematic perfection. Like Ben and Elaine, I found myself experiencing the same emotions as their faces radiate with joy at first and slowly devolve into uncertainty, nervousness, and regret. Looking back, it's hard to believe that Elaine isn't even a major character until well into the second half of the film. It's a testament to the film's excellent pacing, writing, and character development. Like all great films, The Graduate is able to make so many diverse, great scenes and moments feel like they were in a much shorter film and leave viewers questioning what they previously thought they remembered.

Benjamin is just so insane to behold sometimes, making insane little noises and sputtering out with remarkable consistency and being a creep and all that. And poor Elaine, who seemingly just gets caught up in the weird crossfires of it all. A million things can be said about the ending, and I think it‚Äôs because on one hand it‚Äôs clearly a harsh comedown of realization of ‚Äúhey what did we do‚Äù but I do think there‚Äôs also just a ‚Äúwell we got what we wanted, what do we do now?‚Äù feeling that is scary but does leave the door open for life to be, if not good, then at least pretty okay. I think it‚Äôs safe to say that we are all a little worried about our futures. But, personally, I never had my own Mrs. Robinson. And that‚Äôs probably a good thing.
This was Dustin Hoffman‚Äôs breakout role in 1967, and it‚Äôs easy to see why. He does a great job as Ben, the newly-minted college graduate trying to figure out his plan for the future when an older, married woman comes along and throws his life into chaos. He knows the affair isn‚Äôt right, but feels entirely powerless to stop it when it begins. Anne Bancroft is perfect in that role, giving off as much class as she does sex appeal, gaining his affections across the board. She portrays the exact amount jealousy she feels over Ben dating her daughter that we would expect. She wants to be seen as an object of as much desire as her daughter, and when Ben falls for her instead, Mrs. Robinson simply can‚Äôt handle his decision.
Director Mike Nichols crafted an instant classic here, capturing the mood of the late 60s with a wonderful soundtrack and open ideas about sexuality. He got a lot out of his cast and, working with Robert Surtees as director of photography, achieved some great shots. The early party scene follows Ben at an uncomfortably-close clip, really pushing the sense of claustrophobia that comes with everyone having such high expectations of you at such a stage in your life. One friend of the family wants him to get into the plastics industry, but says only a few words, assuming he will take that idea and run with it to a long and successful career. It‚Äôs constricting, and that scene plays into Ben‚Äôs mindset wonderfully. Things open up, literally and figuratively, once Ben begins to make his own choices, whether they are seen as right or wrong.
Calder Willingham and Buck Henry wrote a very good script that hits all the right notes. They didn‚Äôt try too hard and overwrite their characters, trusting the actors to fill in the blanks for them. The finale of the film sees Ben interrupt Elaine‚Äôs wedding before running out with her and boarding a bus, leaving the wedding party and families shocked as they ride away smiling. But their smiles give way to a hint of underlying doubt. Have they actually done the right thing? Do they really feel this strongly about each other? Hoffman and Katharine Ross play this scene beautifully and help a great film end on an iconic note.

From the startling, subversive edits to the infectious Simon & Garfunkel soundtrack, this still feels fresher & more exciting than 95% of American films being made today. Also, THE GRADUATE easily boasts one of the coolest opening title sequences of all-time. It's been erroneously & short-sightedly dismissed as just being about the fling between Benjamin & Mrs. Robinson but it's such a brilliant, incisive satire about post-college panic & it's still perfect for twenty-sonethings, in particular.

New favorite once again! Dustin Hoffman was literally perfect for this role, he portrays the character and the feelings he feels perfectly. I love the camerawork, each aspect of it is thought out perfectly. Like how at the beginning where Ben is being greeted by the many family friends of his and how they use a handheld camera to portray the annoyance and anxiety he feels from this. Also the realization scene of where Elaine realizes that Ben had an affair with her mother is shot by making Elaine‚Äôs face very blurry and as she begins to realize the truth her face becomes more and more coherent. Usually I don‚Äôt like romances but this one is quite special. At the end, on the bus, both Elaine and Ben realize that their decision wasn‚Äôt thought through enough, which you can tell by their facial expressions going from happiness to more and more worried. I really wish I was back in California again because this movie is making me yearn to go back there. I could go on and on about this movie but I got more movies to watch so I‚Äôll end it here. Amazing and brilliantly done movie, watch if you haven‚Äôt!

Words can not describe how amazing this film is.
The Graduate is the quintessential coming of age flick, if you ignore the affair with Mrs. Robinson - as I do not think that is quite relatable. The feeling of not knowing what you want to do with your life. The feeling of your parents trying to force you into becoming just like them, having a life just like theirs. Wanting a different experience than others. Getting what you want and realizing you still have no idea on how to navigate the world or who you are.
Despite this film debuting in 1967, this film has managed to stay so relevant and relatable due to its themes and messages.
In my personal opinion, this is one of the best movies ever made. The acting, the soundtrack, the plot, the cinematography, the symbolism.. the foreshadowing. Just amazing.

Five years after first my first viewing, The Graduate remains a film that only becomes more and more relatable for me each and every time I watch it. When I laugh, I'm laughing at the movie, but I also feel like I'm laughing at myself. Watching The Graduate is like looking in the mirror for an hour and 46 minutes, except I actually like what I'm seeing.
I finally got around to exploring many of the special features on the Criterion edition of this movie and I absolutely adored everything about it. From the excessively long and meandering original trailer to the hours upon hours of interviews and insights from the aging cast and crew members, I felt like a kid in a candy store. I loved watching the crew explain how everyone hated Dustin Hoffman as the lead before the film was released. Buck Henry and Lawrence Turman recounting their experiences making this film is like watching them relive the happiest moments of their lives. It's amazing that it took me this long to take a deep-dive into the making of my all-time favorite movie, but I only love it even more now.
Watching the screen tests for Ben and Elaine by other lesser actors was quite a revelatory experience. It makes it clear how easily this film could have been ruined in the filmmaking process. All it would have taken to ruin the entire film was one overly-serious person who had no grasp of the comedic tone of the film. The other actors who screen tested weren't bad, but they were far too melodramatic and had no grasp of the material they were filming. Dustin Hoffman and Katharine Ross have such electrifying and lighthearted chemistry together. It's like lightning in a bottle.
The Graduate is filled to the brim with captivating, creative, and daring filmmaking techniques. Mike Nichols wasn't afraid to demand what he wanted while making The Graduate and it paid off. He insisted on using the church in the final scene and the film wouldn't work without it. The way the movie was filmed is so confident that it demands your attention without distracting from the story. The Graduate is one of the first American films to demonstrate the revolutionary style of the French New Wave. The use of popular music, POV shots, and unconventional editing would seem to distract from the story, but it all elevates it to brilliant heights.

I can see people quickly dismissing The Graduate as a quirky coming of age story with love affairs, but is a movie that holds more value today than anything else.
In a society made by consumerism and capitalism everyone is trying to make a meaning out of themselves is there any meaning within life?. Some could argue that the relationship the protagonist has with Miss Robinson wouldn't be that far off from the type of relationships young men/women have on Tinder or Grindr in case of gay/bi guys with older people and these people just aren't aware of what they are getting themseleves, because in the mindst of all the mandess in life, this is a movie about hopeless people making hopeless relationships trying to find something in the world, we know these relationships won't last and you are irrational thinking you will but you just want to get something out this parents would your parents rethink it twice their marriage the same way? It is something to think about in what makes life that maxes the graduate so complex and go beyond a quirky coming of age movie. But the question in life always remains
''What does the future hold?''
Is your love for this person going to be the same from 10 years on? Is your degree going to be worth it?. Because from generations and generations that's what we seek a connection to life that isn't going to last forever.
It‚Äôs an absolute genius of a movie.

The Graduate is one of those few films that really is timeless, even 50+ years later. The film is very much a product of its time from the film-making, the music choices, etc, but the way it captures the fear of growing up, the feeling of being suffocated by  expectations and generational gaps is something that transcends all time periods. I actually had this film rated 5 stars before, and now I‚Äôm feeling more of a 4.5 because the second half of this film (minus the ending) just isn‚Äôt as perfectly paced as the first half. But regardless, while I don‚Äôt think this film is quite perfect, neither are the feelings of growing up and finding a sense of purpose in life, and gosh darn it‚Äôs as close to perfect as most films ever get.

I like how at the beginning of this film the camera puts you firmly in Benjamin's mindset. The party scenes become a floating anxious-comedic nightmare, conjuring up the character's turmoil. What really makes the film special, however, is how much it begins to distance you as the film goes along. By the last act Benjamin is a rom-com protagonist with this glitz and charm fully stripped away, until he's basically The Shape hiding in the bushes stalking a woman.
It's weird how most of the characters lose their complexity as we near the last act, but I think it's mainly an effect of our POV character losing his internal complexity, becoming a rote estranged being with one goal shambling like an alien from step to step. He doesn't recognize his own interiority at this point, let alone anyone else's.
Plus, of course, that damn ending is phenomanal.

Three times I have seen this, and three times I've found myself unable to like it. Having now read Charles Webb's original novel, however, I can clearly see all of the ideas contained in the story.
On one hand, it's a somewhat universal story about the transition from childhood to adulthood, and the many conflicts that come with it; I feel that Ben's parents are representative of the inevitable responsibility of adulthood, while Mrs. Robinson represents the consequences that can come from a lack of that very responsibility.
It's also a story about the changing culture of the 1960s (that interestingly came out right in the midst of it); the children of the generation that won WWII were caught in a simultaneous flurry of privilege and expectation, and their only feasible reaction was to stand counter to what any authoritative figure instructed of them. We see that very clearly here with Ben, who disobeys his parents and the Robinsons to a point that might have a permanent effect on several people's lives, including his own (this seemingly comes to fruition in the final moment where the true light of the situation appears to dawn on Ben and Elaine).
I used to think Ben and Elaine's relationship was rushed, and while in some ways I still do, I realize now that it's rushed by design. Elaine arrives at a point in the story where Ben feels an utter sense of defeat, and he appears to see something special in her; whether it's a kindred spirit, a symbol of innocence and simplicity, or something else entirely, Ben truly feels that Elaine is the only one who understands him. As we know, Ben quickly and easily becomes misguided by that, which leads to the aforementioned conclusion, and the ultimate realization that revolution without purpose has great potential to do more harm than good.
All those ideas are there, and I suppose they're communicated well enough, but what ultimately keeps this movie at a relatively mediocre level for me is the all-around execution. I never know exactly how I'm supposed to feel or react to the events onscreen; sometimes it seems like a dry comedy, but the performances and dialogue come off as so clumsy that I don't feel comfortable laughing at it. All I can really do is take in the events and gauge my internal reactions, but the story is so oddly paced and presented that I'm never quite sure how to do that either.
What I can say this time is that, having read the book, the filmmakers and performers didn't have much to work with. The dialogue in the book is (by design) clumsy, repetitive, and without any discernible inflection, and I find that this style doesn't translate well to the screen. The technical aspects of this movie are too well done for me to think that it's some sort of terse, matter-of-fact presentation of life, but the lack of charisma is too noticeable for me to accept it as a straightforward narrative. It's a strange cinematic stalemate that I could never articulate before reading the book, but now I see where the problem lies.
I feel that I can now say with relative confidence that I'll probably never consider this to be one of my favorites. As I said before, it has some fantastically well-realized ideas that still hold plenty of weight, but the movie itself doesn't have a strong enough structure to really let those ideas shine the way they should. I suppose what I'm ultimately saying is that this isn't for me, nor do I think it ever will be. If for nothing else, I'm glad I can finally put my finger on why I don't dig it as much as many others do, but I do still have hope that someday I might come around on it. Someday...

I've been on vacation for a week so I'm easing back into reviewing with a short review of The Graduate starring Dustin Hoffman. I had seen this film many years ago but barely remember it, probably wasn't paying attention knowing me. However, upon a second viewing I was able to fully appreciate what a gem this film is.
Dustin Hoffman's performance is outstanding; his shy, naive awkwardness brought a lot of levity to the film and makes us care for him. He plays a character named Ben who has recently graduated from college but hasn't quite figured out what to do next in his life. As a graduate myself, I really identified with the character; during the party scene at the beginning of the film, his family and friends congratulate him and constantly ask what he is going to do now, a question that he does not know the answer to yet. These are the same questions I dreaded being asked after I graduated because I wasn't quite sure what route I was going to take and to be honest I still don't!
The cinematography is the film is also very beautiful, including shots that are famous in film history. The angles are awkward and usual at times just like our main protagonist and on quite a few occasions, Ben is covered in darkness reflecting the aimless despair he is feeling. Not only does the cinematography reflect our characters feelings and mental state but the Simon & Garfunkel songs enforce it very well from The Sound of Silence to Scarborough Fair, very off-beat yet incredibly fitting songs for the narrative.
The ending of this film I feel is going to become one of my favourites of all time. After the unexpected brawl in the church, Elaine and Ben escape on a Santa Barbara bus. At first they are happy and enthralled by what has just happened as they come to realise the reality of it, the happiness slowly drains from both of their faces. Exquisite.
I really cannot wait to get in some more repeat viewings of this film because it truly is a classic.

There were quite an awkward moment here and there, however that was probably the reason why the movie felt so down to earth and relevant. I just regret that I didn't watch this movie sooner.

It is a good movie, the disconnect Ben has from the world around him as The Sound of Silence plays over the scenes really resonated with me. Right as he returns triumphantly from college there's the song, right after he gets the girl there's the song. Moments he should be savoring always end with the song.
Or more likely most people see the troubling parts, but choose to focus on the other bits.

Screened this one for my coworkers, all of whom had not seen it before. The energy of the crowd made it an awesome viewing. Everyone was laughing really hard, myself most of all: this movie is so freaking funny. Using "The Sound of Silence" as a punchline to really sad character moments is genius. The entire first sequence at the Taft hotel is a masterpiece of pacing and comedic timing. 

I think the whole movie is perfect, but I especially adore the first hour, which is an excellent character study of a very aimless and lonely man, and an equally lonely and aimless older woman, who no longer has the liberty of time to figure things out for herself. Everyone is sad and selfish in this movie, but we empathize with these emotions that they are exhibiting.

One of my favorites.

I have so many things to say about ‚ÄúThe Graduate‚Äù but I‚Äôll just stick with the most important.

The Graduate is about relationships, empty relationships.

Ben‚Äôs relationship with his parents is empty because they expect something out from him he doesn‚Äôt want to do, conformed to their lifestyle which is empty on its own.

His relationship with Mrs. Robinson is empty because it‚Äôs strictly physical and emotionally detached. It turns out being more like a drug than just sex. This toxicity is evident by Ben taking up smoking during the affair.

Mr and Mrs Robinson relationship is empty since they‚Äôve only stayed together because of the pregnancy.

Elaine‚Äôs relationship with Carl is empty because it‚Äôs something she‚Äôs unsure of and also because her parents had a large role in arranging the wedding for her.

All the relationships here are empty because they are all based in the happiness through the ownership of stuff and given how women were treated in the late 60‚Äôs, people.

The only relationship with real potential is Ben and Elaine‚Äôs. Ben is so empty inside that the only thing that pushes him forward is his relationship with Elaine and that‚Äôs all it took him to do everything to have her.

I think that in the final scene in the end when the smiles fade away, means that they knew they were making a mistake, which reminds us to another failed relationship, Mr and Mrs Robinson‚Äôs and why Mrs Robinson strictly didn‚Äôt want them to date, so that they don‚Äôt make the same mistake they‚Äôve made.
Mike Nichols‚Äôs understanding of the world his characters live in is splendourous, from another world. He deserved and still deserves that Oscar he won.
Also Sam O‚ÄôSteene in the editing did a wonderful job. This is one of the best editing in filming history. He had an amazing career editing films like Chinatown, Rosemary‚Äôs Baby and Cool Hand Luke.
I wanna talk about the initial scene though. Benjamin is being pulled along by a sidewalk as if life is controlling him, just pulling him along. 

The Sound of Silence is on in three parts of the movies and in all three parts gives this feeling of uncertainty that amazed me so much. The BSO is perfectly used here and I loved that.

Also Katharine Ross was beautiful.

"Benjamin."
"Yes?"
"Isn't there something you want to tell me?"
"Tell you?"
"Yes."
"Well, I want you to know how much I appreciate this. Really."
"The number."
"What?"
"The room number, Benjamin. I think you ought to tell me that."
"Oh, you're absolutely right. It's 568."
"Thank you."
"You're welcome. Well... I'll see you later, Mrs. Robinson."
I have to admit that the first time I watched The Graduate I wasn't really into it, but I wasn't really giving it a fair chance either. That's why I bought it in one of Barnes & Noble's Criterion sales a while back. I knew I needed to revisit it when I was ready. Tonight was the night.
I still like the first half of the film better than the second. The affair with Mrs. Robinson is a bit sad, but it's also darkly comedic as Ben is so completely out of his element and trying so hard to find some reason for being with her other than the obvious. Once Elaine comes home, he's even further out of his element though. He has no idea how to handle the situation and his attempt to turn Elaine off is hilariously dimwitted. But that's also where the film shows how well written the script is as these young kids go from hate to love to hate again in less then 24 hours, simply because Ben is an idiot. The scene that really shows how little these two know about life is the final one as they escape the church and get on the bus triumphantly. The smiles on their faces couldn't be any bigger. And then reality sets in and you can almost see the thought, "What the fuck did we just do?" pass across their eyes.
I understand why this is so beloved by so many now.

So this is where the Fifty Shades Mrs. Robinson reference came from. 

First of all, this film is as old as my parents yet still very relevant today. At some point in our lives, we all were Ben Braddock - in that gray area between being young and being old, where we are either forced to make decisions for ourselves or end up taking orders from the much experienced adults around us - and that is what makes this film hella relatable. The only time Ben was able to take hold of his life was when he decided to go to Berkeley and ask Elaine to marry him. Everything about this movie just blows me away, Mike Nichols deserves all the awards just for that pool-dive-to-bed transition. It's one of those films that just ages well in my opinion.
dustin hoffman used to be really fucking cute don't even dare to deny it

Could this be Hoffman's defining role? That it came so early in his career isn't necessarily to his own detriment, especially considering his own doubts about his suitability. In a way that may have seeped into his performance and been channelled by Hoffman himself. I had only seen The Graduate once before and one thing that occurred to me is that Hollywood doesn't make comedy films so confidently restrained as this. It is the awkward silences and the half sentences that make The Graduate so funny. Perhaps the subject is now taboo. A 20 year old has an affair with a woman twice his age then falls in love with her daughter. It is quite a web that is woven here. The Graduate is full of surprises and no more so than that final shot. A brave ending, but a necessasry one. One in line with idiosyncratic nature of the film.

Film School Drop Outs - Weekly Challenge 2017
Week 26: Movement - New Hollywood (1968-1980)
The feeling of this film, only after watching it for a few minutes, reminded me quite a bit of Hal Ashby's Harold and Maude, which I believe also falls into the New Hollywood category. I'm thinking that Harold and Maude actually took cues from The Graduate since The Graduate seems to be one of the first New Hollywood films; it's incredibly sly, and absolutely brimming with editing and tonal choices that are downright inspired.
Since I don't live under a rock, I already knew the gist of the plot, its most famous lines ("Plastics......") and the very last scene. Even so I was totally engrossed. The leads are all great but Anne Bancroft in particular had me cackling - her comedic timing and the ways her lines slink out of her is flawless.
I did not know that I'd be treated to "Hello darkness, my old friend..." right out of the gate. This is how a movie should be scored if the music is gonna be contemporary. I paused the movie a handful of times to look up Simon and Garfunkel on Spotify.
Side note: while I'd like to see some citations, the lists of actors considered for Benjamin and Mrs. Robinson are nuts in the best way. Can you imagine The Graduate, starring Jack Nance (aka Eraserhead) and Anouk Aim√©e? Steve McQueen and Audrey Hepburn? Jack Nicholson and Joan Crawford? Christ......

This is one of those movies that I have returned to every now and then for some odd reason. I felt like the Fathom Event screening of this provided a good enough excuse to see it again. The truth is that the film is so good. There's so many striking images that grab me. I could watch those opening credits if they lasted for another five minutes. I could see more montages of Dustin Hoffman jumping from a pool onto Anne Bancroft. I could watch him drive around the California coastline as Simon and Garfunkel played behind him. This film's "nothing" moments are better than most film's "something" moments.
With that said, I think a portion of the film's charm is lost on me. I cannot seem to undoubtedly love this movie as much as I want. It could be that - for reasons that allude me - I think that the middle drags a little. Not enough to derail the movie, but the shift between the Robinson women definitely has drama that doesn't connect with me. Maybe I am just not one for infidelity. Maybe it's something about the idealized 60's youth culture that I don't get. After all, it's been 50 years. If anything deserves to show its age, it's a 50 year old "youth" movie.
Yet I keep coming back to it, hoping that I get over those bumps that I cannot quite get over. Don't get me wrong, this is a very entertaining movie and Hoffman started off his film career very well. However, I think to younger viewers like myself, it is easier to see as a drama than a comedy. Yes, there's awkward humor, but the subject feels richer than that. I think it's in part because I often overlook bad jokes (though not here) in comedies for the story, and I don't know that too much of the affair stuff is funny. Maybe I just need to travel back in time and experience a generation who liked Love American Style. Who knows.
Still, I'll keep searching for the answers every now and then. Maybe I'll figure it out by the time I'm 30. It's my Aunt's favorite movie, and I hesitate asking her why that is because I want to find the answer myself. I guess in that sense I'm just like this movie: lost and unsure. Still, this is a masterpiece worthy of the big screen, and I'm glad to have seen it that way once in my life.

A genius work of art. Fine cinema from one of the greatest periods in American film history thus far. Evocative, sensual, humorous, satirical, and best of all, relatable.
The Graduate follows the life of young Benjamin (Hoffman), who's just earned his undergraduate degree and has no idea what he wants out of life. Along the way, he begins a steamy affair with the smoldering Mrs. Robinson (Bancroft), a longtime family friend. While unwinding and taking advantage of all the spare time summer has to offer, Benjamin finds himself caught up in a bigger dilemma -- one that threatens his future, happiness, and love life.
Some of the best acting you will see is right here in this film. You can't ask for a better cast: Bancroft and Hoffman (still new to the screen!) are professionals, slipping effortlessly into their respective roles. Katharine Ross is great. Not one actor gives a weak performance. The dialogue is wonderfully poignant, witty, and makes for some great laughs.
This is the zeitgeist of the counterculture era, the sexual revolution and the winds of changes that dominated the late 60s. One of my all time favorite films, and one that's not to be passed up on by any means. 4.5 stars.

Always find a way to come back to The Graduate this week was seeing Art Garfunkel in Bad Timing. Not that the films are in any way are alike just kept singing Simon & Garfunkel songs all week.
Watched this on my small mobile phone and it's still the most brilliant social satire film ever. Most film fans have seen this and know it's significance in history. 
For  me The Graduate was the birth of quirky social comedies. It's a little off beat in its characters and story. Particularly Hoffman walking around in Scuba Diving gear. Directors such as Alexander Payne, Wes Anderson, Jason Reitman all can be thankful for this classic film. 


Love this film so much

The Graduate seemed to hold the same tone throughout the whole movie. The melodic music and zoom shots add a sort of seriousness that counteracts the subtle humor. The editing is also gorgeous. The cuts between scenes fit perfectly with the next sequence. I really enjoyed this early "New Wave" Era innovative piece. :) 
Plan to watch it again soon since Netflix has it at my disposal.

Hands down, one of my favorite films of all time.
The Graduate depicts perfectly what it's like to be lost and scared about growing up for good. Even if we know what kind of job we'd like or what career to study, we still hesitate and wonder if we're making the right decision. I adore this film, especially because I was able to relate to Benjamin on so many levels. What I enjoy and appreciate the most is that it doesn't have a completely happy ending. On the last two shot of Ben and Elaine sitting on the bus, we can see how their happiness fades into concern. Ben's face shows pure confusion and fear. He has the girl but he still doesn't know what he wants to do with himself. That's life. One moment you feel like you're on top of the world, but suddenly you realize you've actually fucked up. Kudos to Dustin Hoffman for nailing his performance as Ben. I'm obsessed with the constant lost and stupid look on his face. 
Apart from an amazing plot, The Graduate has some amazing shots. I'm in love with the shot of Ben's and Mrs. Robinson's reflection on the bar table. Beautiful. Also, the sudden flashes of Mrs. Robinson's breasts. That was a clever and creative way of showing Ben's nervousness and POV. Ugh, this film <3

The themes of disaffected youth and social inadequacy and anxiety sort of make The Graduate the The Fight Club of its generation. While the second half feels slightly tangential, the first half remains the definitive text in comedy of manners which a recent graduate such as myself can strongly relate to (sadly sans hot cougar seduction). However, for me, the film‚Äôs key misstep is its failure to completely see out the comparable existential problems endemic in adulthood that are set up with Mrs. Robinson‚Äôs decidedly tragic character. Unfairly, her magnetic and immortal persona is notably neglected during second act and the inner release she seems to be in desperate need of never comes.

I've been wanting to watch this for years. I saw the Criterion at my local movie store a couple times but decided not to pick it up because of the price. 39 freakin dollars‚Ä¶..kinda wish I did though cuz I loved this movie.
I feel that this is the first movie pre-70‚Äôs that I actually love. This movie‚Äôs messages are so very relevant to the point that it makes this movie feel like it came out post 2010 and was made to look like something that came out in the 60s. Everyone has or had that feeling of not knowing what to do with your lives after graduating. And the pressure of everyone around you asking what you‚Äôre gonna do with your life just feels so suffocating. I loved how this movie handled all of that. This movie also talks about toxic relationships. I‚Äôm pretty sure everyone has been in one or knows someone that‚Äôs been in one. I wish I could say the stuff that happens in this movie is over exaggerated but it‚Äôs really not. Some people are just that crazy.
This movie is just so wonderfully directed. It‚Äôs jam packed with symbolism. I was able to catch a few things here and there. Very interested in watching this again to see what else I can catch.
As for negatives, this movie replayed the SHIT out of some of these songs to the point of annoyance. Listen, I like Simon and Garfunkel to a degree but shit man‚Ä¶relax. They played the beginning of Mrs Robinson like 4 times in the span of 5 minutes. Sound of Silence was played throughout the movie like 5 times and Scarborough Fair was played a TON. I lost track of how many times. Like, take a shot every time it‚Äôs played.
That‚Äôs my MAIN gripe with this movie and it‚Äôs a pretty decently sized one too. Every time one of those songs played I just let out a sigh. A good movie soundtrack is great. I love to throw one on for something to listen to while I‚Äôm doing something but man, I‚Äôll never do that with this one.
Aside from that, I loved this. Movies like this are why I have a strong passion for film. It‚Äôs such a beautiful art form that some people in my life don't understand and that‚Äôs so incredibly frustrating. There's so much to it and that‚Äôs why I love it.
4 out of 5

i feel like y'all are about to hate me for this one üßç‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è LMAO. like i feel like i was supposed to get it and relate more to it but i just didn't. for god's sake i am turning 20 in 8 days why did i not understand the graduate u know. but god idk it just did not resonate with me like i figured it probably would. i feel like maybe it's another one of those movies i'll learn to appreciate more with time, and maybe i would enjoy it more or find more relatability in it when i have a little more life experience - but at the same time, i'm honestly not sure if that's true. i feel like people look at this as like a really relatable movie or even a life-altering movie - i did not feel that way. the only really relatable part to me was the whole idea of aimlessness after leaving some kind of structured institution you've been in for your entire life (school ü§™). sure, there are relatable aspects of Benjamin Braddock as a character as well, specifically for me his state of just not making his own decisions for a while bc he's so used to other people doing it for him so he just kinda does whatever other people tell him to do. his awkward nature is something i think a lot of people can partially see themselves in as well, including myself. but idk to look at this as like a coming-of-age dramedy doesn't really feel right to me. i just feel too far removed from the story. like idk not everyone grows up to fuck milfs and then destroy their own love lives and mentally scar other people üßç‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è. i think whatever i expected this to be was just different so i didn't like it as much as i wanted to - and that's okay !!! it happens sometimes. i'm just a little sad that i didn't enjoy what's regarded as one of the best movies ever made a little more than i did. there's still plenty to admire though. for one thing the performances are very good. Dustin Hoffman was great in the lead role as Benjamin Braddock - also insane to see him so young??? i forgot he wasn't always like 40+ LMAO. Anne Bancroft was a perfect Mrs. Robinson, and Katharine Ross is always a delight. also ummmmmmm the camerawork??? just about flawless really. my favorite thing about this movie was the camerawork, easily. all the movements of the camera just felt so cool to watch, and the transitions were just so smooth,,,,,,,,, god yeah it just looks so impressive. the standout that comes to mind first is the first time Benjamin sees Mrs. Robinson naked - like the way the body parts flash quickly on screen and the shot keeps focusing on different areas like its just a perfect way to showcase the actual act of his eyes darting around it was SO GOOD. but there are so many other specific instances where there was a certain technique or something that just made me go "wow,,,,,,, that was really cool !!!" u know. the soundtrack is pretty solid as well shoutout to Simon & Garfunkel. yes the amount of Scarborough Fair needle drops is tiring BUT April Come She Will??? perhaps one of the best little tunes ever. the symbolism with the water was well-executed as well, using that as a way to communicate the feeling of being stuck in an aimless period of transition was really smart. all in all i can see why it's so highly praised, it just didn't hit for me. by the time i got to the end and realized Wayne's World 2 spoofed the ending i was literally just like "damn what if i rewatched that instead u know" üßç‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è. it just did not resonate enough !!! oh well u know. it happens. perhaps i will give it another shot after i graduate college.
Alright I gotta admit it this is da best movie of all time

Like once he completely misunderstands the complexity of Mrs. Robinson's position and‚Ä¶

The more I watch this film, the more I love it.
And each time I watch it, my interpretations and meaning I derive from it changes.
This time around, I saw the sad cycle all the characters were caught up in. How youthful rebellion leads to regret, and how regret fuels oppressive/controlling parenting... Which in turn leads to youthful rebellion and the cycle repeats. The film never condones the immature, rash actions of the characters involved. It simply calmly observes‚Ä¶

I find it fascinating how the film almost never stops following the character, right from the opening shot of his face. The film has some striking directorial choices and editing for the time that are pure New Hollywood.

The Best Picture line-up at the 40th Academy Awards represents the changing shift within Hollywood that led to the New Hollywood movement in the 1970s. Doctor Dolittle and Guess Who‚Äôs Coming to Dinner represent the old generation of Hollywood filmmaking, Bonnie & Clyde and The Graduate represent the new generation of Hollywood filmmaking, and the winner of the category (In the Heat of the Night) has elements of both eras. The Graduate is the coming-of-age story of a man expected to have it figured out. In a way, the film challenged the norms of young adulthood upon release in the 1960s. Traditionally, the path in life was school, college or university, career and settling down with a significant other. It is expected to understand how the rest of their lives will go during the application process for college or university. But Ben (Dustin Hoffman) still feels lost and confused about how the rest of his life will go. Mrs. Robinson (Anne Bancroft) also feels lost and aimless in her marriage. Bancroft and Hoffman give excellent-mannered performances when they have to present a facade to the world. It has an element of melodrama. The Graduate is not only a funny film, but it is also a stunningly crafted piece from Mike Nichols. The brilliant use of Simon & Garfunkel music to capture a feeling of aimlessness, beautifully shot, the remarkable editing and the final shot that reflects the uncertainty of life. Who knows what will happen to Ben and Elaine (Katherine Ross) once they get off the bus and start their lives together? And it is meaningful because of the ambiguity. But I do know that The Graduate is a remarkable film.

I feel like this also did a really good job of showing how hopeless, insecure and lonely you feel after graduating. I like this makes fun of both young people and adults. I don't remember why this was on my watchlist, but I am glad it was. A funny timeless movie straight out of the 60s.
Dustin Hoffmans deadpan delivery has just the right amount of humor to make you laugh without being silly. His demeanor perfectly captures being young and nervous about the future. All he wants is to control his own life and make his own decisions, but is frequently being forced into situations where older adults manipulate him. At first I felt great sympathy for Benjamin and resented Mrs. Robinson, then their relationship developed and my sympathy shifted a bit more to her. A woman desperately trying to being young again because she feels her life have come to a standstill when she married and got pregnant very young. Then Benjamin starts being more of a jerk and I really felt sorry for Elaine.
What really set this movie as a top-rated one for me was how it ends up not being a "happily ever after"-romance. On the surface it looks like one, but Benjamin and Elaine are not really in love. They just both want to free themselves from their parents and make their own decisions, and the final shot in the bus when that reality hits them hard is among the best end scenes ever.
It is remarkable how it is really a movie from the 60s, but also very timeless. It is not a movie that simply have "aged well" or was "ahead of its time". My only minor complaint is that I didn't believe in the age difference of the actors. They should be around 20 years apart but the actors are only a handful of years in age difference, which isn't very convincing. I can write it off as a relic of movie productions of the time that couldn't cast woman over 40.

*Vague Spoilers*

Oh man, so I guess we‚Äôre just eternally doomed to perpetuate this cycle of generational divide, aren‚Äôt we? Where the old smother the youth with expectations and projections and the youth will forever be aimless and adrift. At the beginning we see Benjamin being moved along the straight and narrow path of the airport walkway, imbued with as much independence as his luggage. By the end he believes himself to have a purpose in fighting for Elaine, but the filmmaking still reflects that sense of being lost that we see in the beginning. It‚Äôs a cruel trick of misplaced bravado that Ben and Elaine don‚Äôt realize until it‚Äôs too late. The older generation isn‚Äôt in a much better spot either, they‚Äôre the ones that are destined to put their children and themselves in a box and inevitably push away their children when they decide to make life choices out of spite toward them. Mrs. Robinson in particular is such a tragic figure, with Anne Bancroft bringing a lot of sadness in her many closeups. 
I get why many people think the second half is a lot weaker than the first. In some ways I do agree, watching Benjamin fumble his way through an affair is comedy gold and it‚Äôs a lot easier to enjoy than the moodier, less focused second half. Thematically however, I think the latter half of the film is perfection. I think it‚Äôs of great importance that we see Benjamin change from awkward and fresh faced graduate to an impulsive rebel fighting for nothing of terrible importance. I love that by the end his car (presumably a graduation present) is beaten up and out of gas, he‚Äôs ditched the suit and tie for a hoodie that‚Äôs covered in sweat when he gets to the church, and he‚Äôs fulfilled the parental ideal of settling down with the girl next door albeit in a rather twisted manner.
Comedically I also think the second half of the film still has plenty to offer. The very mercenary way Elaine and Benjamin discuss the possibility of marriage we see through montage, Benjamin‚Äôs final conversation with Mr. Robinson, and my personal favorite which is Benjamin fending off all the churchgoers at the wedding with a cross (which to me feels like a clever and funny way of visualizing youthful rebellion), all of these scenes are just as funny as watching Benjamin nervously buy a hotel room.
Anyway, I‚Äôm sure this is a film that will always be pertinent to me as I continue through my 20‚Äôs, and then I‚Äôm sure when I hit my 40‚Äôs Mrs. Robinson will be my new Black Panther frfr.

Una pel√≠cula realmente contraria a los valores tradicionales de la √©poca de su estreno (si se estudia minuciosamente el contexto) y que brilla con una puesta en escena magn√≠fica, de ensue√±o y que se siente tan veraniega. Jugando entre los escenarios con el estado mental de nuestro protagonista, Benjamin; un joven con la presi√≥n de ser alguien en la vida, un joven para el que sus padres tienen expectativas altas, pero ni √©l mismo sabe ad√≥nde ir.
Una pel√≠cula que trata de vivir incondicionalmente ante las exigencias de nuestro entorno, es la representaci√≥n viva del alma rebelde por un estilo de vida alejado a las demandas de lo que socialmente se espera de cada uno.
