So at night I see films that are different from my experiences during the day. Thus there is a strict separation between experience and the cinema. That is the obstacle for our films. For we are people of the 60s, and we do not believe in the opposition between experience and fiction.
‚ÄìAlexander Kluge, 1988
THE GRADUATE opened in December 1967, the same month the first successful human heart transplant was performed. It was a few weeks after the premiere of BONNIE AND CLYDE and about three months before the launching of 2001: A SPACE ODYSSEY. Among the albums that came out the same year were the Beatles‚Äô Sgt. Pepper‚Äôs Lonely Hearts Club Band, the Rolling Stones‚Äô Their Satanic Majesties Request, and the Mothers of Invention‚Äôs Absolutely Free. Simon and Garfunkel‚Äôs Sounds of Silence and Parsley, Sage, Rosemary and Thyme had both come out in ‚Äò66, and THE GRADUATE appropriated tracks from both of them on its sound track. (The ‚ÄúMrs Robinson‚Äù lyrics were added for the sound track album.)
For many fans, including myself, of Mike Nichols and Elaine May who had seen them perform live or heard their ferociously funny records, Nichols‚Äôs early career as a director seemed tame, considering both his comic gifts and the political cast of the 60s. THE GRADUARE, his second feature (his first was WHO‚ÄôS AFRAID OF VIRGINIA WOOLF? in ‚Äò66) was entertaining, but hardly the rallying cry of a rebellious youth explosion that some claimed it to be once it took off at the box office (it was the second highest grossing movie of the 60s, after THE SOUND OF MUSIC). Even now, when new prints of the movie struck from the original internegative are being released, the only ‚Äúrevolutionary aspect‚Äù of THE GRADUARE described in the press book is the use and impact of the Simon and Garfunkel songs -‚Äì not the songs themselves but the new marketing possibilities derived from transplanting ‚Äúfound‚Äù material into a Hollywood hit, which clearly set a lot of wheels spinning.
‚ÄúShe was always brave,‚Äù Nichols said of May during their partnership as a comedy team. ‚ÄúBut I became more and more afraid.‚Äù This certainly appears to be the case if one compares their subsequent careers as directors. (For a candid look at the complex dynamics of their relationship during the height of their fame as a team, see Edmund Wilson‚Äôs posthumously published journals, The Sixties.) On the other hand, according to Janet Coleman in her book The Compass -‚Äì a fascinating study of the mid-50s Chicago improvisational comedy workshop from which Nichols and May sprang -‚Äì they both, along with comedian Shelley Berman, lost some of their edge when they became famous:
‚ÄúOn becoming stars, each member of the trio once referred to as ‚ÄòTwo Cocksuckers and Elaine‚Äô had unwittingly pulled some plugs from the main currents of ordinary life that had charged their improvisations with humanity. They had been almost instantly isolated from the ensemble work of their peers, the extraordinary improvisational foot soldiers. Thus, their passage into celebrity did not return to the political comedy of the improvisational theater any insights into the issues of status and money, or hard looks into the workings of power in the arts and society, or revelations about the entertainment industry. Without the focus and urgency of the improvisational theater, they were atomized from their most integrated and revealing work. Substituting for commonality and spontaneity the narcissism and obsessions of show business, they grew silent in the society they once had satirized.‚Äù
As a passionate fan of the four features May directed ‚Äì- A NEW LEAF, THE HEARTBREAK KID, MIKEY AND NICKY, and ISHTAR ‚Äì‚Äì who finds plenty of ‚Äúinsights into the issues of status and money,‚Äù ‚Äúhard looks into the workings of power in the arts and society,‚Äù and even a few ‚Äúrevelations about the entertainment industry‚Äù in these dark, vibrant movies, I feel that Coleman‚Äôs basically sound observation applies differently to the careers of May and Nichols. In many ways, May, unlike Nichols, is too large and unwieldy a talent to accommodate herself to the entertainment industry in a manner that can easily translate into fame and success, and given the complex and tortuous skirmishes she had with studios on all four of her features, it is hardly surprising that she has worked in Hollywood chiefly as an anonymous script doctor. More recently, she has teamed up with Nichols again as a writer on THE BIRDCAGE and, as reported in a lengthy article in the March 3 New York Observer, on an adaptation of PRIMARY COLORS budgeted at $65 million and starring John Travolta and Emma Thompson as the Clintons -‚Äì a project that seems highly political. It will be interesting to discover to what degree May‚Äôs dangerous satirical gifts and Nichols‚Äôs commercial savvy can work in tandem.
THE GRADUATE, Nichols‚Äôs main ticket to mainstream success, replays various aspects of the Nichols-May partnership in telling ways ‚Äì- as does THE HEARTBREAK KID (1972), May‚Äôs own second feature, which can be read in many ways as a response to THE GRADUATE. Both movies chart the hero‚Äôs ditching of a dark, overpowering woman for an inaccessible WASP princess (each monomaniacally pursuing her to the university she‚Äôs attending, where he hangs out on the campus), echoing Nichols‚Äôs abandonment of the dangerous side of his routines with May. Furthermore, Charles Grodin, who plays the lead in THE HEARTBREAK KID, was originally cast by Nichols to play the lead in THE GRADUATE, and Jeannie Berlin, who plays the ditched woman in THE HEARTBREAK KID, is May‚Äôs daughter.
The two movies take notably different approaches toward ethnicity: Nichols pretends it isn‚Äôt there and May flaunts it. Though Nichols and May are both Jewish, May grew up in the Yiddish theater, and the anomaly of a Jewish New York actor playing Waspy Los Angeleno Benjamin Braddock in THE GRADUATE has to be weighed against the explicitly Jewish New York wedding at the beginning of THE HEARTBREAK KID ‚Äì- and the explicitly WASP Minneapolis wedding that closes it. In other words, May accentuates ethnic difference whereas Nichols muddles it. THE GRADUATE ends with a Christian wedding of its own, but in this case, significantly, the hero isn‚Äôt the groom; and the fact that Benjamin winds up using a cross both as a battering ram and as a tool for escape can be read allegorically as Nichols‚Äôs own determined flight from his roots in courting mainstream success. Even the uses of pop songs as anthems of their hero‚Äôs aspirations have ethnic implications: in contrast to the euphoric Jewish assimilation (and mainstreaming of folk music) of Simon and Garfunkel in THE GRADUATE, THE HEARTBREAK KID offers multiple versions of a pop single associated with the Carpenters, ‚ÄúClose to You,‚Äù and each successive version registers as more bitterly ironic.
‚ÄúDon‚Äôt trust anyone over 30‚Ä≥ is the only 60s counterculture motto honored in THE GRADUATE, though the picture has only two under-30 characters of any importance, neither of them especially well defined apart from their southern California affluence, and the innate corruption of all the over-30 characters is more felt than analyzed. Dustin Hoffman wears a jacket and tie throughout the picture (his first movie role), and his rebellion relates exclusively to personal rather than social or political issues -‚Äì his determination to marry the daughter, Elaine (Katharine Ross), of his father‚Äôs law partner after having an adulterous affair with her mother, Mrs. Robinson (Anne Bancroft, whose style and authority make her a clear stand-in for May). Indeed, one of the film‚Äôs running gags is the erroneous impression of a suspicious rooming-house landlord in Berkeley that the straitlaced Benjamin is some sort of campus radical.
In fact, Benjamin has no convictions, no politics, no ambitions, no ideas, no friends, no professional interests, and, apart from sex and romance, no nonprofessional interests of any kind. He doesn‚Äôt take pot or acid, his exemption from fighting in Vietnam is assumed rather than spelled out, and apart from the conspicuous affluence of his background, his remoteness from the world around him, Berkeley included, is defined iconographically rather than ideologically: it‚Äôs a movie-star pose. Yet somehow he‚Äôs perceived as a social rebel, and Nichols‚Äôs transplant of the ‚Äúheart‚Äù of counterculture, not to mention the ‚Äúheart‚Äù of his satiric routines with May, into the Hollywood mainstream clearly struck some kind of elemental paydirt. To borrow the title of a subsequent Simon and Garfunkel album, his movie provided a bridge over troubled water that millions were happy to take.
To understand this alchemy, it‚Äôs helpful to consider what the other top moneymaking pictures of the 60s were that had some relationship with ‚Äúrebellious‚Äù youth culture: SPLENDOR IN THE GRASS (1961, set mainly in the late 1920s), BYE BYE BIRDIE (1963, an adaptation of a stage musical about the impact of a rock-and-roll singer on a small town), A HARD DAY‚ÄôS NIGHT (1964, a film about and starring the Beatles), THE WILD ANGELS (1966, an exploitation feature about a motorcycle gang), BLOWUP (1966, Michelangelo Antonioni‚Äôs art film about ‚Äúswinging London‚Äù), 2001, and EASY RIDER (1969). None of these pictures with the possible exception of the last can be described as an expression or even an accurate representation of 60s counterculture apart from a few passing elements. When Antonioni dealt directly with American counterculture in ZABRISKIE POINT (1970), the film was a resounding flop with audiences and critics alike, and the same could be said of Otto Preminger‚Äôs grotesque if fascinating SKIDOO the previous year; perhaps only WOODSTOCK (1970) succeeded both in dealing directly with the counterculture and in reaching a wide mainstream audience.
No doubt the sense of ‚Äúnewness‚Äù projected by THE GRADUATE came less from the film‚Äôs subject matter than from the offscreen Simon and Garfunkel songs, from the comic dialogue (the obvious legacy of Nichols‚Äôs satiric routines with May, adroitly adapted by screenwriters Buck Henry and Calder Willingham from Charles Webb‚Äôs source novel), and, above all, from the eclectic, free-wheeling, and attention-grabbing visual style. Much of that style had clear antecedents in some of the better-known art films of the early 60s ‚Äì- work by such filmmakers as Truffaut, Godard, Antonioni, Fellini, and even Cassavetes.
The film‚Äôs first extended sequence is a party given for Benjamin by his well-to-do parents (William Daniels and Elizabeth Wilson), attended exclusively by the parents‚Äô friends, filmed almost entirely in claustrophobic closeups and hand-held camera movements. The style has a great deal in common with the style of party sequences in Cassavetes‚Äôs SHADOWS (1959) as well as in his subsequent Hollywood feature TOO LATE BLUES (1962), although Andrew Sarris, in his contemporary review of THE GRADUATE, noted that these ‚Äúbobbing, tracking, lurching heads in nightmarishly mobile closeups looks like an ‚Äòhommage‚Äô to Fellini‚Äôs 8¬Ω,‚Äù which indeed may be a likelier source. Either way, it looks nothing like standard Hollywood filmmaking of the early 60s. (Pointedly, in his same review of THE GRADUATE, Sarris noted that ‚ÄúA rain-drenched Anne Bancroft splattered against a starkly white wall evokes images in [Antonioni‚Äôs] LA NOTTE.‚Äù)
An even more striking example of this mainstreaming of New Wave techniques comes at the end of the protracted comic seduction of Benjamin by Mrs. Robinson (the only name he or the dialogue ever assigns her), who orders him to drive her home from the party and issues a series of commands to him when they are alone in her house -‚Äì to have a drink, to accompany her upstairs, and so on -‚Äì as she proceeds to remove her clothing. This climaxes when Benjamin, alone in Mrs. Robinson‚Äôs daughter‚Äôs room, sees reflected in a framed portrait of Elaine the nude figure of Mrs. Robinson entering the room and closing the door behind her. When Benjamin spins around to face her, this single gesture is broken up into four separate dovetailing shots, each filmed from a different angle, all but the last of which is so brief that the effect is mainly subliminal. (The successive lengths of the four shots -‚Äì at least in my un-‚Äùrestored‚Äù video copy -‚Äì are 15 frames, 13 frames, one single frame, and then, as Benjamin says ‚ÄúOh, God!,‚Äù 70 frames.) Insofar as the early features of Godard and Truffaut can be said to have visual tropes, this is clearly one of them, though the use of it here is more pointedly tied to the viewer‚Äôs identification with the subjectivity of a single character than it would have been in the French originals.
This is followed by other shots of Benjamin‚Äôs frantic responses to Mrs. Robinson, punctuated by other near-subliminal shots of her nude body -‚Äì ten frames of her midriff, four frames of one of her breasts, and five frames of her navel -‚Äì which effectively suggest the sources of his panic without spelling them out. In this case, it is more difficult to point to precise New Wave counterparts and more likely that the pressures of studio censorship led to some of the subliminal abridgements of shots. (THE GRADUATE came out after the far-ranging revision of the Production Code in 1966 and prior to the launching of the rating system in 1968 -‚Äì a transitional period in more ways than one.) But the titillating effect of these brief inserts and their stylistic eclecticism point to the inroads made by New Wave films on Hollywood thinking and practices.
And the same could be said for many of the movie‚Äôs other stylistic flourishes, ranging from sound overlaps (such as the beginning of a scene‚Äôs dialogue over the end of the previous sequence) to fancy camera setups (e.g., Mrs. Robinson appearing at a hotel bar rendezvous with Benjamin as a reflection on a glass table) to extended uses of first-person camera (such as the sequence featuring Benjamin inside a deep-sea diving suit, nearly all of it seen and heard from his vantage point).
The differences between the uses of such techniques in New Wave pictures and their uses in Hollywood usually have to do with the mechanics of storytelling and the identification of the viewer. The stylistic play of BREATHLESS and SHOOT THE PIANO PLAYER generally had the effect of making the viewer identify with the filmmakers, while the stylistic play of THE GRADUATE made the viewer identify with Benjamin -‚Äì even if a greater awareness of the director‚Äôs role ensued from the process.
Seeing THE GRADUATE again recently, I enjoyed pretty much the same things that I enjoyed 30 years ago: Bancroft‚Äôs robust, superlative performance (until the script turns her into a one-dimensional monster she‚Äôs the only real character in the movie); the smoothness and assurance of the sketch humor, most of it having to do with Los Angeles affluence and sexual embarrassment; the graceful, dreamlike transition between Benjamin emerging from his swimming pool at home and entering a hotel room with Mrs. Robinson for another bout of lovemaking; the foregrounding of the ebullient and wistful Simon and Garfunkel music (recently appropriated and parodied in Albert Brooks‚Äôs MOTHER, and so integral throughout THE GRADUATE that when Benjamin‚Äôs car runs out of gas at a climactic juncture, the guitar vamps slow down).
What I don‚Äôt enjoy is the cruelty, the glib mindlessness, and the insulated, pampered narcissism that makes the whole thing possible. (If Benjamin had run off with Mrs. Robinson, the movie would have been genuinely rebellious.) By studiously avoiding everything about the 60s that is worth remembering today, apart from some of its energy, Nichols can flatter the audience for its knowingness only by assuming the audience knows nothing at all. ‚ÄúThe small triumph of THE GRADUATE,‚Äù Pauline Kael wrote in 1969, ‚Äúwas to have domesticated alienation and the difficulty of communication, by making what Benjamin is alienated from a middle-class comic strip and making it absurdly evident that he has nothing to communicate ‚Äì- which is just what makes him an acceptable hero for the large movie audience. If he said anything or had any ideas, the audience would probably hate him‚Ä¶.Mike Nichols‚Äôs ‚Äògift‚Äô is that he lets the audience direct him; this is demagoguery in the arts.‚Äù As a bridge over troubled water and a clever piece of merchandise, THE GRADUATE is at best only following the same escapist principles followed today by INDEPENDENCE DAY ‚Äì- or THE ENGLISH PATIENT, for that matter.
--Chicago Reader, March 28, 1997

I‚Äôve seen this movie many times and as I get older I can‚Äôt help but appreciate it more and more. It‚Äôs overwhelming to not know what you want to do once you go into adulthood, and it‚Äôs even more stressful to go down a path that you didn‚Äôt get to decide yourself. Whether it‚Äôs your parents‚Äô friend telling you that the future is ‚Äúplastics‚Äù or Mrs. Robinson manipulating you into having an affair, it‚Äôs always hard to know if you made the right the decision. Even when the decision you took (or were manipulated to take) is clearly the wrong one. The Graduate is a movie that made sense for the time it was released in. I mean, Simon & Garfunkel‚Äôs music itself paints the whole picture. However, I bet non of them ever imagined how timeless this film would end up becoming. Truly essential viewing.

Filme #80 assistido em 2022.
The Graduate, na minha experi√™ncia, foi um grande exemplo do fen√¥meno que a leitura sobre o filme pode impactar na sua experi√™ncia, mesmo posterior.
Quando comecei a estudar saobre hist√≥ria do Cinema e a ir montando a lista, em 2019, The Graduate estava l√°, e lembro de ter escrito o porqu√™, mas n√£o lembro qual era o motivo verdadeiro. Fiquei todo esse tempo sem ver o filme e me mantendo no escuro sobre quase tudo a seu respeito. Assim que terminei, achei um filme divertido e com um tema interessante, mas n√£o tinha achado t√£o incr√≠vel.
Apenas depois de assistir e ter minha primeira impress√£o baseada exclusivamente na emo√ß√£o (e defendo que ainda que essa seja uma das principais, √© sempre bom ir mais profundo), voltei para ler o par√°grafo sobre o filme na descri√ß√£o da lista e a ler os textos das pessoas que sigo aqui, e o que o filme significava para mim mudou completamente depois de relembrar suas inten√ß√µes.
Ao perceber a influ√™ncia da Nouvelle Vague, a d√©cada e o meio onde este filme foi lan√ßado, fica muito claro que, ap√≥s d√©cadas de glamuriza√ß√£o do "American way of life", come√ß√°vamos a ver uma cr√≠tica a burguesia. A real face da juventudo incerta (o take final!), seus dramas, a hiprocrisia dos pais conservadores, tudo muito claro aqui. N√£o apenas um filme divertido, mas um filme diferente do que se fazia no mainstream estadunidense da √©poca, marcando a Nova Hollywood. O uso de The Sound of Silence, e todas as mensagens passadas na imagem elevam o filme como uma obra que realmente usa o som e a imagem para dar poder √† sua hist√≥ria.

Seen this film a lot and I'm surprised how much I still find refreshing in it. On today's viewing I noticed a particular shot where Elaine is interrogating Benjamin over his affair, while Mrs Robinson's graven face is in the background, isolated through a doorframe. As Elaine realises the carnal connection between Benjamin and her mother, her face slowly comes into focus. So much in this film makes clear the links between film technique and aesthetics and culture and theme. This moment is followed up by the pan out from a close up of Mrs Robinson, internally boiling with rage and neglect, to isolate her in the corner of a long white hallway. Anne Bancroft breaks my heart every time.
not horny enough

Watched it six years ago for the first time when I had very little knowledge about how films got made; I fairly enjoyed it as a rom-com‚Ä¶some cute moments and two characters happily running away into the sunset in the end. But, when I re-watched it today, the film showed me why Hollywood films are timeless.
In the 60s, a graduate has difficulty deciding what's the next stage of his life/career going to be. He meets a middle aged woman who had to get married after getting pregnant in college. Topics like these always feel relevant and relatable (in my case, the question of what to do next in life), making the films evergreen even if they have protagonist and the supporting characters belonging to an upper class society. And that final shot! 
It's a beautifully directed film. Benjamin‚Äôs loneliness and Mrs. Robinson‚Äôs personality get captured through the cinematography which I loved so much. I loved the editing too which ensured the pacing was pitch perfect. The use of music and montages were also wonderfully done. 'The Graduate' sometimes feels like it's thin on paper but there's so much meaning behind say, a character's silence, when their despondency is shown on screen. A lesser director may have messed this up, but everything under Mike Nichols's direction felt almost perfect. I wish Benjamin's decision about what he should do next in his career got explored though, along with covering few more chapters from Mrs. Benjamin's life. Still a great film overall.

Jeeeeesh. What a ride this one was. I really had no idea what to expect going in given I knew very little about Mike Nichols and his filmography, but this absolutely knocked it out of the park for me. First and foremost, the cinematography and editing here looks about 15 years ahead of its time. Some of the scene transitions (particularly of Ben going from his home to the hotel with Mrs. Robinson) absolutely blew me away. Hoffman, Bancroft, and Ross were just perfect here, leaving me laughing, cringing, and contemplating seemingly all at once. The plot unraveled pretty much perfectly, and the ending of uneasiness left me thinking not only about the technical aspects of the movie, but the burdens and emotional consequences of love. As Al Pacino would say, what a picture.

One of the best things about this film is all that annoyance that apparently caused to fifty-something Mr.s of the time by social criticism disguised as humor, so ahead of its time. It is a film that we can understand thanks to its protagonist and for being able to see situations through his eyes where even we ourselves could've seen or lived them as well, and it is that completion of some academic process not as satisfactory as perhaps it should be, those times of not wanting to do anything or find real satisfaction in something, the fear and worries about the future for wanting something or maybe for not knowing what to want, internal and external instabilities that are sometimes trying to dealt with, pressures for what comes next in life because of course, you close a cycle, what's next? even though the present is being an internal struggle between conflicts and emotions, you move around and exist at the expense of the rest and what could be.
Between some overly admirable camera shots, a visual quality better than my eyesight, and depressing Simon and Garfunkel songs that are repeated on loop, it is also expressed what Ben is feeling and how his world full of superficiality, pressures and blackmails like ropes around his neck and nothingness seem to completely fill his life with meaninglessness, until the unexpected arrives. Even though Elaine arrives as part of those conflicts, it means for him something contrary to what he has been having during all this time being this positive and comfortable almost like a dissociation that provokes him that something in his life to the point of leading him to see something that he wants for the first time and in a euphoric way going towards it in the most hilarious way possible, and who knows if it will turn out well because as we have learned and know, things that would seem perfect and done completly, rarely are, and they are there starring in one of the best endings of a film where they're returning to the beginning surrounded by too much overwhelming uncertainty.
This movie was for me something else because i went from thinking it would be some romcom to something that express a lot about youth and adulthood, the good and the bad, more bad than good even going beyond the years and generations and providing a whole rethinking of things (or existential crisis yey) that after all should be talked about in the 60s, now in the 2020s and in the future as well.

I cannot help but love it!
The story that it has is actually really simple, but the way it's being told in a very aesthetic way made it very pleasing. Each character is performed astonishingly. The score and soundtrack‚ÄîYES, Simon & Garfunkel‚Äîcomplemented the atmosphere. Let alone the cinematography! It was so minimal yet still colorful and nice to look at. The final shot on the bus wrapped up the film (ONE OF THE BEST ENDINGS, EVER), successfully leaving me a huge impact‚Äîa reason to falling in love deeper to it.

Reflecting on where we are in our life‚Äôs and what to do next isn‚Äôt out of the ordinary and the Graduate captures this. A solid first half between Ben and Mrs Robinson is highly entertaining with jokes and awkward dialogue. Cinematography and transitions stand out, grasping into Ben‚Äôs state of mind, unsure how to progress through the world around him. Constantly pushed into someone else‚Äôs narrative and not his own. I can‚Äôt talk about the Graduate without speaking of the soundtrack by Simon and Garfunkel, musicians I haven‚Äôt listened too much apart from a song here and there yet their music reflects each part of this film so well I‚Äôm gonna dig into their discography now.
